column2: LONDON, May 14.--Sir Winston Churchill returned to the House of Commons today for the first time since he broke his thigh in Monte Carlo nearly a year ago.

Canada Steamship Lines announced yesterday the election of T.R. McLagan to the new post of chairman of the board of directors. Mr. McLagan was also re-elected president and general manager.
The Deputy Governor of the Bank of France offered assurances to Americans yesterday that French economic planning was "completely conducive to free enterprise."
NORTH ARLINGTON, N.J., May 14--Representatives of four Protestant groups took part in a meeting of the Presbytery of Newark last night.
Kirk Douglas will appear in the stage and screen variations of Ken Kasey's best seller, "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest." Both are to be directed by Sidney Lumet.
NEW HAVEN, May 14--A daughter was born May 7 to Mr. and Mrs. Robert Scott Conant in the Grace-New Haven Community Hospital.
WASHINGTON, May 14-- The Senate agreed today to reduce debate on the feed-grains bill after having gone around and around for nearly three and a half hours.
Dr. Robert D. Huebner of 42 East 65th Street, a specialist in peripheral vascular diseases, died yesterday after a long illness at New York Hospital. His age was 45.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 14 --Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Williams have made known the engagement of their daughter Miss Alexandra Williams, to Wallace Randolph Hawley.
CANNES, France, May 14-- The first film by a young French director is the conversation piece of the 16th Cannes Film Festival.
"THE BRIG" opens at the Living Theater, 530 Avenue of the Americas, at 7:30. Kenneth H. Brown's play has been staged by Judith Malina.
BUDAPEST, May 14--Two top Czechoslovak Communist officials have been ousted from their party posts, the Prague party newspaper. Rude Pravo disclosed today.

Eliot Hyman, executive vice president of Seven Arts Productions, Ltd., has been named president of the film, television and stage production and distribution company. He succeeds the late David B. Stillman.
TRENTON, May 14--Gov. Richard J. Hughes named a committee today to study New Jersey's higher educational facilities and report how they might be improved.
Billy Haughton, who earns his bread and butter in harness racing but gets his dessert at the flats, completed an unusual parlay yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 14-- Dr. Arthur Lenhoff of Buffalo received the Austrian Cross of Honor, first class, at a ceremony today at the Austrian Embassy here. Dr. Lenhoff is professor emeritus of Buffalo University's school of law. The award was given in recognition of his teaching, study and writing on Austrian civil law and international civil procedures.
WASHINGTON, May 14-- The United States bowed to British demands today and directed United States airlines to conform to the schedule of higher fares charged on Atlantic routes by European carriers.
The recommendations submitted by a Presidential emergency board offer a sound basis for strike-free resolution of the long dispute over excess manpower on the nation's railroads.
WASHINGTON, May 14--Secretary of Defense McNamara is gradually managing to make his policies prevail at the Pentagon, but there is still an ugly fight ahead.
Vladimir Ivanovic, a stepson of the late Bozo N. Banac, a leading Yugoslav shipowner, died of a heart attack Sunday. He was 45 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 14-- The United States and Britain have reached agreement on the construction of a $95,000,000 undersea weapons testing center in the Bahamas.

The Treasury is considering a new tax step designed to make United States industry more competitive with that of Western Europe. The plan is to increase depreciation allowances to compensate for the rise in replacement costs caused by inflation.
The State Department of Insurance moved in Supreme Court yesterday to dissolve the Dental Insurance Plan, Inc., saying that effort is salvage the 150,000-subscriber plan would be "futile."
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 14--A plan for reorganizing the public schools here and for providing free bus service to all public and private schools was made public tonight by the Board of Education.

NEWARK, May 14--The New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad Company asked the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners today for permission to consolidate its passenger operations pending a decision on complete abandonment of the service.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, MAY 14--The United Arab Republic and other governments represented here for the forthcoming African conference are ...
The Port of New York Authority borrowed yesterday $25,000,000 on revenue-term bonds at competitive bidding. An investment banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart ...
WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI)--Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, introduced a bill today limiting the import of lead and zinc.
GENEVA, May 14--The International Social Service announced today the appointment of Stewart A. Sutton as its international director.

SKYTOP, Pa., May 14--A Roman Catholic priest and a Protestant divinity professor agreed on the revolutionary effect of the Ecumenical Council during the opening session here today of the annual American Book Publishers' Council meeting.

LONDON, May 14--It is the special function of George Devine's English Stage Company to discover promising playwrights, and it appears to have made a splendid discovery in Frank Hilton. Mr. Hilton's "Day of the Prince" opened tonight at the Royal Court Theater.
MOSCOW, May 14 (UPI)-- The Soviet press agency Tass reported today that Russian astronomers had discovered an abnormal belt of radiation around the planet Jupiter.

Quotations on long-term Treasury bonds advanced again yesterday in moderately active trading. New municipal issues that came to market were mostly sluggish, and corporates continued steady but inactive.

DELHI, N.Y., May 14 (UPI) --Delaware County, for the first time since 1922, is free of any financing obligations. County Treasurer Charles O. Field, apparently happy over the debt-free nature of his county, held a celebration yesterday.
The Board of Education selected an unusual site yesterday for two new Manhattan public schools: the air space above a subway car yard.
The election of four additional trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art was announced yesterday by Roland L. Redmond, president of the museum.

Heublein, Inc., food processor and liquor importing and distilling company, expects record sales and earnings for the fiscal year ending June 30, Ralph A. Hart, president, told the New York Security Analysts yesterday.

PARIS, May 14 (AP)-- Pierre Courtade, foreign affairs writer for L'Humanite, the French Communist party newspaper, and a member of the party's central committee, died after surgery today. He was 48 years old.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 14--Contemporary architecture will be in the limelight again in this town, which is noted for the preservation of its original early American charm.
The New York Hungaria Sport Club will play Guadalajara of Mexico in an international soccer match tomorrow at Gaelic Park.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI)--Robin Roberts of the Baltimore Orioles pitched a four-hitter tonight to beat the Washington Senators, 6-1, for his first victory of the season.

The Bankers Trust Company, New York, and L'Union des Mines, a French bank with headquarters in Paris, have entered into a reciprocal arrangement designed to provide broader service and advice to their customers on two continents.
Business failures in the country rose to 322 in the week ended May 7, from 306 in the preceding week and 310 in the comparable 1962 period, Dun Bradstreet reported yesterday.
An optimistic statement by the chairman of Imperial Chemical Industries and good company reports lifted prices on the London market yesterday.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 14-- The leader of the neutralist force that has clashed with proCommunist troops in Laos declared today that only the presence of Indian and Canadian officers of the International Control Commission has prevented an attack on his men by a division of North Vietnamese.
CHICAGO, May, 14--Thousands of hungry families on relief here received Federal surplus food today.

In another move to save the five-year-old nuclear test ban talks from collapse and avert another East-West testing race, the United States has now canceled the three minor tests it had scheduled for later this month. This is a wise and welcome decision.
Railroad stocks went into orbit yesterday while most other issues milled around on the ground. There were more advances than declines but leading market averages showed slight declines.
Richard P. Walsh, former treasurer of the Provident Savings and Loan Association of Haverstraw, N.Y., was arrested yesterday by the Federal ...
NEWBURGH, N.Y., May 14 --City Manager Joseph McD. Mitchell said today he had received $5,170 in back pay for the four-month period during which he gave up his office to fight bribery charges.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 14--The United States has informed the Congo that it will provide supplies and equipment for the retraining of the Congolese armed forces.

Michael J. Prendergast, former Democratic state chairman, said yesterday he opposed the re-election of Mayor Wagner in 1961 because, he said, the Mayor was supporting Liberal party judicial candidates against their Democratic opponents.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 14--Saul W. Meltzer, a home builder, died today at Beth Israel Hospital in Newark. He was 66 years old, and lived at 6 Linden Avenue here.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 14 (UPI)--The Illinois Supreme Court refused today to intervene in the dismissal of a professor who had advocated premarital sexual relations.
The 25-hour week in the electrical industry has created fewer jobs than anticipated last July when it was introduced, Theodore W. Kheel reported yesterday.

Stocks of refined copper in this country at the close of April came to 95,822 short tons, down 10,303 short tons in the month, according to figures reported yesterday by the Copper Institute. This figure was the lowest reported for the year.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 14-- Dr. Jerome G. Kaufman of Maplewood was inaugurated today as president of the Medical Society of New Jersey at the annual meeting at Hotel Chalfonte-Haddon Hall.

A special feature of the annual Dogwood Festival, sponsored by the Women's Guild of the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church in Fairfield, Conn., will be a walking tour on Thursday of six Colonial homes in the area.

MOSCOW, May 14 (Reuters) --The pianist Vladimir Ashkenazy, baking his first trip to the Soviet Union since he decided last month to live in Britain, said today he did not expect to meet any pressure to stay in his native land.
CHICAGO, May 14 (UPI)-- Old May wheat plunged more than 4 cents a bushel in a generally lower grain futures market today on the Board of Trade.
Dr. Lester R. Tuchman and Mrs. Barbara W. Tuchman, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucy Gwen Tuchman, to David Eisenberg.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 14--South Africa has relaxed its apartheid laws in regard to hospital accommodations for Chinese.

WASHINGTON, May 14-- The House of Representatives, in a wildly confused session, disagreed with the Senate today over the distribution of $73,000,000 to complete the payment of World War II damage claims in the Philippines.
The receipt of $12,509,433 in gifts to finance the construction of a 12-floor addition to Roosevelt Hospital has been announced by Mrs. Donald F. Bush, president of the hospital.
Credit Industrial Corporation of New York has consented in Federal Court to the request of three major banks that it be found bankrupt.

Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon took title yesterday to a cooperative apartment at 810 Fifth Avenue. He was accompanied by Mrs. Nixon at the closing. Josephine G. Schaefer of Douglas L. Elliman Co. was the broker.
A half-hour study of a report on pesticides will be televised by C.B.S. Reports" tonight at 8.
DETROIT, May 14 (UPI)-- Gene (Big Daddy) Lipscomb, who came off the Detroit sandlots to become a star in the National Football League, will be buried here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)--A bill authorizing military purchases totaling more than $15,300,000,000 cleared Congress today and was sent to President Kennedy.
MILWAUKEE, May 14 (UPI) --The Milwaukee Braves tonight renewed the contract of Manager Bobby Bragan. The contract will extend through 1964.
WASHINGTON, May 14-- The long-awaited reorganization of the Food and Drug Administration will begin shortly.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. William J. Diamond of 220 East 79th Street last Wednesday in the Beth Israel Hospital. Mrs. Diamond is the former Miss Marylin Gelfand, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. H. Harold Gelfand of New York.
NEW HAVEN, May 14-- Yale University has created a new position--Pursuivant of Arms--and has named Theodore Sizer, professor emeritus of the history of art, to fill it.

BOSTON, May 14--The St. Botolph Club of Boston presented its first arts award of $1,000 tonight to Edward Hopper of New York and Truro.
MOSCOW, May 14 (UPI)-- An earthquake shook today the Soviet city of Frunze, capital of Kirghizia in south-central Asia, the Soviet press agency, Tass, reported.

The Baseball Rules Committee yesterday, officially dropped the one-second clause from the definition of a balk as suggested last week by Commisioner Ford Frick and the two league presidents.
A new organization to combat alcoholism was officially opened yesterday at 167 East 80th Street. It is called ACCEPT, for Alcoholism Center Coordinating Education, Prevention and Treatment.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 14--The Netherlands goes to the polls tomorrow after one of the most peaceful campaigns in her history.
HARTFORD, May 14--The Connecticut House of Representatives approved today a bill that would repeal the state's 84year-old birth-control law. The Senate, however, is expected to let the measure die.

Biology and its related fields appear to be following the course of physics and chemistry in becoming more closely dependent upon mathematical techniques virtually unknown to most biologists of earlier generations.

WASHTNGTON, May 14-- President Kennedy and Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy suggested to Alabama editors today that failure of the "nonviolent" movement for Negro rights might open the door for Negro extremist groups, such as the Black Muslims.

CAIRO, May 14--An agreement for a three-year program of management training and consultation was signed here yesterday by the United Arab Republic and the United States Agency for International Development.
At least 150 diners were forced to leave a midtown restaurant last night because of a fire in a grease duct.
At least 150 diners were forced to leave a midtown restaurant last night because of a fire in a grease duct.
LITTLE ROCK, May 14--The Arkansas Supreme Court has ruled constitutional a 1959 state law making it a misdemeanor not to leave a place of business when asked to by the management.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 14 (Reuters)--President Sukarno has given the attorney general power to ban foreign and Indonesian publications that endanger "the interests of the Indonesian state," Antara, the Indonesian news agency, reported today. The regulation applies to publications of all kinds.

CHICAGO, May 14 (UPI)-- Jim Landis drove in three runs with a homer and a bases-filled single tonight and Ray Herbert pitched his fourth straight shutout as the Chicago White Sox beat the Detroit Tigers, 3--0.

The Rockefeller administration cautioned the city yesterday that voter resistance to increased expenditures for low-income housing should be heeded as a warning to seek new ideas and methods.
A television newsman was beaten and 11 store windows were broken in the aftermath of an anti-segregation rally last night in Harlem.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that a favorable turn of events in the last month had produced a $26,250,000 windfall for the city.
DEER PARK, L.I., May 14-- Two children playing on a lawn rolled down a three-foot embankment into the path of a mobile crane this afternoon, and one was killed.
"The Santos of Puerto Rico," an exhibition of traditional religious wood-carvings, will open tomorrow at the Pepsi-Cola Ex-hibition Gallery, 500 Park Avenue (59th Street).

A secondary sale of 80,000 common shares in Ekco Products Company at $28.75 each is being made by Lehman Brothers and associates. The selling shareholders in the cutlery and utensils producer were not disclosed.
GREENWICH, Conn., May 14 --The Marian Book Club of Greenwich will hold its seventh annual benefit luncheon and fashion show on Thursday at Schrafft's in Eastchester, N.Y.
CAMPERS with trailers will find that state forest areas in New Jersey are now better equipped to accommodate them than in the past. Such sites now number 200.
MOSCOW, May 14--Premier Khrushchev received today Berthold Beitz, general manager of West Germany's Krupp concern, and had a "business conversation" with him.

PITTSBURGH, May 14--The United Steelworkers of America exhibited today its softer approach to labor negotiations by deciding to continue labor-management discussions within the framework of an existing committee.
WASHINGTON, May 14.-- Hopes were raised here today that President Francois Duvalier of Haiti would surrender his powers and flee the country tomorrow when his constitutional term of office expires.

SALTA, Argentina, May 14 (UPI)--Nine persons were killed and six were injured when a truck carrying peasants ran off a mountain road and plunged 180 feet into the Chorro Blanco River, authorities reported today. Rescuers found the victims pinned underneath the truck.

Msgr. John Stanislaus Middleton, Roman Catholic educator, author and pastor of St. Peter's Church at 18 Barclay Street for the last 11 years, died yesterday at the Benedictine Hospital in Kingston, N.Y. He was 63 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) --The House tried today to stop Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr.'s planned trip to Europe, but it apparently wound up giving him a blank check for expenses.
THOSE whose tastes in theater run to lurid little ballets should rush right out and buy tickets for either tomorrow's or Friday's performances of the Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 14 (UPI)--Gov. George C. Wallace sent another telegram to President Kennedy today. It charged that, despite the President's statement to the contrary, "Federal military troops are now on duty in Birmingham.
European currencies maintained yesterday the pattern of strength set on Monday in dealings on the New York foreign exchange market.

SUDLERSVILLE, Md., May 14 (AP)--Six persons died today in the pre-dawn crash of a car and a tractor-trailer on U.S. 301, about three miles west of here.
MANILA, Wednesday, May 15 (UPI)--A Filipino bantamweight boxer, Sabino (Rocky) Mangubat, died in a hospital this morning from brain injuries he received in a bout last Sunday night.

The Yankees returned to the Bronx last night, weathered a rainstorm, accepted the plaudits in a gathering of 14,507, and then behind the slick five-hit pitching of Whitey Ford, polished off the Minnesota Twins, 2-1.

Abraham D. Beame, New York City controller, announced yesterday that $30,520,760 of, short-maturity city serial bonds, now held by pension funds, would be offered for public bidding. The sale is set for May 28.

A registration of the syndication of the 22-story office building occupying the blockfront on the east side of Park Avenue, between 56th and 57th Streets, has been cleared for filing by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 14 --Striking workers of Locals 711 and 54 of the International Labor and Hod Carriers Union ended their 13-day strike today.
A PRIZE souvenir of Samuel Rosenman is a card inscribed "from his affectionate partner in crime uplift. Franklin D. Roosevelt."
The tallest hotel on the European continent, the Brussels Westbury, will be opened formally today in Brussels by Knott Hotels Corporation.
J. Raymond Jones, Democratic leader of Harlem's 13th Assembly District East, was unanimously elected by the City Council yesterday as a Councilman to serve through Dec. 31.
BONN, May 14--West Germany, Britain and the United States are embroiled in a threecornered debate on application of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's new forward defense strategy.
Opposition to the formation of a nuclear force under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was expressed yesterday by the National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy, Inc.
SHOOTERS ISLAND, N.Y. and N.J., May 15--New York Harbor's old piers don't just fade away; they have to be carried off piecemeal to this bi-state island and burned.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 15 --Sixty business and industrial leaders gave implied support today to the token desegregation plan that brought a truce in this city's racial crisis.
BUFFALO, May 15--Whether their engaging corporate image of ineptness can bear it not, the New York Mets have a success story on their hands in this city, the home of the Buffalo Bisons.
The "quiet" suburbs are growing noisier, and the noise tolerance of residents in many places is reaching a limit, an acoustics expert said here yesterday.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 15 (AP)-- Maj. L. Gordon Cooper Jr., assigned to spend more time in space than any other American to date, Christened his space vehicle Faith 7 for a variety of reasons.
MODENA, Italy, May 15 (AP)--The Ford Motor Company was reported here today to be negotiating to take over the Ferrari Company, maker of racing cars and luxury automobiles.
DETROIT, May 15--The fast pace of automobile sales in early May indicated another record month for the industry.
The country's leading chain stores and mail order houses continued to increase their sales in April and in the first four months of the year, a survey by The New York Times indicated yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, May 15--The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations took a gloomy view of the economy's prospects today.

Sterling had a hectic day on the New York foreign exchange market yesterday. Trading in the British pound started slowly, but by the afternoon orders were flying Back and forth across the Atlantic, most of them in the range of $2.80 to $2.8003.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 15--Secretary General U Thant said today that it was imperative for the General Assembly to take action at the current special session on the United Nations' financial situation.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 15--The United States is urging Secretary General U Thant to speed the establishment of a United Nations "presence" in Yemen.

SKYTOP, Pa., May 15--Members of the American Book Publishers Council were told today of increasing numbers of censorship actions and some favorable developments in their campaign for the "Freedom to Read" and of a "clampdown" by the Registrar of Copyrights.

GENEVA, May 15--Ministers of the 50 member nations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade gathered here today with the aim of setting in motion the most sweeping reduction of tariffs the modern world has yet seen.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May. 15 (AP)--Gov. George C. Wallace said today he would institute a suit to determine if Federal troops could be used in Birmingham. He accused President Kennedy of setting up a military dictatorship.
ST. LOUIS, May 15--The International Association of Machinists announced today the ratification of a new three-year contract with the Boeing Company covering 40,000 workers represented by the union.

LOS ANGELES, May 15 (UPI)--Two of America's top distance runners, Jim Beatty and Jim Grelle, and other members of the Los Angeles Track Club withdrew today from Friday night's Coliseum Relays.

LONDON, May 15--Harold Wilson, leader of the Opposition Labor party, warned today that the "nuclear citadel" of the Western world was likely to be undermined by "economic dry rot" unless the West's monetary base is expanded.

LONDON, May 15--The London premium in investment dollars--funds British residents and investment companies use to buy dollar securities--has been declining recently.

Allan Haymes, realty investor and builder, has bought the five-story commercial building at 429-31 West 53d Street from a client of Abraham Zemlock, lawyer. Before taking title, Mr. Haymes net leased the entire building to one tenant. The rental for the first 21 years of the lease is more than $750,000. O'Gara Co. were the brokers in the sale and lease. Title has been insured by the Title Guarantee Company.

Sales of the United Aircraft Corporation rose in the first quarter over the level a year ago, but earnings declined, the report disclosed yesterday. Net income amounted to $3,739,363, equal to 52 cents a common share, compared with $4,566,180, or 66 cents a share, for the three months last year.

The earnings of the Sinclair Oil Corporation for this year will show a substantial gain from the 1962 total of $47,300,000, or $3.16 a share, E.L. Steiniger, president and chief executive officer, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday.

Yeoman 1st Cl. Nelson C. Drummond indicated that he was not the first or only Soviet informant inside the United States naval establishment in London in 1957-58, according to Government testimony yesterday at his trial in Federal District Court here.
The Society of Colonial Wars in the State of New York will hold its sixth annual tea dance at the Sheraton-East next Thursday.

A French Government official and a leading German Industrialist clashed yesterday on the merits of economic planning and in particular whether it should be attempted by the European Economic Community.

NEW DELHI, May 15-- Indian and Pakistani negotiators moved today toward an indefinite adjournment of their six-month-old talks on the Kashmir problem.

WASHINGTON, May 15-- Pierre-Paul Schweitzer, Deputy Governor of the Bank of France, is regarded here as the most likely successor to the late Per Jacobsson as managing director of the International Monetary Fund.
The Chicago Union Station Company sold at competitive bidding yesterday a total of $49,000,000 of securities.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 15 --Ten children complained to Mayor J. Walter Kennedy today that they were unable to ride their bicycles because the roads in their neighborhood were unpaved.
A basic tax rate of $4.25 for each $100 of assessed valuation of property was predicted yesterday for 1963-64 by the Citizens Budget Commission. The current rate is $4.16.

Mayor Wagner was honored last night by Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism for "initiative, resourcefulness and persistence" in helping to settle the 114-day New York City newspaper strike.

The City Club of New York will not have its Award Luncheon for the Albert S. Bard Citations for Excellence in Civic Architecture this year for the simple reason that there are no award-winning buildings. In the City Club's own words, New York has failed to build "boldly, beautifully and well."

Henry Modell Company, Inc., operator of four sporting goods stores in New York City, purchased yesterday the inventory, goodwill, trademarks and name of the bankrupt Davega Stores -- Corporation. The price was $311,100.
New York State borrowed $48,755,000 yesterday in the bond market to finance low-cost housing.

Advertising agencies have had difficulty lately in recruiting top ranking college graduates to agency work. One reason for this problem, some officials believe, is that agencies have not sufficiently emphasized their strongest selling point--namely, opportunity.

NEW DELHI, May 16--India and Pakistan broke off talks on the Kashmir territorial dispute tonight and announced in a joint statement their "regret" that they had been unable to achieve a solution. The talks had been going on for six months.

Operations of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company in the fiscal year ended Feb. 23 resulted in record sales and earnings for the nation's largest food chain, John D. Ehrgott, chairman, reported in the annual statement released today.

Borrowing by New York City banks from the Federal Reserve reached their highest level in a year and a half in the week ended Wednesday as an expected influx of reserves from their correspondent banks out of town was not forthcoming.

Representative Oren Harris sharply rebuked broadcasters yesterday for allowing themselves to become "slaves" to ratings.
The Government bond market added to its gains yesterday on selected buying in moderately active trading. High-grade corporates were steady and firm, and municipals continued quiet.

HERE comes the Green Crow wearing a colored cap. "Under a Colored Cap" is the bright title of Sean o'Casey's new book of essays that Macmillan has published in London. (It will be published here by St. Martin's Press June 14.)

This week, the Dow-Jones industrial average has been nudging its all-time high, but Harold Clayton, market analyst for Hemphill, Noyes Co., a large brokerage house, points out that that average fails to tell the real story.
WASHINGTON, May 16-- The Washington Ballet Guild's board of directors voted today to continue to "sponsor" the American Ballet Theater, but not to underwrite the costs.
THE chronic complaints of some older persons alienate them from their middle-aged children, a conference on the aged was told last week by specialists in this field.

The 2,646 men and women over the age of 65 who filled Philharmonic Hall yesterday afternoon for four hours spent most of their time applauding-- both for the music they heard and for every repeated mention of the word "medicare."
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 16 (AP)--Dominicus Hugo Ollemans, newspaper publisher, died today at the age of 54.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 16--Maj. L. Gordon Cooper Jr. landed safely in the Pacific today after a magnificently executed 22-orbit flight.
Forecasts of a continued, broad business expansion of moderate strength were made yesterday by businessmen and economists at the 47th annual meeting of the National Industrial Conference Board.
HOLLYWOOD, May 16--Polite, but cold hostilities have broken out between the movie industry and the Department of Defense.

CLEVELAND, May 16 (AP) --The growth of tax-exempt foundations during the last 10 years has forced the Internal Revenue Service to re-evaluate its standards governing them, Mortimer M. Caplin said here today.
WASHINGTON, May 16-- President Kennedy telephoned his congratulations to Maj. L. Gordon Cooper Jr. minutes after he emerged from the space capsule Faith 7 tonight.

TRENTON, May 16 (AP)-- Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today he believes that birth control is a matter of personal conscience and that "it is not the function of the state to interfere in this area of private life."
DES MOINES, Iowa, May 16 --More than 250 Presbyterians formally established here today a national council to press for direct, and "vigorous" action in combating discrimination and segregation.
The world is on the brink of a third psychiatric revolution, a psychiatrist said here yesterday.

Fred Johnson, the one-armed Harlem tennis professional who started Althea Gibson on her way to interantional stardom, died of a heart attack Wednesday in his home at 1784 Amsterdam Avenue. He was 74 years old.
BONN, May 16--The West German Parliament, having reconfirmed West Germany's fidelity to the Atlantic alliance, give final approval today to Adenauer's controversial Treaty of Cooperation with France.

Economic stability for the nation and economic assistance to its jobless workers will both be advanced if Congress approves President Kennedy's proposals for a basic liberalization of the Federal-state unemployment insurance system. Present benefits are too low and too limited in duration to meet the demands of an economy in which the unemployment rate has stayed above 5 per cent for more than five years.
CHICAGO, May 16 (UPI)-- Old May wheat rose more than a cent a bushel in irregular evening-up activity today on the Board of Trade, Soybeans fell after liquidation and profit taking.
Maj. L. Gordon Cooper Jr. will receive New York City's traditional accolade, a ticker-tape parade, next Wednesday in honor of his space achievement.

THE latest version of the A ever-popular hibachi is a hanging design with a pagoda roof that looks like a bird-feeding station when dangling from a branch or patio roof. This 36pound metal utensil from Abercrombie Fitch is 24 inches in diameter.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 17 --A plan to extend the Negro pupils' sit-in at Cleveland School to two other predominantly white schools here was suspended today as a result of the State Education Commissioner's order to the Orange School Board on Thursday to end de facto segregation there.
A prominent social scientist yesterday called on the Government to finance research into prejudice and bigotry as part of the Government's mental-health program.
The State Department, after receiving some unfavorable notices, has reshaped its program that exports $2,500,000 worth of American culture annually.

PARIS, May 17--The extraordinary fact of this spring is the absence of any major international crisis. The world seems to be getting used to living on the brink of danger. It is content to bask in the sun and marvel at such exploits as Major Cooper's, without getting edgy. This is a seasonal holiday in the Land of Cockaigne.
Protests mounted yesterdays in northern Westchester and Rockland Counties as well as in North Jersey against the aerial spraying for the gypsy moth.

OTTAWA, May 17--Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson told the Canadian Parliament today that Canada remained uncommitted on the question of joining the proposed nuclear force under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
HOT weather usually arrives suddenly and, when it does, most women wish they had a supply of beauty preparations designed to make life easier in the summer.
DES MOINES, Iowa, May 17-- The responsibilities of churches in this country's racial crisis has become the major topic at the 175th General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church.

HOUSTON, May 17 (AP)-- Houston's Don Nottebart tonight pitched the second nohitter in the major leagues this year, allowing four base runner's and one run as the Colts defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 4--1.
DETROIT, May 17--The American Baptist Convention approved today plans for a $20,000,000 world mission campaign.

Cable spinning for the $325,000,000 Verrazano-Narrows Bridge is one-third completed, and this and other jobs are keeping more than 3,000 men busy on the bridge and its Brooklyn and Staten Island approaches.
American business executives are the most efficient and best educated in the world, but they are sadly lacking in good taste, Walter Hoving, chairman of Tiffany Co., observed yesterday.
Sales and earnings of the Glen Alden Corporation this year are expected to better those of 1962, Albert A. List, president, stated yesterday.
Active and reserve forces will march down Fifth Avenue today in the fourteenth annual Armed Forces Day parade of men, missiles and equipment.
WASHINGTON, May 17--The United States has suggested to Poland that the removal of trade barriers to Polish goods may depend upon Poland's cooperation in maintaining a cease-fire in Laos.
BALTIMORE, May 17--All the alibis are in, and the horses in the Preakness have no fears --either of one another or of the weather.

Wth the exception of the October contract, world sugar futures hit the 50-point permissible trading limit yesterday for the third consecutive day but fell back in late trading and profit taking. Domestic sugar prices were up but did not attain the limit.

Another relatively light calendar of competitive sales of capital debt issues faces the capital market next week.
Members of more than 150 Greek-American societies will parade, 35,000 strong, up Fifth Avenue tomorrow to mark the 142d anniversary of Greek independence.

ROBERT FROST once said that writing free verse was like playing tennis without a net. In open defiance of that rather defeatist theory Evan S. Connell Jr. has written a very long poem that is a heady and hypnotic mixture of free verse and even freer association.

CAPE CANAVERAL, May 17--Medical scientists, monitor ing astronaut L. Gordon Cooper, said today they were fascinated by the data they had obtained on the first good "night's sleep" experienced by an American in orbit.
The first of a series of twilight Town Hall programs by young folk singers "whose abilities exceed their recognition" was given yesterday evening bye three performers.
ATHENS, May 17--President de Gaulle, in his first round of talks with Greek Government leaders, explained today his reason for insisting on an independent French nuclear striking force.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)--Adlai E. Stevenson said today that he tried to keep up with the United Nations social whirl to the limits of his "endurance and strength," but that it was getting to be onerous.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) --Francis Keppel, United States Commissioner of Education, branded as a national shame today the fact that 23,000,000 Americans over 18 have completed only eight years of schooling.
LONDON, May 17--Only the most discrete criticism was aired today at an annual meeting of the Hudson's Bay Company, a business enterprise chartered 106 years before the American Revolution.
LONDON, May 17 (UPI)-- Cyril Saunders Spackman, sculptor, painter and etcher, died yesterday in the home that he had designed here. He was 75 years old.
HARTFORD, May 17--A former State Controller filed with the House Insurance Committee today a list of sub-agents to whom he distributed $950,000 in state insurance commissions when he held the post.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 17--Ambassador Raymond L. Thurston played 18 holes of golf yesterday afternoon, shooting around cows that occasionally graze on Port-au-Prince's hilly course.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 17 --Five Negro pupils, described as followers of "Islamic teachings," have been suspended from a public school here for up to three months because they refused to salute the United States flag, the Board of Education said today.

WASHINGTON, May 17,-- The index of wholesale primary market prices rose two-tenths of 1 per cent to 100.0 per cent of its 1957-59 base during the week ended May 14, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Sugar shares and a few special-situation issues stood out in a generally quiet stock market yesterday. Closing prices for the market as a whole were up slightly. Volume eased sharply from the rapid pace of the two preceding sessions.

PARIS. A NEW shop at 17 avenue Matignon looks as if it belongs on Main Street, U.S.A. The retail shop has been established by Lanz of California, manufacturers of junior fashions.

IT looks as if the season hasn't much more activity left in it. Compared to last year's, which rolled happily on to June, this season has been short with few exhibitions each week. The quality of shows, however, has been in general, somewhat higher.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., May 17 --Dorchester County Circuit Judge W. Laird Henry moved quickly today to assume leadership of white moderates here as this tannery town on the Eastern Shore of Maryland ended its fifth straight day of desegregation demonstrations.

India and Pakistan have again failed to resolve their 15-year-old conflict over Kashmir which keeps their armies poised against each other and imperils the whole Indian subcontinent. The latest round of direct talks between them, initiated last December under pressure from the United States and Britain, has broken down. All they could produce was a joint statement of "regret" about their failure to agree.

IN the bidding, one can often get as reliable information from the opponents' bids as from his own hand. It is a great, though frequent, mistake to double in the belief that competent opponents do not know what they are doing.

The worst item in this package was trimmed off--application of the 4 per cent sales tax to out-of-city deliveries of goods bought in New York. But it is unlikely that the package will be otherwise substantially altered.

Mangel Stores, Inc., a readyto-wear chain occupying the building at 115 West 18th Street, has leased the adjoining six-story building at 125 West 18th Street containing 60,000 square feet in an expansion move. The Royal Ballet ended its five-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night with "The Sleeping Beauty." Dame Margot Fonteyn and David Blair had the leading roles.

HONG KONG, May 19--A senior Government official participated today in a Buddhist ceremony aimed at exorcising spirits supposedly haunting the offices of his department.

TRENTON, May 19--Gov. Richard J. Hughes appears to be exerting every effort to maintain New Jersey's position as one of the two remaining states that have neither a sales nor an income tax. But the Democratic Governor's $750,000,000 bond plan may not prove to be the solution.

Foreign exchange market was fairly active during the past week. British pound sterling was generally steady while the Canadian dollar showed a soft undertone. The German mark reflecting a tight money situation in that country was very strong on good turnover.

PARIS, May 19--Premier Georges Pompidou and Michel Debr his predecessor, affirmed today their harmony as leaders of the Gaullist forces in France.

BALTIMORE, May 19--With Candy Spots back into a winning orbit, his owner, Rex Ellsworth, and his trainer, Mesh Tenney, have big immediate plans for their horse. PITTSBURGH, May 19--Demand for steel lagged a little last week but was still strong.

MILK was praised, milk was drunk and milk was even spilt (but no one cried) at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel yesterday. The occasion was the celebration of "June Is Dairy Month." The figure of Premier Fidel Castro has cast a shadow over the stock market recently, but the reaction has been far different from last fall when Cuban crises shook investors' nerves. This time the news has been about the worsening Cuban sugar production, and it has induced rising prices for sugar and rising prices for sugar stocks.

ARDSLEY, N.Y., May 20-- William J. Keating of 36 Revere Road, a lawyer and the former counsel for the old New York City Anticrime Committee, died yesterday in Dobbs Ferry Hospital. He was burned May 9 while using an explosive fluid to start a charcoal fire in a barbecue grill at his home. He was 47 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 20--In order to find unconstitutional all prosecutions and trespass convictions of Negro sit-ins in privately owned restaurants in the South, the Supreme Court today was obliged to rest one part of its general finding on an assumption.

SCHUBERT was the composer with whom the six-concert Janacek-SchubertStravinsky series at Hunter College closed last night. There were two artists to interpret him--Leonard Shure, pianist, and Mary Simmons, a Philadelphia soprano who makes her home in Toronto.
SOUTHPORT, Conn., May 20--Wilmot F. Wheeler of Sasco Hill, former chairman and president of the American Chain and Cable Company, Inc., in Bridgeport, died here today. He was 80 years old.
NORWALK, Conn., May 20 (UPI)--Harry M. Nordberg, president of Pitney-Bowes, manufacturers of postage meters and mailing machines, died tonight at the age of 58. He had been ill for some time.

CHICAGO, May 20--The American Medical Association set up today a new expanded central registry of adverse reactions to drugs and chemicals. It was called an "early warning system" for the guidance of doctors prescribing drugs, providing fast, up-to-date information.

ELMIRA, N.Y., May 20 (UPI) --Arthur Modell, the president and general manager of the Cleveland Browns, will arrive tomorrow to attend the wake for Ernie Davis, who signed a contract with the National Football League team but never played in a professional game.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 20--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Corwith Davis of the engagement of Mr. Davis's daughter, Miss Louise Fabian Davis, to Ens. Stuart Beattie, U.S.N.R. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Sinclair Beattie of Fair Lawn, N.J.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)--The American Bar Association endorsed today a proposal to provide legal representation to all criminal defendants in Federal courts regardless of their lack of financial resources.
Foot patrolmn and radio car policemen are now including the grounds of city housing projects on their regular beats, the Police Department announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 20 (UPI)-- Decreasing local stocks and the expiration of May contracts at noon tomorrow prompted heavy buying of old crop wheat today on the Board of Trade, and prices soared more than 9 cents.
IT is only coincidence, but a notable coincidence, that the two pioneer tournament directors of this country announced their forthcoming retirement on almost the same day last week.

WEST TOWSHEND, Vt., May 20--On a popular stretch of angling water on the West River, noted for its tranquility, pretty surroundings and big trout, a trusting disciple of Izaak Walton almost drowned the other day.

Dr. Linus C. Pauling, Nobelprize winner and an advocate of nuclear disarmament, has filed a $1,000,000 libel suit against the conservative weekly, National Review, its publisher, William A. Rusher, and its editor, William F. Buckley Jr.

Ilana Rubenfeld returned with her New York Lyric Ensemble to Carnegie Recital Hall last night in a program that was well made and nicely sung. The 19-voice group made its debut last year and has already commissioned a major work, Paul Reif's "Requiem to War," which was given its premiere on this occasion.
A leading Catholic theologian said here last night that forces in this country opposed to interracial justice were doomed to defeat and that they knew it.
Mayor Wagner widened the breach between himself and Controller Abraham D. Beame yesterday, expressing doubt that Mr. Beame knew the meaning of the word "gratitude."

A specialist of the New York Stock Exchange supplied information useful to Alexander Guterma when he was "running the market" in United Dye and Chemical Corporation stock in 1956, according to testimony yesterday in Federal District Court.

The Eastern Traffic Bureau, Inc., and its affiliate, the Eastern Travel Agency, have leased the 10th floor in the 12-story office and bank building at 149 Madison Avenue, southeast corner of 32d Street. The lessees, who are traffic consultants and travel agents, are expanding and have moved their headquarters from 99 Hudson Street.
Lorelei Lee, the little girl from Little Rock with platinum head and diamond heart, will begin conquering new daddies tomorrow along the international route from Southampton to Saint-Tropez.

ALTHOUGH Ernie Davis never played a minute of professional football, he affected the course of recent professional football history. He left an impact different from what had been expected, but he left one nonetheless. The expectation had been that this wondrously gifted athlete, with the happy disposition would be a tremendous halfback for the Cleveland Browns, a hecan't-miss candidate for the Hall of Fame.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, May 20--Riot policemen clashed with demonstrators in Georgetown today, the 31st day of a paralyzing general strike.

HOUSTON, May 20 (AP)-- With Dick Drott pitching a fivehitter, the Houston Colts downed the slumping Pittsburgh Pirates tonight, 2--0. Houston now has won eight of its last 11 games while Pittsburgh has lost six of the last seven.

Luis Rodriguez, the world welterweight champion, and Emile Griffith, the challenger, successfully negotiated boxing's traditional venture into penmanship--the contract signing--yesterday in preparation for their title bout at Madison Square Garden on June 8.

Stockholders of the B.S.F. Company approved yesterday the sale of the holding company's investment in the American Hardware Corporation to the Glen Alden Corporation. A suit, however, has been filed in Chancery Court at Wilmington, Del., to block completion of the transaction, according to The Associated Press.

Six hundred and ten of the 238,000 stockholders of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., got their annual chance yesterday to tell management how best to run the business. They talked for one hour nine minutes before getting down to the three items on the agenda.
WASHINGTON, May 20-- Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff called today for limited aid to private schools through a sixpoint program designed to solve "the religious controversy."
The London stock market failed yesterday to maintain last week's forward surge.
VIENNA, May 20--Newspapers reaching Vienna from Prague indicate that recent disorders in the Czechoslovak capital included demonstrations by youths against the Communist regime.
WASHINGTON, May 20--The House Ways and Means Committee tentatively approved today the Administration plan to provide tax relief for actors, athletes and others whose incomes fluctuate sharply.
LONDON, May 20--The Bahama Islands were promised their own legislature and internal self-government today, possibly by the beginning of next year.
West German and American rowing leaders lifted their glasses yesterday in toasts to the bonds of friendship established during the visit here of the world-champion Ratzeburg crew.
ROME, May 20--Pope John XXXIII received Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, the Primate of Poland, in a private audience today. The audience lasted over an hour.
DETROIT, May 20 (AP)-- The auto industry's drive towards a record production year was sidetracked last week by a Ford labor dispute that reduced that company's production by 4,500.

Two weeks ago, when 1,000 Birmingham Ne groes were arrested for chanting demands for "freedom," the commander of the city's police sneered as the youthful demonstrators were swept off to jail. "If you'd ask half of them what freedom means, they couldn't tell you," he declared. Yesterday the United States Supreme Court made some important new contributions toward providing every American with a clearer definition of what freedom means.
The first race of the season over Aqueduct's turf course, a $10,000 purse for 3-year-olds and upward, was run yesterday afternoon with black clouds overhead and just after a sprinkle of rain.

Retail sales of apparel rose last year despite the Cuban crisis and the stock market decline, it was pointed out yesterday by J. Louis Dubow, executive director of the New York Coat and Suit Association.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 20--President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana arrived this afternoon, the ninth head of state on the scene for the African summit conference which will open Wednesday. Others are President Joseph Kasavubu of...

Industry's do-it-yourself man was in his glory yesterday. They came by the thousands from Everywhere, U.S.A., to look in on the design engineering show at the Coliseum and to hear of advances in industrial design at a concurrent conference of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at the Americana Hotel.
BOSTON, May 20 (UPI)-- Bob Allison, Earl Battey and Harmon Killebrew hit homers tonight and paced the Minnesota Twins to a 6-5 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

The Commissioner of the Federal Urban Renewal Administration said yesterday that the conservation and rehabilitation of existing housing offered "greatest opportunity" for providing housing for low-income and middle-income families.

The state has pigeonholed plans to extend the Taconic State Parkway beyond the Berkshire section of the Thruway. The cutback is a result of the $55,000,000 reduction in road construction funds in the state's new budget.

CHESTER, Pa., May 20 (AP) --The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People picketed a grade school in neighboring Twin Oaks today. It said more demonstrations were in store unless racial discrimination ended there.
The United States Court of Appeals yesterday upheld the misdemeanor conviction of a motel operator who told an airline employe in jest that there was a bomb in a passenger's bag.
WASHINGTON, May 20-- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
Station WNEW-TV has decided to present a second episode of "What's Going On Here!," the program of satirical comment. The date has not been set, but the telecast will probably go on in a few weeks.
Investors in a seven-state real estate operation may lose as much as $8,000,000, the state has charged, because of the "contrivances, fraud, improvident acts and negligence" of its promoter.
LONDON, May 20--Sir Maurice Powicke, one of Britain's most distinguished authorities on the Middle Ages, died yesterday at his home in Oxford. His age was 83.
BALTIMORE, May 20 (AP) --The Baltimore Orioles backed the five-hit pitching of Milt Pappas with four home runs tonight and whipped the etroit Tigers, 6--0.
TRENTON, May 20--A record $543,949,806 state budget was balanced today as the Legislature gave final approval to a $34,100,000 tax-increase package.
Viewers who are disturbed by television's commercial clutter may derive some satisfaction from this fact:

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 20 (AP)--Maj. L. Gordon Cooper Jr. reviewed his space flight with engineers today, then relaxed in preparation for a meeting with President Kennedy in Washington tomorrow and a ticker-tape parade in New York Wednesday.

The City Council is about ready to complete action on Mayor Wagner's tax and budget package. Several significant events have occurred since the Mayor delivered his budget a month ago: $40 million in expected revenue was lost by wise abandonment of the out-of-city sales tax; about $26 million was recovered in "found" money--some of it dubious--to make up part of...
SUSHAN, N.Y., May 20-- Some cynic once, observed one shouldn't worry about one's enemies, but friends, they are another matter.
LONDON, May 20--The Soviet Union has offered to sell Britaitn sophisticated machine tools that she now buys from the United States and Switzerland.

TRENTON, N.J., May 20 (AP)--The New Jersey Senate recalled from the Assembly today a resolution supporting a constitutional amendment to bar Federal courts from applying equal rights doctrines to state legislative reapportionment.
A controversial sketch about the Crucifixion has been eliminated from "The Establishment," the satirical revue, after complaints were made to Bernard J. O'Connell, City License Commissioner.
"Please come," was the urgent request, "my mother is sick." Following the child along a Greenwich Village street, Lillian Wald hurried to the little girl's door.

Mr. and Mrs. Herman Frasch Whiton of New York and Oyster Bay, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mr. Whiton's daughter, Miss Emelyn Leonard Whiton, to David Seccomb Patterson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Russel Hugo Patterson of New York and Bedford Hills, N.Y.

Yeoman 1st Cl. Nelson C. Drummond took the stand for the first time yesterday in his espionage trial in Federal District Court. He sharply revised the accounts he had given previously of his association since 1957 with Soviet officials in Britain and the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 20 --One spring morning in 1961, The Hartford Courant carried a front-page picture that proved, in the estimate of some observers, to be worth not 1,000 words but...
DES MOINES, May 20--The United Presbyterian Church allocated $500,000 today to fight racial discrimination.

The Board of Higher Education last night cleared the president and the dean of the Bronx Community College of charges of wrongdoing leveled against them by an "aggrieved committee," made up for the most part of former teachers at the college.

WASHINGTON, May 20-- The Supreme Court said today that a city that makes segregation a policy by ordinance or official statements could not prosecute Negroes for seeking service in privately owned stores.
WASHINGTON, May 20-- Treasury bill rates rose slightly on today's sale of regular weekly issues.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 20--The city Board of Education today ordered the expulsion or suspension of some 1,100 Negro students who had been arrested in anti- segregation demonstrations.

When it comes to recognizing such unconstitutional governments as President Duvalier's in Haiti, there are all kinds of precedents and, as Prof. Charles G. Fenwick of the Pan American Union has written, "no more controversial question can be found in the whole field of international law."
MIAMI, May 20 (AP)--Cuban exiles formed a central organization today to wage war on the Communist regime of Premier Fidel Castro.
Prices of Government securities eased further yesterday in slow trading. High-grade corporates weakened, and municipals were dull.

WASHINGTON, May 20-- Indian sources said today that India wants $1,500,000,000 in military assistance over three years from the United States and British Commonwealth nations to meet the threat from Communist China.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20-- Dr. Francis Keppel, United States Commissioner of Education, declared today that the "besetting sin" of many schools was that they feed all pupils "a sort of universal baby food, without challenge or variety."
WASHINGTON, May 20--The Supreme Court cleared the way today for Federal regulation of natural gas prices on the basis of production costs estimated for a whole area rather than company by company.
Widespread dissatisfaction with maintenance and supervision of local parks was reported yesterday by the Park Association of New York City.
A 90-day crash program to improve pier accommodations for passengers and to ease problems in clearing baggage was promised yesterday by city and Federal officials.
BUDAPEST, May 20--With last week's meeting of Hungarian and Polish Communist leaders, some of the critical issues in the Soviet bloc's effort to integrate its members' economies are becoming clearer.
RABAT, Morocco, May 20-- Morocco's royalist party failed to win a clear-cut majority over the opposition in last Friday's parliamentary elections, the Interior Ministry confirmed today.

The New York City Housing Authority has leased more than eight floors in a 29-story office and store building nearing completion at 250 Broadway facing City Hall Park. The space, which contains 175,000 square feet, will be occupied next fall and will enable the agency to consolidate its facilities now at 299 Broadway, and at 93 Worth Street and 267 Broadway.

Edward Everett Cauthorne was born when Abraham Lincoln was President--and in Lincoln's first term, at that Yesterday, observing his own 101st birthday, Mr. Cauthorne offered some advice for his fellow-residents at the Neponsit Home for the Aged in Queens.
After holding nearly steady for two weeks, steel production spurted ahead last week. Operations were at 85 per cent of estimated capacity, the best industry showing in more than three years.

A recent decision of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court has set a new tax policy that can revise the city's method of assessing real estate and, as a curious extra-legal effect, make good building in New York more difficult than ever.
WASHINGTON, May 20-- The Supreme Court held today that the New York Stock Exchange was not immune from the antitrust laws.
HOLLYWOOD, May 20-- "Cleopatra" has won the approval of the Production Code Authority, the movie industry's censorship arm.
The formation of a new civic group, the Civic Foundation of New York State, was announced yesterday by the organization's president, Ira Hirschmann, banking and merchandising consultant.
Short interest in the New York Stock Exchange in the month ended May 15 declined nearly 4 per cent to reach 5,796,618 shares.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 20--In the last few days South Africa has received two expressions of economic confidence that are significant in view of the frequent criticism of South Africa and threats of trade boycotts from many nations.

WASHINGTON, May 20-- The controller of the Currency and the Securities and Exchange Commission expressed today apparently irreconcilable views over the proper regulation of certain bank investment activities.

THERE is something collegiate and likable about the Karmon Israeli Dancers, who arrived at the Royale Theater last night. The seven girls and seven boys who make up the group are all good-looking, lively and quite earnest in their desire to entertain with the songs and dances they have to offer.

OTTAWA, May 20 (AP)-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the North At lantic Treaty Organization representatives at the forthcoming Ottawa conference should "place any differences on the table," and try to reach a consensus on how to deal with current problems.

PARIS, May 20 (UPI)--Topseeded Roy Emerson of Australia today rallied from the brink of defeat against Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy in the French international tennis championships Wand won his quarter-final match, 6--8, 4--6, 6--1, 6--3, 6--4.
VIENNA, May 20--The International Atomic Energy Agency announced today it had adopted unanimously a proposed worldwide accord called the Vienna Convention on Civil Liability for Nuclear Damage.
Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union won the world chess championship yesterday.

THE shift has taken over Franklin Simon's second floor. The collection is one of the prettiest in town and the prices are reasonable. For example, a paisley print with square neck and slits at the hem is $8.95. It has the look of silk but is actually a drip-dry fabric in red, blue, gold or...

DAMASCUS, Syria, May 20 (AP)--Premier Salah el-Bitar made a peace offer today to President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic, promising to lead Syria into a rederation with Egypt and Iraq and then step down.
CLEVELAND, May 20-- Negroes need more than equal rights, the leader of the National Urban League said here today.
GENEVA, May 20--The Soviet Union reopened unexpectedly today the issue of the recent United States launching of millions of minute copper wires into space in a communications experiment.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Tuesday, May 21--Turkish dissidents led by a former army colonel attempted a coup d'etat early today. President Cemal Gursel announced over the Ankara radio that forces loyal to him had crushed the brief revolt.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 20 (AP)--Billy Haughton became the first American driver to record 2,000 harness racing victories, guiding two winners at Brandywine Raceway tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 20--Mexico said today she was opposed to the taking away of the General Assembly vote from members who are behind in their assessments for United Nations peace-keeping operations.
BONN, May 20--Vice Chancellor Ludwig Erhard and the opposition Social Democratic party were hailed today as the big winners in yesterday's state election in Lower Saxony.
"Do-it-yourself" engineering by physicists has handicapped this country's efforts in space and in the exploitation of atomic energy, it was charged here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 20-- The Senate Government Operations Committee virtually ended today the possibility that Nassau County might be able to buy the rest of Mitchel Field for less than the Government's $13,628,000 asking price.

Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower will arrive here today to receive two awards during the week. At one of the affairs, he will be at one end of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel while President Kennedy attends a Democratic function at the other.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 20 (AP)--A Negro lawyer today called integration irrelevant to the progress of his race and said civil rights campaigns "destroy rather than create pride and dignity in the Negro."
CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., May 20 --Parents in this high-income commuters' community expressed alarm today over the exposure of "considerable" shoplifting by teen-agers.
PARIS, May 20--"The real danger to French democracy," said a Gaullist Deputy recently, "is not in these absurd charges of dictatorship, but in the absence of an effective political opposition"
President Kennedy's chief economic adviser asserted last night that the nation's economy was expanding at a rate "a notch or two" better than even the Administration had hoped last January.
GREENSBORO, N.C., May 20--An estimated total of 420 more Negro demonstrators have been arrested and jailed here in the sixth day of protest marches in front of segregated theaters and cafeterias.

LOS ANGELES, May 20-- James Francis Cardinal McIntyre, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Los Angeles, said today that he did not think that a tax proposal by Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff altered the central question about Federal aid to education.
The Air Force announced yesterday the first successful flight test of its "slit wing" plane with a revolutionary airinhalation system.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 20 --The first of two 650,000-kilowatt generating units at the new $183,000,000 Paradise Steam Plant in western Kentucky went into operation yesterday, the Tennessee Valley Authority announced today. The second unit will go into operation this fall.

Walter J. Mahoney, majority leader of the State Senate, said last night that he would ask a special legislative study group to look into the feasibility of a constitutional amendment to permit some form of state aid to private colleges and universities.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May, 20 --Thirty-four Negro children, including four who were present for the first time, participated today in the sit-in at the nearly all-white Cleveland School as the demonstration entered its third week.
Two agencies in port development, the city's Marine and Aviation Department and the Port of New York Authority, took another step toward "peaceful co-existence" yesterday.
Cotton futures declined 65 cents to $1.25 a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Two hundred and eighty-two golfers will compete Tuesday in this area's qualifying trials for the United States Open championship.
The virus-infection epidemic, which has spread to virtually every harness-racing track, continued to upset the sport yesterday.
PERTH AMBOY, N.J., May 20--City street department crews searched several catch basins here today hoping to find a set of about 20 missing keys, two of which are for Perth Amboy bank buildings.
Bus drivers and motorists on two streets in Brooklyn and Staten Island enjoyed a bit of peaceful coexistence yesterday as they took part in a test designed to keep them out of each other's way.
International airlines are hopeful that a meeting opening tomorrow in Montreal will resuit in a compromise on the trans-Atlantic air fares quarrel.
Pan American World Airways has ordered five more cargo jets while preparing to start scheduled jet freighter service next month, the company announced yesterday.
MOSCOW, May 20--The Soviet capital was put today in the unaccustomed role of acting as host to an Albanian delegation.
The Municipal Art Society of New York presented Certificates of Merit yesterday to a sculptor and three architectural firms ahd their sponsors for their contributions to the beauty of the city.
LAGOS, Nigeria, May 20-- Final arrangements for the Dick Tiger-Gene Fullmer fight, the first world championship bout to be staged in Africa, were completed last night.
HOUSTON, May 20 (UPI)-- Lieut. Col. John A. (Shorty) Powers will leave Project Mercury about the time that public honors for Maj. L. Gordon Cooper Jr. are completed. The Houston Chronicle said today.

Directors of the New Jersey Natural Gas Company proposed yesterday a two-for-one split of the common stock and declared the regular quarterly dividend on the present common shares, payable July 15 to holders of record July 1.

Sixteen men and a woman were arraigned in the Brooklyn Criminal Court yesterday on charges of possessing dangerous weapons. The charges were an outgrowth of a series of raids by the police to avert further warfare between the Gallo and Profaci gangs for control of the borough's underworld.
Heads are swelling, arms are being twisted and legs are being pulled these days in Barrow Street, where Bil and Cora Baird are preparing puppets for their Russian tour.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) --Personal income increased in April to a new high annual rate of almost $455,800,000,000. This represents an increase of about $2,500,000,000 from the March annual rate.
BOSTON, May 20--The courtappointed trustees of the New Haven Railroad announced today that within a month they planned to petition for curtailment or abandonment of New York commuter service.
GOV. TERRY SANFORD of North Carolina in vites comment on a proposal to establish in his state "a special type of arts school."

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 6 --The United States Ambassador in Bangkok, Kenneth Todd Young, ordered the helicopter pilot to fly along a country road in northeastern Thailand until he had spotted a yellow bulldozer. The pilot circled over the machine while the Ambassador took a good look through the open door of the cabin.

THE jargonauts do a fair amount of romping in "Latin America: Evolution or Explosion?"* But quite a lot of clear, disturbing and informing exposition emerges from this record of an important symposium on what's now troubling the nations in our dynamic hemisphere.
An ex-convict who served time as an accessory in a murder case and a former union official were indicted yesterday in the investigation of corruption in the State Liquor Authority.

GENEVA, Tuesday, May 21--The six nations of the European Common Market rejected early this morning a last-minute United States compromise proposal on how to reduce tariffs and create freer world trade.

OTTAWA, May 20--On the eve of the North Atlantic ministerial conference, Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson was challenged in Parliament today to give assurances that Canada would resist dictation from Washington and avoid becoming a "satellite" of the United States.
OL MOKES, Kenya, May 20 --What are the mechanics of an election in the heart of Africa?

CHICAGO, Tuesday, May 21 (AP)--Operations at the Ford Motor Company's stamping plant in suburban Chicago Heights resumed today after a nine-day strike that ended after a court injunction was served on United Automobile Workers Local 588.
George London, the Metropolitan Opera Company baritone, will make his Broadway debut in the musical-comedy "Solomon and She." It will be presented in the spring of 1964 by David Merrick.
WASHINGTON, May 20-- New York won in the Supreme Court today its 85-year-old fight to end railroad rate differentials in favor of ports farther south on the Eastern Seaboard.
IF there is python in the parlor next fall it may well be the result of Arthur and Theodora Edelman's plans for invading home decor.

LOS ANGELES, May 20--A day off in Los Angeles offers a chance to go sight-seeing, visit movie studios, loaf and, in the case of the Mets (who are populated with ex-Dodgers and other Californians, a chance to visit friends and families.

YONKERS, May 20--Repeat-performance harness races, rather than the announced heat-racing, was presented before a crowd of 21,417 at Yonkers Raceway tonight. Because of the shortage of horses caused by the virus epidemic, two of tonight's events saw some horses return for a second appearance.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) --Negotiators seeking to settle the railroad dispute moved quickly to the central issue to day, the elimination of 40,000 firemen from freight and yard trains.
There was a sweet-and-sour flavor to the stock market yesterday. Prices of sugar stocks continued to surge upward but the rest of the list tended to dip moderately.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)--The Supreme Court refused today to speed its hearing of an appeal in which Gov. Ross R. Barnett of Mississippi claims the right to a jury trial in the criminal contempt case pending against him.

Wheat farmers are faced with a difficult choice in today's nationwide referendum. They have to vote for or against the Department of Agriculture's plan to eliminate the wheat surplus, which calls for a combination of rigid production controls and liberal price supports. If two-thirds of those voting approve the plan, the Government will take over responsibility for wheat, the nation's most widely grown agricultural crop.

Net income of Dresser Industries, Inc., in the second fiscal quarter ended April 30 rose to $2,312,000, equal to 50 cents a share on sales of $59,632,000, stockholders were told yesterday. This compares with $1,973,000 or 42 cents a share on sales of $58,096,000 in the 1962 period.
Jim Bouton, a graduate from the bull pen, will get his third starting assignment when the Yankees meet the Kansas City Athletics tonight at the Stadium.
WASHINGTON, May 20-- The Senate approved for the sixth time today machinery to help Congress give betterinformed rebuttals to calls for money from the executive branch.
To compete in the 1964 Olympics, athletes will have to run, jump and throw faster, higher and farther than did most of the champions crowned at the first postwar games in 1948.

THE rug department at Abraham Straus has been taken over by a miniature, 9-by-26-foot showboat. Even the carpets cannot dull the sound of music, cancan dancers and other animated activity going on inside this authentic reproduction of the Cotton Blossom and her paddle wheel tugboat, the Dixie Belle.
MADRID, May 20--It is not yet clear who will be the "Gran Triunfador" of the 12 days of bullfights in honor of San Isidro, which end here May 26. But all know the name of the big loser.
WASHINGTON, May 20-- President Kennedy called on wheat farmers today to approve "in their own interests" a tough new plan for wheat production control in tomorrow's national wheat referendum.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI)--Mike Hershberger led the Chicago White Sox to a 4-3 victory over the Washington Senators tonight with two key singles.

PROOF OF INSURANCE ON CARS DUE YEARLY SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 21 (AP)--The State Motor Vehicle Commissioner said today his department was taking new steps to assure that all registered motorists in the state carried the automobile insurance required by law.
The British Blue Funnel Line will place a new passengercargo liner on the West Australia-Singapore run next spring.
BERLIN, May 21--East Germany asserted today that the scheduled visit of President Kennedy to West Germany and West Berlin next month was being exploited to "aggravate international tensions."
The fight Negroes are making to end de facto segregation in Northern schools is a reminder that constitutional guarantees of equal opportunity are imperfectly observed in every section.
The big news in the bond market yesterday was the sale at a discount of more than $62,000,000 out of the dormant $122,000,000 Washington Public Power Supply System account.

The Columbia Broadcasting System turned to jazz last night for the American contribution to the "International Hour," a new series of one-hour television programs on which the music and dancing of 12 countries will be seen during the next two and half months.
A brisk mid-afternoon rally enabled stock prices yesterday to recover most of Monday's losses.

The General Motors Corporation unveiled two new transportation items at a press conference here yesterday, stressing their modest price tags--$198,500 for one, $385,500 for the other, not including generous trade-in allowances.
RYE, N.Y., May 21--An informal prelude to The Griscom team matches among women golfers from Boston, Philadelphia and New York was held today on the South Course of the Westchester Country Club.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 21--Two leading officials of the Yugoslav League of Communists have outlined Yugoslavia's conditions for closer cooperation with the Soviet Union and other Soviet bloc countries. They make it clear that the Government will continue its policy of firm independence.
ALBANY, May 21--The Department of Motor Vehicles announced today the resignation of Thomas H. Brown, who had been suspended from his $15,000-a-year position as Deputy Motor Vehicles Commissioner.

Eddie Lopat and his ambitious Kansas City Athletics, who have been bobbing around in the first division since the start of the campaign, cracked head-on into a rude awakening at the Stadium last night.

The Chicago North Western Railway said yesterday it would "vigorously oppose" the proposed merger of the Union Pacific Railroad and the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad.

ROME, May 21--Palmiro Togliatti, secretary general of the Italian Communist party, threatened the nation today with riots and possible bloodshed if another center-left Government were formed having as its main purpose the isolation of the Communists.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 21--Doug Ford, home for a brief visit, won the Westchester Professional Golfers Association championship today with a 144.

The election of Charles B. Thornton as a director of the Lehman Corporation, investment bankers, was announced yesterday by Robert Lehman, president. Mr. Thornton is chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Litton Industries, Inc.
WASHINGTON, May 21-- The Mayor of Albany, Ga., Asa D. Kelley Jr., said today that his city government had "anticipated" the Supreme Court's sit-in decisions by repealing all segregation ordinances.
Three five-story apartment buildings at 490, 496 and 502 East 189th Street, the Bronx, have been sold by the Lyric Realty Corporation to the 490 Realty Company for investment.
OTTAWA, May 21--The minority Liberal Government of Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson survived tonight an important confidence vote on its decision to accept nuclear arms from the United States.

When he was inaugurated, Governor Hughes of New Jersey said that the people want government "unafraid to act in the people's service." He promised that his administration "will do its full duty, measuring it carefully and providing for its cost."
A plan to operate a public heliport on the roof of the new 59-story Pan Am Building was sharply attacked yesterday.
CLEVELAND, May 21 (AP) --The Brush Beryllium Company of Cleveland denied today a contention by the General Accounting Office that it overcharged the Navy for secret parts for Polaris missiles.
Two major retailers--Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and J.C. Penney Company--reported sharp earnings declines yesterday despite increased sales in the first fiscal quarter.
