BALTIMORE, May 21 (UPI) --Dick Hall's relief pitching helped the Baltimore Orioles to a 4-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight.
Ship travel on the Atlantic will continue to grow despite mounting competition from faster and faster airliners, Antonio Premuda of the Italian Line predicted yesterday.
ART The I.B.M. Gallery, 16 East 57th Street, has an exhibition of "Monumental Brass Rubbings of Great Britain." Forty blackand-white rubbings of brasses date from the 13th to the 17th century.
A landlord who failed to make good on a promise to remove violations in a Harlem tenement was sentenced to eight months in jail yesterday by the judge who had given him a month's reprieve.

SHUSHAN, N.Y., May 21-- There is something about a small and innocent trout of tender years that makes a fly-fisherman's heart throb with kind thoughts. They are lovely to contemplate, but unexciting to catch.

The Government's decision to lay up the nuclear ship Savannah until next fall because of a dispute over wages for her 29 engineers highlights the intolerable labor troubles that plague the American merchant marine.

Leonard H. Goldenson, president of American BroadcastingParamount Theatres, Inc., said that some of the television programs had not measured up to expectations, and this was reflected in the reported lower first-quarter earnings from a year ago.
LONDON, May 21--A lively debate has been stirred in Britain over taxes proposed for independent television companies.

Washington Mews was strung with thousands of red, white and blue lights and filled with little red booths last night for the second Carnaval de Paris, an event that benefits La Maison Francaise of New York University.
The City Council voted overwhelmingly last night for a record budget of $3,082,883,182 and for $98,000,000 in additional taxes to balance it.
WASHINGTON, May 21-- The American Bar Association came out in opposition today to two of the three states-rights amendments to the Constitution being pushed by conservative groups.
MR. KENNEDY--We've had a number of these ceremonies at the White House and at Cape Canaveral to pay tribute to a very distinguished group of Americans who have in our time in this ...
WASHINGTON, May 21-- the 18-month-old son of the President met Maj. L. Gordon Cooper Jr. today. John Fitzgerald Kennedy Jr. promptly buried his face in his mother's shoulder and sucked his thumb.

A.M. Kidder Co., Inc., one of Wall Street's oldest and wealthiest brokerage houses, will go out of business on June 3, when its assets and offices will be taken over by Reynolds Co. and Francis I. duPont Co. The sale was announced yesterday by the three concerns.
The Union Oil Company of California would like to buy back the block of its stock owned by the Phillips Petroleum Company.
The Georgia-Pacific Corporation announced yesterday the purchase of all of the 51,818 shares of stock of the Fordyce Lumber Company of Fordyce, Ark., at $400 a share.
WASHINGTON, May 21-- The Treasury announced today that it had increased its borrowings of foreign currencies by $53,000,000 through the sale of bonds to Belgium and Switzerland.

MOSCOW, May 21--The United States and the Soviet Union signed today a three-year agreement for a cooperative program in nuclear studies. One of the provisions calls for the exchange of two or three research specialists for terms of up to a year.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 21-- Anti-Government terrorism exploded in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, last night and early today as the ceremonies marking President Francois Duvalier's new term gained momentum.

A public offering of $50,000,000 of Associates Investment Company 4 3/8 per cent, 21-year debentures is being made today by an investment banking group managed by Lehman Brothers and Salomon Brothers Hutzler.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 21 --A Federal Court was urged today to order the reinstatement of 1,100 Negro school students expelled or suspended as a result of antisegregation demonstrations.
Despite strong protests from the Soviet Government, the National Broadcasting Company televised last night a one-hour program filmed in the Kremlin.
While passing through Times Square yesterday a woman put a piece of chewing gum into her mouth and, with no apparent guilt, tossed the gum wrapper onto the sidewalk, ignoring the trash ...
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 21--The Congo's House of Representatives voted today to cut away half of President Moise Tshombe's province of South Katanga.
The cost of producing electricity went up again yesterday.
Maj. L. Gordon Cooper Jr. comes to town for a ticker-tape parade today and at Aqueduct a 2-year-old named Cooperstown is scheduled to run in the fourth race.

MADRID, May 21--The Falange movement published today an unusually radical call for a peaceful social "revolution" in Spain. The call had been issued by the movement's representative in the Government. Jose Solis Ruiz.
DES MOINES, Iowa, May 21 --The United Presbyterian Church, at its General Assembly here, opposed devotional acts in the public schools today in a statement on church-state relations.
The eve of National Maritime Day finds the shipping industry speculating on the Federal maritime budget for the 1964 fiscal year.
The rate at which checking accounts were used in banks outside major money market cities increased by 5 per cent in April to another high following two months of decline.
The National Maritime Union and the American Merchant Marine Institute agreed yesterday to arbitrate labor grievances before they develop into work stoppages.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 21 --Turkey's Supreme Security Council imposed martial law today in Istanbul, Izmir and Ankara, the capital. The action followed a confused night of shooting between army units and war college cadets who attempted to stage a coup.

DES MOINES, May 21--The ouster last year of the Rev. Stuart Hamilton Merriam from the Broadway Presbyterian Church in New York City was upheld here today by the General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church.

WASHINGTON, May 21--From the highest officials to the youngest children, this capital gave its praise and its heart today to Leroy Gordon, Cooper Jr., the homespun Air Force major who became a national hero by orbiting the earth 22 times.
NEW DELHI, May 21-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party suffered defeat today in two of three by-elections for the lower house of Parliament.
WASHINGTON, May 21-- The United States Government has had to bear in frustration the passage of a crucial week of effort to tncourage the overthrow of Haiti's President, Dr. Francois Duvalier.
BONN, May 21--Georg Heuser, the major defendant in a case involving the murder of 70,000 Jews, was sentenced today to 15 years at hard labor by a Coblenz court.
Paintings for which an artist could be--and, in fact, was--arrested in Mississippi were previewed yesterday in the Martha Jackson Gallery at 32 East 69th Street. There wasn't a policeman in sight.

GENEVA, Wednesday, May 22--An important concession by the United States made possible an 11th-hour agreement yesterday with the European Economic Community on a general formula for reducing tariffs and freeing trade.

THE art-conscious homemakers interested in begin ning to collect pictures may find an ally in Art A La Carte, Inc. This new concern has gathered a group of lithographs and prints that are well framed and reasonably priced.
WASHINGTON, May 21-- Business spending for inventories was greater in the first quarter of the year than originally estimated. Consumer spending was less.
A who's who in contemporary American music gathered last night to pay homage to the 78-year-old composer, Edgard Varese, at a dinner inaugurating the Koussevitzky International Recording Award.
Contests have developed in the Bronx for the Republican designations for district attorney and councilman at large.

MILWAUKEE, May 21 (AP) --Jim Maloney, Cincinnati righthander equaled the modern major league record of eight consecutive strikeouts and fanned a total of 16 tonight as the Reds defeated the Milwaukee Braves, 2--0.

BOSTON, May 21--The chairman of the Connecticut Public Utilities Commission asserted today that the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroad systems must assume any burden created by including the New Haven Railroad in a proposed merger.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 21--Foreign ministers of African countries will recommend to the African heads of state that a proposed charter for continental unity be developed over a three-month period.
LONDON, May 21--The highly decorative "art nouveau" of the turn of the century, which never made much of an impression on Britain, is getting a second chance.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 21-- Although apprehensive about the virus infection epidemic that has affected horses at many harness racing tracks, Roosevelt Raceway was preparing today for its 24th opening tomorrow night.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 21 --Federal District Judge Hobart H. Grooms told the University of Alabama today that it must admit two Negroes June 10.
WASHINGTON, May 21-- Barry Finclair, a 17-year-old violinist from Queens, tonight won the Merriweather Post contest of the National Symphony Orchestra for cellists and violinists under 19 years old.
Net earnings and sales of the General Foods Corporation rose for the 11th successive year in the 12-month fiscal period ended Mar. 31, Charles G. Mortimer, chairman, announced yesterday.

E.H. LESSING of Jersey City reported today's deal in the thought that it might be a problem difficult enough for the department that Alvin Roth and Tobias Stone used to conduct in Bridge World magazine--if that department is ever resumed.
More than 1,000 students from public and private junior and senior high schools were honored yesterday at the ninth annual citation ceremony of the Mayor's Committee on Scholastic Achievement.

The first phase in the prosecution of Gerardo A. (Jerry) Re, his son, Gerard F., and four others charged with defrauding the public in the sale of unregistered Swan-Finch Oil Corporation stock, ended yesterday in Federal District Court.
WASHINGTON, May 21--The political consequences of Gordon Cooper's space flight may not be as significant as the scientific, but they are important just the same.
Research Grants to Assist Farming in Poorer Lands

DETROIT, May 21, (UPI)-- Charley Wolf, who had concluded that he didn't fit into the plans of the new owner of the Cincinnati Royals of the National Basketball Association, quit as head coach of the Royals today and signed a two-year contract as head coach of the Detroit Pistons.
Developments reported yesterday and in recent weeks have brought the intensely powerful light generator, known as the laser, significantly closer to general use.
Grey Advertising, Inc., figured prominently yesterday in trade speculation involving two important advertising accounts.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is planning a new campaign to spur school integration in this city.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, May 21--Confirmation that the Central African Federation is finished was seen in simultaneous statements tonight by Rhodesian Selection Trust, Ltd., and the Anglo-...
MOSCOW, May 21--The elite of the Soviet music world acclaimed Lorin Maazel tonight as the young American conductor opened a two-week concert series here.

Mrs. Rita Wallach Morgenthau is retiring this week after 35 years as director of the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theater. At a luncheon in Sardi's yesterday, 175 friends, theater personalities and graduates of the school saluted her.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 (AP)--Billy O'Dell of the San Francisco Giants, backed by home runs by Ed Bailey, Orlando Cepeda and Jose Pagan, stopped the Philadelphia Phils, 3--2, on five hits tonight for his sixth victory without a loss.

LOS ANGELES. AT Christian Dior in Paris this afternoon, a gaunt model mill sweep through a curtained doorway dressed in an ankle-length column of crepe. It is eggplant purple belted in neon pink and its name is "Beverly Hills."
Scores Flee Unhurt As Sniper in Hotel Shoots Into 73d St. A former mental patient fired at least six shots into West 73d Street from his hotel room yesterday before being overpowered by the police.

STUTTGART, May 21--A British scientist urged European nations today to form a space agency similar to that in the United States to "develop the technology and logistics of an economically viable space transportation system."

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., May 21--Three North Shore society women were notified by this village today that they would not be permitted to hold a twist dance contest during a fair to benefit a cancer research foundation.

THOSE responsible for the revival of Arch Oboler's "Night of the Auk" last night must have been motivated by the thought that the play is even timelier now than when it was originally offered on Broadway in 1956.

The Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would seek Board of Estimate approval today for nine low-rent public housing projects--the last that can be built here with Federal money now available.

Most European stock exchanges weakened yesterday. The London market failed to respond to a new statement of economic optimism by Chancellor of the Exchequer Reginald Maudling. Much of the list moved down.
CORNWALL-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 21--A new storm is brewing over Storm King Mountain.

WASHINGTON, May 21-- While the public was voicing its acclaim for Maj. L. Gordon Cooper Jr. today, politicians and astronauts were maneuvering behind the scenes on matters concerned with the future of the space program.
Sugar futures climbed sharply yesterday in an otherwise irregular New York commodity market.
ALBANY, May 21--The State Board of Law Examiners announced today that 296 of the 567 persons who took the bar examinations on March 26 and March 27 had passed.

The First Chicago International Banking Corporation, a subsidiary of the First National Bank of Chicago, has leased about 6,500 square feet in the new Sperry Rand Building, 1290 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) at 51st Street.
Any doubt that Elizabeth Taylor has become the highestpaid performer in motion picture history was dispelled yesterday by Darryl F. Zanuck.
DURHAM, N.C., May 21-- Mass Negro demonstrations were suspended here for a day, after newly elected Mayor R. Wense Grabarek announced today that seven drive-in restaurants had agreed to desegregate.
Frank D. O'Connor opened his campaign for re-election as District Attorney of Queens last night with an attack on Governor Rockefeller and the state's two Republican Senators.

Winthrop H. Brooks, formerly president and chairman of the board of Brooks Brothers, Madison Avenue clothing manufacturers and merchants, died yesterday in St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases, the Bronx. He was 73 years old.

LONDON, May 21--Like France's Theatre Nationale Populaire, Italy's Teatro Popolare Italiano is a popularizing, rather than--as yet--a popular, theater. Its aim is to proselytize the unsophisticated on behalf of the pleasures and the glories of theatergoing.
The Park Association of New York City disclosed yesterday that it had been prevented from completing a survey on park conditions as a result of an order by Commissioner Newbold Morris.
CHICAGO, May 21 (UPI)-- Frantic last-minute buying spurred May wheat prices and the contracts went off the board at noon with gains of more than 9 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade.
--The blue, white and gold jetliner used by President Kennedy flew here nonstop from Moscow today--a flight of 5,009 miles--in 9 hours 53 Minutes 52 seconds.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 21 --Severe fighting has broken out again on the Plaine des Jarres between pro-Communist Pathet Lao troops and neutralist forces of Gen. Kong Le, the Government announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 21-- Last year's steel price increase would have been revoked even if the Kennedy Administration had never intervened, a steel industry economist told Congress today.
BRADENTON, Fla., May 21 --Rear Adm. Jesse G. Coward, who won two Navy Crosses for heroism in Pacific naval engagements in World War II, died yesterday at his home here. He was 63 years old.

IT is the age of jet travel and, along with it, the age of efficiency packing. Each year, at about this time, the prospective vacationer can find a host of new gadgets that make it possible to carry all the conveniences of home away from home.

Two leading economists have expressed confidence that the United States can solve the economic problems that would follow a disarmament agreement. And they say that economic fears should not handicap efforts at the bargaining table.

CHARLEVOIX, Mich., May 21--Michigan's first nuclear electric power plant, the Big Rock Point plant, was dedicated here today. It was described as an important pilot project that would pave the way for bigger and more efficient facilities in the future.
THE tour of the Kremlin, seen on film last night over the television network of the National Broadcasting Company, was an accomplishment of stunning magnificence.

The Coast Guard is asking would-be seamen and dock workers if they have ever been under even "indirect influence of a foreign government" or ever have subscribed to "matter" prepared by anyone associated with the Communist party or 276 other groups.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 21--Schneor Zalman Shazar was elected Israel's third President today.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, May 22--The Administration's stiff productioncontrol plan for wheat was buried under a landslide of "no" votes in yesterday's national referendum.

LOS ANGELES, May 21-- Like cats against mice, Roman legions against barbarians and ordinary citizens against the Internal Revenue Service, there's not much doubt about the outcome when a left-hander pitches against the Mets.

MICK O'CONNELL of County Kerry recently was voted Ireland's greatest football player--Gaelic football, that is. According to the extravagantly exuberant Irish, he is the Babe Ruth of his sport and he will be on display at Gaelic Park in the Bronx on Sunday when he takes part in a charity exhibition game.
THE plight of children without parents or neglected by them is getting worse-- at least if we are to judge by several recent novels.
WASHINGTON, May 21-- Adm. George W. Anderson, outgoing Chief of Naval Operations, will be named Ambassador to Portugal, President Kennedy announced today.

CONCH, pronounced "konk," is a shellfish known to only a few New Yorkers. It is available here the year round, although in limited quantities, and usually only in fish stores that cater to shoppers of Italian, French or Caribbean background.

The North Atlantic Council meets today in Ottawa for an important session. The basic unity of the alliance as the main bulwark of free world defense must be preserved. And a start must be made toward creating a NATO nuclear force and giving our European allies a larger share in nuclear arms control.
OTTAWA, May 21--Britain's Foreign Secretary, the Earl of Home, rejected today any plan for a North Atlantic nuclear force without the complete integration of United States military power.
WASHINGTON, May 21-- Legislation to subject most Federally aided construction projects to some measure of coordinated planning received a warm reception at a Senate subcommittee hearing today.
Maurice J. O'Rourke, the junior commissioner on the Board of Elections, called yesterday for "a full airing" of a dispute about the form the ballot will take in the coming primary election.

Tennessee borrowed $25,000,000 yesterday on various purpose bonds due 1964-83.

Yeoman 1st Cl. Nelson C. Drummond testified yesterday that he had tried to shake off his Soviet employers by asking for large sums of money.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) --Three more union spokesmen opposed today a bill to provide compulsory arbitration as a last resort in settling major maritime labor disputes. One described the bill as another "nail in the coffin of individual liberties."

CLEVELAND, May 21-- American Negroes who seek identification with the emerging African nations or with such United States nationalistic groups as the Black Muslims are showing emotional immaturity, a psychiatrist said here today.
OTTAWA, May 21--Everyone remembers the blind men who inspected an elephant and were much impressed. Later, however, when they compared notes they found themselves discussing different creatures.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI)--Some Senators attacked the Civil Rights Commission today as undesirable and others praised it as "almost the only outlet for the pent-up grievances of the Negro community."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 21--Critics and proponents of a plan for reorganizing the public schools and providing free school bus transportation for all students attended a stormy public hearing tonight.
The North Atlantic Ports Association will hold its annual meeting here on June 3 and 4 at the Sheraton Motor Inn.
BERLIN, May 21 (AP)--A move to award the 1968 Olympic Games to Berlin developed today, and the idea drew immediate support from Avery Brundage and other Olympic officials.

Benjamin Franklin, with five individual winners, captured the Public Schools Athletic League's Manhattan Borough track and field championship at Van Cortlandt Park, Bronx, yesterday for the fourth successive year.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 21 (AP)--Four persons, including an official of the International Longshoremen's Association, were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of tampering with jurors in the trial of James R. Hoffa last year.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 21-- Schneor Zalman Shazar, who became Israel's third President today, has devoted less than two years of a lifetime of social welfare work to government service.
YONKERS, May 21--Yonkers Raceway's 73d and final night of the longest meeting in harness racing history drew 21,713 fans, who wagered $1,913,916 at the Westchester track tonight.
Artists--some very young, some old, others blind and some in wheel chairs--attracted large audiences yesterday in Times Square's first outdoor art show.
Aid to less-developed countries can, like trade, be made mutually profitable, Andrew W. Cordier, an educator and former United Nations official, told a gathering of foreign traders yesterday.
A PRETTY new face and figure have been added to New York's lively foreign colony. They belong to Mrs. Marie Edith Legendre, wife of Michel Legendre, the new French Consul General.

The earnings of Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., for this year should continue to exceed 1962 figures barring unexpected developments, Herbert Willetts, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
At a gas station on the Lower East Side a car owner gets the same cheerful, efficient service he finds at most other modern filling stations.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 22 --Ambassador Lincoln Gordon of the United States made a sharp public attack today on left-wing nationalist critics of United States investment in Brazil.

HONG KONG, May 22--Tan Chen-lin, a Deputy Premier of Communist China and a member of the Politburo of the Chinese Communist party, praised Albania's Communist leadership tonight for its contributions to ship with Tirana.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 22--The Soviet Union served notice today that it would refuse to pay its share of any expenses assumed by the United Nations that were "unlawfully" voted by the General Assembly.

BRUSSELS, May 22--With all signs pointing to an acute energy shortage in Europe within the next decade or two, European oil companies are joining forces with American petroleum companies in an intensified search for oil under the North Sea.
Stock prices rose moderately in active trading yesterday morning and then fell back in the final 90 minutes of trading.

"I am obligated to carry out the court order." In those unequivocal words President Kennedy set forth yesterday his determination to enforce the admission of two Negroes to the University of Alabama, even if Governor Wallace persists in his threat to stand in the classroom door to bar their entrance.
CHICAGO, May 22--Charles B. Shuman, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, predicted today a transition to fewer controls on agriculture.
CLEVELAND, May 22--The shortage of trained social workers in public welfare is a "national scandal," a report by an opinion-research organization declared today.

PARIS. THE term "French furniture" is still associated in most people's minds with antiques. It evokes the names of kings and the glories of Empire. However, increasing numbers of French householders today shop for contemporary designs that fit their modern apartments.
Jacques D. Angelvin, a Parisian television performers, admitted in State Supreme Court yesterday that he had conspired to bring $3,500,000 worth of pure heroin into the country from France.

Fordham University announced yesterday that it would open a coeducational college of liberal arts and sciences on its Rose Hill campus in the fall of 1964.

American Broadcasting Co.Paramount Theaters, Inc., will invest more than $1,000,000 in three Broadway musicals. The corporation is the parent organization of the American Broadcasting Company, United Paramount Pictures and A.B.C.Paramount Records.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., May 22 --Dr. Jefferson Weed, medical director of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company of Newark, died this morning of a heart attack in his home, 6 Hamilton Road. He was 56 years old.

MADRID, May 22--Labor slowdowns continue to be reported from various parts of Spain. Officials observed today that the workers were resorting to these tactics rather than to strikes to press their demands.
ONEONTA, N.Y., May 22 (AP)--Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino agreed today that the state should consider giving financial aid to private colleges--but not at the expense of the State University.
New York City took Maj. L. Gordon Cooper Jr. to its heart yesterday with a triumphal parade, a welcome at City Hall and an official luncheon.
Foremost Dairies, Inc., plans to sell $14,400,000 in properties to two eastern companies.

LOS ANGELES, May 22--It isn't only left-handed pitching that stops the Mets, or righthanded pitching, but just plain pitching. Tonight at Chavez Ravine the man they had to swing at was Don Drysdale, who beat them, 7--3.
HONG KONG, May 22--The sun blazed down from a clear sky today on a Hong Kong parched and almost gasping for water.
ELMIRA, N.Y., May 22 (AP) --Elmira paid final tribute today to Ernie Davis, the 23-yearold football star, who died of leukemia Saturday in Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI)--A former Pentagon employe said today that Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara had "no real supportable" technical case for awarding the TFX fighter plane contract to the General Dynamics Corporation.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 22--An unborn baby has become a topic of great concern to much of the diplomatic community here.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 22-- Nothing makes much sense in Birningham. The industry is Yankee steel, the politics is Balkan, the redearthed ridges are Castilian and the social structure is South African apartheid.

Both sides claimed victory yesterday at the annual meeting of the United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company in Portland, Me., as the dissident group elected four directors to a sixteen-man board by a vote of 520,606 to 364,131.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- President Kennedy charged today that the Republicans "know it is untrue" when they raise the possibility that he plans to abandon the Guantanamo naval base in Cuba.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI)--Two Senators opened a bipartisan drive today for legislation designed to wipe out segregation in virtually every facet of daily business.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 22-- Plans for a multimillion-dollar sand restoration project on a 15-mile barrier beach off the Hamptons have bogged down because of a disagreement between Suffolk County and the Army Corps of Engineers.

TEL AVIV, May 22 (AP)-- Kurt Blumenfeld, president of the Zionist Organization of Germany from 1924 to 1933 and a leader in establishing the theoretical foundations for the Zionist movement and the State of Israel, died yesterday. He was 79 years old.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 22--Barring his overthrow as a result of acts of terrorism such as those occurring in Port-au-Prince in the last few days, the prospects are for President Duvalier to stay in office in Haiti for at least several months.

John H. Breck, Inc., the big shampoo and toiletries company, has decided to shift some $7,000,000 in billings to Young Rubicam. The Breck company recently became a wholly-owned subsidiary of the American Cyanamid Company.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 22--The Congo has notified the United Nations that agreement has been reached for Nigerian police officers to train the Congolese police force.

BECAUSE dance as art is having a difficult time finding its rightful place in television, it would be nice to report that the Repertoire Workshop had done a great job in its presentation of dances by Paul Taylor, which were seen on tape last night over WCBS-TV.
The Central and South West Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday an increase of 8.2 per cent in kilowatt-hour output of electricity during the first four months of the year.

LONDON, May 23--Robert Muller, a tough young drama critic until he retired last year, offered his first play tonight at the Saville Theater. It is "Night Conspirators," a political melodrama about Mr. Muller's native country, Germany.
GREENSBORO, N.C., May 22--Three thousand Negroes marched silently through the downtown area tonight, while a newly formed biracial committee met in private to work toward desegregation.

Pan American Airways will allot space aboard its new cargo jets to Japan Air Lines between Tokyo and San Francisco, the airline's vice president for traffic and sales, Willis G. Lipscomb, has announced.

Wall Street brokers, who woo the public's commission business, traditionally keep a tight lip on their private operations. But brokerage houses depend on mergers and acquisitions for their changing character much as do industrial companies whose stocks trade on the street.

KATMANDU, Nepal, Thursday, May 23--Two American teams climbed to the top of Mount Everest yesterday, one by the previously unconquered West Ridge of the world's highest mountain, the United States Everest Expedition reported from its base camp today.
WASHINGTON, May 22--The decisive rejection by farmers of the Administration's wheat-production control plan touched off a political scramble today.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 22 (AP)--A Federal judge has ruled that "it is equally as unconstitutional to discriminate against a white man as it is to discriminate against a colored man."
Harry Sacher, a lawyer who defended 11 top American Communists in Smith Act trials, died yesterday in his home at 390 West End Avenue. His age was 60.
Alumnae and parents of students at the Convent of the Sacred Heart at 1 East 91st Street are planning a theater party at the promenade concert June 7 in Philharmonic Hall.

WASHINGTON, May 22-- Gov. George Romney of Michigan repeated his denial of Presidential aspirations today. At the same time he gave the clearest exposition to date of his position on several national issues.
WASHINGTON, May 22-- The Kennedy Administration is considering new legislation to deal with segregation at lunch counters and in schools.

NOT the least blessing of living on an island called Manhattan is the almost yearround availability of hard shell clams. The delicacy is far and away the typical New Yorker's favorite dish on the half shell, and local residents consume in the course of a year nearly six times as many clams as oysters.

The bargaining over the ground rules just concluded at the meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) gave both Europe and the United States a foretaste of what lies ahead in the forthcoming negotiations.

Cocoa and sugar futures soared yesterday and lead most New York commodities higher in price.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI)--Gil Hodges of the New York Mets was signed today to replace Mickey Vernon as manager of the Washington Senators.

DETROIT, May 22--Mrs. Stanley S. Kresge, wife of the vice chairman of the S.S. Kresge Company, turned the company's annual meeting yesterday into an earnest discussion of the morality of keeping some of the company's stores open on Sundays.
The Board of Estimate will vote today to restore a number of key cuts made by the City Council on Tuesday night in trimming the record city budget to $3,082,883,182.

WASHINGTON, May 22-- Morris Green, vice president of Sound Studios, producers of radio programs and a former New York theatrical producer, died Monday night in the Veterans Administration Hospital here. He was 73 years old.
CHICAGO, May 22--The home-base company of the Second City opened last night its new revue, "20,000 Frozen Grenadiers, or there's been a tangible accident at the factory."

RYE, N.Y., May 22--A team of metropolitan New York women golfers won the Griscom Cup today for the first time since 1954. Playing over the difficult West Course of the Westchester Country Club, the squad of seven scored 26 out of a possible 42 points to beat Philadelphia and Boston.
Assurances of speedier processing to cut a mounting backlog of antidumping cases against importers were given yesterday by James Pomeroy Hendrick, deputy assistant secretary of the Treasury.
Two sets of air fares are still in effect across the Atlantic, one of them 5 per cent higher than the other.
LONDON, May 22--Britain's shipyards, already in a severe slump, lost another tanker order to Japan today. The news touched a sensitive nerve in Parliament and the shipbuilder's union.
Dr. Hubert M. Evans, professor of natural sciences at Teachers College, Columbia University, died of cancer Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 106 Morningside Drive.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 22 (UPI)--Tom Haller's grandslam homer, the first of his major league career, highlighted a seven-run fourth inning today and helped the leagueleading San Francisco Giants defeat the Philadelphia Phillies, 10--2.

CHICAGO, May 22 (UPI)-- Wheat futures closed unchanged to down today after an opening setback that reflected the farmers' rejection of the Administration's wheat program. Other grain futures rallied from lows. Soybeans, corn and rye closed strong and oats were up slightly on the Board of Trade.
Prices of Government securities were mixed yesterday in a moderately active session. High-grade corporate debt issues were firm in busier trading and municipals remained stalled.

WEMBLEY, England, May 22 (UPI)--Milan of Italy became the first non-Iberian team ever to win the European Soccer Cup when it beat the defending champion, Benfica of Lisbon, 2-1, today, before a crowd of 45,000.
A duel all the way through the seven furlongs between William Stone's George Barton and Joseph Roebling's Rainy Lake, thrilled the 28,748 customers at Aqueduct yesterday.

Eight of the financially distressed companies in the worldwide shipping empire of Manuel E. Kulukundis filed a voluntary petition under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act yesterday in the United States District Court at Foley Square.

The Southern California Edison Company borrowed $60,000,000 yesterday, on first and refunding mortgage bonds.
BONN, May 22--Pope John XXIII and his reappraisal of the Vatican's political and social policies are under sharp criticism in Roman Catholic circles in West Germany.

The Board of Examiners yesterday invalidated part of a recent test for prospective assistant principals of elementary schools. It acted after an investigation found that some candidates had had advance knowledge of the subject of the test.
New York City's park system was defended yesterday by Acting Commissioner John A. Mulcahy against criticisms contained in a report issued earlier this week by the Park Association.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 22--President Fran ois Duvalier told 50,000 Haitians massed in front of his palace today that they faced a future that would be "difficult and even frightening."
ALBANY, May 22--Norman Hurd, the state budget director, lifted a "freeze" order today against the filling of vacancies in state positions for 18 of the 35 state departments and agencies.
WASHINGTON, May 22-- President Kennedy said today that South Vietnam's leaders could get any number of United States troops out of their country simply by suggesting a withdrawal.
Bartex Fabrics, a textile concern occupying half a floor at 149 Madison Avenue southeast corner of 32d Street has leased additional space there to expand its main office showrooms and shipping room.

LEWISBURG, Pa., May 22-- Dr. Lewis E, Theiss, professor emeritus of journalism at Bucknell University and author of adventure books for boys, died today in the Evangelical Community Hospital here. He was 84 years old.
A weekly half-hour television comedy series is being developed for Zero Mostel, who is starring oh Broadway in "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum."
Top executives of major steel companies indicated some encouragement here yesterday at the course of labor contract talks.
In 38 words, Maj. Leroy Gordon Cooper Jr. gave New York his heartfelt thanks yesterday "for this wonderful day."
WASHINGTON, May 22-- President Kennedy suggested today that public schools should spare the rod. But he cautioned parents not to spoil the child.
The research director for the General Electric Company chided the steel industry yesterday for falling behind plastics in research and in creative selling.

A first and a fourth for 7 points in the final event, the triple jump, gave Evander Childs the championship in the Public Schools Athletic League Bronx track and field meet yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.

PANJIM, India, May 22-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru visited Indian Goa for the first time today. He received thunderous applause when he told the people of this former Portuguese enclave that their land would remain a "seperate entity" in the Indian Union as long as they wanted to keep it that way.
VIENNA, May 22--Austria observed the beginning of President Adolf Schaerf's second sixyear term today with a 4,000man parade on Ringstrasse Boulevard, showing off the country's armed forces.
Sir David Ormsby Gore, the British Ambassador, urged last night that Britain and the United States make new efforts to revive unity among the Western democracies.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., May 22--"1 want that title back. Losing it to Luis Rodriguez hasn't made any difference to my friends, but it has made a difference to me."

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., May 22--Plans for four new high schools with a total enrollment more than double that of 12 present Roman Catholic high schools were announced today by the Most Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg, Bishop of Rockville Centre.
A decline of 1,263,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

AKRON, Ohio, May 22 (AP) --Three Appellate Court judges granted an injunction today to prevent a spacesuit scientist from sharing trade secrets learned while he was working for the B.F. Goodrich Company with his new employer, the International Latex Corporation of Dover, Del.
The Leake and Watts Children's Home held its formal dinner dance at Gracie Mansion last night, and although the atmosphere was familial, not everyone was related by blood or by marriage.

The Yankees brought down the Kansas City Athletics, 8--7, in a torrid 11-inning struggle at the Stadium last night as Mickey Mantle belted one of the most powerful home run drives of his spectacular career.
WASHINGTON, May 22--The Department of Agriculture has called off its planned spraying of a Washington State forest with DDT to prevent contamination of oysters in nearby waters.

An all-male jury deliberated into the early hours today the espionage case against Yeoman 1st Cl. Nelson Drummond. At 1:40 A.M., 11 hours after they had begun their discussions, the weary jurors were sent to hotel rooms for the night.

WHEN Eddie Lopat was a 21-game winner for the Yankees, he overpowered no hitters. He outslicked them with an infinite variety of pitches. He used guile instead of speed and loved to lure the batters into a duel of wits. This was no contest. The tantalizing left-hander could outthink the best of them.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI) --Walter P. Reuther told Congress today that the United States was the "most callous, indifferent nation in the world" about unemployment.
ST. LOUIS, May 22 (UPI)-- The National Football League named a West Coast law enforcement officer today as a "roving watchdog" to protect players and league personnel from undesirable elements."
WASHINGTON, May 22-- President Kennedy said today that the new agreement on basic principles for next year's international trade negotiations was "a satisfactory settlement."
ROME, May 22--Reports that Pope John XXIII is seriously ill circulated again today when the public audience he customarily gives on Wednesdays in St. Peter's Basilica was unexpectedly canceled.

Mrs. L. Gordon Cooper Jr., who within the last week has traveled 612,000 miles, part vicariously and part in person, maintained the same total composure yesterday as she rode the 14 blocks up lower Broadway to City Hall through a storm of ticker tape and noise.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The legislation which Senators Cooper of Kentucky and Dodd of Connecticut will formally propose tomorrow to sweep away all discriminatory practices of privately owned, public marketing facilities is a logical application of the Supreme Court's lunch room sit-in decisions last Monday.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 22 --The 3,250,000-member United Presbyterian Church ended its week-long General Assembly here today after approving a series of "guidelines" designed to strengthen and improve relations with Roman Catholics.

HOUSTON, May 22--The earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) should be "appreciably better" this year than in the record year of 1962, unless upset by major adverse developments, M.J. Rathbone, chairman and chief ...

Jack Brause, realty investor, has purchased and taken title to the Executive Hotel, a 15story building at 237-39 Madison Avenue between 37th and 38th Streets. The building, which was remodeled a few years ago, contains 150 air-conditioned rooms and a restaurant.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 22-- The surprise, as Roosevelt Raceway opened for business tonight was not that Mr. Budlong won the featured $7,500 Mental Health Pace, but that only 20,597 harness racing fans were on hand to see him do it.
Yesterday's spring ceremonies of two societies honoring something less than a joyous festival.
A leading Soviet physicist told an American television audience last night that both East and West were equally obsessed with the distrust that stands in the way of disarmament.

THE 19th game of the 24game world title match in Moscow between Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union and his countryman Tigran Petrosian, who went on to win the title, was,won by the challenger after 66 moves. The 20th game was drawn after 21 moves.
PARIS, May 22--France and Guinea signed today accords that ended five years of strained relations.
The nine-project package of low-cost housing submitted by the City Housing Authority came under heavy attack yesterday before the Board of Estimate.
LOS ANGELES, May 22-- Jimmy Piersall, one of the most controversial players on the current baseball scene, may soon be a Met as a result of Gil Hodges becoming manager of the Washington Senators.
The New York Publishers Association is studying a proposal for a joint labor-management board to cope with problems of the city's newspapers, Donald R. McVay, executive secretary, said yesterday.

The names of the 31 African heads of state meeting in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, are like the roll of native drums. Yet a Joseph, a Milton, a Philibert, an Ibrahim, come like counterpoint to remind us that Europe and Islam are also present.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 22 (AP)--The city began burning today the books of John R. Lindmark, 74year-old book dealer who was evicted from his store to make way for a highway.

The Western Electric Company announced yesterday the creation of five new service division regional areas as the final phase of a reorganization aimed at facilitating service to Bell System telephone companies.
The United States was urged yesterday by Fred Korth, Secretary of the Navy, to remain a great maritime nation in the face of Soviet challenges and to avoid repeating past shipping mistakes.

Yesterday was an on-and-off day for several stocks. The American Stock Exchange delayed the opening of trading in CompuDyne Corporation. The company filed a petition the day before in Philadelphia under the bankruptcy law.
The Council for Financial Aid to Education predicted yesterday that if corporate support of higher education continued at the present rate it might exceed $500,000,000 by 1970.
Most European stock exchanges improved yesterday, but the London market continued erratic.

Governor and Mrs. Rockefeller are expected to return to New York today from their 17-day honeymoon trip to Venezuela and the Virgin Islands, a Rockefeller family spokesman said yesterday.

Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said here last night that the "sense of duty" of the American people was weakening.

WASHINGTON, May 23-- Democratic and Republican officials of Nassau County, N.Y., united today behind the effort to buy the remaining uncommitted acreage at Mitchel Field for less than the $13,680,000 the Government seeks.

MOSCOW, May 23--Tigran Petrosian, the newly crowned world chess champion, met the press today and proved himself an articulate and outspoken commentator on the two-month title match in which he defeated Mikhail Botvinnik.
TOMORROW was to have been a glorious day for boating enthusiasts in Huntington, L.I.

Dr. Emil Goetsch, a Brooklyn surgeon and medical educator, died yesterday at the age of 80 in his home at 2 Montague Terrace.
Contract talks were broken off here late yesterday in a dispute that has closed 18 Jewish community centers. No further meetings were scheduled.

MANY good things are coming from across the Hud son. New Jersey fields are now starting to contribute lettuce and cauliflower in addition to increasing quantities of asparagus. Strawberries, too, are making the river crossing in larger land larger numbers.

The Citizens Budget Commission urged yesterday that a determination first be made on shifting the use of tracks during rush hours before any final action was taken on improving subway service in Queens.

President Kennedy spent a day and informal evening yesterday at a fund-raising birthday dinner given for him here by the President's Club of New York.
The Bronx Grand Jurors Association charged yesterday that inmates of the Manida Street annex to the borough's Youth House for Girls had worse living quarters than "animals in the Bronx Zoo."
WASHINGTON, May 24-- The Senate Finance Committee approved today an increase in the national debt limit to $309,000,000,000, the highest ever voted.

Thirty-two American short subjects have been chosen for the Venice Film Festival's documentary competition, to be held July 10-20. The selection is made annually by the Committee on International Nontheatrical Events in Washington. Last year the United States had 24 entries.

Cherry Valley, winner of Series II in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches, challenged Inwood, the last team in Series I, yesterday and won. Playing over the North Hempstead Country Club, Cherry Valley defeated Inwood, 8--7, and moved into Series I.

WASHINGTON, May 23-- The Securities and Exchange Commission has reached agreement with securities industry leaders on several important proposals for enlarging the commission's authority to police securities trading.

Taking the lead approaching the final jump, Mrs. George Greenhalgh Jr.'s Bimeland won the $11,500 Hitchcock Steeplechase at Aqueduct yesterday.

A former law associate of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz was arrested yesterday on charges of conspiracy to bribe officials of the State Liquor Authority. The defend ant, Hyman D. Siegel, who was associated with Mr. Lefkowitz for 27 years, had served as a Special Deputy Attorney General and was a Republican candidate for Congress in 1958.

David Nemerov, former president and board chairman of Russeks Fifth Avenue, Inc., died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 68 years old, and lived at the Palm Beach Towers Hotel in Florida. He was the father of Howard Nemerov, the poet and critic.

June 30, 1964, at the earliest. Asked for reaction to the re ports, Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday that he saw nothing special about the June 1 date. He would not comment on the reported bargaining goals of the two sides.

Mayor Wagner's first executive budget to pass the $3 billion mark is moving to completion after a public debate that has been louder than usual because, in the first place, education is again short-changed and secondly because of $200 million in new taxation.

Pierre Boulez will give a lecture-concert tonight at 8:30 in Hunter College Assembly Hall. Bethany Beardslee, soprano, will assist, and Arthur Weisberg will conduct the Contemporary Chamber Ensemble.

The Internal Revenue Service has revoked the tax-exempt status held since 1926 by the Fellowship of Reconciliation, an interfaith group opposed to wars and weapons of mass destruction. PORTLAND, Ore., May 24-- The decision to abolish Portland's civil defense agency has been followed by a move to cut the state program drastically.

MARGATE, N.J. May 24-- Mr. and Mrs. William J. Gibbons have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Veronica Noreen Gibbons, to Alfred E. Schretter of New York. He is the son of Mrs. Frank Wadsworth Dyer of Summit and the late Francis J. Schretter. The couple will be married here June 22.

Plans of the J.C. Penney Company to occupy extensive office and store space in the proposed Madison Square Garden development above Pennsylvania Station have been abandoned.

An unquestioned landmark of contemporary avant-garde music was explained and performed at Hunter College last night. The work was "Le Marteau sans Maitre" by Pierre Boulez. Disappointing the high hopes of a few months ago, the news coming out of Brazil recently has not been good. POWNAL, Vt., May 24-- Vermont, whose people are noted for their thrift, industry, independent thinking and conservatism, today became the 25th state to join the nation's pari-mutuel network.

A bill to provide new relief to the beleaguered domestic cotton industry passed the House Agriculture Committee yesterday by a 19 to 15 vote.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur got a Silver Buffalo from the Boy Scouts of America yesterday, and was reminded how a brown buffalo almost got him nearly 70 years ago.

FAR down on the list of credits for a Broadway musical, discoverable only by the most intrepid of theatergoers, is the name of the musical theater's missing link, the great unsung hero, the music copyist. Unsung though he may be without hisq efforts the show, too, would be unsung and unplayed.

Evidence is beginning to pile up rapidly that Western Europe will soon join the United States in extending substantial longterm financial aid and other economic assistance to the nations of Latin America.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP)-- The Fourth Estate Stable's entry of Times Roman and Editorialist finished 1--2 today in the $27,350 Myrtlewood Handicap at Washington Park.

Secretary of Agriculture Orville Freeman is tempted to let the farmers stew in their own juice and discover for themselves the harsh realities of an abrupt return to the free market.
LONDON, May 25--Bad luck is plaguing Hyde Park Corner underpass, one of the most widely discussed traffic projects in Britain.

WASHINGTON, May 25-- Representative Carl Vinson, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, announced today that he would introduce a bill next week to provide standard four-year terms for members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

MOSCOW, May 25--The editor of the only major Soviet periodical in Yiddish maintains that its "Jewish" orientation is now recognized even by "reactionaries" abroad who have criticized it because it dealt with Soviet propaganda themes.

A majority of the 730 Girl Scout Councils have approved the organization's Council Coverage plan according to a Survey by national headquarters. Under this plan, local groups have been merged or consolidated to include areas not previously served by a council.

The Atlantic community has successfully passed through two crucial meetings the past week that could have deepened the rifts within it but instead confirmed its basic solidarity and laid the first foundations for a stronger military and economic partnership with political overtones of worldwide impact. These meetings were the North Atlantic Council session in Ottawa and the conference of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) in Geneva.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 25-- In a country-fair atmosphere in which ice cream salesmen did a big business with the smallfry, pari-mutuel clerks paid off on worthless tickets and the public-address system failed to operate, the annual Adjacent Hunts one-day race meeting was held this afternoon.

PARIS, May 25 (AP)--Roy Emerson, the Australian champion who is regarded as the world's No. 1 amateur tennis player, made shaky progress into the final of the French international tennis tournament today.

During nearly a month in the Soviet Union, Cuban Premier Fidel Castro has received the red carpet treatment. He has visited most of Russia's major cities, conferred with its top officials from Premier Khrushchev down, attended a gala round of receptions, dinners, ballets and theatrical performances.

Label A. Katz, president of B'nai B'rith, asserted last night that Jewish secular groups having a religious motivation must play a strong role in the development of adult study programs devoted to Jewish life.

GOOD decorating, like haute cuisine, is a careful blending of many ingredients to provide a pleasing whole. The Southport, Conn., house shown on these pages exemplifies the successful mixing of three diverse elements--an l8thcentury New England clapboard house, many pieces of antique furniture, and a distinguished collection of modern art.

IN common with millions of other 16-year-old highschool students, Patty Duke is getting ready these days for her final examinations.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 25 --The marriage of Miss Gail Cranford Moffat, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Palmer Moffat Jr., to Lieut. David Loyal Jones, U.S.N., took place here this afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. John Wilson Jones of Oakland, Calif., and the late Mr. Jones.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 25 --Fewer horses coughed, more fans turned out and four oddson favorites failed to win tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. To many among the 31,133 on hand for the first Saturday program of the meeting, this made for a good night's sport with the promise of better things ahead.

LONDON. WHEN Dino di Lauren tiis was interviwed on television here, recently he was at pains to distinguish between the two kinds of pictures he makes-- epics and art films. If these categories bracket the market for the Italian producer, they do not to do so in Britain.

Slim, light-footed Johnny Kelley, who has monopolized the event since 1956, will be out to prove he's still king of the roads when he faces a record field of more than 150 in the national marathon championship at Yonkers today.

Apparel markets will be playing host to a great influx of buyers in the weeks immediately following Memorial Day. Buyers will have two objectives--attend showings for the fall fashions and, if they can, place orders for additional summer merchandise to dress up their current stocks.

CAPE MAY CITY, N.J.-- This quiet resort com munity, where the atmosphere of Cape Cod is pleasantly blended with the charm of the Deep South, has embarked on a most unusual urban renewal project.
HARTFORD, May 25--The Republicans announced this week that they would reduce proposed tax increases recommended by Gov. John N. Dempsey, a Democrat, from $68,000,000 to $8,000,000.
HAVANA, May 25 (AP)-- Several hundred Russian men, women and children left Havana today on the Soviet passenger liner Mariya Ulyanova, apparently bound for home.

PARIS--Tourists this season will be reminded, in still another way, that France's nostalgic turn of-the-century character never disappears. Prices throughout the country will be quoted on the same ratio to the dollar as they were back in the days of the Grand Tour.

NEW DELHI, May 25--The Soviet Union will provide financial and technical assistance for a major expansion of two oil refineries it is already building in India. It will also provide credit for establishing a large plant to make precision instruments in the state of Kerala.

Is Mickey Mantle off on another batting spree that eventually will see him belt a fair ball out of Yankee Stadium?

TEMPE, Ariz., May 25-- Adolph Plummer of New Mexico University smashed the world record in the 440-yard dash tonight in the finals of the Western Athletic Conference track and field championships with a clocking of 44.9 seconds.

GREENSBORO, N.C., May 25 (AP)--Negro students called a temporary halt to their antisegregation demonstrations. They said they were giving civic officials the weekend to work out a solution of the city's racial troubles.
SEOUL, Korea, May 18--Is U.S. aid to South Korea really appreciated by the people here?

THE combinational chess player is like a prize fighter with a knockout slug in each fist. The defending boxer, reeling as he must from a solar plexus blow or an uppercut, may weather the round by hanging on the ropes, clinching or covering up. Later he may outbox his adversary and win on points.

BONN, West Germany, May 25--It was just 25 years ago this week that a group of Nazi officials broke ground for an auto factory on the banks of the Mitteland Canal near the village of Wolfsburg. Ten years later the factory was a war-devastated ruin.
HANOVER, Va.--Tourists hurrying south from Fredericksburg or Washington to Williamsburg often overlook the treats that are offered them in the historic Virginia county of Hanover.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., May 25--Choate School announced today the beginning of a significant phase in its 20-year, $10,000,000 expansion and improvement program that has been made possible by a $1,000,000 gift from Paul Mellon, son of the late Andrew W. Mellon, the industrialist.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., May 25--The Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs adopted a resolution today extending congratulations to Governor Rockefeller for his recent marriage.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 25 --The Princeton University library this week opened an exhibition of ancient hand-written manuscripts and antique printed volumes designed to illustrate the history of the Christian-Jewish Bible.
LONDON, May 26--The Russians have taken the initiative in reopening talks with the British Government on the possibility of a joint appeal to the feuding factions in Laos.

AUBURN, N.Y., May 26-- Three of the state's top Democrats appeared together publicly tonight in an effort to show a measure of harmony after the recent controversy over who is the party's state leader.

SOME of the old-time habitues of Ebbets Field may have stirred restlessly and perhaps wonderingly in front of their television sets a week ago while watching the New York Mets wage bitter battle with the Los Angeles Dodgers. There might even have been a bit of a double-take when Camilli stepped up to bat for the Dodgers. The name was familiar enough. So was the team. But, no, it couldn't be--and it wasn't.
Paul O'Dwyer, brother of former Mayor William O'Dwyer, was picked by the Democratic reform faction yesterday for the party's nomination to a Councilman-at-large seat in Manhattan.
The name of Ira Aldridge is not mentioned in the Encyclopaedia Britannica. Nor does it appear in Who's Who in the Theater or in the Dictionary of American Biography.

Rabbi Maurice N. Eisendrath, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, called on the lay and spiritual leaders of Reform Judaism yesterday to work with all groups of different faiths toward the attainment of world peace.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 26--Adlai E. Stevenson declared today that racial incidents at home were as damaging to the United States as Communist advances abroad.
GENEVA, May 26--The men of Switzerland voted today to allow the Federal Government to decide whether they should be armed with nuclear weapons to defend their country's neutrality and independence.
Two applications to establish national banks in midtown Manhattan have been filed with the Federal Government.
The Chain Belt Company of Milwaukee reported over the weekend that after-tax earnings in the first half of its fiscal year totaled $1,924,710, or 24 per cent more than in the 1962 period.

ROME, May 226--Pope John XXIII told the Polish nation in a recorded radio message today that as long as he lived he would be solicitous of their interests and would do what he could to defend their rights and improve their conditions.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- The Air Force has undertaken a series of studies of its future that could conceivably lead to dramatic new missions in space --or to a sharp reduction in its present roles and missions.

UNTIL last week, it seemed that the last word had cer tainly been written about wigs. Then, Bruce Reid, previously a market research consultant in such unrelated things as airplanes and dried foods, introduced a synthetic wig, which he has developed to be better than real hair.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP)--Despite a Congressional outery and a price setback Friday, a market chief predicted today that there would be no major reversal of the recent jump in sugar prices for perhaps a year or two.
Another city block has been added to the area being redeveloped under the stimulus of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.
Helen Hayes will auction many of the paintings, books, theater memorabilia and furniture that fill her 20-room home in Nyack, N.Y.

OTTAWA, May 26--Ottawa's major NATO event last week was not the highly advertised meeting of allied ministers which, for the most part, was merely an agreeable exercise in semantics. The major event occurred May 20 when Paul Martin, Canadian Minister, for Internal Affairs, met U.S. Ambassador Butterworth and started formal negotiations to close the atomic gap in North American defense.
DEFIANCE, Ohio, May 26 (AP)--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower called on youth today to have the courage to restore lost rights and to reform the Government.

Miss Alice Ginsburg, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Meyer Gins burg of Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to Gerald W. Padwe, son of Mrs. Ira S. French of New York and the late Walter W. Padwe. Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman performed.
Miss Ruth F. Woodsmall, an international leader in welfare work for women, died Saturday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived at Butler Hall, 400 West 119th Street.
WASHINGTON, May 26-- Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday.

When Bernard Peiffer left Paris late in 1954 to come to the United States, he was considered the finest jazz pianist in France. With his departure, this ranking shifted almost automatically to a young pianist from Algiers, Martial Solal.
What started out to be a great day for the Irish yesterday at Gaelic Park in the Bronx didn't end that way.

THE Eastern States regional tournament continues tonight at the Statler-Hilton Hotel with the first round of the team-of-four contest for the Curt Reisinger Trophy. Among the players in this famous annual event, which has been held annually for 33 years, will be many highranking stars.
Eight scientists, three of them Nobel laureates and most of them in academic positions, spoke out yesterday in support of the United States program for landing men on the moon.
METUCHEN, N.J., May 26-- Frederic A. Whitaker, a ceramics engineers, died today at his home, 451 Oak Ridge Road, in Clark. He was 77 years old.
The Democratic party is turnting to a new device, using President Kennedy's personal touch, to raise money for the expensive campaign that lies ahead next year.
LINDENHURST, L.I., May 26--The details of a $3,800,000 urban renewal project for this village have been announced after a 22-month study.
An artist who believes the creation of stained glass windows is very much like the creation of symphonies saw two new examples of his work dedicated yesterday.
The city's real estate interests and the Wagner administration are facing a major battle over the politically and emotionally explosive issue of rent control.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- The Administration has decided to ask Congress for broad and flexible authority to regulate interest payments to savings depositors in all types of financial institutions, including savings and loan associations.

BAYPORT, L. I., May 26-- Shortly before 8 A.M. today Harry Routledge of Sayville, an instrument technician, arrived at a Girl Scout camp here, loaded a dozen pieces of lumber onto a truck and drove off into the woods.
WALLINGFORD, Conn., May 26--Francis William Coker, Alfred Cowles Professor of Government Emeritus at Yale University, died last night at the Gaylord Sanitarium here. He was 84 years old.

The increasing complexity of labor contracts has prompted a local in the International Longshoremen's Association to set up a school to teach shop stewards their obligations and rights.

The Universal Terminal and Stevedoring Corporation, one of the largest stevedoring concerns in the country, has leased an entire floor at 1 Broadway through James Stewart of Helmsley-Spear, Inc., broker. Universal had been at 24 State Street for 33 years.
Development of a "baby airliner" for short hops on thin traffic routes is being urged as a means of curing the ills of local service airlines, all of which are subsidized.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- France's leading diplomats have ended a weekend in Washington in which they tried to persuade the Administration that there was no such thing as a united Europe and that there would not be for some time.
Ships in the Port of New York became safer places for longshoremen and ship repair men to work last year, the Bureau of Labor Standards of the Department of Labor reported last week.
WASHINGTON, May 26-- Harper Lee, author of the Pulitzer Prize novel "To Kill a Mockingbird," has received an award from the Washington chapter of the University of Alabama Alumni Association.
A uniform retirement system designed to give all future city employes improved benefits without waste was recommended in a report made public yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
The Broadway Congregational Church is trying out a new worship service designed to restore the "internal logic" of ritual and eliminate "incongruous" elements from the traditional order.

More than 30,000 marchers-- "the longest parade Harlem has ever seen," according to one official--trooped up Seventh Avenue from 112th to 142d Street yesterday. It was the annual parade of the 369th Veterans Association, and it included military corps, brass bands and pretty girls.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy will hold a series of meetings this week to explore new ways of advancing equal rights for Negroes.
The American West African Freight Conference is engaged in studies to determine whether most of its nine member lines should provide regular cargo ship service to and from Great Lakes ports.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 26-- President Joao Goulart has assumed personal command of the Government's campaign for a sweeping land-reform law, now stalled in Congress.
MOSCOW, May 26--Pravda called anew today for vigilance against Western intelligence agents.

Contracts awarded for new construction throughout the country in April amounted to $3,982,605,00, an increase of 3 per cent over the volume of $3,860,460,000 in April, 1962. Large gains in residential and nonresidential work more than offset a decline in contracts for public works and utilities construction.
Conference on "Nuclear Energy, Public Policy and the Law" under the auspices of New York University, Vanderbilt Hall, 40 Washington Square South, 10 A.M. and 2 P.M.

Something continues to be seriously wrong with the state of business forecasting. The sharp rise in economic activity comes as a shock to most economists, who had expected a decline during the first half of 1963.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 26--Emperor Haile Selassie bade good-by to his fellow heads of African states at Addis Ababa Airport today. Back at Africa Hall they had left behind what the Emperor had passionately wanted--their signatures affixed to a charter for continental unity.
Plans were completed yesterday for the funeral this morning of Orvil E. Dryfoos, president and publisher of The New York Times, who died early Saturday morning.
THE dance program presented by Aileen Passloff and company in the Music Hall of the Brooklyn Academy on Saturday night was divided into three parts.
PITTSBURGH, May 26-- Steel leaders are talking optimistically about market prospects.
ROME, May 26--The condition of Pope John XXIII grew worse today. The Pope suffered a recurrence of hemorrhaging, the condition for which he received blood transfusions last week.

When Supreme Court Justice Goldberg was our peripatetic Secretary of Labor, his skill at settling strikes was exercised so flamboyantly that the country almost forgot there was a Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. The national labor-management panel President Kennedy has just appointed to advise the service's director, William E. Simkin, should help restore that agency to the prestige it deserves as the Government's principal instrument for preserving labor peace.

INDIANAPOLIS, May. 26-- The final hour for qualification to the annual Memorial Day 500mile race here is always an exciting drama. Packed into these 60 minutes are joy and heartbreak and frustration. Altogether they provide an unmatchable thrill for thousands of speed lovers.

E. William Henry, the chairman-designate of the Federal Communications Commission, said yesterday that radio and television audiences were too often subjected to a "clamorous casbah of pitchmen."

Three Jewish religious leaders expressed differing viewpoints yesterday on the relationship between worship and study within a synagogue.

The American Civil Liberties Union expressed concern yesterday over Federal Communications Commission delays-- ranging from five months to four years--in acting on license applications of three often controversial radio stations. The group said such delays could deter freedom of speech.

The Federation of the Italian-American Democratic Organization of the State of New York held a spring concert at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. Three operatic and four popular singers entertained.

YONKERS, May 26--Some of Westchester's sleepier communities went through the shakedown ritual today that annually conditions them to screeching sirens, traffic snarls at unimportant intersections and thinly clad athletes.
WASHINGTON, May 26-- Western plans to extend longterm military aid to India have led to an open conflict between Indian and Pakistani diplomats here.

At 11:30 A.M. a month ago when the front of the house fell off, Mrs. Lillian Schultz was getting ready to wash the two living room windows. Before her eyes, one window slid down into the void, carrying the wall with it.

PARIS, May 26--A major onslaught, product by product, on the high duties that have long protected some American industries from foreign competition is shaping up as a result of the compromise reached this week in Geneva between the United States and the six-nation European Common Market.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 26--Juan Bosch, the Dominican Republic's first freely elected President in 38 years, is learning how difficult it can be to keep democracy alive in a country where many people do not seem sure they want it.

Investors with holdings representing sizable capital gains have another opportunity to evaluate "swap" funds, with the recent announcement by Vance, Sanders Co. of the establishment of the Exchange Fund of Boston. This will bring to about 12 the number in existence.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 26--Graham Hill of Eng land drove his steel-gray B.R.M. to victory by less than five seconds in the Grand Prix de Monaco today. Mrs. Vincent Astor of 778 Park Avenue has announced the engagement of her niece, Miss Emily Sophia Harding, a student at Barnard College, to Michael Zimmer. He is the son of Mrs. Heinrich Zimmer of New York and the late Professor Zimmer.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- The Soviet Cosmos satellites, launched in rapid succession during the last year, are probably designed more for military objectives than for the scientific purposes cited by the Soviet Union.
SMITHTOWN, L.I., May 26 --Three teen-agers were killed near here last night when a car struck them as they were walking along a road.

BRUSSELS, May 26--The rejection last week by United States wheat farmers of President Kennedy's control program has caused much chagrin ans some alarm in the European Economic Community. Edwin O'Connor, author of the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel "The Edge of Sadness," has completed his first play, "I Was Dancing."

The Wolverhampton Wanderers, who finished fifth in the First Division of the English Soccer League, had little trouble in whipping Schalke of West Germany yesterday. Paced by Jimmie Murray and Terry Wharton, the English won, 4--2, before 8,217 at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 26-- A revolution in cargo-handling is gradually taking place on the bustling docks of the San Francisco area and at other ports along the West Coast.

Three hundred unionized employes of 18 Jewish community centers yesterday approved an agreement reached late Sunday and returned to work.

When Roger Bannister achieved his historic break-through of the four-minute barrier nine years ago this month, he wore agony's mask. WASHINGTON, May 27--Gov. George C. Wallace's legal challenge to the posting of Federal troops in Alabama was swiftly rejected today by the Supreme Court. Nine days ago, on May 18, the Alabama Governor filed a motion for leave to bring an original lawsuit in the Supreme Court.

Ten years ago Edward Lamb had trouble renewing his television license for an Erie, Pa., station. His problem stemmed from a charge by the Federal Communications Commission that he had been a Communist. Five years later he was vindicated after witnesses recanted their charges.

WASHINGTON, May 27--Dr. James E. Allen Jr., New York State Education Commissioner, told Congress today that the size of the state's unsolved education problems demanded a substantial increase in Federal assistance.

DETROIT, May 27 (AP)-- The auto industry, which has broken many production and sales records this year, is expected to reach another milestone this week. For the first time, sales are expected to exceed 700,000 in each of two consecutive months.

Cardinal Spellman blessed and dedicated yesterday a new $800,000 community center at 137 East Second Street, which a named for him. The Junior League of Plainfield, N.J., will hold its third cotillion June 17 at the Plainfield Country Club. Mrs. Edward W. Snowdon and Mrs. George Treglown are co-chairmen of the event, at which 16 young women will make debuts.

A new ingredient has been injected into the stalled Geneva test-ban negotiations.
