Leonard Lyons, the newspaper columnist, won an empty victory yesterday in his court move to block the distribution and sale of the June 1 issue of The Saturday Evening Post.
WARSAW, May 28--Poland rejected tonight Western charges that her representative on the International Control Commission in Laos had been sabotaging efforts to end fighting in that troubled land.

Warwick Legler, Inc., has resigned its portion of the Revlon account. A Revlon agency for six years, Warwick Legler had handled between $1,500,000 and $2,000,000 in billings for such products as Clean and Clear, Silicare, Natural Wonder and Contempera.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)--The Senate passed today, 70 to 4, the $986,000,000 appropriation bill for the Interior Department after overriding a Republican effort to reduce it by $50,000,000.

A host of players from the world over will again be flown under the sponsorship of Col. Edward P.F. Eagan's Peopleto-People Sports Committee to the United States for the national amateur tennis championships this year.

WITH the summer travel season at hand, the American tourist will soon be indulging in her favorite foreign pastime--shopping. More than ever before, she will be tempted by a wide assortment of leather, suede, reptile skin accessories and fashions.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 28--The United States urged the Secretary General, U Thant, today to speed United Nations peace-keeping operations in Yemen to avert the possible spread of the civil war to other Middle Eastern areas.
What this country needs urgently is action "to spur investment by cutting taxes, controlling costs, and bolstering confidence," according to the Chase Manhattan Bank.
The Boston Fund, a balanced mutual fund, reported yesterday an increase in asset value a share, from $9.30, to $9.64 in the first fiscal quarter ended Apri1 30.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 28--Parliament completed action today on a bill to partition President Moise Tshombe's province of South Katanga.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI)--A Democratic Representative denounced, in House testimony released today, the United States' action in giving the Soviet Union maps showing undersea cables linking stations of the Distant Early Warning line.
The downtown small-businessmen opposed to the plans for the Manhattan civic center protested sharply yesterday and caused a delay in City Council action on the center.
Interest was revived yesterday in the City Council in a proposal for selling bonds to city residents and awarding cash prizes on the basis of monthly drawings.
WASHINGTON, May 28-- Congress opened 'hearings on civil defense today. The Administration defended itself against charges that the national shelter program was technically and morally unsound.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)--The Post Office Department said it would not have to make any drastic cutback in mail deliveries, after all, as a result of a compromise budget worked out for it by SenateHouse conferees today.
ATHENS, May 28--The funeral of a Leftist Deputy who was fatally injured by a motorcycle after political clashes in Salonika last week, was turned today into a massive show of anti-Government feeling.

The E.J. Korvette chain of department stores has leased four floors in the 23-story office building being erected at 1180 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), northeast corner of 46th Street, for new executive headquarters. The company's offices, now at 12 East 46th Street, will be moved next week.
WASHINGTON, May 21-- The Senate approved today a two-step increase in the national debt limit to $309,000,000,000, a record.

Bob Ussery, the leading jockey at Aqueduct, had a bit more trouble than usual yesterday "getting home," as he puts it. He was out of the money in the first race second in the next, out in the fourth and out in the fifth. But he was first in
The state has moved to block the promoters of a Black Angus cattle-breeding farm, accusing them of fraudulently obtaining $70,000 from New York State investors, each of whom purchased a cow.
The Transit Authority said yesterday it hoped to begin working on plans and specifications for a new East River sub way tunnel to Queens before the end of the summer:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 28--Federal Judge Seybourn H. Lynne refused today to order the total desegregation of the Birmingham public schools. He said the "good faith" of the city's school board on the desegregation issue had not yet been tested.
JACKSON, Miss., May 28-- Two Negroes and a white college professor were beaten and kicked today in a sit-in demonstration that marked the start of a drive by Negroes here against discrimination.

CHICAGO, May 28 (AP)--A United States district judge acted today to end a boycott by a loaders' union against a Canadian grain vessel that has been idle more than five weeks because of a labor dispute.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 28--Belgium is planning to pay $2,876,284 in overdue assessments for the United Nations Congo force if she can reach an agreement with the organization on claims and counter-claims arising out of the force's operations.
Twenty-two high-ranking members of the Police Department received promotions yesterday and 100 men ranked captain or higher were transferred.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 28-- Edward T. Breathitt Jr., a virtual political unknown a year ago, scored a smashing upset victory over former Gov. A.B. Chandler in today's primary election.
A well-informed friend of Greece remarked the other day, "The desperate needs of a decade and a half ago are gone. Greece isn't any longer an underdeveloped country--it is a developing country."

IT'S an odd sensation to en counter again a play like "A Month in the Country," with its fidelity to human nature and its compassionate understanding of the weaknesses, follies and feelings of men and women. How oldfashioned and how gratifying!
BILOXI, Miss., May 28 (AP) --A Federal judge ordered the University of Mississippi today to admit a Negro student to its law school for the summer semester beginning June 5.

WASHINGTON, May 28-- Although the United States is subject to heavy foreign criticism for its treatment of Negroes, officials here report, a new understanding overseas of this country's racial problem.

Crowds and tension were absent from the brokerage-house board rooms yesterday, a year after the big stock break on May 28, 1962. In fact, it seemed to be business as usual, with a healthy number of smiling and relaxed customers, watching the quotation boards.

Now that its election is over, Kenya faces a vital testing period of its ability to govern itself. No date has been set for independence, but the British have indicated that the success of the Africans in the coming months in running their own affairs will be the major determining factor.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 28--A mission of the International Monetary Fund completed a study today of Brazil's anti-inflation program and indications were that the program was in trouble.

MILWAUKEE, May 28 (UPI) --Sandy Koufax of the Los Angeles Dodgers scored his seventh victory and fourth shutout of the year tonight in defeating the Milwaukee Braves, 7-0. The triumph brought the Dodgers to within one game of the first-place Giants, who lost to the Reds.

BOSTON, Mays 28--The Yankees arrived tonight determined to learn what was keeping the Red Sox up. What this first meeting of the year with the Sox taught was most disturbing. The Yanks ran into a tea party for Boston.

HO-HO-KUS, N.J., May 28-- John R. Costanza, president of the Vitamerican Corporation of Little Falls, died yesterday of a heart attack at White Sulphur Springs, W.Va., where he was attending a Pharmaceutical Manufacturers' Association convention. His age was 62.
J. Donald Duncan, a, corporation and estate lawyer, died yesterday in his home at Mayfair House, Park Avenue and 65th Street. His age was 69.
The Citizens Union urged the city yesterday to drop two park projects to get funds for a quick start on the Breezy Point Park on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens.
MOSCOW, May 28--Mongolia has reached an agreement with the United Nations for the training of officials by Western specialists. The Asian nation previously sought aid only within the Communist bloc.

WASHINGTON, May 28-- Government investigators believe they know in general how botulism got into tuna, fish canned on the West Coast. The poisoned tuna killed two Detroit women, and reportedly has caused canned-tuna sales of some companies to fall 30 to 35 per cent.
Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson dismissed yesterday a $100000,000 fraud suit brought in 1960 against financier Allan P. Kirby and three other defendants by the Murchison brothers
Federated Department Stores, Inc., which includes Abraham Straus and Bloomingdale's in its retail chain set records in first-quarter sales and earnings.
WASHINGTON, May 28--The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People moved today to reduce the representation in Congress of states that deny Negroes the vote.
The chapel of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Miss Clare Fraser Fooshee to Robert Dean Childres.

The Gerber Products Company, whose baby foods business exceeds that of all similar companies combined, reported yesterday record net earnings of $10,630,668 for the fiscal year ended March 31, a gain of 14.9 per cent from the $9,249,035 net of the preceding fiscal year.

The United States Treasury is getting out of the currency business. This is the real significance of the repeal of the silver legislation still on the books. The one dollar bill, which by statute has been backed by silver, will be replaced gradually by Federal Reserve notes having a partial gold backing. When the job is completed the Treasury will issue only coin, the Federal Reserve will issue all paper money.
DEVON, Pa., May 28--Red Shoes scored a victory in the open jump class of the 67th annual Devon home show tonight.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 28 --Dr. Richard Alpert denied today that he had broken faith with Harvard University by involving an undergraduate in a psychological test using hallu cinogenic drugs.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 28-- The " heavyweight fourcylinder Offenhauser engine that has dominated the 500mile Indianapolis automobile race for so many years is facing its greatest challenge.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland May 28--Stavros G. Livanos, a leading Greek shipowner, died today in the Lausanne Cantona Hospital of a heart attack. His age was 73.

Eighty players, managers, directors and masseurs of four European soccer teams arrived at Idlewild Airport yesterday aboard a KLM chartered airliner from Amsterdam, the Netherlands. The group included Willie Waddell, the manager of Scotland's team. He was a little sad and a little puzzled.

Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American World Airways, said, yesterday that the proposed merger of Pan American and Trans World Airlines could move ahead as soon as a Federal Court here had set damages in a complex case involving T.W.A. and Howard R. Hughes.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 28-- More than 400 yellow-robed Buddhists today mourned nine Buddhists killed by Government troops. They vowed to hold four weeks of memorial services for the victims and 48-hour hunger strikes.

TOKYO, May 28--President Sukarno of Indonesia will meet in Tokyo this week with Malaya's Prime Minister, Prince Abdul Rahman, to discuss the sharp controversy over plans to form the new nation of Malaysia.

THE COIN OF CARTHAGE. By Bryher. 240, pages. Harcourt, Brace World. $4.50. THE strange and melancholy historical novels of the English waiter who calls hersef Bryher are less likely to be con cerned with historical personages and events than they are with the essence of human experience.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced plans yesterday to send an economic survey mission to the Territory of Papua and New Guinea.

Bernard Kaufman, New York realty investor, has contracted to buy an 85-year net leasehold on four taxpayer buildings occupying a plot 155 by 285 feet at 47 to 61 South Main Street and 34 East Sunrise Highway in Freeport, L.I.W.T. Grant is the major tenant with a department store that occupies a new building that was constructed at a cost of $500,000.
Blanchon the whale wore white, and Olaf the walrus charcoal gray, for the "Whale of a Party" last night at the New York Aquarium in Coney Island.
LONDON, May 28--The Government presented today a $280,000,000 housing program that it said would eliminate the housing shortage and clear Britain of slums within 10 years.

WASHINGTON, May 28-- David Sarnoff, board chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, has warned that a recent "technological breakthrough" in undersea cables could postpone by several years the economic need for a communications satellite system.
SEATTLE, May 28 (AP)-- Washington State's 1957 redistricting law was declared unconstitutional today by a panel of three Federal judges, who called it "invidiously discriminatory."

Wall Streeters could afford to smile yesterday when they looked back on "Blue Monday" --May 28, 1962--that shattering day when American Telephone dropped 11 points to 100 5/8 and International Business Machines plunged 37 points to 361.

LYNBROOK, L.I., May 28-- Nassau County District Court Judge Douglas F. Young said last night that increased activity by youth gangs in the county made it imperative that a juvenile aid bureau be established in the Police Department as soon as possible.
Dana Adams Schmidt, New York Times correspondent in the Middle East, received the highest honor of the Overseas Press Club of America at its annual awards dinner last night in the Americana hotel.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI--The United States appeared for a while today to be on the brink of a "tuna war," complete with an improvised blockade.

TECHNICALLY speaking, it no longer comes under the category of news that "The American Dream" and "The Zoo Story" by Edward Albee are back in town. According to the record keepers, this is the third revival for "The American Dream" since its original production in 1961 and the fourth revival for

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., May 28--R. Parker Kuhn, a retired director and member of the exexutive committee of the First Boston Corporation, investments bankers of 20 Exchange Place in New York, died today at his home. His age was 69.

Stock prices edged up in quiet trading yesterday. The slow, lackluster performance was in sharp contrast to activity one year earlier--May 28, 1962-- when prices broke sharply in one of the heaviest trading sessions on record.

Seven men, including five purported henchmen of the Brooklyn Gallo mob, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in connection with the hijacking of $100,000 worth of Japanese transistor radios.

The British pound moved up at the opening of business on the New York foreign exchange market yesterday and was stationary for the rest of the day. The spot pound closed at $2.8007 offered, compared with $2.8003 Monday. The spread on sterling futures was unchanged.
WASHINGTON, May 28-- President Kennedy will let the Navy operate the nuclear ship Savannah if her labor problems cannot be solved, Secretary of Commerce. Luther H. Hodges said today.
PORTSMOUTH, N.H., May 28 (AP)--The Navy narrowed the area of search for the Thresher today after recovering 15 small boxes of metal rings from the ocean floor.

WASHINGTON, May 28-- The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to reduce the capital-gains tax on the profits from the sale of stocks, real estate and other assets that have been held by the owner for at least three years.
STOCKHOLM, May 28-- More people are starving to death today than at any other time in history, Dr. Sture C. Linner, former head of United Nations operations in the Congo, said in a speech here today.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn, May 28 --The Tennessee Valley Authority and distributors of T.V.A. electricity will pay a record of $20,200,000 to states, counties and Cities during the 1963 fiscal year in taxes and in lieu of taxes.
WASHINGTON, May 28-- The United States has begun a last-minute campaign to dissuade Indonesia from imposing severe economic restrictions on three foreign oil corporations.

Today, Tuesday, the Holy Father listened to mass celebrated in the study adjoininghis bedroom, and received holy communion as is done whenever a Pope is prevented from celebrating the divine sacrifice.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) --Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, told the senate today that two groups given most benefits in the past under this country's Sugar Quota Act, were holding back supplies while prices soared.

Twenty years after rent control was established and ten years after the Federal Government abandoned jurisdiction over it, New York remains the only large city in the nation to remain price-fixed on housing. About 5,000,000 of this city's 7,800,000 people are still living under the paternalistic shelter of rent control.
Operatic versions of two short plays by Eugene Ionesco, one of the playwrights who contribute to the so-called "theater of the absurd," were presented at Judson Hall last night.

ROME, Wednesday, May 29--The Vatican virtually acknowledged yesterday that Pope John XXIII has cancer. Several sources said definitely that this is the malady that afflicts the 81-year-old Pontiff. His condition was said to be "very grave" and he was not expected to live much longer.

A jury in Federal District Court received evidence yesterday on the scale of the alleged fraudulent operations of Gerardo A. (Jerry) Re and his son Gerard F., on the American Stock Exchange in 1956-57, as well as some detail on their methods.

A tall, young left-hander named Dick Ellsworth, who owns the best earned-run average in the majors, spoiled the opening of a long home stand for the Mets last night. With last-inning help from Lindy McDaniel, he pitched the Chicago Cubs to a 5-2 victory.
GREENWICH, Conn., May 28 --The no-welcome mat will be out again this year for out-oftown visitors to many of Fairfield County's municipal beaches.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 28--A total of 14 Benzedrine tablets were found in two of the trailer-trucks involved in Monday's accident on the New Jersey Turnpike that killed six persons, it was disclosed today.
Jim Farley turns 75 years old tomorrow and the political craftsman of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal era is as rugged and genial as ever. Also, he is ready for more political activity.
The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company will begin construction late this year on an $80,000,000 cold reduced sheet mill at its Indiana Harbor Works near Chicago, the concern said yesterday.
MOSCOW, May 28--The Soviet Union announced today the completion of a major molybdenum mine, considerably strengthening its output of strategic metal for nuclear and missile technology.

The Federal Maritime Commission will open an investigation to determine whether the decline in exports of United States steel and iron products is due to higher labor costs or to lower ocean shipping rates for imports of foreign steel materials.

Bob Charles, a left-handed golfer from New Zealand playing out of Sarasota, Fla., shot a spectacular 65, 67--132 at Memphis yesterday and led the nation's golfers in the second day of preliminary qualifying tests for the United States Open championship.
Thousands of veterans will parade tomorrow as Americans everywhere take part in Memorial Day exercises honoring the dead of all of this nation's wars.
WASHINGTON, May 28-- President Kennedy said today that the American people understood the urgent need to continue foreign aid as "a vital arm of American foreign policy."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 28 --G. Darlington Richards of 106 Brambach Road, who retired 10 years ago as organist and choirmaster of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church on Madison Avenue at 71st Street in New York, died yesterday at Law rence Hospital in Bronxville. His age was 86.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 28-- The rapid and continuing growth of harness racing seldom, has been so strongly emphasized as it was by the situation at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. There they were, only 24 hours away from tomorrow night's first stakes event of the meeting, the $85,663.50 Realization Purse for 4-year-old trotters, and only one of the eight listed drivers was on the grounds.

WASHINGTON, May 28--The Senate accepted today House amendments to a measure providing equal pay for women. The bill was then sent to the White House. President Kennedy had supported the measure, so his approval was assured.
ANSONIA, Conn., May 28 (AP)--Fernley H. Banbury, an inventor and a retired executive of the Farrel Corporation of Ansonia, died Sunday in Torquay, England. He was 81 years old.

The Bankers Trust Company moved swiftly yesterday to take advantage of what it saw as a favorable development in the Federal Reserve Board's merger policy and to avert a possible legal fight with the board. It withdrew an application to the State, Banking Department for approval of the acquisition of the First National Bank of Farmingdale. L.I., by a subsidiary ...

A 79-year-old woman who has been discovering trees, plants and mountains for more than three decades drove up from her home outside Philadelphia yesterday to attend the opening of an exhibition of her work at the New York Botanical Garden.
A record $220,600,000 school building program for 1964-65 was proposed yesterday by Dr. Calvin E. Gross, the Superintendent of Schools.
Francois Paul Scaglia, a 35year-old French nightclub owner, was found guilty in the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday of possessing $3,500,000 worth of heroin.

SYRACUSE, May 28--Stated Controller Arthur Levitt said today that Governor Rockefeller's administration had run up a deficit of $38,300,000 in fiscal 1962-63 instead of the $2,700,000 surplus it had reported.

KANSAS CITY, May 28 (AP) --A three-run homer by Al Smith and strong pitching by Robin Roberts carried the Baltimore Orioles to their ninth straight triumph tonight, a 4-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.

Jacques Tiffean for Tiffeau Busch: The designs at this house get younger and snappier every year. They are contemporary in feeling with just enough pepper to make it fun to be young. Significant points:
Brooklyn detectives yesterday broke up what they described as a revolver renting service whose manager tutored youths in robbery.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 28-- The head of Yemen's ousted royalist Government was reported today to have ordered resumption of offensive operations against the republican regime.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, bidding alone, purchased yesterday $30,520,760, par value, of New York City bonds, due next year, held, by the city's pension funds. The bank bid $30,977,155, plus accrued interest for the bonds.

THE thousands of recreational shooters in the met ropolitan New York area, as well as in the nearby sections of New Jersey, Connecticut and Massachusetts, now have their wishes fulfilled. A center covering every aspect of shooting is open to the public at Clinton Corners, N.Y., just off the Taconic State Parkway.

"Hedda, Gabler," which stars Ingrid Bergman, has finally been scheduled for television by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Dec. 9 from 9:30 to 11 P.M. The network had withheld the Ibsen drama for lack of a sponsor; one has not yet been found.

Mr. and Mrs. William Durant Campbell of 1 Beekman Place and Fishers Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margot Beatrice Campbell, to Jeremiah Milbank Bogert. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. H. Lawrence Bogert Jr. of 791 Park Avenue and Fishers Island. A December wedding is planned.
A crew from the Humble Oil and Refining Company's tanker Esso Baltimore won its second consecutive victory in the International Seaman's Lifeboat Race in The Narrows yesterday.

The Pink and White Ball will be held at the Bath and Tennis Club in Westhampton Beach, L.I., on June 22. Mrs. Howeth Townsend Ford is chairman for the annual dinner dance and a member of the board of trustees of Cancer Care, Inc., of the National Cancer Foundation, beneficiary of the event.
A Buddhist priest gonged a temple bell and chanted a sutra yesterday to dedicate a Japanese "symbol of paradise" in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, May 28--J. Lindsay Almond Jr., former Governor of Virginia, was final ly granted a hearing today by the Southern Senators he had affronted.
GARY, Ind., May 28--A strike by 1,400 Gary teachers that began this morning ended tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 28--President Kennedy will be 46 tomorrow, which is about the time when "Happy Birthday" begins to sound slightly off-key.

PARIS, May 28--Soviet doubt about the United States' willingness to use atomic forces to defend Western Europe is one of the basic reasons for France's desire for her own atomic deterrent, according to Alain Peyrefitte, French Minister of Information.
The tight situation in the money market here resulted in a "quiet deterioration" in prices of Treasury issues yesterday.

Cotton futures were 25 cents a bale up to 10 cents down yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, Trading was quiet. Commission Houses were small sellers. Trading was marked by purchases of October against sales of May at 75cent price differences.

HELSINKI, Finland, Wednesday, May 29--President Urho K. Kekltonen has made what amounts to a new appeal for a nuclear-free zone in Scandinavia by "mutual undertakings" among Finland, Sweden, Norway and Denmark.

TWO exhibitions--one major, the other minor--open to day at the Whitney Museum of American Art. The major comprises recent acquisitions, works of art added to the permanent collection since last May. The

Sugar futures continued to plummet yesterday to lead most New York commodities down. In other dealings here, copper, wool tops, lead, zinc, hides, rubber, and cocoa declined; potatoes, coffee and cottonseed oil advanced, and wool uncombed) was irregular.
OTTAWA, May 28--Racial tension among United States personnel at the Ernest Harmon Strategic Air Command base near Stephenville, Nfld., was brought to the notice of the Canadian Parliament today.

Space agency technicians believe they have pinpointed the electrical failures that caused Maj. L. Cordon Cooper Jr. to make a manual instead of an automatic descent from orbit at the end of his 34-hour space flight May 16.
CHICAGO, May 28 (UPI)-- Grain futures rallied to score firm to strong gains today on the Board of Trade.

READING, Pa., May 28 (AP) Two boys from Phillipsburg N.J., who the police said were planning several holdups committed suicide tonight by taking poison just before officers closed in on them, the state police reported.
Wes Ellis and Al Feminelli yesterday shared the lead in the local qualifying trials of the metropolitan district for the United States Open golf championship.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)--The Senate adopted a resolution today authorizing Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy to testify in the trial of Anthony Provenzano, president of a Teamsters Union local in Newark.
Mayor Wagner ordered all city departments and agencies yesterday to step up their attack on racial discrimination.
LONDON, May 29--The Government announces today that it wad prepared to help the shipbuilding industry by offering generous credit terms to British shipowners placing new orders.
A movement toward reduced savings and loan association dividend rates has gained momentum in the last few days, even reaching into the metropolitan New York area.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) --Cuba charged today that a United States Navy plane fired Sunday on a Soviet-Cuban crew drilling for oil off the island's north coast. Secretary of State Dean Rusk said the accusation was "simply not true."
WASHINGTON, May 29-- The Administration predicted today that the price of sugar soon will return to "normal."
A policeman was shot and killed on an East Harlem tenement roof yesterday and a hunt for the slayer was still under way last night.
BERLIN, May 29 (UPI)-- East German Communists said today that proposals to hold the 1968 Olympic Games in Berlin were "unbelievable."

WARSAW, May 29--President Tito's recent call for worldwide support of Premier Khrushchev's position in the Soviet-Chinese Communist ideological feud points up Eastern Europe's dual position on the subject.

Large sales gains and further plans for diversification and expansion by Brother Industries, Ltd., of Nagoya, Japan, were reported yesterday by Max Hugel, president of the affiliate Brother International Corporation.
LOS ANGELES, May 29-- The 15-member Los Angeles City Council, which had no Negro members up to this year, will have three as a result of Tuesday's municipal election.
Charles Alonzo Mason, a former insurance man and towing executive on the New York waterfront, died Tuesday in Hampton, N.H. He was 77 years old.
An extensive program to integrate the arts into school curriculums throughout the state is being planned by the State Education Department.
Stock prices advanced yesterday on trading volume that brokers termed surprisingly heavy for the day before a holiday. Autos, steels and many long-neglected "glamour" stocks led the rise.
Mrs. Harriet Lies Kreisler, widow of Fritz Kreisler, the violinist, died yesterday in her home at 435 East 52d Street. She was 93 years old.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 29 (AP)--A resolution endorsing Gov. George C. Wallace's promised defiance of a court order to integrate the University of Alabama passed the State Senate today with an appeal to the people to prevent mob violence.

ONCE upon a time there was a pitcher on the St. Louis Browns named Bobo Holloman. He talked as big as Bobo Newsom and was given the same nickname that Newsom wore with such distinction. But he couldn't pitch as big. Newsom, the great showboat, was a tremendous pitcher. Holloman was a figment of his own imagination.
HARTFORD, May 29--Gov. John N. Dempsey signed today two bills that will abolish the traditional system of distributing state insurance commissions as political patronage.

The Breezy Point Cooperative, Inc., charged yesterday that the establishment of a four-and-a-half-mile oceanfront park at Breezy Point in Queens would "set back New York City's park development plans for at least 50 years."

JERSEY CITY, May 29-- O. Roy Chalk, the new chairman of International Railways of Central America, said today he planned to order "$7,000,000 worth of new diesel equipment" within two weeks in an effort to revitalize the company's railroad.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders of listed companies.
LONDON, May 29--The Soviet Union joined Britain today in appealing to the warring factions in Laos to bring about "peace, concord and strict neutrality" in the Asian kingdom.
ROME, May 29--The condition of Pope John XXIII was reported today to be much improved, although his illness continued to be "very grave."
A West Side civil rights group seeking to promote integration expressed concern yesterday over what it called the increased gravity of the racial situation here.

AUBERGINES, as the English and the French call eggplant, are probably one of the showiest of vegetables because of their glossy purple skins and impressive size. Currently, they are one of the outstanding offerings at vegetable markets.

The Paul Winter Sextet, a jazz group that has toured Latin America for the State Department and played at the White House at the invitation of Mrs. John F. Kennedy, added another diplomatic sponsor to its list yesterday when it gave an early evening concert under the auspices of the United Nations Jazz Society.
TOKYO, May 29--President Sukarno of Indonesia and United States officials met here today to begin a round of talks on "oil politics" that may deeply affect relations between their countries.
The ninety-seventh Memorial Day Regatta of the New York Rowing Association will be held today with the largest entry in years.

MOSCOW, May 29--The Soviet Government disclosed tonight that Chief Marshal of Artillery Sergei S. Varentsov had been demoted because of his association with Oleg V. Penkovsky, the Soviet official who was executed as a spy for the West.

David Kidd for Arthur Jablow: This coat and suit house has a country look that is under the influence of the Scottish Highlands. Its important suits come in four parts--vest, blouse, skirt and jacket--and only the skirt and jacket are of the same tweed. Blouses generally are crepe. Vests are suede, corduroy, kidskin or zebra-printed calf skin. The extra added attraction in the coat department is one with its own Inverness cape. Other points:
MSL Industries, Inc., has announced plans to acquire George K. Garrett Company, Inc., of Philadelphia, maker of fasteners and stampings, for an undisclosed cash sum.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 29 (AP)--Negroes and white sat down to lunch together today in public dining rooms of five Charlotte hotels and motels for the first time.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 29--The United Nations financial crisis took a slight turn for the better today.
OTTAWA, May 29--Defense Minister Paul Hellyer confirmed today that the United States wanted to deploy more jet interceptor squadrons in Canada.

A baker's dozen of thoroughbred horses, with total earnings of more than $2,500,000 among them, are listed for the Metropolitan Handicap at Aqueduct today. If all thirteen go, the value will be the greatest of all 70 runnings of the famous one-mile handicap.

Dick Weber, who almost rolled a perfect game in the final, won the men's title in the fifth annual Ruppert-Brunswick bowling Tournament of Champions at Madison Square Garden last night.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 29-- Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike, the only woman Prime Minister in the world, reshuffled her Cabinet today.

PARIS, May 29--Economic indicators of the countries of Western Europe are flashing increasingly clear signals that expansion and growth will continue this year at a rate close to that of recent years.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 29-- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the Negro integration leader, arrived here this afternoon and got the kind of reception he usually does not find south of the Mason-Dixon line.
ROME, May 29--Aldo Moro, Premier-designate, promised today that he would try to form a government on a platform "clearly opposed to the Communist party."
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 29 (AP)--The University of Kentucky today became the first school in the Southeastern Conference to open its athletic program to all races.

WASHINGTON, May 29-- President Kennedy conceded today, in the midst of a rigorous day in his office, that this was his 46th birthday. While he hesitated before saying so, Mr. Kennedy did not seem to resent passing another milestone. He jokingly told a
The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company improved its earnings in its second fiscal quarter, ended April 30, over those of a year ago, the report disclosed yesterday.
A 65-year-old landlord whose case had been postponed three times was tried yesterday without a lawyer and fined $200 for failing to provide adequate heat in an East Side tenement.
An investment banking group headed by the First National City Bank was awarded yesterday $25,000,000 of Houston, Tex., improvement bonds, due from 1964 to 1983.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 29--Dr. Hugh Grant Rowell of 483 Munroe Avenue, a retired public-health administrator at Columbia University and a former director of the Rockefeller-financed Sleepy Hollow Restorations, died today in Phelps Memorial Hospital. He was 70 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 29--If the President recommends, Congress accepts and the Supreme Court validates the proposal now before President Kennedy--a legislative ban on customer discrimination by the private owners of public accommodation facilities--the long-existing judicial, executive and legislative concept of private property rights will not be the only casualty.
DETROIT, May 29 (AP)-- Automotive News said today that automobile production for May would total 715,007 units, second highest May total in automotive history. The record of 724,892 was set in 1955.

Whether by chance or design, the second of the two orchestral concerts given by the Composers Forum at Columbia University's McMillin Theater turned out to be afar more conservative affair than the first. The music last night
Borough President Albert V. Maniscalco of Richmond said yesterday he would put before Mayor Wagner an issue of Staten Island piers.

EARLY in July, in Los Angeles, eight interna tional grand masters will participate in the first Piatigorsky Cup Tournament. The field in this double-round round-robin comprises Pal Benko and Samuel Reshevsky of the United States, Miguel Najdorf and Oscar Panno of Argentina, Fridrick Olafsson of Iceland and Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia.

EPSOM, England, May 29-- Relko, a classically-trained French colt and the 5-to-1 favorite, went ahead in the last two furlongs at Epsom Downs today and gave France her sixth post-war victory in the English Derby.

WASHINGTON, May 29-- The Federal Reserve Board reported today the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended May 22:

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -The Federal Communications Commission today ordered that the license of radio station KWK in St. Louis be revoked for misconduct in the operation of two treasure-hunt contests.

With a pause that refreshed him even more than the drink he loves to sell, James A. Farley, the Coca-Cola executive and former Postmaster General, celebrated his 75th birthday yesterday--and refused to throw in the towel. He couldn't. It was

CHERRY HILL, N.J., May 29 (AP)--Candy Spots, beaten only in the Kentucky Derby, is expected to go off as the 3-to-5 favorite tomorrow in the Jersey Derby at Garden State Park. He will seek his fifth victory in nine $100,000plus races.
JERUSALEM, May 29--Three faces in a newspaper cartoon seem to tell more of Israel's ambivalent attitude toward contemporary Germany than all that has been said and done recently in the public forum.
New York City's record budget of more than $3,000,000,000 was put into an apparent balance last night when Mayor Wagner signed new tax proposals expected to raise $98,000,000.
LARCHMONT, N.Y. May 29 --James Picker, founder and board chairman of the Picker X-Ray Corporation of White Plains, died of a heart attack today at his home. He was 80 years old.
TODAY'S fare in the Eastern States Championships tournament, being played at the Statler-Hilton Hotel, is a two-session contest for mixed teams of four at 1 and 7 P.M.

Military bands, old soldiers marching and a wreath-laying at Eternal Light in Madison Square Park yesterday began the city's observance of today's national holiday honoring the war dead--Memorial Day.
WASHINGTON, May 29-- The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to impose sharp restrictions on tax benefits available to corporation executives through stockoption plans.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 29 (AP) --The state's highest court refused today to hear an appeal against the $26,000,000 annual increase in rates imposed by the Consolidated Edison Company in New York City in 1961 and 1962
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 29--Some 300 young Negroes demonstrated this afternoon in front of two Tallahassee theaters while policemen stood by to prevent disorder.
A TELEVISION experience that seared the conscience of the white set owner was offered over Channel 13 in an unforgettable halfhour interview with James Baldwin, the author.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29-- With miles of highways surrounding Indianapolis Speedway transformed today into huge overnight parking areas, the police called on their overnight guests to avoid setting fires by sidewalk cook-outs.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI)--Trucking industry representatives told Senators yesterday that legislation to repeal minimum-rate control powers of the Interstate Commerce Commission could injure the national interest.

A one-time roving horse trainer has received special-- and unprecedented--treatment from brokers trading for his account off the floor of the American Stock Exchange, it was testified yesterday in Federal District Court.
JACKSON, Miss., May 29-- Nineteen integrationists were arrested here today in a series of demonstrations in front of downtown stores.

WASHINGTON, May 29-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the Soviet Union had shown no interest in an agreement to ban nuclear testing in any form that might be acceptable to the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 29-- The Administration rallied support for its shelter program today in testimony before a House Armed Services subcommittee.

With every minute that ticks away, the proposed Breezy Point beachfront park on the Rockaway Peninsula will cost the city more money for its purchase. The issue ought to be carried to a decision. Soon it will be a year since the matter was first forcefully brought to public and official attention (by the Regional Plan Association) as a great opportunity. Offering the

Young people awaiting court action are held in detention in various institutions in this city, mainly at Youth House. This is a private organization, financed by the city and the state, which runs four centers for girls under age 18 and boys under age 16 in the Bronx and on Welfare Island.
WASHINGTON, May 29-- Most organization Democrats bade dry-eyed good-bys today to A.B. (Happy) Chandler.
WASHINGTON, May 29-- Cardinal Spellman criticized President Kennedy's program of aid to education today for its failure to provide assistance to private schools.
Sugar futures dropped yesterday, for the fifth successive decline in as many trading days on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
FOR the second offering in its current musical series, the City Center last night brought back "Pal Joey," that wicked, wicked entertainment that startled the town late in 1940.
WASHINGTON, May 29-- The Federal Communications Commission voted today to outlaw the device by which television networks pre-empt air time on their affiliated stations.

The market for fixed-interest securities was mixed yesterday. Treasury bills were unchanged, to up a basis point despite reports of new buying by the Federal Reserve. Coupon issues were unchanged to down 4-32, with the markdowns heaviest in the intermediate area.
The state's road-building program has been slashed by more than $100,000,000, with indications that further cuts will be made.
An official of the nation's largest general merchandising company said yesterday that "the retailer was the focal point in the development" of the economy from July, 1962, to March, 1963.
Sometimes money comes from unusual sources--the type that might be classed as conservative and basking in obscurity.

The Chemstrand Company, a division of the Monsanto Chemical Company, has increased its space in the Empire State Building by leasing an additional half floor. The company, which is expanding its New York headquarters and marketing offices, now occupies the entire 16th and 17th floors of the skyscraper as a result of the new lease. Chemstrand is a leading maker of chemical textile fibers.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) --The Federal Communications Commission paved the way today for an increase in rates on leased telegraph lines and a cut in rates on leased telephone lines to go into effect Aug. 1. Press customers were not included.

WASHINGTON, May 29--The first "billiard lounges" are just beginning to crop out of the landscape, but there is good reason to expect that they will soon cover the country. It is another troubling example of the American weakness for leaping before we look.
BERLIN, May 29 (AP)--The leadership of the Protestant Church in East Germany has directed its subordinates to stand up to abuses of the Communist regime and resist efforts to restrict church affairs.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 29--The Nauruan people, now occupying a tiny Pacific island, appeared today to have found a new home to preserve the population's distinct identity--Curtis Island just off Australia.
THE joyful troublemaker is the despair of meanly harassed minds. He questions pettifogging tyranny. He en hances freedom. He enriches humanism with humor. And as John Haase suggests in his
INDIANAPOLIS, May 29-- A crowd of more than 200,000 is expected here tomorrow for the 47th running of the 500mile automobile race.

Six legitimate theaters in five Southern states have eliminated segregation since the Actors Equity Association ruled last year that members should shun out-of-town playhouses following that practice.
A decline of 1,879,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
A Sanitation foreman found $6,000 worth of mungo yesterday.
A lawyer refused to sign a waiver of immunity yesterday before the grand jury investigating corruption in the State Liquor Authority.
Indictments that have been outstanding fifteen years against eight convicted top Communist party leaders were dropped yesterday by the Government with permission of the court.
Computer equipment that may be used in the future to monitor a patient's heart continuously in periods of stress, such as during an operation or after a heart attack, was described here yesterday.
ATLANTA, May 29--Mayor Ivan Allen Jr. announced today that swimming pools would be opened June 12 on a desegregated basis.

HOLLYWOOD, May 29-- James Stewart, probably the only Princeton alumnus whose manner suggests that he major in whittling, may soon be able to talk a six-syllable minute, his verbal equivalent of the four-minute mile.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)--The Air Force presented pilot-astronaut wings today to Maj. L. Gordon Cooper Jr. for his 22-orbit flight around the earth.

American tramp-ship operators who feel they have long been the stepchildren of maritime policy are looking to the future with "guarded optimism," according to a report issued by the American Tramp shipowners Association.

The Cities Service Company, a major oil company, has signed a consent decree that apparently cleared the way for the company to acquire the Tennessee Corporation, a large producer of industrial and agricultural chemicals.
PHILADELPHIA, May 29-- A Negro leader warned here today that mass demonstrations against labor discrimination in municipal projects would be extended across the nation.
VIENNA, May 29--The emergence of a new chemical industry for the transmutation of familiar raw materials by radiation was predicted this week at a scientific conference at Salzburg, Austria.
PHILADELPHIA, May 29-- Louis I. Kahn, professor of architecture at the University of Pennsylvania, stressed today the difference between a way of life and a way of living.

The Sukarno Government of Indonesia seems inexorably addicted to one nationalistic excess after another. The recent acquisition of West Irian through the irresponsible and unnecessary use of military action has been followed by a quite unjustifiable campaign against the formation of the independent new state of Malaysia.

A proposal to persuade law schools throughout the country to provide graduate courses for training judges was approved yesterday by the Advisory Council of Judges, a branch of the National Council on Crime and Delinquency.
The Senate Commerce Committee will maintain permanent surveillance of foreign preference plans and discriminatory rules and charges that operate at the expense of American-flag shipping.
WASHINGTON, May 29--The agreement providing for withdrawal of Egyptian troops from Yemen should take full effect in "the very next few days," Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today.

DEVON, Pa., May 29--Placing one-two in the Professional Horsemen's Association event at the Devon Horse Show tonight, Uncle Max and Skryne moved into a tie for the lead in the open jumper championship scoring.

A strong performance by British Government bonds gave an advancing tone to the London stock market yesterday. Heavy investor demand pushed the bonds sharply upward, with some registering gains of as much as 10 shillings.

"TRAINING a dog is easy, the real job is training the handler," said Milo Pearsall, often called "Mr. Obedience," by dog pedagogues. "More than 90 percent of the problems are created by the trainer and not the dog."
IN the back of the mind of every hunter and animal lover is the never dimming goal of a trip to Africa and the world of storied game and bird life. Sometimes that goal is realized.

WASHINGTON, May 29-- The House of Representatives voted today to terminate the program that has brought hundreds of thousands of Mexican farm workers into the United States seasonally. The vote was 174 to 158.

ALBANY, May 29 (AP)-- Governor Rockefeller and his wife will open a busy round of official, political and social activity when they return to public life on Monday after a month-long honeymoon and va cation.

MOSCOW, May 29--Soviet officials said today that the United States had submitted two feature entries for the third film festival here, opening July 7. A spokesman for the organizing committee identified them as "The Great Escape" and "West Side Story."
WASHINGTON, May 29-- President Kennedy urged nine Democratic Governors today to take the lead in assuring equal opportunities to all citizens of their states regardless of race.
Lord Taylor and De Pinna are the latest New York stores to discover that oil paintings have a marketable value and they have added them to their traditional lines of merchandise.
Public and judicial apathy about fatal highway accidents was condemned yesterday by Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes.

ALBANY, May 29--State Controller Arthur Levitt uses the right figures but he is wrong in conculding that the state ran up a $38,300,000 deficit in the l962-63 fiscal year, state budget division officials said today.
Signs of "creeping capitalism" are showing themselves in the Soviet Union's efforts to increase exports to non-Communist countries.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 29-- Sprite Rodney, making her own pace for most of the mile-anda-sixteenth journey through fog and over slop, trotted to an easy victory tonight in the Realization Purse at Roosevelt Raceway.

FONTANA, Calif., May 29-- The Kaiser Steel Carporation and 4,100 workers at its steel mill here split $1,196,000 today --the second month's benefits under an ingenious new plan for sharing savings in manufacturing costs.

Despite the financial crisis facing the United Nations because of previous peace-keeping operations, Secretary General Thant is organizing another peace mission, this time to Yemen. Its purpose would be to supervise the disengagement of Egypt and Saudi Arabia from a still-simmering civil war in Yemen in order to avert a possible spread of hostilities in the volatile Middle East.

ALBANY, May 29--State Controller Arthur Levitt uses the right figures but he is wrong in conculding that the state ran up a $38,300,000 deficit in the l962-63 fiscal year, state budget division officials said today.
Signs of "creeping capitalism" are showing themselves in the Soviet Union's efforts to increase exports to non-Communist countries.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 29-- Sprite Rodney, making her own pace for most of the mile-anda-sixteenth journey through fog and over slop, trotted to an easy victory tonight in the Realization Purse at Roosevelt Raceway.

FONTANA, Calif., May 29-- The Kaiser Steel Carporation and 4,100 workers at its steel mill here split $1,196,000 today --the second month's benefits under an ingenious new plan for sharing savings in manufacturing costs.

Despite the financial crisis facing the United Nations because of previous peace-keeping operations, Secretary General Thant is organizing another peace mission, this time to Yemen. Its purpose would be to supervise the disengagement of Egypt and Saudi Arabia from a still-simmering civil war in Yemen in order to avert a possible spread of hostilities in the volatile Middle East.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)--Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said today that the United States would make no tariff agreements with countries of the European Economic Community unless American farm products were granted fair access to the Common Market.
MOSCOW, May 29--The countries of the Soviet bloc are manifesting signs of greater independence in their relations with the Kremlin.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 29 --A Federal judge ruled today that the Justice Department did not have the right to sue for desegregation of two Alabama school systems.
WASHINGTON, May 29-- Chaperoned by a Treasury lawyer, a new and higher ceiling on the national debt was sped to final enactment today, not a minute too soon.
A small upstate manufacturer has developed a simple milk homogenizer that may dry up the vast surplus of American dairy products in Government storehouses.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)--Secretary of State Dean Rusk telephoned the Foreign Minister of Ecuador today and asked for the immediate release of two United States tuna boats held by Ecuadoran naval vessels. Mr. Rusk offered to send officials to Quito to negotiate a settlement.

EAST GREENBUSH, N.Y., May 29 (UPI)--The East Greenbush Central School District in Rensselaer County has removed from its library shelves, at least for the time being, copies of a children's book, "Wicked John and the Devil," by Richard Chase.
Will Met fans continue to support a loser? The answer may be provided today when the last-place New Yorkers meet the Chicago Cubs in two games at the Polo Grounds.
PARIS, May 29--President de Gaulle made known today his intention to visit President Kennedy in the United States at an "opportune" time.

WASHINGTON, May 29-- President Kennedy has decided to appoint Charles H. Tenney, Deputy Mayor and City Administrator of New York, to a vacancy on the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York.
Public Works Commissioner Peter J. Reidy announced yesterday that within a few days he would commission Edward Durell Stone as architect for the coordinated design of the New York Civic Center.

After a night of quiet rest, during which the Holy Father had no need for assistance, at 6:30 this morning the Pope listened to holy mass, officiated in the study adjoining his room and received holy communion.
"The Ballad of Will Rogers" is to begin a season's pre-Broadway tour in September in Claremore, Okla., the birthplace of the humorist.

For some 230 factory workers in Luxembourg, fresh-caught trout can be on the lunch menu, and possibly an Eskimo pie for dessert. They work for Societe des Refrigerateurs Silvia, an af filiate of the Bernzomatic Corporation of Rochester, N.Y.

Philharmonic Hall had a new look and a festive, informal air last night as the New York Philharmonic inaugurated its "Promenades" with a preview concert, but the audience was as respectful and dignified in behavior as if it were listening to a regular subscription program.

LONDON, May 30--Two men who provoked a riot in Paris 50 years ago when they introduced the pulsating "Rite of Spring" stood again together last night to hear the enthu siastic cheers of a London audience.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, May 30--Within 48 hours of the conclusion of an agreement in Teheran for the resumption of diplomatic and trade relations, the Pakistani and Afghan representatives who participated in the meeting have reiterated the 16-year-old policies that have caused friction.

LONDON, May 30--Prof. Frank Percy Wilson, professor emeritus of English literature at Oxford University, and a critic and editor known for his work on Elizabethan England, died Tuesday at his home in Oxford.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) --A group of businessmen, organized last month to whip up support for a big tax cut this year, said today that a reduction in President Kennedy's 1964 budget "is reasonable and practicable."

LONDON, May 30--The British Government announced today a tenfold increase in a reciprocal monetary arrangement with the United States that guards the pound sterling and the dollar against speculative attacks.

Dr. Sidney Hook, an internationally known philosopher who has been on the faculty of New York University since 1927, will conduct an "Introduction to Ethics" next fall on Channel 2's "Sunrise Semester."

The nickel bar of candy is headed either for extinction or a drastic reduction in size. This is because of the runaway rise in the price of sugar, already reflected in higher costs for consumers. Speculators have made huge profits out of sugar, driving its price up to unsustainable heights. Now sugar refiners are reducing their prices a little, but there is no assurance that the consumer will materially benefit.

THEY call it the "Promenades," and the new series was inaugurated last night, but the chances are that everybody will be calling them "Proms." A sold-out house, and a happy one, was on hand to see and hear Andre Kostelanetz lead the opening in Philharmonic Hall.
DEVON, Pa., May 30--Not Always clinched the green working hunter championship and War Ghost the amateur-owner hunter title at the Devon horse show today.
The nation's economy is losing $14,275,000 000 a year because of 'industry's most underdeveloped resource"-- Negro manpower, according to estimates by the National Urban League.

CORNWALL, Conn., May 30 (AP)--Seven persons, including a family of five, perished today when a sports car went out of control at the peak of a hill and crashed into a sedan, the state police reported.
"Foxy," the musical starring Bert Lahr, is likely to be produced by Billy Rose. If so, the show would open in November or December at the Ziegfeld, owned by Mr. Rose.

CINCINNATI, May 30 (AP) --Home runs by Cap Peterson and Felipe Alou plus a key infield single by Billy O'Dell tonight paced San Francisco to a 5-4 victory over the Cincinnati Reds and increased the Giants' National League lead to 2 games.
NAIROBI, Kenya, May 30-- The first thing a safari bound visitor to East Africa finds is that white hunters meeting him at the airfield tend to look as if they had stepped from a motion picture.

LONDON, May 30--Another letter from President Kennedy and Prime Minister Macmillan seeking to revive the stalled negotiations for a nuclear test ban treaty will probably be delivered to Premier Khrushchev tomorrow.

President Tito's recent review of Yugoslav foreign policy included a scorching attack on Communist China that has already had important repercussions. In Moscow, Pravda devoted an entire page to the text of the speech, but carefully censored out all references to the Chinese. From Peking and its allies the address has provoked a new fusillade of bitter attacks on the Yugoslavs as "agents of imperialism."

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 30--With a final burst at 42 strokes per minute, the New York Athletic Club overtook the Union Boat Club of Boston and won the Hughes Memorial Cup by nine-tenths of a second today.

KEP, Cambodia, May 30 (AP) --An outspoken Asian neutralist, Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, says he fears both his war-torn neighbors, Laos and SouthVietnam, are doomed to fall to the Communists.

The six-story building containing 54 apartments at 1915 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Sierra Apartments, Inc., through Leonard Schiller, brokers. The property includes an adjoining parking lot for 30 cars. It was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $397,000. The plot is 143 by 135 feet.

WASHINGTON, May 30--Whether it is true, as some believe, that the patient efforts of this Government to effect a settlement of the Kashmir dispute between India, and Pakistan were set back because the I negotiation was taken over by a British Minister, Duncan Sandys, ambitious for higher office, the Pakistan Ambassador to the United States has presented powerful arguments why the subcontinent can never become a solid bastion. of the free world without this settlements

Americans throughout the world mourned their war dead yesterday. The men who died in all of this nation's battles were honored with Memorial Day parades and prayers, martial music, gunfire salutes and the bugle's haunting echo of taps. Hopes for peace were joined with vows that democracy and freedom would be preserved whatever the cost.

Dean Edward W. Barrett of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism announced yesterday that a second group of distinguished alumni would receive 50th anniversary medallions. Twentyone names have been added to the anniversary honors list.

West Ham United of London has earned the reputation as a tough team to beat. The Hammers lived up to that reputation yesterday by fighting back for a 3-3 tie against favored Kilmarnock as the fourth International Soccer League season opened at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 30--Vice President Johnson declared today that whites and Negroes must work together "to lead the way through this moment of challenge and decision." He told a Memorial Day audience in this town, made legendary as a Civil. War battleground, that "in this hour, it is not our respective races which are at stake, it is our nation."

MILWAUKEE, May 30 (UPI) --Warren Spahn, Milwaukee's 42-year-old lefthander, gained his seventh victory of the season today by beating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7--4. The Braves shelled three pitchers for 12 hits, including Hank Aaron's 15th home run of the year.

WASHINGTON, May 30--New legislation to coerce the South into desegregating the Negro race is being discussed here as if all the instruments of persuasion had been tried and failed, but this is demonstrably not true.
INDIAN POLIS, May 30-- There were plenty of thrills on the way to and at the Indianapolis Speedway today.

BRUSSELS, May 30 (Reuters)--The European Common Market decided today to raise the price of imported chickens by 2 cents a kilo (2.2 pounds), market sources here said, in a surprise move expected to anger the United States.
ROME, May 30--Pope John XXIII has rallied sufficiently to dispel immediate fears for his life.
The summer musical season had its official opening last night at Central Park Mall. It was strictly no-tie and whitesneaker, and a fine time was had by all.

VANCOUVER, B.C., May 30 (Canadian Press)--Rod Heinekey, 32-year-old vice president for the west coast of the Seafarers International Union, was lured from his home by a telephone call early today and fired on by an unidentified assailant with a shotgun.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 30 (AP)--Camilo Pascual drove in the winning run with a sacrifice fly in the ninth inning today as the Minnesota Twins beat Washington, 3--2, for their 10th straight victory.

The recent "white paper" of the Department of Commerce telling the story of the labor troubles and the lay-up of the nuclear ship Savannah is being criticized in maritime industry circles here--both by labor and management--as inadequate and misleading.
ST. LOUIS, May 30 (UPI)-- Stan Musial's three-run homer today led the St. Louis Cardinals to a 9-5 victory over the Houston Colts, who allowed eight unearned runs while committing five errors.

MEMPHIS, May 30 (AP)-- City officials, acting under a court order, agreed today to desegregate all recreational facilities. But they said that public swimming and wading pools would be closed "for the time being. "

WASHINGTON, May 30-- The National Science Foundation has discharged its chief technical advisers on Project Mohole, capping a long-standing dispute between them and the project contractor, Brown Root, Inc., of Houston.

DACCA, Pakistan, May 30-- At least 500 people lost their lives in a storm that hit the East Pakistani city of Chittagong and adjoining coastal areas on the Bay of Bengal on Tuesday. The winds raged until early yesterday.
CHICAGO, May 30 (AP)-- The Chicago White Sox rallied in each game with big innings today and swept a double-header from the Cleveland Indians, 8--4 and 4--2.
The Federal Maritime Commission appears to have been thwarted in instituting tomorrow a new set of rules and regulations for the foreign freight forwarding industry.

Seventeen years, three aborive dissertations, five books and numerous published articles after beginning graduate work at the New School, Robert L. Heilbroner will finally say farewell to his career as a student.
The International Monetary Fund approved yesterday a plan to rearrange Liberia's $125,000,000 external debt, originally scheduled for repayment within the next five years!
BOSTON, May 30--Ralph Terry today staged one of those pitching exhibitions that very well could age Manager Ralph Houk long before his time.

Further signs of the improvement, ascertained yesterday and still increasing, have been recorded at 8:30 A.M. during routine checkups. The hemorrhagic phenomena which in the last few days had raised some preoccupation has now stopped. The substitutive therapy had good results, thanks to the strong constitution of the august patient and his general condition has shown a sensible recovery.
THE, discussion of religion here on April 23 was a complete success. Everyone objected.

The expansion of the city's Youth Board from 31 to 35 members was announced yesterday. Top officials concerned with mental health, probation and hospitals were among those added to help the board deal with a wider variety of problems.

LOS ANGELES, May. 30-- Predictions of calamity came from western farmers today in the wake of the House of Representatives' refusal to renew the Mexican seasonal labor importation statute, Public Law 78.
NAIROBI, Kenya, May 30-- Prime Minister Jomo Kenyatta announced his Cabinet proposals today. They are expected to be accepted by Gov. Malcolm MacDonald without objection.
RYE, N.Y., May 30--Bob and Ellen Stern's yellow-hulled sloop, Etoile, today headed the 210 Class for the second successive Yacht Racing Association regatta of the new season on Long Island Sound.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 30--Foreign Minister Joseph M.A.H. Luns of the Netherlands underscored today the need to bring Britain into close and formal ties with the six members of the Common Market.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 30--Policemen used tear gas tonight to disperse about 150 Negro youths marching through the city and shouting against segregation.
LAWNSIDE, N.J., May 30-- This suburb of Camden is an unusual community in this period of widespread racial tension.
M. Carl Levine, a lawyer here for 59 years until his retirement a few month ago, died yesterday in his home at 785 Park Avenue. He was 84 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) --President Kennedy, like many another American, went to a cemetery today to pay his respects and remember the hosts of the nation's military dead.
LONDON, May 30--It took a long time for "On the Town" to get from New York to London, but a first-night audience at the Prince of Wales Theater here tonight decided that the wait had been worthwhile.

PARIS, May 30--Twelve days from now a brief flash of publicity will illuminate one of the quietest and yet most effective international organizations in existence. It is the Bank for International Settle ments.

Teri Thornton is a young singer who has a supple, silken voice and an easy, straightforward approach to a song that, combined with the warmth and freshness of her beauty, mark her as a distinctive new arrival in the world of popular music.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 30 --The 18th race of the Storm Trysail Club from a Larchmont start to a Stamford finish with a turn around Block Island in between began with 109 cruising yachts being favored by benign weather today. Before they are through they will have sailed at least 200 nautical miles in the spring season's foremost distance event.
Cyrano of the Greentree Stable took the long way around in the $115,100 Metropolitan Mile at Aqueduct yesterday, yet wound up in first place.
Coordinated Caribbean Transport, Inc., a "fishyback" operation between Miami and five Central American countries, is now carrying surface mail for the United States Post Office Department.

NORFOLK, Va., May 30--A vessel searching for the nuclear submarine Thresher, which sank in the Atlantic April 10 with 129 men aboard, located and photographed the submarine today about 220 miles east of Boston.

PITTSBURGH, May 30 (UPI) --Tony Taylor squeezed home Bobby Wine in the sixth inning today to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 6-5 victory over Pittsburgh in the second game of a double-header. The Pirates won the opener, 7--1.
VIENNA, May 30--Roberta Peters, the Bronx girl who became an opera star without ever leaving the United States, made her bows tonight to the European operatic theater as Gilda in "Rigoletto."

ALBANY, May 30--A group of American medical students will soon be sent to a foreign land for a medical-anthropological experiment. They will try to discover if they can help medical practitioners to learn that a society's culture is an important factor in the illness and health of man.
With Mayor Wagner's signing of the last of the new tax, bills, the end of the 1963 chapter in state and city fiscal crisis is written. It is a good occasion for inventory.
Times Square bustled with tourists yesterday, Central Park billowed with balloons and, at the edge of the Hudson River, a tall, chesty man stood in the sun, all alone, playing a saxophone.
HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., May 30--Dr. Paul Meyer Wood, a leader in anesthesiology, died last night. He was 68 years old.

The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, which includes Lord Taylor of New York in its operations of 13 divisions and 45 stores across the country had slight declines in sales and earnings for its first fiscal quarter of this year.

Development of a hightemperature sterilizing process to purify water supplies and sewage has been announced by the Worthington Corporation, Harrison, N.J. Based on what is termed the "Pasterilizer" principle, it is to destroy harmful microorganisms through controlled heating, the company reported.
The International Finance Corporation, private investment affiliate of the World Bank, has acquired a new look since September, 1961, when its charter was amended to permit it to invest in shares.

MOSCOW, May 30--Vissarion Y. Shebalin, Soviet composer and music teacher, died yesterday. He was 60 years old. He wrote four symphonies, a dramatic symphony entitled "Lenin," and other orchestral works.

The Whitehead Metals Company, which supplies industry with stainless steel, aluminum, brass and other metals, has bought nine acres in the Carteret Industrial Center in Carteret, N.J. FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., June 1 (UPI)--A $25,000,000 experimental nuclear reactor planned for the northwestern Arkansas hills one day may put atomic energy to work in Southern homes and factories more cheaply than present power sources, according to leaders in the project.

TOKYO, June 1--Indonesia and three Western petroleum companies signed an agreement today that will put the country's oil industry under a combination of private foreign enterprise and gradual, compensated nationalization.
The third annual American Debutante Ball of the Silver Rose will be held on June 29 in the Schwarzenberg Palais in Vienna.

The solution to teen-age thievery, drinking and vandalism must be sought "neither in corporal punishment nor in decrees that simply drive misbehavior underground," the Rev. Dr. Judah Nadich said yesterday.

THE Newark Museum, dedicated in about equal parts to science and art, limits itself to one major art exhibition a year, but makes that one good. This year's, now in place for the summer, is called "Classical America, 18151845."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 1 -- Vice President Johnson will be the commencement speaker here Wednesday at the United States Naval Academy's 113th graduation exercises.

The General Assembly has been so preoccupied with the United Nations financial crisis that the most important international issue now confronting the organization, the United Arab Republic's intervention in the civil war in Yemen, has attracted little attention.

Clifford Klenk Jr. of 133 East 64th Street and Wainscott, L.I., and the late Richard Nelson Ryan, to Roy Rainey Plum. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthias Plum of Chatham, Mass.

The tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee cheered investors last week in tentatively approving capital gains proposals that exceeded the Administration's in generosity. In addition, it began a point-bypoint consideration of the President's reform program.

PARIS--Fellow tourists, the French Government is thinking of you. It has just put out a list of do's and dont's for restaurant owners--all in the interest of visitors, and, of course, in the French interest, too, for France wants its foreign friends to come back again.

CHITTAGONG, Pakistan, June 1 (Reuters)--More than 10,000 persons were killed by the storm that swept East Pakistan on Wednesday, Education Minister Fazlul Quadir Choudhary said today after a three-hour tour of the disaster area.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla.--The growth of summer vacationing in Florida is a phenomenon of this age of fast transportation.

NUMISMATISTS specializing in United States coins are wondering what effect the pas sage by Congress of recent silver legislation will have on their hobby. The legislation authorizes the Treasury to retire $1 silver certificates and replace them with Federal Reserve notes so that the metal held by the Government to redeem them will be freed for coinage.

HARRISBURG, Pa.--This state, which leads the nation with about 325 covered bridges, is an ideal hunting ground for motorists interested in vanishing Americana. Here, zealous devotees, have formed local organizations to protect and preserve these picturesque, 19thcentury landmarks.

DENVER, June 1 (AP)--A Federal Power Commission order automatically rejecting natural gas purchase contracts with indefinite price-changing clauses has been invalidated by the 10th United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

THE annual Emmy awards constituted a devastating commentary on the state of television. In many categories, routine competence became "outstanding" solely because of the industry's growing default in creativity. In other instances a few heartening examples of genuine quality were ignored in favor of popularity considerations.

SINCE there is a slight element of doubt as to the possibility of the New York Mets meeting the New York Yankees in the World Series this October, adroit schedulemakers have done the next best thing. WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) --An investigation into a movement that seeks to deny Presi dent Kennedy Southern support in 1964 was ordered today by Senator Estes Kefauver.

IN THE murky haze of an unpromising morning, Candy Spots galloped a mile yesterday and Mesh Tenney seemed sat isfied. This is the final week of preparation for the 95th running of the Belmont Stakes at Aqueduct on Saturday and, unlike most of the other horsemen, the shrewd Tenney prefers to handle his training chores on the actual battleground.

Two members of the City Council, calling for immediate steps to expand the city's taxing authority, declared yesterday that the city soon would be faced with budgets higher than the $3,000,000,000 record total for 1963-64.

BILOXI, Miss., June 3 (UPI)--A United States district judge today cleared the way for a second Negro to be admitted to the University of Mississippi. He acted despite a warning from Gov. Ross R. Barnett that disturbances were likely to result.
CHICAGO, June 3 (UPI)-- Soybeans posted healthy gains and set the trend for new crop wheat and all corn contracts today on the Board of Trade.
OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 3--Bradley Martin, a banker who devoted much of his life to social and philanthropic activities, died here today in Knole, his home. His age was 89.

DAMASK is weaving its way back into the dining room. The reversible fabric, which reigned for centuries in silken glory over the royal households of Europe and later served as the backbone of Victorian girls' hope cheats, disappeared from American table tops prior to World War II.

Eric H. Hare of Slade, Cornwood, South Devon, and Mrs. Francis K. Wilson of Beech Hill, Wadhurst, Sussex, both in England, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss June Hare, to Howard C. Dickinson Jr. of New York and Marblehead, Mass. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Dickinson of Marblehead.

Governor Wallace of Alabama is the latest in the long list of diehard Southern segregationists to accuse the North of hypocrisy on race relations. JUNEAU, Alaska, June 4 (AP)--All hope was abandoned today for 101 men, women and children on a military-chartered DC-7 that crashed into the North Pacific Ocean. Search vessels reported recovering bodies from the water.
Throngs of mourners filled St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday at a Pontifical requiem mass in tribute to Pope John XXIII.
OTTAWA, June 4--Canada will establish a 12-mile territorial limit for the exclusive use of Canadian fishermen, Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson told Parliament today.

Those with better memories may remember that he was a Proper Bostonian who commanded a regiment of Negro troops in the Civil.

WASHINGTON, June 4-- Specialists in Latin-American affairs believe that Premier Fidel Castro and Premier Khrushchev struck a significant political and ideological bargain during the Cuban's visit to the Soviet Union.

The Paramount Pictures showing in the first half of months are expected to "give 1962," Barney Balaban, president, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 4-- New York State is in danger of losing $9,000,000 in Federal contributions to its employment and unemployment insurance Programs.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI) --Representative Francis E. Walter was buried today in Arlington National Cemetery with full military honors, reflecting his 33 years as a Congressman and military service spanning two world wars.
