DENVER, June 5--Electric utility leaders heard plenty of good news, here today but it was somewhat tempered by a warning from their host, the Public Service Company of Colorado.
The New York State Banking Board approved yesterday the plan of Bankers Trust Company to buy The First National Bank of Farmingdale, L.I.

Isidor Sommer, a primitive painter whose works often have been compared with those of Grandma Moses, died yesterday at Coney Island Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 83 years old and lived at 1530 East 14th Street in Brooklyn.
New York State has moved against a key construction trade union for allegedly discriminating against Negroes in its apprentice-training program.

Open non-Communist political opposition to the South Vietnam Government has heretofore come mainly from upper-crust rivals of President Ngo Dinh Diem who want to oust him and take over his power and prerogatives for themselves. Most of them have even less popular support than the President, whose mass popularity has dwindled sharply in recent years.
WASHINGTON, June 5--The House passed a $1,633,000,000 military construction bill today over the protest of a West Virginia legislator who complained there was "not one penny" for his state.
LONDON, June 5--The Treadury reported today that the sterling area's gold and convertible currency reserves rose last month by 29,000,000 ($81,200,000).
MOSCOW, June 5--The Soviet Union appeared today to have failed to overcome the resistance of Rumania to its plans for the economic integration of Eastern Europe.

In an age in which the nations of this world reach for the stars and seek to formulate laws for outer space, they are still, ironically enough, at odds over an ancient law much closer to them: the law of the freedom of the seas, involving the extent of their territorial waters.

"The New Frontier," a comedy written by Rabbi Herbert Tarr of the Westbury (L.I.) Temple, is to be produced here next April by Joe Cates and Robert Weiner, after tryouts in New Haven and Philadelphia.
LONDON, June 5--Britain's major economic planning body gave its reasons today for a decline in the nation's share of world manufacturing exports since 1953.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 5-- Ravel's "Spanish Hour" and Bartok's "Bluebeard's Castle" were presented last night to an enthusiastic audience at a spring series production of the San Francisco Opera.
WASHINGTON, June 5-- A Cabinet officer "worried about farm surpluses" and a historian, concerned with overpopulation, differed today over the capacity of science to end world hunger.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 5--"Negroes are utterly weary of tokenism," Arnold Forster, general counsel for the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, declared here today.
Most major European currencies weakened in their relation to the dollar yesterday in trading on the New York foreign exchange market.
The American Stock Exchange's board of governors will meet this afternoon to consider the allocation of three stocks slated to begin trading within the next month to exchange specialists.
A Bronx youth who had been skin-diving in 40 feet of water at Orchard Beach was rushed to a decompression chamber in Greenwich Village last night after being stricken with the bends.
VIENNA, June 5--Austria's coalition Government, a political fixture in varying forms since 1945, was shaken today in the "Habsburg crisis."
WASHINGTON, June 5--The House Ways and Means Committee agreed today to tighten the taxation of profits from sales of buildings by commercial real-estate operators.
August Heckscher will resign next week as President Kennedy's special consultant on the arts, but he will leave a series of recommendations for his successor.
MOSCOW, June 5--A virtual breakdown of Communist party control is reported from a Soviet film studio whose pictures have been criticized for Western orientation.

PARIS, June 5--Britain tried again today to widen consultation and cooperation with the six members of the European Economic Community, or Common Market, from which she had been excluded by a French veto.
The big soft-drink companies this summer plan to channel substantial advertising expenditures into a relatively new and tricky market--low calorie beverages.

President Kennedy's top housing adviser declared yesterday that racial tensions in Harlem and Negro concentrations in other American cities would be eliminated only when Negroes were given the freedom to live and work where they chose.

The F.W. Woolworth Company, the nation's largest variety chain, is planning to expand into the shoe business. Negotiations are under way to purchase the G. R. Kinney Corporation from the Brown Shoe Company, it was announced yesterday.
Rembrandt's "Aristotle Contemplating the Bust of Homer" was moved yesterday from the Great Hall at the Metropolitan Museum of Art to a studio on the top floor.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 5 -- June week festivities ended at the United States Naval Academy today with the wedding ceremonies of 16 new officers.
The Ceylon Government has decided to take over the distribution of oil from the AngloDutch Shell Company, Caltex Ceylon, Ltd., and Esso Standard Eastern, according to Reuters.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 5 (AP)--Henrik Kauffmann, Danish diplomatic hero of World War II, was found dead today. The police said his American wife had taken his life, apparently to save him the agonies of incurable cancer of the prostate gland, and then killed herself.
A motion that District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said had never been made before in the United States was made and granted yesterday in a robbery case in State Supreme Court.
PHILADELPHIA, June 5-- Many major medical centers have developed techniques using X-ray motion pictures for diagnostic purposes in the last three years, it was reported here today.
WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., June 5--Integration took another giant step today in North Carolina with lowering of major color bars in this tobacco and industrial city.

Machinery was set in motion yesterday to resolve the renewed jurisdictional controversy between the Amateur Athletic Union and the National Collegiate Athletic Association over the control-of track and field.
NAIROBI, Kenya, June 5-- Tanganyika and Uganda announced here today that they were committed to the establishment of an East African political federation before the year's end.

WASHINGTON, June 5--The Federal Martime Commission approved today the first new dual rate steamship conference contract under the new and tighter supervisory powers granted it by Congress in October, 1961.

Candy Spots, who is scaring most of the talent away from Saturday's Belmont Stakes, went through his prescribed routine in the morning under the direction of his trainer, Mesh Tenney. He worked seven furlongs in 1:23 4/5 and went the mile in 1:37.

A group of investors headed by Manville H. and Junius P. Abramson of Abramson Brothers, lawyers and realty investors, have taken title to the 25story office building at 274 Madison Avenue between 39th and 40th Streets.

Six hundred and fifty partygoers, including the Duke and Duchess of Windsor and Governor and Mrs. Rockefeller, boarded the Rotterdam last night for a five-and-a-half-hour pleasure cruise to Ambrose Lightship and back.

DIXIE WALKER'S smile was a trifle forced. "Yes, I'm the hitting coach of the Braves," he admitted in a whisper. "I make the statement merely to avoid confusing you. Our hitters, as you can tell from their batting averages, are confused enough."
A band of 224 Old Believers, members of the old Russian Orthodox faith, stepped out of two planes at Idlewild Airport yesterday, ready to begin a new life in a new world.
CHICAGO, June 5 (UPI)-- Most soybean contracts fell sharply, wheat and rye were firm and other grain futures steady to easy today on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) --The Senate Banking Committee approved today the Kennedy Administration's request for a $455,500,000 increase in funds for area redevelopment to aid regions afflicted by chronic unemployment. The vote was 11 to 4.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 5 (AP)--Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor assured West Point graduates today that the American military man received a serious hearing from his civilian leaders, who he said "seek his advice and listen to his arguments."

OTTAWA, June 5 (Canadian Press)--The Federal Government was urged today to stop United States charter flights into Canada at the border until Canadian airlines get a better deal on flights into the United States.
The New York and American stock exchanges reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders of listed companies.
WASHINGTON, June 5--A dozen men and women picketed the White House this week in support of Krebiozen, with the future of the 12-year-old anticancer compound undecided.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The director of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, virtually vetoed today a proposal by the astronauts for another flight in a Mercury capsule, lasting as long as 100 hours.

WASHINGTON, June 5-- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has opened an intensive, five-year "catchup" program of basic education for about 1,500 Negro children in Prince Edward County, Va.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (UPI) --Two Kennedy brothers today led a group of prominent speakers into the Washington slum areas in an effort to persuade young people to stay in school.

THE 34th annual renewal of the team contest for the Curt H. Reisinger Cup, played Tuesday afternoon and night, ended in victory for the same team that won the trophy last year, Sol Rubinow, Mr. and Mrs. Victor Mitchell, Samuel M. Stayman, Tobias Stone and Philip Feldesman.
HARTFORD, June 5 -- The Connecticut General Assembly completed action early today on a bill assuring the state's participation in the proposed TriState Transportation Commission.

WHEN foreigners arrive in the United States, their culture is rapidly altered to meet the demands of a particular area. If the process does not occur in the first generation, it does in the second. In this age of conformity and cake mixes, it is always a pleasure to meet a young woman with a desire to perpetuate the foods of her fathers and forefathers.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 5 (AP)--A crowd of 1,500 was on hand today as 94 cadets received degrees and commissions at the United States Coast Guard Academy's 77th commencement exercises.
A brisk rally in stock prices collapsed late yesterday afternoon and closing prices generally were below Tuesday's level.

LIMA, Peru, June 5--The high command of the Apra party has ordered its district leaders to prepare for a general strike call if the Peruvian armed forces annul the results of the presidential election Sunday.

The marine engineers' assertion that the nuclear liner Savannah is in danger has been rebutted by the Atomic Energy Commission and by the Babcock and Wilcox Company, which designed the vessel's atomic plant.

OXFORD, Miss., June 5--A second Negro entered the University of Mississippi today, but there was neither interference from Gov. Ross R. Barnett nor the violence that marked the initial desegregation of the school.

WASHINGTON, June 5-- A special inter-American investigating committee reported today that Communist subversion in Latin America, with Cuba as its base, "has increased considerably during the past year."
BOSTON, June 5 (AP)-- Crimson King Farm's Crimson Satan took the lead coming into the stretch and won the $59,300 Massachusetts Handicap by 2 lengths at Suffolk Downs today.

ROME, June 5--Hundreds of thousands of people filed by the body of Pope John XXIII today to pay their last tribute of affection. The Pope's body lay in state in St. Peter's Basilica beneath Michelangelo's mighty dome.
The thinning ranks of a certain kind of blue chip--the 8 per cent preferred stocks -- probably will soon be smaller.

While he was studying history at Jackson College in Mississipi, his greatest interest was in reading about the American, French and Russian Revolutions. As the first Negro to enroll at the University of Mississippi Law School, he sees himselftaking part in a new uprising.
A lawyer was held in contempt yesterday after he had refused to tell a grand jury whether he had passed $39,000 in bribe money for Martin C. Epstein, former chairman of the State Liquor Authority.
LONDON, June 5--Lieut. Gen. Sir Adrian Carton de Wiart, one of Britain's most heroic military figures, died today at his home in Killinardrish, County Cork, Ireland. He was 83 years old.

The price of lead was increased a quarter-cent to 10 cents a pound by a leading smelter yesterday.
OTTAWA, June 5--After six years of bickering, the Federal Government of Canada has reached agreement with the province of British Columbia on the sale of Columbia River power to the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 5-- Representative Edwin E. Willis, Democrat of Louisiana, was elected chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities today. He succeeds Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, who died last Friday.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 5--A four-lane, limited access highway through one of the most congested areas of Nassau County was proposed today by the county Department of Public Works.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 5-- There have been harness racing "nights" in the past. Henry Thomas, Steve Phillips, Proximity and Adios Butler were honored upon their retirement, but all those occasions, notable though they were, became dwarfed alongside "Billy Haughton Night" at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 5 (UPI) -- Dick Davies, the defending champion, and five other Americans gained the fourth round of the British Amateur golf championship today. They were the last of 39 original starters from the United States.

The 6th of June reminds us that history refuses to compromise with time. Neither personal lives nor lives of governments remain true to wartime dreams. Anachronisms abound; enigmas puzzle still. It meant the beginning of the end of Nazi Germany.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 5 (AP)--The Naval Academy sent 855 officers into United States armed forces today with a warning from Vice President Johnson against slogan chanters who threatened "our existence as a free people."

WASHINGTON, June 5--The agreement to establish a sure and quick communications link between Moscow and Washington is ready for signature in Geneva, probably next... week. It provides for a cable hook-up, passing through Helsinki, Stockholm and London, for use in emergencies to reduce the chances of accidental war.

PARIS, June 5--A consortium of 10 countries and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development pledged economic aid totaling $915,000,000 for India this year. This was less than was provided for in either of the last two years.

Mayor Wagner was assured by labor leaders of the city's construction industry yesterday of an all-out effort to end discrimination in building trades unions.

PARIS, June 6--Europe's booming aircraft manufacturers prepared today for an expected total of 1,000,000 visitors to the 25th International Air Show, which opened at Le Bourget Airport.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) --Local problems and traditions plus flagrant mistakes by wellintentioned people often make it difficult to provide food for the hungary people of the world, Princess Aline, wife of Premier Souvanna Phouma of Laos said today.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 6-- Mrs. Harry Day of Woodway and Mrs. Fred E. Wright of Winged Foot posted a 154 today to win the Women's TriCounty Golf Association's Grace Herbert Memorial Trophy tournament by one shot at Old Oaks County Club. They had a bestball score of 77 for the second straight day.

MARION, Ill., June 3--A new era in Federal prison administration, combining maximum security and maximum opportunity for the toughest young convicts, drew closer today with the arrival of two Bureau of Prison buses here.

Chateaugay turned in a most satisfactory workout yesterday and the move had a salutary effect on the Belmont Stakes picture.

WASHINGTON, June 6--Among the tributes paid to Pope John XXIII by leaders of every group through-- out the world, none more percep-- tively described the mission to which he dedicated his prelacy than George Meany, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. The Pope's "historic encyclical, Mater et Magistra," said Meany, "will stand to the end of time as an eloquent delineation of the human spirit and a charter of human rights."
RUBE GOLDBERG has insisted that his first "invention" was a system of sewers and water mains for the city of San Francisco.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 6--Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Harbor Hills, the metropolitan champion, today scored a runaway victory in the Women's Long Island Golf Association 54-hole medal-play championship at the Creek Club.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, exercising the arbi tration authority conferred on him by President Kennedy, yesterday ordered the nation's col leges to lift the restrictions some had imposed on their athletes' participation in open track and field meets.
A lawyer who was held in contempt of court Wednesday for refusing to answer questions in the State Liquor Authority investigation apologized to the court yesterday and promised to testify.

HINGHAM, Mass., June 6-- The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Martin A. Greenman have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Margaret Lynn Greenman, to John Alan Barmack. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Barmack of Larchmont, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, June 6-- An unusually large increase in the number of teen-agers looking for jobs pushed the unemployment rate back up near the 6 per cent mark in May.

Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower made a flying visit here yesterday from his home in Gettysburg, Pa., to participate in the dedication of the new Red Cross Headquarters at Amsterdam Avenue and 66th Street.
WASHINGTON, June 6--The United States Chamber of Commerce urged Congress today to cut President Kennedy's $4,500,000,000 foreign aid request by at least $900,000,000.

LONDON, June 6--In the months that the rumors about the "Profumo scandal" have been going around London, the name of Dr. Stephen Ward, a 43-year-old American-trained osteopath, has cropped up regularly as a central figure.
SALT LAKE CITY, May 31-- The top leadership of the Mormon church is seriously considering the abandonment of its historic policy of discrimination against Negroes.

The chief of the Boston police homicide squad came here yesterday to question a 33-year-old furniture mover who assertedly had confessed to the strangling last week of a woman in a hotel off Times Square.
What are "special circumstances"? Yesterday, the Interstate Commerce Commission was being asked that question, but it kept the answer well zippered.
WHITE PLAINS, June 6-- Teen-agers spoke more bluntly than adults about the problems of youth at a two-day conference that ended here today at the Westchester County Center.

GRAND BLANC, Mich., June 6 (UPI)--Tony Lema, plagued by a series of second-place finishes, had a leading five-under par 34, 33--67 wiped out by thunderstorms today in the first round of the Buick open golf championship.

Thomas Newton Armstrong Jr., assistant to the manager of the development and research department of the International Nickel Company, died Wednesday in Margaretville, N.Y. Mr. Armstrong, who was 58 years old, had been on vacation there. He lived at 37 Edgewood Raad, Summit, N.J.
WASHINGTON, June 6-- Department-store sales in the week ended June 1 were 1 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year.
Anna M. Kross said last night that she had asked City Hall to let her stay on as Commissioner of Corrections past an automatic retirement date next month.
Taxpayers wishing to telephone Mayor Wagner or one of the city's Commissioners will soon have new telephone numbers to call and a new system of telephoning extensions directly.
The Sacramento, Calif., Municipal Utility District sold yesterday $10,000,000 of electric revenue bonds.
A city contract permitting the construction of a commercial golf-driving range in Kissena Park was ruled illegal yesterday.
Indecisive conditions settled over the London stock market following the resignation of John Profumo as British Secretary of State for War.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) --Rachel L. Carson said today that low concentrations of chemical poisons tended to be increased as they progressed through the food chains in nature.

WASHINGTON, June 6-- Senator J.W. Fulbright assailed the system of assigning sugar quotas to foreign countries today as a "heads they win, tails we lose" operation. It leaves American consumers without price protection, he asserted.

A proposed settlement of a stockholder suit against Television-Electronics Fund, Inc., and the Television Shares Management Corporation will be discussed at a hearing on June 22 in the State Chancery Court of Delaware.

LOS ANGELES, June 6 (UPI)--The International Professional Tennis Players Association today suspended Richard (Pancho) Gonzalez and Francisco (Pancho) Segura indefinitely for contracting to appear in a television series without the group's permission.

Sugar futures made their best showing in two weeks yesterday morning only to beat a sharp retreat in afternoon trading. Cocoa futures also gave ground after a firm opening. Both staples were actively traded.
Governor Rockefeller charged last night that "vacillation and uncertainty" by President Kennedy on Cuba and civil rights had created "two of the great crises of our times."

PIANO lessons have become as much a part of Japanese family life as the tea ceremony once was. Tots approach the keyboard at the age of 3 and elementary school youngsters struggle nightly with problems in music theory.
An agreement is expected to be signed soon between the State Dental Society and Blue Cross for a new nonprofit dental insurance plan in New York City and 10 nearby, counties.

THE world-champion pair, Pierre Jais and Roger Tre zel of France, bid their notrumps as do many of the best American rubber-bridge players, such as Theodore Lightner: weak, when not vulnerable; strong when vulnerable.

NEWTOWN, Conn., June 6-- One should no longer think of a poet as being long of hair and short of cash. Although poets have not moved from garrets to plush penthouses, poetry has become increasingly profitable.

The United States Court of Appeals upheld yesterday a decision of the Federal District Court that permitted GraysonRobinson Stores, Inc., to continue in possession of the business while working out an arrangement to pay off creditors under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
A bankrupt clothing manufacturer who had made known plans to reopen his former Brooklyn factory soon was shot to death yesterday a few doors from his Bay Ridge home.
BALTIMORE, June 6--The Yankees sent Luis Arroyo, the finest relief pitcher in the American League two years ago, to Richmond of the International League today and recalled Al Downing.
A "far-reaching" investigation of theatrical financing practices--both on and off Broadway--is under way in the office of the State Attorney General.

A "blood bath unparalleled in the history of this nation" could strike a half-dozen Northern cities owing to the "often suprarational anger and aggressiveness" of Negro masses, according to a moderate Negro spokesman.

WASHINGTON, June 6-- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, pledged today that Republican leaders would be consulted before President Kennedy's new civil rights proposals were submitted to Congress.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 6-- The on-again, off-again Adios Butler Cup that was supposed to have occupied the featured spot at Roosevelt Raceway's 1963 opening last month finally has made it. The $25,000 freefor-all mile pace is scheduled tomorrow.

WHEN a curlous reporter sounded out some of the leading sluggers in the American League during spring train ing in Florida last March as to the likeliest winner of the home run championship, there was a surprising unanimity of opinion.

A seven-point policy statement against discrimination in the employment of broadcasting talent was announced yesterday by the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists and major elements of the broadcasting, advertising and recording industries.
William Baziotes, a leading American painter, died of lung cancer Wednesday in his home at 90 La Salle Street. He was 52 years old.
A pair of big Western railroads--the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe and the Missouri Pacific--has heaped fresh fuel on the roaring merger fires with their plan to begin ex ploratory studies soon.

Eugene H. Nickerson, County Executive of Nassau, wrote Mayor Wagner yesterday that the proposed Breezy Point Park in Queens would be a welcome addition "to the chain of excellent public parks along the Atlantic Ocean."
William Baziotes, a leading American painter, died of lung cancer Wednesday in his home at 90 La Salle Street. He was 52 years old.
A pair of big Western railroads--the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe and the Missouri Pacific--has heaped fresh fuel on the roaring merger fires with their plan to begin ex ploratory studies soon.

Eugene H. Nickerson, County Executive of Nassau, wrote Mayor Wagner yesterday that the proposed Breezy Point Park in Queens would be a welcome addition "to the chain of excellent public parks along the Atlantic Ocean."
Mickey Mantle, the New York Yankees' $100,000 center fielder, will be lost to the club for at least five weeks.
ROME, June 6--Thirty-five Cardinals took possession of the secret documents and seals of the Government of the Roman Catholic Church today.
A second big New York City bank, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, wants to open a branch in Rockville Centre, L.I. It would be the bank's first office outside the city limits.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 6--The United States accused the Soviet Union today of at least six violations of an agreement to report all space launchings to the United Nations.

THE art season is continuing to decline peacefully into a state of summer suspension. But a new gallery, the Royal-Athena, 1066 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, has opened with a good show by Leong, an abstractionist devoted to discretion. It is appropriate work to accompany the departing season--muted, dark and meditative.
Liberal party leaders have agreed to nominate Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan for a full term as a Civil Court judge once he has been appointed to the post.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 6-- For the first time in the dispute between Buddhists and South Vietnam's Government, preliminary steps may have been taken toward a settlement.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI)--The House Appropriations Committee voted $140,000,000 today toward the cost of running Congress next year and warned that $20,000,000 more would soon be needed to make sure that the Capitol dome did not collapse.
WASHINGTON, June 6--Consumers had their day in the Senate today.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company reported yesterday record sales for the three and six-month periods ended April 30, but earnings were below a year ago.
Charges that a city deputy commissioner had specified "white only" in seeking a temporary employe are being inves tigated by the City Commission on Human Rights.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., June 6--Frank Burton Lounsberry, a director and former vice president of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation in Pittsburgh, died here today in his home at 66 Palm Club. His age was 73.

ROME, June 6--After solemn ceremonies in the majestic setting of St. Peter's Basilica, Pope John XXIII was laid to rest late this evening in a crypt not far from what, according to tradition, was once the grave of Simon Peter, Prince of the Apostles.
HANOVER, N.H., June 6-- The Hopkins Center Repertory Company at Dartmouth College will open its first summer season here on July 12.
Negro leaders from both parties and many organizations have formed a new group to lobby in Washington for immediate new civil rights legislation.

WASHINGTON, June 6.-- The Federal Radiation Council, under mounting Congressional pressure, pledged today to, establish within the next year standards permitting the public to assess the danger of radioactive fallout from atomic tests.
The expansion of two Federal programs to assist in vocational rehabilitation, especially for the aging worker, was advocated here yesterday.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 6--The Congolese Government has seized what is purported to be a copy of a letter from President Moise Tshombe of Katanga to a high East German communist official. Government sources...
BONN, June 7--The West German Government disclosed today that it has had under way since last year a $40,000,000 military aid program for Nigeria and other African countries.

WHITE PLAINS, June 7-- A motorist whose speeding car struck another car and killed two occupants was convicted of criminal negligence in Westchester County Court today. He faces a possible prison term of five years and a fine of $1,000.
The orthodox rules of "How to Succeed in Business" would be unlikely to include conceding an advantage of two years or more to a No. 1 competitor.
Carmine G. De Sapio has told close associates he will decide "in a week to 10 days" whether he will attempt a political comeback.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 7--Ghana urged today the establishment of a voluntary "peace fund" on which the United Nations could draw at once in future crises.

MUNICH, Germany, June 7 (AP)--A special board of inquiry of the Christian Socialist Union today cleared the party's deputy treasurer, Dr. Max Fraundorfer, of charges that he was once personal adjutant of Heinrich Himmler, the Nazi S.S. chief.

WASHINGTON, June 7(AP) Mayor Wagner told an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing today that the proposed merger of the New York Central and Pennsylvania railroads should be approved only if employe jobs are protected, the New Haven Railroad is made part of the merger and the Erie-Lackawanna merges with the Norfolk Western. .
A California retail clothing chain has filed suit against Botany Industries, Inc., charging that Botany obtained representation on the clothier's board for harassment.
Stock prices closed with a moderate loss yesterday after retreating steadily for most of the session.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7-- Dr. Francis Ashley Faught, inventor of the blood--pressure measuring device, or sphygmomanometer, used by physicians around the world, died in his home Wednesday at the age of 82.

Trading in commodity futures was dominated again yesterday by rapid and wide fluctuations in world sugar. Prices closed unchanged, to up 22 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). Domestic sugar was down 7 points, to up 15.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI)--G. Mennen Williams, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said in Congressional testimony made public today that the number of "hard-core Communists" in Africa would be a cause for concern within three years.
St. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 7 (AP)--The last four Americans in the British Amateur gold championship were eliminated today.

COMPTON, Calif., June 8 (AP)--Brian Sternberg raised his world pole vault record to l6 feet 8 inches and Peter Snell won the mile in 3 minutes 55 seconds tonight in the Compton invitation track meet. For the first time in history, six men bettered four minutes in a mile race.
WASHINGTON, June 7-- Pan American World Airways and two unions signed today an unusual agreement to submit disputes over new contract terms to arbitration.

A new treasure will be on exhibition on Tuesday at the Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park. It is an exquisite 14th-century shrine before which a queen kneeled many centuries ago. The acqtusition for the medieval branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art is said to be the most important one announced by the museum in many months.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 7-The Methodist Church was the scene this evening of the marriage of Miss Pamela Chatterton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Chatterton Jr., to the Rev. David Allan Purdy. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Purdy of Ardsley, N.Y.

Luis Rodriguez, the world welterweight champion, and Emile Griffith, the former titleholder who lost his crown to Rodriguez less than three months ago, will meet tonight in a 15-round title fight at Madison Square Garden.
SOUTH in the deal shown today lost his contract because of a deceptive play by one of the defenders, but most observers applauded the defender and did not blame the declarer

OXFORD, Miss., June 7 (UPI) --A Federal court jury cleared two white men today of charges that they attacked Federal of ficers with pistols and gasoline bombs during racial rioting at the University of Mississippi last fall.

NEW faces have been brightening the gray showrooms of Seventh Avenue during the last two weeks and, although their presence has enlivened the semiannual ritual of buyer showings, it is also reviving an age-old problem. Should a wholesale manufacturer encourage visits from retail customers?
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 7--The centennial of thoroughbred racing at Saratoga is the occasion for the return of shell racing here for the first time in more than half a century.
AMITYVILLE, L.I., June 7 -The Long Island Rail Road will open a new bus branch line along Suffolk County's South Shore here tomorrow.

PARIS, June 7-The International Federation of Stock Exchanges unanimously agreed today that greater disclosure of financial information by listed companies was desirable to increase public interest in securities.
A Queens Republican leader said yesterday that his prospective appointment to the State Supreme Court bench had been delayed so long by Governor Rockefeller that he was withdrawing as a candidate.
Mayor Wagner charged yesterday that extremist groups and fanatics had organized a nationwide campaign against cooperation between states.

THE Guggenheim Museum's summer exhibition, "Ce zanne and Structure in Modern Painting," can be looked at in two ways. First it brings out an exemplary group, of 20th-century works belonging to the Guggenheim, some of which have not been shown publicly, before and others only infrequently on view. Secondly, it has borrowed some of ' the greatest Cezannes from New York private collections.

MANCHESTER, England, June 7 (Reuters)--West Indies, avoiding allrisks and batting strictly to orders, scored a total of 501 runs for six wickets declared on the second day of the first test here today.
ATHENS, June 7--The Greek Embassy in Moscow has protested strongly to the Soviet Foreign Ministry over the kidnapping of a Greek national by the Moscow police, it was announced here today.

In a quiet classroom at New York University, a few hundred young music lovers gathered last night to hear three old men from Memphis sing and play the blues. In its unsensational way the concert, sponsored by the nonprofit Friends of Old Time Music, was a historic event.

The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is approaching new days of decision. Between now and the late fall political changes and new military programs may alter the character of the alliance, or at least decisively influence its future plans.
WASHINGTON, June 7.-- The Federal Aviation Agency today summoned New York and New Jersey officials to a meeting that may decide the location of the proposed metropolitan area jetport.

KUCHING, Sarawak, June 7 --An unidentified band raided a settlement near the Indonesian frontier yesterday. The purpose was to terrorize Dyak tribesmen in border areas, a spokesman for the Government of Sarawak said today.
The first families of thoroughbred racing were represented last night at the 12th running of the Belmont Ball. Today they will be at the 95th running of the Belmont Stakes.
Dr. George James, the city's Commissioner of Health, urged a graduating class of physicians yesterday to try to persuade their patients to stop smoking cigarettes.

Reluctant to cancel, his ill-timed trip to Europe, President Kennedy has sought to give it greater significance by expanding it to include a visit to Britain for "informal talks" with Prime Minister Macmillan. Such a visit will undoubtedly lend more weight to the trip than it otherwise would have, but it may also generate ill-will through a suspicion that our President is interfering in Britain's internal politics.
Supreme Court Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff refused yesterday to sign an order for the arrest of Representative Adam Clayton Powell.
WASHINGTON, June 7--The Kennedy Administration told representatives of 100 countries today that the United States was "dedicated to a policy" of accelerating the rate of progress on civil rights.

LOS ANGELES, June 7--The multi-racial United Civil Rights Committee expressed some dissatisfaction today with Los Angeles' civic leaders' reception yesterday of demands for "immediate" eradication of local racial discrimination in housing, education, employment and law enforcement.

Saying in effect, "enough of this nonsense," General of the Army Douglas MacArthur stepped in again yesterday and settled the wrangle over sanctioning rights and powers in track and field. The United States Track and Field Federation bowed to his edict.
LONDON, June 7--A routine audience with Queen Elizabeth II at which John Profumo was to hand over his seals of office as Secretary of State for War was canceled today by mutual consent.

LONDON, June 7--Kenneth Macmillan's "House of Birds," which was performed for the first time in Covent Garden last night, will probably be best remembered as the ballet that unequivocably established Christopher Gable, its hero, as a star.
CHICAGO, June 7 (AP)--A lawyer argued today that workers' refusal to load a stranded Canadian grain vessel was not a secondary boycott as the Government had charged.

Rare indeed is the summer concert series that manages to get through two whole weeks without including a note by Tchaikovsky. This is just another of the many feats pioneered by the Philharmonic in its new Promenade series; last night, however, Andre Kostelanetz and the orchestra made up for lost time by devoting an entire evening to works by this well-loved Russian.
COMMUNITY-hunting precedes house-hunting for many families who are more concerned with the character of a particular suburb than with the floor plans of a particular home.

ST.LOUIS, June 7-- A large crowd of singing, placard-waving Negro parents led by a white woman today blocked the transportation of hundreds of Negro children to public schools where they have been kept apart from classes of predominantly white pupils.

OTTAWA, June 7--Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson charged in Parliament today that the Conservative Opposition was using material deliberately calculated to insult the United States and poison American-Canadian relations.

WASHINGTON, June 7--A revolutionary form of currency, patented by a Washington engineer, would replace bills with square plastic wafers. One advantage claimed for the new currency is that it could easily be counted and identified by automatic machines.

PEANUT butter may be a "non-U" food in certain cir cles, but it has its supporters. Americans consume an average of 16,000,000 peanut butter sandwiches a day. In a year, they manage to put away, either between slices of bread or in some other form, 400,000,000 pounds of the spread.
SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., June 7--Members of the Bond Club of New York turned their backs on practical matters today to enjoy the annual field day activities.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) --Adlai E. Stevenson, United States representative at the United Nations, has told Congress that he is "not too happy" about the settlement reached by Indonesia and the Netherland in the New Guinea controversy.
JACKSON, Miss., June 7 (UPI)--Forty-two Negroes staged demonstrations today despite a state court injunction barring racial protests for the time being.

PARIS, June 7--Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer declared today that the proposed North Atlantic nuclear force built around surface vessels must be placed under the Supreme Allied Command. Any other course, he said, could be "militarily disastrous" to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Candy Spots will take "The Test of the Champion" at Aqueduct today and the general helief is that Rex Ellsworth's colt will pass summa cum laude.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 7-The establishment of a permanent Arts Council for Huntington Township was recommended her a today by the Huntington Citizens Advisory Committee on the Arts.

Mayor Wagner cast 42 vetoes yesterday to reject the City Council's proposed budget changes for the fiscal year beginning July 1. He thereby left standing the Board of Estimate's total of $3,083,228,272.

WASHINGTON; June 7-- Krebiozen sponsors said they had mailed to the Government today information on the controversial "anti-cancer" drug that would allow its continued distribution. The deadline for the filing was midnight tonight.

Net income of the United States Shoe Corporation for the six months ended April 30 reached a record total of $2,479515, Jos. S.Stern, chairman, and Nathan Stix, president, reported yesterday. The income is equal to 83 cents a share. It compares with $2,070,740, or 78 cents a share, in the six months to May 31, 1962.

When figured in billions of dollars, the increase in stock prices since the start of the year is impressive. Through June 4, 1,154 common stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange-almost the complete roster-rose 4,679 points to add $40,500,000,000 in paper values. The figures were compiled by Harold Clayton, market analyst for Hemphill, Noyes Company.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7--If harness racing with pari-mutuel wagering, presented in Pennsylvania for the first time tonight, is to prove a success, more persons must turn out and bet more money than they did at Liberty Bell Park's opening night.
BOSTON, June 7 (AP)--Gov. Endicott Peabody proposed to the legislature today a dozen bills to increase taxation and impose tight restrictions on racing at agricultural Pairs.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has asked the United States District Court here to enjoin Paul Richter, as an individual and doing business as Meade. Co., 27 William Street, from allegedly breaking S.E.C. regulations. These include the commission's net capital requirement, bookkeeping and hypothecation rules.

WASHINGTON, June 7-- Whispered Soviet threats of a boycott against the United Nations have been received calmly here as merely the first, predictable signs of a major constitutional crisis now brewing in the world organization.
The Marine Midland Corporation, New York State's only bank holding company, his making another bid to enter rapidly-growing Suffolk County, L.I.

To stress the selectivity of its vintage screen fare, the Bleecker Street Cinema near West Broadway in Greenwich Village, is planning a series of 52 movie "classics" as a "summer revival showcase" from June 21 through Sept, 26.
WASHINGTON, June 6-- Lincoln White, "the State Department spokesman," is giving up spokesmanship.

LOS ANGELES, June 7-- Shaw's "Heartbreak House" made its professional debut in Los Angeles on Wednesday through the Theater Group, which has become one of the best sources of legitimate theater on the West Coast.
EASTHAMPTON, L.I., June 7--The object of the Off Soundings Club is simply stated in the constitution: "To promote good fellowship between men actively interested in sailing." That's all.
CHICAGO, June 7--A French destroyer with a crew of 300 docked at the Michigan Avenue Bridge today to shouts of "Vive la, France!"
WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) -The Federal Communications Commission was advised today to refuse a license renewal to two men involved in the 1959 scandal over fixed quiz programs.
Broadway and Off Broadway had mixed feelings yesterday about the State Attorney General's investigation of theatrical financing.

Dennis S. Farber, who was to have graduated as a physician from the State University of New York Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn, next Wednesday, died suddenly Thursday in Brooklyn Jewish Hospital after receiving a pollen injection for nay fever.

"Open End," which left New York television under stormy circumstances last month, will return tomorrow from 6:30 to 8:30 P.M. for a special interview--with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on Channel 11.

CHICAGO, June 7 (AP)--The Los Angeles Dodgers, aided by consecutive home runs by Frank Howard and John Roseboro and the steady pitching of Don Drysdale, beat the Cubs, 4--1, today. The loss snapped Chi
The State Commission for Human Fights pressed yesterday for an early report from the city on whether a deputy city commissioner had specified "white only" in seeking an employe.

MANILA, June 7--Indonesia and the Philippines relaxed today their firm opposition to the proposed merger of Malaya, Singapore and three Britishheld territories of the island of Borneo into a new state to be called Malaysia.
MOSCOW, June 7--Britain has warned the Soviet Union that there are "alarming indications" that the pro-Communist Pathet Lao forces may be planning to resume offensive action in Laos.
LOS ANGELES, June 7-- President Kennedy switched his attention to politics here tonight after two days of learning what a Commander in Chief needs to know about the Navy's weapons.
ROME, June 7--Movie theaters have been empty' and churches have been crowded since the death of Pope John XXIII on Monday.

An erstwhile butler for Lowell M. Birrell, fugitive financier, flatly contradicted a dozen times yesterday in United States District Court the sworn testimony of Gerardo A. (Jerry) Re before the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The Department of the Army moved here yesterday to hire more Negroes and Puerto Ricans in this area.
WASHINGTON, June 7-- Representative John J. Rooney, Democrat of Brooklyn, who has stalled many a State Department appropriation, has finally stopped a train.

Takeover rumors involving the Canadian Pacific Railway Company drifted down to Wall Street from north of the border yesterday. But the top officer of Canada's mightiest stockholderowned transport system said there was no substance to these reports.

Hobart Taylor Jr., executive vice chairman of the President's Committee on Equal Employment said here yesterday that equality of job opportunity was dependent "on equality of opportunity in education and training."
Hyman D. Siegel's complaint that his law office had been "bugged" by the District Attorney was rejected by State Supreme Court Justice Abraham N. Gellinoff.
A shipping exchange pact between the United States and Venezuela has been denounced by Caracas because of delays by a United States Federal agency eight months after the agreement was signed.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 7-- Teheran was quiet but tense today after two days of riots, looting, street fighting and clashes between supporters of the majority Shiite Moslem sect and the security forces.
PARIS, June 7--Three French cave explorers reached safety today after being trapped underground by flooding since last Sunday. One of their two companions remains lost.

REDDING; Conn., June 7-- Miss Marjorie Wray Patterson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Calvin Patterson, was married here this afternoon to Charles Edward Westergaard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Christian James Westergaard of Warren, Mich.
ROME, June 7--Pope John XXIII once said in a letter to his family that "the honor of a Pope does not consist of making his family rich."
Today is the feast of your great patron saint, that of your true and proper name which is Francis Xavier, as our uncle was called and now happily our nephew Zaverio.
CHICAGO, June 7 (UPI)-- Wheat ended firm to strong while most other gran futures were mixed today on the Board of Trade.

MOSCOW, June 7 (UPI)-- Premier Khrushchev declared in an interview published today that the Soviet Union was keeping nuclear rockets trained on Mediterranean nations that harbor United States nuclear submarines.
The Kroger Company, the nation's third-largest food chain, is planning to acquire Market Basket, a California supermarket chain, for about $21,500,000.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 7-- George Sholty, the 108-pound driver-trainer who aspired to be a jockey in his youth, did a surprising amount of jockeying for position tonight as he guided J.R. Rick's Royal Rick to victory in the $25,000 Adios Butler Cup at Roosevelt Raceway.
BALTIMORE, Md., June 7--Here in the heart of the free state the overdue revolt against the tyranny of the transistor radio has at last begun.

WASHINGTON, June 7 The ultimate implications of North American minority extremists are not yet fully understood. Lunatic fringe terrorists among French-speaking Canadians, known as the Quebec Liberation Front. (F.L.Q.), want to partition Canada: Right-wing fanatics among
LOS ANGELES, June 7-- Richard M. Nixon bade a cheerful, appreciative farewell today to his native state, noting he was shifting his roots after 50 years.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 7 (AP)--President Ngo Dinh Diem, broadcasting an appeal for calm, conceded today that some of his officials lacked "sufficient comprehension and sensitivity" in dealing with the Buddhist crisis.

Glory struck the New York Mets just as suddenly and unexpectedly last night as disas ter usually does. Duke Snider smashed a three-run homer off Diomedes Olivo with one out in the ninth inning. With that one swing, he turned an impending ignominious defeat into a 3-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

HOUSTON, June 7 (AP)-- Nate Adams of Purdue, the Big Ten sprint champion, rallied in the last 10 yards tonight to win the 100-yard dash in the United States Track and Field Federation's first championships. His time was 9.4 seconds.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., June 7--Negro leaders here have agreed to halt demonstrations until next Tuesday to await action by the City Commissioners on demands for total integration.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 7--The Secretary General, U Thant, announced today that the long-delayed peace-keeping operation in Yemen would begin immediately.

NORFOLK, Va., june 7(UPI) -The report of a Navy-court of inquiry into the sinking of the nuclear submarine Thresher arrived here by plane today for review by Adm. Harold Page Smith, Atlantic Fleet commander.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 (AP)--Representatives of two cargo ships that crashed off Point Reyes Tuesday night are moving toward another collision -in Federal Court.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) --Mrs. Frances G. Knight, director of the passport division, was rebuked by her State Department superior for holding a glamour show for her office girls during the Cuban crisis last year.
LEXINGTON, N.C., June 7 --Tension mounted in North Carolina tonight following a race riot in which one white man was killed.

In the absence of signs to the contrary, it was widely assumed that the Democratic party had learned to get along very well without Carmine G. De Sapio, the deposed Tammany boss. The first contradiction of this assumption comes from a somewhat unexpected quarter.

Canadian Industrial Gas, Ltd., Toronto, announced yesterday that it will issue a new 5 per cent cumulative preference stock at $10 par. The issue is convertible until 1973 on the basis of five preference shares for four common shares.
ROME, June 7--The first of nine solemn masses for Pope John XXIII was said in St. Peter's Basilica this morning while in a crypt below the faithful gathered to pray at his temporary tomb.

The worst victims of our continuing failure to curb national unemployment are youngster s seeking their first steady jobs. Eighteen out of every hundred teen-agers who wanted to work last month could find no one who wanted them. This was more than triple the jobless rate among older workers-a rate itself inexcusably high.

Ojibway Indians and French fur traders shot the rapids in diminutive canoes that pitched and rolled dangerously on the churning waters.

Recent developments in the Southwest Pacific have made this year's Anzus meeting the most important for some time. LIMA, Peru, June 10 Fernando Belaunde Terry has won Peru's Presidential election, according to unofficial but conclusive returns from yesterday's voting.

The British pound eased on the New York foreign exchange market yesterday in what some traders described as a reaction to the political crisis caused by the resignation of John Profumo as British Secretary of State for War.
George A. Hormel Co., meat packer, had a 21.8 per cent drop in earnings for the, six months ended April 27, despite a 2.7 per cent gain in tonnage, the semiannual report disclosed yesterday.

The musical instruments industry, which has more than doubled its sales in the last decade, is combining upto-date merchandising methods with new manufacturing techniques to push its volume to more than $650,000,000 this year.
KNITS and crepes can be the mainstay of a year-round wardrobe, and the new collection at Lord Taylor is priced to permit even the budgeter to invest in more than one.
Tracy Stallard, a reluctant baseball immortal two years ago at the age of 24, won the first complete game he has ever pitched in the major leagues last night at the Polo Grounds.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that it was obvious someone was not telling the truth about the selection of a Republican candidate for councilman at large in Manhattan.
The United States Lines, along with a major airline and two large travel organizations, has opened an experimental drive to stimulate off-season trans-Atlantic travel.
THERE is an apprehensive perhaps a mournful note in much of the literature of nature today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 10 Forty-six nationally prominent lawyers called on Gov. George C.Wallace of Alabama today to obey the law on integration at the University of Alabama.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y,, June 10 Members of the State Bar Association heard today a prediction that a recent United States Supreme Court decision aiding impoverished defendants marked the beginning of "a revolution in the administration of criminal justice in this country."
WASHINGTON, June 10President Kennedy appealed to Gov. George C. Wallace today to stay away from the campus of the University of Alabama.

NASHVILLE, June 10 (AP) James R. Hoffa stood silent in Federal District Court today as a plea of not guilty was entered for him on charges of trying to influence the jury in his conspiracy trial last year.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 10 (AP) Happy Angle, a 5-yearold son of Johns Joy, set a world record for five furlongs on the turf today when he covered the distance in 58 seconds at Monmouth Park.
WASHINGTON, June 10 Rental sales were steady in May for the third consecutive month, according to a preliminary report published today by the Commerce Department.
The Housing and Redevelopment Board sought Federal funds yesterday to plan extensive urban renewal of a 102-acre tract in upper Manhattan.

PARIS, Tuesday, June 11 The Paris Playhouse Company won a warm welcome last night at the Charles de Rochefort Theatre in two works by the American playwright Edward Albee "The Zoo Story" and "The Death of Bessie Smith."

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) Agriculture Department reports indicated today that wheat production this year would be perhaps 10 per cent less than domestic and foreign demand but not enough less to make more than a small dent in existing surplus stocks.
The Defense Department has designated four Harlem tenements with a long history of health and building code violations as fallout shelters.

IF women bird watchers are suitably dressed to stalk the red-eyed vireo, they usually look thrown together or mannish. If they wear an ensemble inspired by a fashion magazine, they are likely to scare the birds. It is a clothes problem that Elizabeth Phelps would like to solve.
WASHINGTON, June 10 The Supreme Court agreed today to hear four more sit-in cases, thus assuring a substantial legal test of the Negro protest movement.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 10 President Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan of India declared at the United Nations today that world peace required the elimination of political domination, economic exploitation and racial discrimination.
IN THE late nineteen-forties, homemakers across the na tion were pouring the first of the new "miracle" detergents into their laundry machines and everything was coming out whiter than white.

ALBANY, June 10 The State Thruway Authority, using powers it has had since 1952, made a dawn attack today on billboards it considered offensive along the 559-mile super-highway.
New Yorkers wandering the streets of Paris, Rome, London and wherever this summer will know they are there because suddenly they will come upon an unexpected little square or park.
The Greeks have a word for nearly everything. And they are offering one now that may be the answer for companies seeking a way around tariff barriers of the European Common Market.

A Presbyterian minister told a group of public health physicians and nurses yesterday that the church could not be proud of the "irrelevant moralism" with which, he said, it approaches the necessity of sex education.
MOSCOW, June 10 Premier Khrushchev said today that the Soviet Union had terminated the production of strategic bombers and surface warships because of their vulnerability to missile attack.

The manner of awarding defense contracts in the Pentagon is still a major issue in the continuing investigation of the now famous TFX experimental tactical fighter.
WASHINGTON, June 10 The Federal Government today began another effort to get the nuclear vessel Savannah, the world's first atom-powered merchant ship, off the shoals of labor strife.

WASHINGTON, June 10 An Italian Nobel Prize winner suggested today that synthetic food products that could be manufactured cheaply on a large scale would be a beneficial "treatment" for world hunger and malnutrition.

ESCALANTE, Utah, June 10 Eight Boy Scouts, two of their leaders and a woman reporter were killed tonight when their open-bed farm truck rolled over on a rugged dirt road in remote mountain country south of here.
Expanded cooperation among states with transportation problems was urged yesterday by Gov. John N. Dempsey of Connecticut.
WASHINGTON, June 10 The Supreme Court struck down today a Missouri law prohibiting strikes against public utilities seized by the state.

Dow Finsterwald, a former Professional Golfers Association champion, shot a 69, 64 133 at the Clovernook Country Club in Cincinnati yesterday and led a group of 30 players qualifying for the United States Open championship.

WASHINGTON, June 10 Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower told the American Booksellers Association tonight that in his new book, to be published in the fall, he would try to explain in a broad way the decisions he had made as President.
Stock prices slumped sharply yesterday in a continuation of the decline that began on Friday.
INDIANAPOLIS, June 10 (AP) The United States Auto Club executive committee today placed Eddie Sachs of Detroit on probation for one year for uttering comments it considered detrimental to racing.

Satirical revues are much in vogue nowadays. A new one has just been produced by an unexpected sponsor Life Magazine.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., June 10 Negro leaders charged today that white negotiators here had "double-crossed us." They announced the end of a three-week racial truce and called for "immediate, all-out" demonstrations with the aid of groups from Baltimore and other Eastern cities.
WARSAW, June 10 Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski left Warsaw by train tonight for Rome to attend the conclave that will elect a successor to Pope John XXIII.
Works by Horatio Alger, Hans Christian Andersen and Franz Kafka played a prominent role last evening in the annual scholarship awards of the Society of Illustrators, 128 East 63d Street.

Prices of Government securities advanced on a wide front yesterday in light to moderate volume. High-grade corporate bonds improved in more spirited trading and municipal issues were quiet in routine transactions.
Mayor Wagner was accused in a court action yesterday of playing conflicting public and private roles in planning a playground in Riverside Park.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 10 The Soviet Union demanded today that the Security Council assume complete responsibility for financing the proposed United Nations observer group in Yemen. Other members of the Council feared that a Soviet veto of the observer plan would follow if the Council did not accede.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 10 Public school officials today asked a special five-judge Federal Appeals Court to throw out an injunction forbidding a Virginia county to close its schools to prevent integration.

Steel production declined sharply last week. Industry observers speculated that in view of a safe level of inventories and the industry's improved picture, the expected downturn in production was under way.

WASHINGTON, June 9 The New York Yankees' roughest road trip in years is now history. It concluded tonight on a less-than-successful note: All the world champions could do was split a double-header with the American League's lastplace team, the Washington Senators.
ROME, June 10--Workmen on the roof of the Sistine Chapel began placing a long pipe of shiny white metal into position this morning.

WASHINGTON, Pa., June 10 Del Miller, the normally gentle and carefree harnessracing figure, acted this morning as if he were the last angry man in western Pennsylvania.

State Senator George R. Metcalf deplored yesterday the failure of industry to send spokes, men to a public hearing on legislation that would require even the smallest employers in the state to provide "some form of minimal hospitalization insurance" for their employes.
Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Hilton Smith of Houston, New York and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Keith Smith, to Robert Livingston Gerry 3d.
BALTIMORE, June 10 (UPI) Barry Latman pitched and batted the Cleveland Indians to a 3-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.
Sales of Manhattan real estate in the first quarter of this year declined substantially from the level of the previous year. Distress conveyances also were lower this year than last.

WASHINGTON, June 10 President Kennedy's effort today to alter the direction of Soviet-United States relations represented his fundamental and long-held views on the cold war.
BASEL, Switzerland, June 10 The United States got poor grades today for its economic policy from one of the world's most renowned judges, the Bank for International Settlements.

SPA, Belgium, June 10 For the 1961 season, over the anguished protests of the sport itself, the engine size of grand prix race cars was reduced by regulation by 40 per cent, from 2.5-liter capacity to 1.5-liter.
BALTIMORE, June 10 (AP) Seventy tons of bells, destined to peal in Washington from the Washington National Cathedral, arrived here today from Britain.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 10 Gen. Paul D. Harkins has ordered American military advisers to stay away from their assigned South Vietnamese units if those units are used to suppress protest demonstrations by Buddhists.

Each year Dun Bradstreet, Inc., takes a searching look at its statistics on business failures and comments on the trends indicated. Last year 15,782 businesses failed, compared with 17,075 in the preceding year, but the total of liabilities rose ...
Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Doll Ina won the $10,000 feature event at Aqueduct yesterday under a chance-taking ride by Larry Adams. The mile-and-a-sixteenth turf event was for older fillies and mares.

BASEL, Switzerland, June 10 An Austrian accused of being a secret agent for Israel testified at his trial here today that Germans were working in the United Arab Republic to provide that nation with rockets bearing capsules containing radioactive strontium and cobalt.

WASHINGTON, June 10 State law enforcement officers were told by the Supreme Court today that they are subject to the same constitutional limits as Federal officers in making arrests, searches and seizures.
A tempting choice of weding dresses at prices that should please most budgetminded brides is to be found in the fall and winter bridal collection at Stern's.

In the wake of Premier Khrushchev's agreement to new high-level talks on a nuclear test ban treaty has come what could be a first sign that the Soviets are modifying their rule-or-ruin policy in the United Nations. At least they failed to carry out their threat to veto the projected peace mission to Yemen, even though they did not get their way in the Security Council.
The American Museum of Immigration, under construction at the base of the Statue of Liberty, will be completed despite the failure of a broad fund drive, the National Park Service said yesterday.
LONDON, June 11 Prime Minister Macmillan has summoned his Cabinet to meet tomorrow on the Profumo scandal. The conference could be vital in determining whether he will survive as Britain's leader.

The London stock market rallied yesterday, but not enough to recover all of Monday's sharp losses that were touched off by the political crisis in Britain. The Financial Times index of 30 industrial shares advanced 4.6 points to 307.2 yesterday. On Monday, the index plunged 7 points.

Borough President Abe Stark of Brooklyn announced yesterday a comprehensive plan to build an air-conditioned arena with a skating rink, a glassenclosed restaurant and more parking facilities bordering on the Coney Island boardwalk.
The American Football League's plan to help its two have-not teams proved to be a dud yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 11 Ralph McGill, editor of The Atlanta Constitution, and Sir Charles Snow British author and scientist, warned the American Booksellers Association today that a distorted "face of America" was being transmitted abroad.

The trans-Atlantic airlines were said yesterday to be considering uniform rates for charter flights, which many carriers believe are unduly diverting passengers from their higher-priced scheduled services.

City College will graduate its largest class since 1950 tonight in Lewisohn Stadium. It will confer 3,541 undergraduate and graduate degrees at its 117th commencement. In 1950 the class numbered 3,710.

ALBANY, June 11 (AP)Governor Rockefeller said today that President Kennedy must use whatever power and authority he considered necessary to "uphold the authority of law and orders of the Federal courts."
WASHINGTON, June 11 President Kennedy's proposals for revision of special tax benefits available to persons over 65 years old were rejected today by the House Ways and Means Committee.
A top official of the City Commission on Human Rights has been officially censured for asking the State Employment Service to supply him with a white secretary.
WASHINGTON, June 11 President Kennedy told the nation tonight that it faced a "moral crisis" as a result of the rising tide of Negro discontent.
LONDON, June 11 A world record for the sale of modern paintings was set tonight in the sweltering auction rooms at Sotheby Co.

The possibility that the city's new tax on commercial rents may prove more costly to landlords than to tenants, who must pay it, has been noted by a real estate executive specializing in commercial leases.

TEANECK, N.J., June 11 The marriage of Miss Abby Victoria Binger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Binger, to Ady Selinger took place here this evening. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Schmuel Selinger of New York and Kfar Saba, Israel.
WASHINGTON, June 11 President Kennedy has chosen W. Averell Harriman to lead United States efforts to reach a nuclear test-ban agreement at new three-power negotiations in Moscow next month.
Trading in Government securities was light yesterday during the one-day subscription period for the Treasury's new $1,250,000,000 4 per cent, seven-year, two-month bonds.

A majority of the faculty members of the New York City Community College in Brooklyn petitioned the Mayor and the Board of Estimate yesterday to turn the institution over to the Board of Higher Education.

RYE, N.Y., June 11 Seven seeded players, led by the defending champion, Ham Magill of Choate, entered the singles quarter-finals of the 32d Manursing Island Club Eastern interscholastic tennis tournament today.

GARISSA, Kenya, June 4 The semi-desert lying between Nairobi and the Tana River ends abruptly a few miles from the river. There is a band of light green, then a belt of dark green up to the river. The lighter green represents the limits of the river's flooding; the darker green has moisture the year round.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 11 President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam appealed to the nation to remain calm today after a 73-year-old Buddhist priest committed suicide to dramatize the Buddhists' protest against the Government's policies on religion.
Few companies have made more efforts to let the world know it was for sale than the Texas Gulf Producing Company. Perhaps the theory is that the more active the bidders, the bigger the price tag.
The City Planning Commission has begun discussions with Federal officials on getting Federal financial aid for the New York metropolitan region's transit problems.

WASHINGTON, June 11--President Kennedy today called about 300 of the nation's top national, state and local labor leaders to the White House Thursday to discuss eliminating discrimination against Negroes in employment.
PRAGUE, June 11 President Antonin Novotny of Czechoslovakia denied yesterday that he differed with Premier Khrushchev on the policy of deStalinization.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 11 The Board of Education voted unanimously tonight to close the predominantly Negro Lincoln Elementary School on June 30.

There is an end of the line for every railroad, and there must be an end of the line for the long dispute over featherbedding on the nation's railroads. Postponing a showdown, as Secretary of Labor Wirtz has just done, is pointless unless there is some basis for believing that the rail unions are at long last ready to abandon their veto of all proposals for a voluntary solution.

EIGHT Sports Car Club of America national cham pionship races will be conducted on the Lime Rock, (Conn.) course on Friday and Saturday. All events, under direction of the New England region of the club, will be at 40 laps over the 1.5-mile circuit.

Ship engineers who walked out on the nuclear ship Savannah and brought about the layup of the world's first atompowered merchant vessel yesterday called upon all American maritime unions to help stop Government interference with maritime collective bargaining.

WASHINGTON, June 11--Secretary of State Dean Rusk cautioned the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that it would write "a prescription of defeat" by ordering material reductions in President Kennedy's $4,500,000,000 foreign aid program.
Genuine school integration can be achieved only by a program comparable in scope and urgency to the space program, a Board of Education report suggested yesterday.
As Governor and Chief Magistrate of the State of Alabama, I deem it to be my solemn obligation and duty to stand before you representing the rights and sovereignty of this state and its peoples.

MANILA, June 11--Indonesia, Malaya and the Philippines announced plans today for a mutual defense pact against subversion "in any form or manifestation." By implication, the agreement is aimed at Communist China.
The Yanks will look more like the Yanks tonight when they open a two-game stand in the Stadium against the Baltimore Orioles.
NEWARK, June 11 Anthony (Tony Pro) Provenzano, a vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was convicted tonight of having extorted $17,100 from a trucking company.

WASHINGTON, June 11 Air travel gave a quantum jump to personal diplomacy. Secretary Dulles's frequent journeys once provoked acerb comments about motion being no substitute for policy. But the shrinking world has since become accustomed to movement by leading statesmen for purposes either of negotiation or propaganda.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 11 Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran said today that general elections would be held at end of the summer despite widespread rioting last week against the Government's land reform program.
WASHINGTON, June 11--The Senate and House conferees were deadlocked tonight on how $73,000,000 in Philippines World War II damage claims should be paid.

Nelson A. Rockefeller built his official reputation for fiscal integrity in his first year as Governor with his straightforward approach to the problems of taxation. Much unwarranted damage was done to his popularity by his courage in initiating tax withholding and tax increases to put the state on pay-as-you-go.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 11--The Iraqi Army prepared today for a drive to crush Mullah Mustafa al-Barzani's Kurdish forces in the northern mountains.

Georges Wildenstein, author, art dealer, collector and historian, died yesterday at his home in Paris. He was 71 years old.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 11 The courts of New York and other states must eventually be freed from the burden of jury trials of accident cases, Chief Judge Charles S. Desmond of the Court of Appeals said today.
A 74-year-old landlord was fined $700 yesterday for 14 housing violations in an East Side tenement.

WASHINGTON, June 11 Senator John L. McClellan, speaking out on the substance of the TFX controversy for the first time, said today that the issue had been drawn: Whether to obtain the best possible military plane or try for "dubious" economizing.
The City Council decided, 21 to 2, yesterday that 18 was a better age than 21 for applicants to qualify for jobs in 39 occupations officially recognized by the city as hazardous.

OTTAWA, June 11 (Canadian Press) The Air Defense commands of the Royal Canadian Air Force and United States Air Force have signed an agreement to enable American interceptors to use more readily and with greater safety 22 Canadian airfields, authorities disclosed today.
Following is the text of President Kennedy's nationwide broadcast last night, as recorded by The New York Times: Good evening, my fellow citizens.
ALBANY, June 11 A growing demand among upstate Republicans for a special session of the Legislature to draw new Senate lines and reapportion Assembly seats was reported today.
ROME, June 11--All five United States Cardinals participated today for the first time in the daily meetings of Cardinals held in the Vatican since the death of Pope John XXIII.
WASHINGTON, June 11The Kennedy Administration moved smoothly and without undue excitement today through its third major racial crisis.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 11 President Kennedy's speech aimed at breaking the "vicious and dangerous cycle" of the cold war has been widely welcomed here.

Harvard University Press is preparing to salute Independence Day by firing off the first two volumes of the "Adams Family Correspondence (17611778)" on July 4. This series, expected to include some 20 volumes, will eventually cover 130 years of history.
Disturbed by a "lack of guidance afforded to young talent in the performing arts today," Harry Belafonte is quietly lending a hand to several promising musicians.
DANVILLE, Va., June 11City officials were considering a strict curfew today to deal with Southside Virginia's first determined Negro effort to obtain equal rights by demonstrations.

DALLAS, June 11 (AP) Directors of Producing Properties, Inc., approved plans yesterday for liquidating the company through transactions involving $52,000,000.
Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson called yesterday for the spending of $2,000,000,000 in the next 10 years to build facilities to control water pollution in New York State.
The stock market turned around yesterday after Monday's sharp decline and made a small advance, but it did so in lighter trading.
ATHENS, June 11 Premier Constantine Caramanlis resigned tonight because King Paul had rejected his advice to call off a state visit by the King and Queen to Britain next month.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 Vice Adm. John Herbert Brown Jr., retired commandant of the Fourth Naval District and an all-America football star, died yesterday at his home in Middletown, Del. He was 71 years old.

Forgery was a routine part of the stock fraud swindle allegedly carried out by Gerardo A. (Jerry) Re, his son, Gerard F., Lowell M. Birrell and others seven years ago, witnesses testified yesterday in United States District Court.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 11 Industrial production continued to grow rapidly in Asia last year, the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East reports in its annual survey.

The constitutional status of Puerto Rico remains unfinished business 65 years after the island was liberated from Spain. A subcommittee of the House Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs recently embarked on a new effort to define a permanent relationship, but it has already bogged down in acrimonious arguments and in language that was sometimes insulting to Governor Munoz Marin and the Puerto Rican people.
"Cleopatra," the longest, costliest and most publicized motion picture ever made, will have its world premiere at 8 o'clock tonight at the Rivoli Theater.
BONN, June 11, Franz Josef Strauss, former Defense Minister, who just returned from a controversial visit to Israel, called today for West Germany to exchange ambassadors with that country.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York was asked yesterday to reconsider the qualifications of Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan for a post as Civil Court judge.

Colorado Interstate Gas Company intends to file with the Federal Power Commission by next Monday a revised plan for supplying natural gas to the Denver and Colorado markets. This will be, to a certain extent, a replacement for the $151,000,000 Rock Springs Pipeline project that was turned down by the F.P.C. May 1.

Philip D. Crockett, chairman of the Arden Farms Company, the nation's fifth largest dairy products company, said yesterday the new controlling group of directors aims at "straightening out the affairs of the company."
MINEOLA, L.I., June 11 A proposed code of ethics for officials and employes of Nassau County was made public today by County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson.

In the first race at Aqueduct yesterday, a 3-year-old maiden named Bally Maid burst out of the gate and sped down the backstretch in front of 10 rivals.

Net earnings of the United Artists Corporation fell to $578,000 in the first quarter this year from $916,000 in the same period a year ago.
