J.C. Penney Company, department store chain, reported yesterday a decline in earnings for the first quarter, although sales for the period rose to a record peak.

Memo to visiting ready-towear buyers: If you're planning to attend a manufacturer's opening or showing this week, get there early. Otherwise you may not get there on time because the lobbies and elevators on Seventh Avenue are jammed.
The city moved another step forward yesterday in its campaign to improve the piers used by luxury liners and the flow of passengers and baggage.

The Sinclair Oil and Gas Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Sinclair Oil Corporation, has submitted an offer for the domestic producing properties, undeveloped acreage and related assets of the Western Natural Gas Company.
An experimental World College with an international faculty and student body will open this summer on Long Island under the direction of Dr. Harold Taylor, former president of Sarah Lawrence College.
NEWARK, June 11 Three major commuter groups in northern New Jersey today proposed four plans that they contended would solve major transportation problems for the area.

FOUR years ago there died in obscurity in England a lonely woman recluse who was one of the finest writers of fiction yet to come out of South Africa. Pauline Smith never forgot her childhood and adolescence spent as a doctor's daughter in a semi-frontier district inhabited by poor Afrikaner farmers and known as The Little Karoo.

WASHINGTON, June 11--The nation's railroads and the five unions that represent their operating employes agreed today to postpone until Tuesday at 12:01 A. M. at the earliest a possible showdown in their protracted dispute over work rules.

Miss Louise G. Zabriskie, a founder of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies and a former Republican district co-leader in Brooklyn, died yesterday in her home at 1185 Park Avenue. She had observed her 99th birthday on Memorial Day.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., June 11 (AP) Two white men were struck in the chest by shotgun blasts late tonight as racial violence erupted here.

KUCHING, Sarawak, June 10 A new force of border scouts began jungle-warfare training this week as British security officers made a new effort to discourage terrorist raids from Indonesia into Sarawak.

Ben Zuckerman: Other Seventh Avenue houses attract socialites to their fashion openings. This one had a poet. White-haired Marianne Moore, in a bright blue Zuckerman suit, sat among store presidents and buyers, note-taking as avidly as the fashion people.

Jim Maloney, a newcomer to the front rank of National League pitchers, wore himself out yesterday striking out Mets. He had to stop after working eight innings in an 8-3 Cincinnati victory. Jim Owens finished the game for him.
The following listing includes events that have been selected by New York Times critics. For children of all ages unless otherwise noted.
An otherwise quiet and mixed trade in commodity futures was enlivened yesterday by a drop in sugar prices along with a further setback in cocoa prices.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI)--House members today voted for nepotism, "junk" mail, underground parking and their own swimming pool. They defended their budget as modest and said the press was unduly hostile.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 11 Pablo Casals arrived today to conduct the Casals Festival Orchestra tonight in its only performance here. It will be given at the Palacio de Bellas Artes as a "spiritual present" to the Dominican democracy from Puerto Rico's Governor, Luis Munoz Martin, and the Crusade for Peace, which is led by Mr. Casals.
RIVERHEAD, L.I. June 11 Sandpit operators on Long Island are adopting a new policy of rehabilitating the ugly, pitted landscape in an effort to stave off restrictions on their operations.

St. Petersburg, Fla., borrowed yesterday $17,000,000 on utility tax revenue bonds. An investment banking group led by the First Boston Corporation and Shields Co. was awarded the bonds on a bid of 100,022 for various coupons that set an annual net interest cost of 3.2597 per cent.

SPA, Belgium, June 11 A move by France to limit United States capital investment in the European Common Market ran into a stone wall today during a meeting of the finance ministers of the six member nations here.
WASHINGTON, June 11 Robert C.Byrd is a darkly handsome freshman Senator from West Virginia with a talent for pulpit oratory and a poor boy's success story of classical vintage.

ROME, June 11--Aldo Moro, political secretary of the Christian Democratic party and premier-designate, formally asked Pietro Nenni, the Left-Wing Socialist leader, today for his party's support to end the 26-day-old government crisis.
HOUSTON, June 11 (AP)A young Negro has been denied membership here in the First Baptist Church, whose pastor is president of the Southern Baptist Convention.
Merv Griffin, who lost his National Broadcasting Company television show last April, will return with another daytime series in September.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 11 (UPI) Pro-Castro terrorists attacked and burned a Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company warehouse here today. There were no casualties but damage to the North Americanowned property was estimated at $500,000.

Supporters of Capt. William V. Bradley, who is fighting to retain the presidency of the International Longshoremen's Association, struck back yesterday at Thomas W. (Teddy) Gleason, executive vice president of the union.

The City Center of Music and Drama ended its 1962-63 season under its smallest deficit cloud in years. And even that cloud had a silver lining. The financial statement of the City Center Corporation was issued yesterday at the annual meeting of its directors. The center's net loss, for the year ended April 27, came to $114,432,49.
WASHINGTON, June 11 The Administration asked Congress today to create an enlarged Fire Island national seashore that would include 20 miles more of beachfront than anyone had previously suggested.
Two popular novelists, William J. Lederer and Edmund G. Love, are trying their hands at playwriting.

WASHINGTON, June 11 President Kennedy's swift and successful action against Governor George C. Wallace, the King Canute of Alabama, is just the beginning of a bolder White House strategy in the field of Negro civil rights, jobs and retraining.
WASHINGTON, June 11 The steel industry and the United Steelworkers of America were understood today to be close to a history-making agreement on contract revisions.
Either more no-parking signs or more intensive enforcement is needed to end the slowdowns that have been plaguing the "exclusive bus lanes" in Brooklyn, city officials said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) All 13 Republican members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee called today, for a Congressional inquiry into the role played by James B. Donovan, a New York attorney, in the release of prisoners from Communist Cuba.

AN especially convenient arrangement for food shop ping is to be found in a store at 213 East 59th Street. The counters on one side are stocked with a fascinating variety of imported and domestic cheeses. Across the aisle, the display cases are filled with fine French pastries and breads.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 11 Favorites, returning the identical price of $3.80 for $2, won both divisions of the Commodore Trials at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
Sir Alexander Bustamante, Prime Minister of Jamaica, denounced yesterday restrictions on the number of Jamaicans allowed to enter the United States as "an insult to ourselves and our country."

SYRACUSE, June 11 Since Jim Lemmon was elevated to head coach in 1960 upon the retirement of Ky Ebright, the University of California, has won two varsity championships and finished third once in the regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association.
One week last spring, sales of a Beech-Nut chewing gum called Gum Fetti suddenly skyrocketed at the Rogers chain of supermarkets in Fort Wayne, Ind.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 11 In a tense showdown that ended in failure for some of the game's finest players, a relatively obscure golfer carried off top honors today in the sectional qualifying test for next week's United States Open.
CHICAGO, June 11 The journal of the American Academy of Pediatrics today urged a national campaign to tell children that cigarette smoking is "immature, juvenile and silly."

WHILE Vivian Juanita Malone was at Alabama Ag ricultural and Mechanical College at Normal, a town near Huntsville, it occurred to her that since the institution was unaccredited, "it would be a waste of time to finish there."

IN the practice matches the official United States team played last week, preparatory to its trip to St. Vincent, Italy, for the world championship beginning Saturday, the captain of the United States team, John Gerber, said to 6-foot-8-inch Bill Root of New York:

WASHINGTON, June 11 John D. Murchison, former president of the Alleghany Corporation, said today that Alleghany had twice postponed its annual stockholders meeting because he and his associates had considered it possible that Allan P. Kirby might regain control of the company.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 11 (AP) An agreement by leading downtown hotels and motels and most restaurants here to desegregate is seen by Negro leaders as a "major breakthrough, after three years of battling."
HONOLULU, June 11 A move was started today to place the United States Conference of Mayors in opposition to the states' rights position of the secretariat of the Council of State Governments.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, June 11--The police opened fire today on about 1,800 anti-Government demonstrators terrorizing this city in a general strike seven and a half weeks old. It was not immediately clear whether there were casualties.

WASHINGTON, June 11 A new permanent office will be established soon within the Securities and Exchange Commission. It will be charged with making certain that the commission's expanded program for policing securities trading is fully carried out.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 11 With the Soviet Union abstaining, the Security Council voted today to go ahead with a peace-keeping operation under which a 200-man observer team would be sent to Yemen.

A civil rights group announced here yesterday that it planned to picket construction work at Harlem Hospital today, charging discrimination in the building trades against Negroes and Puerto Ricans. The hospital is at 135th Street and Lenox Avenue.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, June 11 Late election returns today showed that the conservative Independence party of Premier Olafur Thors and his coalition partners, the Social Democrats, had won a bare working majority in Parliament. They won 32 of the 60 seats at stake in Sunday's election.

The nation's capital will be the focus of a "massive, militant and monumental sit-in" demonstration this summer unless the Congress acts fast to assure "full equal rights for the Negro now," the Rev. George Lawrence said yesterday.

ROME, June 12 (Comtelburo) --A syndicate of European bankers has negotiated the first issue ever arranged on the London market of dollar bonds to finance the building of Italian superhighways, observers said here tonight.
The rally that began with a bang on the London stock mar ket Tuesday ended with a whimper yesterday.

VIENNA, June 12 (UPI)-- Lev Prchala, a former Czechoslovak general and former millister of the Prague Government to the autonomous CarpathoUkrainian Government, died in the town of Feldbach yesterday at the age of 71.
ALTHOUGH the theater has always been a first love for Lili Darvas, the actress, there is a rival at hand. It is the world of cuisine.

WASHINGTON, June 12-- President Kennedy established today the President's Advisory Council on the Arts as the first governmental body to be specifically concerned with arts, artists and art institutions.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 12--Degrees were granted to 988 graduates at Adelphi College's 67th commencement here today.

NEW CITY, N.Y., June 12--Governor Rockefeller charged today that State Controller Arthur Levitt had been politically motivated in his attack Sunday on state financing practices. The Governor suggested that the attack might have been inspired by the White House.
LONDON, June 12--Admiral of the Fleet Viscount Cunningham of Hyndhope, an outstanding naval leader of World War II, died today in a taxicab. He was 80 years old.
An investigator for the city Alcoholic Beverage Control Board refused to sign a waiver of immunity yesterday in the State Liquor Authority inquiry and Was promptly dismissed from his job.
A decline of 169,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
LONDON, June 12--Britons will start paying less for coal later this year thanks to a "spectacular jump in productivity," in the nationalized coal industry.
The Department of Commerce's call for special pledges of compliance in operating the nuclear liner Savannah got a reply yesterday from the National Maritime Union.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI)--Bertin C. Gamble, chairman of the board of Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., described today some of the negotiations that preceded a stock purchase and option agreement last October involving the Alleghany Corporation.

THE lavish perplexities of high-echelon welfare states are sketched contrastingly in today's books on our table. One is Isak Dinesen's "Ehrengard," a patrician far-away-and-long-ago fable. The other is Andre Couteaux's first novel, "Gentleman in Waiting," an entertaining spoof about a French modern idolator of idleness.

MANILA, June 12--The Philippines celebrated independence day today with a brandnew consciousness of her increasing role in Asian affairs. President Diosdado Macapagal reaffirmed his country's firm alliance with the United States.

DANVILLE, Va., June 12-- Business leaders assumed today the moderate leaderships that has been lacking here during two weeks of sometimes violent incidents between Negro demonstrators and the police, but negotiations with the demonstrators were ruled out.
LONDON, June 12--Behind the brash words and fast fists, Cassius Marcellus Clay, ("the onliest fighter that predicts the exact round") is determined, shrewd, witty, often serious and sometimes wise.

The Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn awarded degrees to 706 graduates last night at its 108th commencement. Dr. Ernst Weber, president of the institute, conferred 421 bachelor's, 234 master's and 51 doctoral degrees. The exercises were held in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
A "family" controversy that could affect the course of publicly supported higher education in Brooklyn will come out into the open at today's meeting of the Board of Estimate.
Acting Mayor Paul R. Screvane ordered an inquiry by a special hearing officer yesterday into charges that a city deputy commissioner had asked for a white secretary.

ALBUQUERQUE, June 12-- Under the cool vigil of the Sandia (watermelon) Mountains and within running distance of the Rio Grande, the 42d National Collegiate track and field championships will come into being tomorrow night at University Stadium.

West Ham United of London got back into contention in the first section of the International Soccer League by beating Oro, the champion of Mexico, 3--1, at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, last night.
WASHINGTON, June 12--The House of Representatives defeated today an Administration bill to strengthen the two-year-old program for helping economically distressed areas combat unemployment.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 12 (UPI)--A special three-judge Federal court dismisses today a suit brought by a big-city interests to reapportion the Ohio Legislature.

BRISTOL, England, June 12 (UPI)--Chuck McKinley, America's top-ranked tennis player, advanced to the quarterfinals of the West of England championship today by defeating Ed Rubinoff of Miami Beach. The scores were 6--1, 6--3.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 12 (UPI)--Bolivia will withdraw permanently from the Organization of American States because of the organization's failure to resolve a border river dispute, the Bolivian Foreign Ministry announced today.
AN ACQUAINTANCE of Richard Steere Aldrich who was asked to describe him said he was "a big, shaggy guy who always looks like he needed a haircut and had slept in his suit."

WASHINGTON, June 12-- Proposals to get the United States and Western Europe back on the track toward economic cooperation were submitted to President Kennedy and other allied leaders today by the Atlantic Institute.
The market for Treasury securities was dominated yesterday by trading in the "when issued" new 4s of 1970.
WASHINGTON, June 12-- The Kennedy Administration appeared headed today for political trouble unless it can soon head off a new dispute among Southwestern states over Colorado River water.

ALBANY, June 12--Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, was urged today to order the Malverne School District to reorganize attendance areas to end what was called de facto segregation.
A man who has served as State Health Commissioner under three New York Governors told his associates yesterday that they must choose between improving their performance and reducing their budgets.

PARIS, June 12--Italy's national airline, Alitalia, ordered an automatic landing system today for its fleet of 16 Caravelle jet aircraft. It is the first airline in the world to accept the recently developed equipment.

Sargent Shriver, director of the Peace Corps, told 1,502 graduates at Fordham University's 118th commencement yesterday that the separation of church and state did not mean "the divorce of spiritual values from secular affairs."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 12-- The Iraqi Army was advancing today from Erbil, Kirkuk and Sulaimaniya in an attempt to reach Ruwandiz and assault the main centers of strength of Gen. Mustafa al-Barzani's Kurdish forces in northeastern Iraq.
PARIS, June 12--A manysided program to improve the French capital market has been recommended to the Minister of Finance by a special committee that has studied the matter for nearly a year.

WASHINGTON, June 12-- An inter-American committee recommended today an appeal to Haiti to observe "the principle of respect for human rights." The committee warned that violations could threaten Haiti's peace with the Dominican Republic.

Republican leaders in 11 upstate counties have endorsed State Supreme Court Justice Felix J. Aulisi of Amsterdam for nomination for associate judge of the Court of Appeals, the Montgomery County chairman said yesterday.
STAATSBURG, N. Y., June 12--Thirty thousand dollars was restored to the budget of the Taconic State Park Commission today, enabling the full operation of four parks this season.
Two strong supporters of Senator Jacob K. Javits were reported yesterday ready to serve on the campaign committee for Richard Lewisohn for Republican Councilman at Large in Manhattan.

Harvey Aluminum, Inc., of Torrance, Calif., will share a 49 per cent interest in a new Norwegian aluminum company formed by Norsk-Hydro, of Oslo, it was announced yesterday. The Norwegian concern will hold the remaining 51 per cent.
ROME, June 12--Pope John XXIII chose the epitaph he wished on his tomb in 1939, it was disclosed today.
SAVANNAH, Ga., June 12-- Several hundred Negroes marched from headquarters of the Chatham County Crusade for Voters into downtown Savannah tonight in a demand for full desegregation.

WASHINGTON, June 12-- The Port of New York has been forced to hold up vital channel improvements because of delays in studies by the United States Army Engineers, it was charged today.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, June 12--Anti-Government demonstrations continued here today. Four men were shot by policemen who fired into a crowd reported to... have been converging on Prime Minister Cheddi B. Jagan's automobile as he was leaving Parliament.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 12--The Soviet Union challenged today the generally accepted doctrine that a member two years in arrears on its assessments automatically loses its vote in the General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, June 12-- High Navy officers told the Senate today that they had been overruled in the award of a contract for a new type of vertical or short-takeoff-and-landing airplane. They said they had recommended a cheaper and better plane than the one selected by the Defence Department.
WASHINGTON, June 12 --President Kennedy, continuing to push ahead on the civil rights front, talked with former President Dwight D. Eisenhower today about the turbulent racial situation.

ROME, June 12--Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, Roman Catholic primate of Poland, arrived today to attend the conclave at which a new pope will be elected.

The 8-to-1 decision puts police and prosecutors on notice that their methods of arrest and detention will be subject to Supreme...

LONDON, June 12--President Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan of India was the guest of Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip today for lunch and dinner at Buckingham Palace. The 75-year-old Indian leader arrived today for a 12-day state visit.
WARSAW, June 12--Czechoslovakia's Communist regime faces a full-scale cultural revolt by artists and writers, according to reports published this week in the Polish press.

City employer were warned in an order from City Hall yesterday not to buy property from the city. The ban includes the purchase of any of the surplus real estate that the city periodically sells at public auction.
ROME, June 12--President Kennedy will arrive here on the evening of June 30 for a 48-hour visit, Pierre Salinger, the White House press secretary, said today.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 12 --Poverty would cease to be a sizable problem in the United States if the nation's economy regained its early postwar rate of growth, President Kennedy's chief economic adviser said today.
HONOLULU, June 12--With only token opposition from a few Southerners, the Conference of Mayors approved today the civil rights program outlined by President Kennedy here last Sunday.

WASHINGTON, June 12--The Government Printing Office, which is one of the world's biggest publishing plants, has just compiled its own guide to American reading tastes, and to read it is to feel a little bit better about the state of the Republic.

MONTREAL, June 12 (UPI) --A five-man coroner's jury today found 21 alleged members of the terrorist Quebec Liberation Front criminally responsible for the April 20 bomb-death of an army night watchman.

The Gulf American Land Corporation announced yesterday an agreement to purchase a "substantial block" of the common stock of Fenestra, Inc. Leonard Rosen, president of Gulf American, a Florida land development company, said that the acquisition would be made as "an investment."

PARIS, June 12--France's Foreign Minister declared tonight that despite profound changes in relations with the United States, the new Europe, based on French-German cooperation, was "a truly valuable partner" in the Atlantic community.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., June 12 --Two Negro students moved through the bustle of the first day of classes at the University of Alabama today without escort or incident.
LONDON, June 12--Gavin Astor, publisher of The Times of London, praised the masscirculation newspapers today for their role in the Profumo affair.

BASEL, Switzerland, June 12 (Reuters)--Two Israelis received nominal sentences of two months in prison tonight after they were found guilty of having threatened a West German rocket expert because he was working for the United Arab Republic.

The spotlight was on "Cleopatra" last night as 10,000 persons massed around the Rivoli Theater for the motion picture's world premiere. The police said this was a record crowd for a Manhattan movie opening.
Modification of the bail system to reduce the number of women who are held in jail while awaiting trial was recommended yesterday by Deputy Mayor Charles H. Tenney.
The tangled affairs of Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., have become more complex, it was disclosed yesterday in the New York Stock Exchange's report on insiders' stockholdings.
MOSCOW, June 12--Izvestia published tonight the text of President Kennedy's speech on Monday in which he appealed for re-examination of attitudes toward the cold war.
WASHINGTON, June 12-- The House Ways and Means Committee moved today to make a popular tax-escape hatch less attractive to the chain stores, chain restaurants and other such concerns that use it.
The head of the National Aeronautics and Space Agency, James E. Webb, has officially closed out that series of spectaculars that went under the title Project Mercury.

KAMUELA, Hawaii, June 12--On this dot of land in the mid-Pacific, 5,500 miles from the nation's best-known preparatory schools on the East Coast, a schoolmaster plans to introduce Greek next fall as a standard course in a boys' academy.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 12--An expected reduction in savings and loan interest rates to depositors is setting in here.

Nearly 4,000 tons of food and medicine, the final shipment in the $53,000,000 Red Cross-Cuban exchange for prisoners, were lying on a Philadelphia pier yesterday.

Roger Maris, who used to concentrate exclusively on pulling home runs into right field, stroked a single into left field at the Yankee Stadium last night.

WOODBRIDGE, Conn., June 12 Miss Barbara Ann Botwmik was married here last evening to Michael Edward Zirlen. Her twin, Miss Helaine Joan Botwinik, was married at the same ceremony to Lawrence Martin Lipsher.

SALEM, Mass., June 12 (AP) --Cromwell A.B. Halvorson, inventor and pioneer in the field of mass illumination, died here yesterday at the age of 80. He retired in 1946 from the General Electric Company after 48 years of service as an illumination engineer.
The rehabilitation of Washington Square Park moved a step nearer reality yesterday when the Department of Parks was authorized to hire consulting engineers to draw plans.
AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, June 12--There is more bridge activity per capita in this country than in the United States.

It is of the time Bob Meusel of the Yankees stole home in the 1921 World Series.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, June 12--Iceland's Communists have announced an all-out attempt to smash the coalition Government's stabilization program.

The Society or Motion Picture and Television Engineers has leased the second floor in the building at 9 East 41st Street and most of the second floor in the adjoining building at 15 East 41st Street. The wall between the floors will be removed and the two areas made into a space of 4,500 square feet.

ANGOULEME, France, June 12--President de Gaulle began the 1965 French Presidential campaign today. At the start of a strenuous five-day whistlestop tour of west central France, the President asked the French people to continue, after he had gone, the policies he had laid down, by choosing a man pledged to follow them.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 12--Bitter opposition was raised today to an expanded version ot a proposed Fire Island National Seashore that would include 21 miles of beachfront into this resort township.
There is a possibility that "I Picked a Daisy," the first musical collaboration by Richard Rodgers and Alan Jay Lerner, will not open on schedule at the Majestic Theater.
Stock prices climbed sharply in active trading yesterday. A late-afternoon round of profit taking trimmed gains profit their highest levels of the day.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 12 --The Stanwich Congregational Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage

Miss Judith Averill Rose, daughter of the Very Rev. Lawrence Rose, Dean of the General Theological Seminary, and Mrs. Rose of 175 Ninth Avenue, Chelsea Square, was married here yesterday morning to Thomas Bullene Woodward. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Brinton Webb Woodward of Topeka, Kan., and Tucson, Ariz.
MILWAUKEE, June 12 (AP) --James Donovan said last night he had acted as a private citizen in negotiating for the exchange of Cuban prisoners.

ONE of the recurring, if infrequent, pleasures of theater-going is to watch skilled and disciplined hands transform a drama of marked sentimentality into a believable occasion of warmth and sincerity. Thanks to Lynn Fontanne, Alfred Lunt and Donald Madden, such was the case last night on Channel 2 in "The Old Lady Shows Her Medals," a presentation that also terminated the Theater Guild's 18 years in radio and television.

The Canada Dry Corporation had record sales in the six months ended March 31, but earnings were slightly loss than in the period a year earlier, according to the report issued yesterday by Roy W. Moore Jr., president.

WEST REDDING, Conn., June 12--John M. Behan, who operates a training school for dogs here and on East 86th Street in New York under the name of Canine College, does not agree with those who think that just anybody can produce a mannerly dog from...

A nationwide housing movement for Negro integration in local communities has made significant progress in the last three years, the National Committee Against Discrimination in Housing reported today.

The Peruvian election has come and gone, somewhat marred by a stupid stunt of sending blank papers instead of ballots to three states, but the result was clear. Fernando Belaunde Terry is the winner by such a margin that all the missing ballots would make no difference.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 12 --Radcliffe College granted Harvard degrees for the first time today to 290 seniors at its 81st commencement exercises.
LONDON, June 12--Three of Prime Minister Macmillan's Cabinet ministers were reliably reported tonight after a Cabinet meeting to be considering resigning over the Profumo scandal.

News that expert testimony had put the value of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., at a level more than five times what the city is willing to pay for the property set off frenzied tracking in the bus company's stock yesterday. Word of the evaluation reached Wall Street soon after noon.
"WHAT was he really like?" Is a question that has fas cinated more than one American when reading a biography of a President.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 12--Francis Kirk Johnson, who started as a wildcat prospector and became president and chairman of the Ambassador Oil Corporation, died of a heart attack today at the Beverly Wilshire Hotel, He was 67 years old.
Buildings Commissioner Harold Birns accused some Staten Island builders last night of turning over new homes to purchasers before certificates of occupancy were issued.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., June 12 --A new nuclear energy development may help in determining the cause of some airplane crashes.

On the eve of his departure for Hawaii Mayor Wagner announced a new program of action against slum landlords. "There is no excuse for the degrading conditions of deteriorated disrepair under which some landlords of jaded conscience force New Yorkers to live," said the Mayor.
Convinced that he was going nowhere as a vagabond and hardly enchanted with his subsequent employment as a doorto-door salesman of vacuum cleaners, Louis Nathanson concluded more than a decade ago
CAMBRIDGE, Md., June 12-- Singing Negroes staged repeated parades through a white area of this Eastern Shore town tonight.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 12--The American Shake speare Festival Theater does not, praise be, walk hat in hand in the presence of "The Comedy of Errors." It romps and roars through the youthful farce in the exuberant high spirit in which it was composed.

SYRACUSE, June 12--The Cornell eight-oared crews arrived at Onondaga Lake today and found they were favored in the poll of the coaches to sweep all three races in the regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association Saturday.
The Rockefeller Institute honored a scientist and a humanist yesterday, each of whom was cited for having contributed to the advancement of scientific knowledge.
"WHAT was he really like?" Is a question that has fas cinated more than one American when reading a biography of a President.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 12--Francis Kirk Johnson, who started as a wildcat prospector and became president and chairman of the Ambassador Oil Corporation, died of a heart attack today at the Beverly Wilshire Hotel, He was 67 years old.
Buildings Commissioner Harold Birns accused some Staten Island builders last night of turning over new homes to purchasers before certificates of occupancy were issued.
The London stock market continued to decline yesterday as a result of Britain's political crisis.
WASHINGTON, June 13-- The House of Representatives approved today the continuation for another year of special tax rates that produce about $4,000,000,000 in annual revenue for the government.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 13--George A. Murphy will assume the presidency of the New York State Bankers Association tomorrow in circumstances that appear to put a premium on diplomatic rather than financial talents.
Acting Mayor Paul R. Screvane called a halt yesterday to work on the Harlem Hospital annex for reasons of "public safety" and to permit an inquiry into charges of discrimination in hiring.

WASHINGTON, June 13--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today gave the most critical examination in recent years to foreign military aid programs and continued United States financial support of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization members in Western Europe.

In this supersonic age, the airlines chafe at the long time it takes bureaucrats to make a decision. Unlike the railroads, they are not accustomed to slow-moving organizations like, the Interstate Commerce Commission, which sometimes devotes years to studying mergers.

Governor Rockefeller needs no outside help in getting himself into trouble. He excels at do-ityourself. But he is now suggesting that a kind of political conspiracy is at work against him, with the White House and possibly the Justice Department inspiring State Controller Arthur Levitt's attack on Mr. Rockefeller's new and...
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13 --The leaders of three of the world's most sensitive listening posts were honored today at the 312th commencement of Harvard University.
Pauline Trigere: This designer places her individual stamp on fashions that are being talked about, and some that have not even been thought of.

BERLIN, June 13--The East German Communists began construction today of what appeared to be a new East-West border crossing in Berlin. It will be the first new passageway since the Communist wall was built in August, 1961.

Coates Brothers announced yesterday the acquisition of the 32-story office building at 555 Madison Avenue at 56th Street from Manuel E. Kulukundis, the shipping leader who filed a petition for bankruptcy recently.
MANGO magic may be added to meals without much ad dition to cost right now. Many vegetable stands are currently displaying attractive specimens of this perfumed fruit.
MOSCOW, June 13--Harold Wilson, leader of the British Labor party, said today that the Soviet Union wished to purchase $280,000,000 in oil-refinery equipment from Britain.

ROME, June 13--Controversy last fall between the Spanish Government and Giovanni Battista Cardinal Montini was reported today to have become the basis of opposition by Generalissimo Francisco Franco to the Cardinal's election to the papacy. The report was emphatically denied by Spanish sources here.
PARIS, Friday, June 14--The National Assembly approved early this morning ratification of the French-West German treaty of cooperation by 325 votes to 107. There were 42 abstentions.
MINEOLA, June 13--Nassau County Executive Eugene Nickerson said today he would ask Governor Rockefeller to investigate the administration of the District Attorney's office.
Adm. Arleigh A. Burke, retired former Chief of Naval Operations, declared yesterday that victory's price in the present-day world over communism "is the self-discipline democracy demands."
LONDON, June 13--Henry Cooper, the heavyweight champion of Britain and the Empire, trains in Southeast London in the neighborhood where he was born, in a gym upstairs over a bar.
WASHINGTON, June 13--Senate Democratic leaders agreed today to make a new drive for passage of the Administration bill to strengthen the area redevelopment program in its fight against unemployment.
The Civil Aeronautics Board has acted to equip its enforcement arm with a powerful new weapon in making preliminary investigations of suspected violations of the Federal Aviation Act.
The wholesale commodity index fell to 93.7 on Wednesday, from 93.9 on Tuesday.
Edwar S. Lewis, executive director of the Urban League of Greater New York, outlined an "immediate action" program yesterday to promote broader civil rights in New York City.

MONTREAL, June 13--Five of 21 persons held "criminally responsible" by a coroner's jury yesterday in the bomb death of an army furnace tender are expected to be arraigned tomorrow on charges of capital murder.
LONDON, June 13--Indignation is welling up all over Britain as the chain of indiscretions in the Profumo affair becomes longer.
EIRE a salute for Lewis John Carlino. On the strength of "Cages," which opened last night at the York Playhouse, he deserves one as a writer of intensity and power.
LONDON, June 13--Seven pubs and inns near Prime Minister Macmillan's Sussex estate got the official word today: They will house President Kennedy's entourage on his forthcoming visit.
WASHINGTON, June 13--A Navy official supported today the Defense Department's choice of the Bell Aerosystems Company of Buffalo to develop the V/STOL plane.

LONDON, June 13--A poet, classical scholar, Professor of Greek, wartime brigadier, and a senior minister of the Crown, John Enoch Powell is a puritan and certainly the official least disposed toward compromise in Prime Minister Macmillan's Government.

ASHFORD, N.Y., June 13-- In a hollow among the rolling hills of Cattaraugus County, Governor Rockefeller broke ground today for a $28,500,000 nuclear fuel reprocessing plant that he hopes will form the core of an atomic industry in western New York State.
The nacotics conspiracy convictions of John (Big John) Ormento and eight other men were upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeal. But new trials were ordered for four other defendants.
WASHINGTON, June 13--A space agency proposal to construct a $50,000,000 electronics research center in Boston has run into bipartisan opposition in the House Committee on Science and Astronautics.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 13--The African-Asian group urged the advanced countries today to agree to a further reduction in the assessments imposed on underdeveloped countries for the expenses of United Nations forces in the Congo and Middle East during the second half of 1963.
A three-way consolidation between the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, the First National Bank of Mount Vernon and the Bensonhurst National Bank of Brooklyn was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 13-- American spokesmen have moved to forestall a plea by the World Food Congress for expansion of the United Nations $100,000,000 World Food Program.

MANY a young camper has been outfitted at Macy's, and the store is now set to capture the adult vacationer. A new shop devoted to furnishings for the second, or vacation, house opens today in the ninth floor modern furniture wing.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 13--Rogelio Frigerio, often described as a shadowy figure who wields great influence in Argentina, said in an interview here yesterday that his role was a very obvious one--he was a friend of Juan D. Peron, former dictator of Argentina.

KUCHING, Sarawak, June 10 --On a wall in the office of Sarawak's Financial Secretary is a huge colored map of Sarawak. It illustrates the problem that Sarawak will face when the colony becomes part of Malaysia.
DAMASCUS, Syria, June 13 (UPI)--Yemen, supported by Syria, sought admission today as the fourth member of the projected new United Arab Republic.
Stock prices fell slightly on average trading yesterday after another late-afternoon retreat erased gains made earlier in the day.

WASHINGTON, June 13--Governor Wallace pledged to the people of his state that he would never "obey" a Federal court order to integrate the University of Alabama. He also pledged he would prevent the eruption of violence that otherwise might be incited by his refusal.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 13--Mrs. William H. Corbin of Morristown and Charles A. Dana Jr. of New York gave a supper dance tonight to present their daughter, Miss Marion Turrell Dana. At the party, held in the Corbin home, the debutante received with her mother. She wore a gown of white peau de soie.
An emotional protest by a group of Brooklyn Negroes forced the Board of Estimate yesterday to postpone the approval of two low-rent public housing projects proposed by the City Housing Authority.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)--The Hughes Tool Company promised today to continue its support of Northeast Airlines, Inc., in the face of a threat by Vickers, Ltd., to repossess aircraft sold to Northeast to satisfy debts.
The profundities and problems of integration were boiled down to the point of disintegra tion last night by a merciless, sharp and furiously funny revue called "The Living Premise."
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)--The National Association of Real Estate Boards objected today to any state or Federal effort to force property owners to sell to Negroes.
The New York World's Fair excpects to offer at least 30 entertainment projects, including an illuminated water show, a wax musuem and a circus in an air-conditioned tent, it was learned yesterday.
OTTAWA, June 13--Canada announced drastic measures tonight to arrest the take-over of Canadian companies by United States interests.
GARISSA, Kenya, June 6-- Elephants are the current targets for this part of the hunting-filming safari being made in the semi-desert waste of this country's Northern Frontier District.
Cotton futures advanced 40 to 70 cents a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 13-- Stephan Smith won the $25,000 Dr. Stanton Pace tonight by two lengths at Roosevelt Raceway while achieving the year's fastest clocking for a mile over a half-mile track.
The Board of Education pledged yesterday to do every thing possible to promote integration in the city school system.
WASHINGTON, June 13--A favorable atmosphere for new civil rights legislation exists in Congress, a check of party leaders indicates, but the prospect is hedged by marry provisos and limitations.
CLEVELAND, June 13--The head of a 70-year-old Jewish organization said today that no American Jew could evade helping the Negro to achieve "full stature as a human being and as an American."

WASHINGTON, June 13-- The United States has warned President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam that it will publicly condemn his treatment of the Buddhists unless he takes prompt action to meet their grievances.
WASHINGTON, June 13-- President Kennedy renewed today his efforts to rally the broadest possible support for new civil rights legislation.

LONDON, June 13--The Cabinet met again today on the political crisis generated by the Profumo scandal, but the 75minute session apparently failed to resolve the big immediate question facing Prime Minister Macmillan's Government.
STRATFORD, Conn., June 13--The fighting and the wooing of Henry V are being enacted at the American Shakespeare Festival Theater with splashes of color and with forthright manly eloquence.
The Defense Department took issue yesterday with the findings of a private research group that the military capacity of the United States to destroy an enemy far exceeded the need.
Shares of the Syntex Corporation, the most phenomenal price gainer of 1963 on the American Stock Exchange, plummeted 12 points yesterday to close at 82 on volume of 60,400 shares.
ALBERTSON, L.I., June 13 --A group of physically handicapped students who have completed their first year in school proudly received awards today for bowling, swimming, music, art and scholarship.

A political crisis even more profound than the storm over Suez which blew Anthony Eden out of office and brought Prime Minister Macmillan to power is now shaking Great Britain to its foundations. The Suez crisis forced a change in Conservative Prime Ministers but left the Conservative Government intact.

LONDON, June 13--the rupture at Brussels that barred Britain's entry into the Common Market has had "no ill effects" on the ability of the British economy to expand, Chancellor of the Exchequer Reginald Maulding said today.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., June 13--Several hundred angry whites carried out their own "freedom march" tonight. They sought to break through police lines to attack Negro marchers one block away.
The Board of Estimate approved an application to the Federal Government yesterday for a "mass transportation demonstration grant" to survey transit facilities here.
BALTIMORE, June 13 (AP) --Two former Democratic Representatives and two co-defendants were found guilty today of attempting to influence the Justice Department to drop a mail-fraud case.

HEARING WEIGHS ALLEGHANY DEAL WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI)--Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., a Minneapolis chain store company, was accused today of fashioning a purchase and option stock agreement last October to disguise indications that it gained a controlling influence in the Alleghany Corporation.
Ira Haupt, the founder and senior partner of the Wall Street securities concern of Ira Haupt Co., 111 Broadway, died yesterday in New York Hospital of lung cancer. He was 74 years old.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 13--Followers of the late Patrice Lumumba have returned to power in their old bastion of Stanleyville.
CHICAGO, June 13 (UPI)-- Old crop soybeans tumbled in late heavy selling after holding firm today on the Board of Trade. Corn and wheat ended narrowly mixed and other grain futures were mostly lower.
ATLANTA, June 13--This city's 12 municipal swimming pools were completely and quietly integrated today when the last five segregated pools were opened to Negroes.

The extraordinary character of the troubles in British Guiana can be gauged from the fact that a punishing general strike there has now lasted eight weeks. The degree of stubbornness and bitterness between Negro and East Indian has to be remarkably high for both sides to keep going that long.

Two Brooklyn landlords were fined and sentenced to 10 days in jail yesterday for failing to correct long-standing housing violations in their tenements. Both had records of previous housing convictions.

BRUSSELS, June 13--Belgium is ranked as one of the four most active bridgeplaying countries along with Sweden, the Netherlands and Denmark, each of which can boast more bridge-playing per capita than the United States and than other European countries.
Prices of Government securities were narrowly mixed yesterday in light--to--moderate trading. Prime corporate debt issues improved further and municipals were firm in better volume.

Joe Weinstein, who landed in New York in 1909 with 12 cents in his pocket and later built the Mays department store chain based in Brooklyn, died early yesterday of a heart attack at his home at 160 Central Park South. He was 66 years old and had been ill for several months.

MILWAUKEE, June 13-- When their game with Milwaukee was postponed because of rain this morning, the Mets had two hours to kill in the clubhouse before taking their chartered plane on to Cincinatti. Four card games promptly were organized.
WASHINGTON, June 13-- Senator Jacob K. Javits's efforts to win for Nassau County a reduced price on 435 acres of Mitchel Field ended in defeat today.
HARRISON, N.Y., June 13 --Refreshed by a four-week vacation from the tournament circuit, Arnold Palmer returned to the golfing wars today with most of his big guns blazing.

RENSSELAERVILLE, N.Y., June 13--No postmen brave the elements of early summer here To get your mail, you walk to the post office. If that is tiring, you read your letters over a cool drink at the soda fountain in the same tiny office. It's that kind of village.

Trans-Atlantic liners are expected to keep a firm and permanent hold on about a quarter of the passenger volume on the world's busiest tourist route, the French Line's new chief executive said here yesterday.
Even the New York Yankees, long accustomed to the high altitude, are finding the footing extremely slippery atop the American League in this wildly scrambled baseball campaign.

JACKSON, Miss., June 13--The police charged today on adults and teen-agers who were jeering and chanting "We want freedom" and clubbed them into submission. A blow to the head felled a white sociology professor in the group.
BRUSSELS, June 13--A head-on collision between the United States and the Common Market in Geneva later this month now seems inevitable.
Sugar futures declined and cocoa advanced in active trading yesterday.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., June 13--Samuel N. Brimberg, who retired eight years ago as president of the Universal Steel Corporation, metal-shelving manufacturers, died Wednesday in his home at 215 Bay Boulevard.

Carol Burnett's impending motherhood could mean a possible loss of $50,000 to the producers of "A Girl to Remember." The musical, in which the actress will be starred, is now scheduled to open next May.
PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (AP)--The Navy's first public demonstration of an experimental boat that rides on an air bubble was a success today after five failures.

SYRACUSE, June 13--Navy arrived on the scene of the regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association today and Coach Paul Quinn revealed that he will send out an entirely new junior varsity on Onondaga Lake Saturday.

WASHINGTON, June 13--At the time when President Kennedy has called for a new initiative for a nuclear test ban, the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency is losing virtually all its most experienced experts and negotiators.

VIENTIANE, Laos, June 13--Pro-Communist Pathet Lao troops attacked an outpost of rightist forces in southern Laos today, but were reported to have been repulsed with heavy losses. The action could mean the broadening of fighting so far restricted to the area of the Plaine des Jarres.

MONTCLAIR, N.J. "HOT Is What Cold Is Not" is a first-grade primer that has thus far had an extremely select audience. It has been read only by 21 first graders at the Edgemont School here. They also happen to be the authors.

The establishment of special science high schools, possibly financed in part by the Federal Government, was advocated yesterday by Dr. Jerome B. Wiesner, Special Assistant to the President on Science and Technology.

WASHINGTON, June 13-- United States officials reiterated today that some American airmen of Jewish faith were now on temporary assignment in Saudi Arabia. The officials thus contradicted a denial broadcast by the Mecca radio.
Record sales and sharply higher earnings for the quarter and six-month periods ended April 30 were attained by Massey-Ferguson, Ltd., a worldwide farm machinery producer in Toronto.
KINGS POINT, L.I., June 13--The Al Sherman Clinic for Football Coaches opened today at the United States Merchant Marine Academy with 43 high school coaches in attendance.
Richard Lewisohn charged last night that the New York County Republican organization was employing a new form of bossism in seeking "to put across the Governor's cousin" for councilman at large.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, June 13--The Trades Union Council received a letter today from Prime Minister Cheddi B. Jagan requesting that a date be fixed to negotiate terms for ending this British colony's 54-day-old general strike. Nongovernment unions were asked to negotiate with their respective employers.
Whatever this country now achieves in civil rights must depend, basically, on the reaction of the public, Associate Justice Arthur J. Goldberg of the Supreme Court said yesterday.

GALES FERRY, Conn., June 13--This has been a cold training season for the sweepswingers from Yale and Harvard preparing here for their 98th crew race on the Thames River Saturday. The rivalry began in 1852.

Cleopatra has been a problem this week for television as well as motion pictures. While 20th Century-Fox was giving thought to cutting its "Cleopatra" movie to something under four hours, station WCBS-TV was trying to arrange 15 more minutes for "Antony and Cleopatra."
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 13 (AP)--Pitt Tyson Maner, a former Alabama official and an active member of the Democratic party for more than 25 years, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.
WITH Safe Boating Week just around the corner, the arrival here on Wednesday of an open 16-foot outboard after a 1,500-mile voyage from Miami was hardly propitious.
WASHINGTON, June 13-- The Association of American Railroads reported that loadings of revenue freight in the week ended June 8 totaled 606,084 cars, the highest since the week ended Nov. 3.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 --The University of California Library today announced the acquisition of the printer's manuscript of D.H. Lawrence's "Sons and Lovers," written in the author's precise longhand.
SAVANNAH, Ga., June 13-- About 300 Negroes marched to Wright Square in downtown Savannah at noon today to hear their leader, Hosea Williams, voice their demand for immediate desegregation.
Earnings of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., declined sharply in the 13 weeks ended May 4, falling to $382,000 from $721,000 in the 1962 period.
William Holmberg has been named general manager of The New York Times Western Edition, it was announced yesterday by Arthur Hays Sulzberger, chairman of the board of The New York Times.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 13-- New evidence was presented here today that brain damage from small strokes, which occur unnoticed and often resemble the beginnings of senility, can be reversed in some measure.
A front-running performance by Badge of Honor resulted in a record-breaking victory in the $19,625 Meadow Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.
HUNTSVILLE, Ala., June 13 --A third Negro enrolled in the University of Alabama today and began classes at its extension center here without fanfare or difficulty.
Huntington Hartford, a man of considerable affluence, says that one of the most striking trends of the last decade has been the "emergence of the affluent intellectual."
The Civil Aeronautics Board has found the rates for shipping monkeys and other primates to be "excessively high" and has disapproved them.
TRENTON, June 13--The State Commissioner of Education refused today to extend his July 1 deadline for the submission by Orange of a plan for ending a racial imbalance in its Oakwood School.

Perhaps buffet guests have had it too easy too long, with everything from liver pate to macaroons laid out for them on a horizontal plane. Last night, a seven-course buffet was served vertically at 325 Central Park West, and the guests had to work for it. There was a course on every floor.

ALBUQUEQUE, N.M., June 13--Julio Marin, a slender senior from the University of Southern California and Costa Rica, paid little attention to the altitude and less to opponents tonight as he got the 42d National Collegiate track and field...

Food Fair Stores, Inc. of Philadelphia, has acquired 65 per cent, or effective control of Fox Markets, Inc., a 39-unit Los Angeles supermarket and drug store chain. The transaction involves about $6,700,000.
Last week's pronouncement by the National Council of Churches calling for an end to the devotional use of the Bible in public schools has been disclaimed by the Greek Orthodox Church.

WASHINGTON, June 13-- Dr. Ruben F. Mettler, a prominent missile engineer and aerospace industry executive, was reported in Congressional circles today to be the leading candidate to become the next director of the manned lunar expedition.
HERSHEY, Pa., June 13-- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower called today for an army of Republican-minded "amateurs" to halt the Kennedy Administration in 1964.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 13 (AP)--Kilkare Farm's Racing Clouds, unable to reach contention until the turn into the stretch, was driven hard along the hedge to win today's Monmouth Park feature, a mile event on the turf. He paid $18.40 for $2.

The marriage of Miss Ruthanne Tuttle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Tuttle of Buchanan, N.Y., to James H. Iselin took place yesterday afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Iselin of New York and Oceanport, N.J.

ATHENS, June 13--Efforts to end the Greek Government crisis appeared to have bogged down today with King Paul insisting on the appointment of a new premier and the Premier Constantine Caramanlis demanding the new elections, probably in August.

A chain reaction touched off by the jostling of Queen Frederika of Greece by pro-Communists in London has precipitated a political crisis that has toppled the Greek Government and could involve the fate of the monarchy. Coming on top of the military uprisings in Turkey, the troubles in Greece could seriously damage the North Atlantic alliance, of which these two countries form the southern flank.
DANVILLE, Va., June 13-- More than 100 Negro demonstrators were driven off the steps of City Hall here tonight after a peaceful eight-hour wait to see Mayor Julian Stinson.

IN England during the 12th century, when land was the chief source of wealth and the only source of rank and power, Jews were forbidden to own land. This meant that the Jews who had gone to England after the Norman conquest lived in the towns and largely by money-lending, which was forbidden, too.
Net free reserves of Federal Reserve System member banks continued at a relatively low level during the week ended Wednesday. however, gave no significant signs of tightening.

Rockefeller Center's first tree show went on display yesterday. Spokesmen said the show stemmed from a growing public interest in other trees growing in the Rockefeller Center area. The 32 new trees, ranging from 6 to 10 feet high, were planted in the Channel Gardens.
The State Commission for Human Rights began its own investigation yesterday in the case of a deputy city commissioner charged with specifying "white only" in hiring a secretary.

JACKSON, Miss., June 13-- Robert Nichols Jr., the city attorney who has been prosecuting racial demonstrators here, tried to explain today the reaction of the White community to the murder of Medgar W. Evers.

HARRISON, N.Y., June 13--Gary Player whistled softly when he finally saw the ball. He was a long time in find ing it, too. His approach shot on the eighth sailed handsomely over the lake but to the right of the green.

TOKYO, June 13 (Comtelburo)--The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation confirmed today press reports that it was planning to issue bonds in New York in the near future.

Justice George J. Beldock announced yesterday that the Kings and Queens Supreme Courts and the Nassau County Court would maintain full schedules in July and August as a means of reducing congestion on the criminal calendar.

The gross national product of the United States has grown a little faster in the most recent business cycle than in the two preceding periods of recession and recovery, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday in a study of major economic indicators.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 13--Business is good and getting better, seven bankers from various regions of New York State reported today.

Cocoa and sugar futures fell yesterday in active trading.
"Brazil!" a musical version of Bertita Harding's book "Amazon Throne," will be presented on Broadway next spring.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 14--The Rutgers University Board of Governors approved increases in tuition today for students attending graduate and professional schools. The increases will bring in $100,000 a year more.

The Board of Education yesterday invited Governor Rockefeller, Mayor Wagner and Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, to a special meeting this month to discuss "the financial needs and problems that urgently and immediately face our school system."
ORANGE, N.J., June 14--The Orange Board of Education has filed an appeal from a state order that the local board submit a plan by July 1 to end racial imbalance in its Oakwood Avenue school.
PARIS, June 14--The European Common Market is importing more than it is exporting, and the gap continued to grow in the first quarter of this year, the executive commission reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)--A White House aide challenged today a statement by real estate men who said that they had no responsibility to help Negroes find better homes.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- President Kennedy will continue next week his efforts to develop a broad base of public support for a civil rights legislative program. His proposals will probably be submitted to Congress on Wednesday.
BONN, June 14--A Dusseldorf District Court ruled in favor of Friedrich Flick, the industrialist, today in his fight to prevent a son's attempt to break up one of Europe's biggest industrial empires.

TOKYO, June 14--Mayor Wagner arrived in Tokyo today to be welcomed by four girls in kimonos, two bouquets of roses, a Japanese police band playing "The Stars and Stripes Forever" and a series of questions about juvenile delinquency, bribery and election corruption in New York.

Senate action to kill a proposal to grant coastwise shipping privileges to a foreign-built foreign-flag, rail-car ferry was hailed here yesterday as a victory for proponents of a strong domestic merchant marine.
MOSCOW, June 14--Premier Khrushchev rejected today the Western contention that international inspection is essential to guard against violation of a nuclear test-ban treaty.
NIORT, France, June 14-- President de Gaulle called on Western Europe today to unite to prevent the spread of Communism.

Geneva, graveyard of so many hopes, has at last produced one important agreement that raises some hope for the success of the Moscow test-ban talks. This is the agreement, now complete in all technical details, on a "hot line" between Washington and Moscow to put President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev in instant communication in an emergency to forestall war by accident, by miscalculation or by misunderstanding.
The Yankees last night exploded the notion they can't beat left-handers in a most dramatic manner as they brought down Don Mossi and the Tigers at the Stadium, 4--2, before a roaring crowd of 33,576.

Tomorrow is Father's Day, a big day for dear old dad. It's also a big day for merchants, since an estimated $940,000,000 will have been spent for gifts for fathers by the time the stores close their doors this evening.
ATLANTA, June 14--Atlanta, where mayors have repeatedly scorned the idea of an official biracial commission, is following its pattern of unofficial biracial conferences.
MOSCOW, Saturday, June 15 --Lieut. Col. Valery F. Bykovsky whirled about the earth today on what is planned as a prolonged orbital flight.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- Industrial production rose again in May, to another record high, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The Labor Department reported at the same time that employment, with the exception of farm jobs, had risen by double the normal amount for the month.
LONDON, June 14--The New York City Ballet's Melissa Hayden made a delayed but triumphant debut tonight at Covent Garden as the heroine in Sir Frederick Ashton's "Sylvia."

WE are told that a work of art should be judged by the way the artist carried out his intentions. If his intentions are at least brushed with excellence, that's fine. But I'd hate to cheer an artist who apparently set out to produce the worst possible example of its kind-- and succeeded beyond trivial cavil.
PARIS, June 14--The question whether the United States still favors the European Common Market is being increasingly asked by officials of the Common Market countries.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 14--France lined up today with the Soviet Union in a refusal to accept the General Assembly resolution that all member states must pay assessments for peacekeeping operations.

Oscar Brand conducted a melodic seminar in topical songs last night at the New School for Social Research. Mr. Brand, the first folk singer in the arts festival in the school's courtyard, will be followed on subsequent Fridays by Brock Peters, Anita Sheer, Odetta and Jean Redpath.
PHILADELPHIA, June 14-- Miss Gerda Crozer Paumgarten, daughter of Mrs. Harald Paumgarten of Chestnut Hill and the late Mr. Paumgarten, was married here this afternoon to Arthur Emlen Newbold 4th.
Najeeb E. Halaby, the Federal Aviation Administrator, said yesterday that all three proposed sites for a new jet airport in the metropolitan area were unsatisfactory.
YORK, England, June 14 (Reuters)--The fifth York Festival of the Arts opened this evening with the 14th-century cycle of mystery plays. A capacity crowd of 2,000 attended.
White House conferences with businessmen on racial problems have added impetus to the Negro drive for desegregation.
The Thalia Theater's 20th annual summer film festival, the most extensive program of regular movie revivals in the metropolitan area, will be held from Friday through Oct. 10.

"It's their country," was the laconic reaction of Wall Street analysts yesterday to the plan of the Canadian Government to make investment more difficult for foreigners.
Reform Democrats threatened yesterday to fight the Board of Elections in court if it refused to list slates of candidates in a straight line on the Sept. 5 primary ballot.

ARKADELPHIA, Ark., June 14--The marriage of Miss Anna Kate Reid, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joe Winston Reid, to William Hayne Hipp, son of Francis Moffet Hipp of Greenville, S.C., and the late Mrs. Hipp, took place here this evening.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- America's first manned space vehicle, the Mercury capsule, was patented this week and was immediately retired with honors.
ROME, June 14--Italy's slowmotion governmental crisis reached a decisive stage today with a four-party conference to negotiate a new center-left coalition.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 14 (AP)--Chaos threatened Indiana's financial Structure today as a judge ruled the new 2 per cent retail sales tax unconstitutional and the state's Attorney General recommended that the decision not be appealed.
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will hold its annual San Juan Fiesta on Randalls Island at 2:15 P.M. tomorrow.

Dr. Philip H. Abelson, director of the Geophysical Laboratory of the Carnegie Institution in Washington, warned scientists yesterday not to become "fat cats" who could not cope with success and thereby lose their creativity.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 14-- This season's crop of 3-year-old pacers, rated stronger than average, will be put to its sternest test so far, when nine go postward in the first presentation of the Commodore Purse tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 14--The first of 21 planned trade fairs for Africans in South Africa, Swaziland and Basutoland will be held by an African trade fair association in Durban, South Africa, in July, the association announced here today.

TEANECK, N.J., June 14-- Boxing fans in northern New Jersey had their first look at ranking boxers in more than six years tonight in the armory. They saw a whale of a fight, but like boxing fans everywhere, some of them disliked the decision.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, June 14--The leaders of the two major political parties in this strife-torn British colony said today that a move was under way to form a coalition government.

LONDON, June 14--British refinery construction companies would welcome the chance to build a $280,000,000 refinery for the Soviet Union, but are convinced it will take years before any contracts are signed.

BONN, June 14--A united front of the United States and West Germany on basic international policy will be achieved during President Kennedy's visist here, authoritative Government sources predicted today.
WASHINGTON, June 14-- President Kennedy notified Congress today that he believed the Federal Government should bear three-quarters of the billiondollar burden of developing a supersonic airliner.
PARIS, June 14--West European governments are watching with concern signs of a revival of isolationism in the United States, diplomats reported today.
LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, June 14--The Soviet Union is seeking to negotiate a cultural exchange agreement with the Congolese Government.
The steady rate of growth in the non-Communist world of the tanker fleet engaged in international oil transport is slowing down and may stop in 1966.

Sunny Jim Fitzsimmon's schedule called for him to get up at 5 o'clock this morning, just as he had been doing for the greater part of the past seven decades. There was one big difference in today's program, though, which carried it out of the realm of routine.

GENEVA, June 14--African delegations led a walkout that almost emptied the big assembly hall of the Palais des Nations here today when a South African began addressing the International Labor Organization's 47th session.
WASHINGTON, June 14-- The latest Soviet space flight was calmly accepted within the Executive branch and Congress today as just another, long-expected step in the Russian space program.
LOS ANGELES, June 14 (AP)--Ernie Banks drove in two runs with a double and his 14th homer tonight as the Chicago Cubs whipped the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4--1.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 14-- The South Vietnamese Government was reported to have made two vital concessions to the Buddhists during preliminary negotiations today to settle their religious-political dispute.
New Yorkers saluted the flag and the men who serve under it at ceremonies jointly marking Flag Day and the birthday of the Army yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- Senators closely questioned officials of United Press International today about the propriety of assigning that news agency's reporters to projects paid for by private industry and public relations firms.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- The index of wholesale primary market prices remained unchanged at 100.0 per cent of its 1957-59 base during the week ended June 11, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Victor Frank Ridder, head of Ridder Publications, Inc., which operates six newspapers, died of a heart attack early yesterday in his home at 120 East End Avenue. He was 77 years old.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 14 (UPI)--Eugene Scott and Donald Dell clinched victory today for the United States over Iran in the first round of the American Zone Davis Cup tennis eliminations.

The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange declared yesterday that it would furnish "all physically and legally available information on sugar futures trading as demanded by the United States Department of Agriculture."
LOS ANGELES, June 14-- An all-white Superior Court jury found 11 members of the Black Muslim movement guilty today of various charges of violence growing out of a fatal riot here in April, 1962.
PHILADELPHIA, June 14-- A jurisdictional dispute over engineers, jobs on a ship loading supplies being sent to Cuba as ransom for released prisoners spread today to two other Delaware River piers.
John Denman, an airline pilot, applies the certainty needed to guide a giant jet in making up his mind about what he likes and doesn't like in art.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 14-- This is the story of three sets of identical twins, of stress, and of crippling arthritis that struck only one of each set.
The prospect of somewhat higher settlements in the building trades than those reached in 1960 and 1957 is emerging from contract talks now in progress.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)--Funds for the employment of 200 more agents by the Federal Bureau of Investigation were recommended today by the House Appropriations Committee.

BERLIN, June 14--The East German Communists said today that their new EastWest crossing under construction at the wall around West Berlin would be open only to allow Western travelers to take a direct route to the East German airport at Schonefeld.
MEXICO CITY, June 14 (UPI)--Mexico ordered today the expulsion of 20 foreigners, most of them Americans, involved in a so-called psychic drug research center near Acapulco.
Two men were arrested in Brooklyn last night after one allegedly sold $260,000 worth of blank money orders to an undercover detective working for the District Attorney's office.

HERSHEY, Pa., June 14--The chairman of the Republican National Committe implied today that President Kennedy was trying to maneuver the Republicans into a position where they could be blamed if a civil rights program failed in Congress.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 14-- Welfare Commissioner John McManus of Nassau County refused to answer questions put to him by the District Attorney today in an investigation into charges that he had taken meals for himself and his family at the A. Holly Patterson Home for the Aged and Infirm in Uniondale.
The re-election of Vice Adm. Roy A. Gano to his third term as president of the United Seamen's Service has been announced by the maritime welfare group.
An Urban League committee said yesterday that it would hold demonstrations at three World's Fair construction sites if action were not taken to end, discrimination in building trade unions.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 14 --Miss Barbara Rose Leeds was married here this afternoon to Edward Andrew Morrow Jr. Dr. Matthew Ies Spetter of the Society for Ethical Culture performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Wurzburger, stepfather and mother of the bride, whose husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morrow of Middletown, N.J.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell was ordered in State Supreme Court yesterday to explain why he should not be arrested for not paying a $211,500 judgment for defamation of character.

SAVANNAH, Ga., June 14-- Negro demonstrations that have been going on daily since last week were suspended today after the Chamber of Commerce called for desegregation of companies "soliciting business from the general public."
SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 14 --A new Panama Canal can be dug with nuclear explosives at one-seventh the cost of conventional methods, an atomic energy expert said today.

Robert Moses, the impresario of highway progress, has just issued a new brochure of road and tunnel building for the future. WHEN buying peaches, it is best to ignore their blushes. It is not a superficial rosy glow that denotes inner ripeness and juiciness. It is mellowness of background color, which should be a healthy yellow and not a sickly green. The latter denotes lack of ripeness at picking time, which in turn promises lack of flavor at eating time.

The Army Corps of Engineers has removed the signs designating four rat-infested Harlem tenements as fallout shelters. A corps spokesman said yesterday that the signs were taken down after a report indicated that the four tenements had a long history of health and building-code violations.
At their Manila conference, the Foreign Ministers of the Philippines, Indonesia and Malaya have made a significant move toward unity in the Malay world.

Dr. Hans A. Bethe, a pioneer in making the atomic bomb, said yesterday that the development of relatively invulnerable missiles had greatly reduced the danger of war. Simultaneously, the development has also made possible a substantial reduction in armaments, he said.
LONDON, June 14--Lord Beaverbrook, the 84-year-old newspaper publisher, has secretly married Lady Dunn, the widow of a Canadian millionaire.

LIME ROCK, Conn., June 14-- Arch McNeill of New York and Paul Hill of Fort Worth, Tex., took top honors today as the New England Region of the Sports Car Club of America opened its annual national championship meeting on Lime Rock Park's 1.5-mile course.

The Unitarian Church of All Souls was the scene yesterday afternoon of the marriage of Miss Sarah Cary Iselin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Iselin Jr. of 432 East 84th Street, to James Madison Morrison. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James G. Morrison of 14 Sutton Place South.
Former President Herbert Hoover has been seriously ill for a week, his family announced yesterday.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes conceded yesterday that premature use of a "reversible-lane" project caused the massive traffic jam Wednesday evening on Queens Boulevard.
The Government securities market continued to mark time yesterday as it awaited the results of the latest Treasury financing, which came an hour after the close.

LONDON, June 14--The first two productions in the Royal Shakespeare Theater's trilogy on the Wars of the Roses have been set back two weeks as a result of the illness of Peter Hall, the managing director.

JACKSON, Miss., June 14-- Negroes will march in mourning tomorrow along the fringe of the downtown business district following funeral services for a slain integration leader.
