Prime Minister A. Milton Obote of Uganda said yesterday that Africa's refusal to take sides in the cold war was an expression of the continent's unique political nature, not "tactical maneuver."

CHERRY HILL, N.J., June 14--In the opinion of Republican state chairmen attending a meeting here, Senator Barry Goldwater has gained considerable support in the Northeast recently for the Republican nomination for President in 1964.
The Ford Foundation has established a two-year program to enable reporters, editors and critics in the arts to travel or study in the United States or abroad.
DARIEN, Conn., June 14-- Little Sailor and Sutton Place, both owned by The Annex of Keswick, Va., clinched two hunter championships at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show today.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- Deputy Defense Secretary Roswell L. Gilpatric told a Senate investigating group today that he had awarded the controversial V/STOL airplane contract on the basis of the winning company's "competence and past experience."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 (UPI)--The United States Ski Association officials completed their selection of skiers for the 1964 United States Olympic team today over the protests of some members who claimed a few of the top skiers were left off the squads.

RYE, N.Y., June 14--Mrs. Allison Choate and Mrs. Bruce McGhie, both of the host Apawamis Club, won the annual two-day best-ball tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association today. Combining their cards for a gross of 38, 36--74, equal to women's par, the Apawamis pair totaled 150 and won by three strokes.
STOCKHOLM, June 14--Residents of Stockholm like to think of their city as the "Venice of the North."
CAMBRIDGE, Md., June 14-- The Maryland National Guard imposed a modified form of martial law here tonight to curb further racial demonstrations.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14-- Gov. William W. Scranton said today that the "No. 1 piece of unfinished business in America is providing full equality for all people, without regard to their color, religion or ancestry."
Stock prices drifted listlessly in narrow trading ranges yes terday. Volume eased sharply.

HARRISON, N.Y., June 14 --A crick in the massive neck of Jack Nicklaus created more excitement today than another mass onslaught on par by the golfing greats competing for gold and glory in the $100,000 Thunderbird Classic.

LE MANS, France, June 14-- The 24 hours of Le Mans, the world's most famous sports car race, begins at 4 P.M. tomorrow for a probable 48 cars. It will end at the same hour Sunday, probably with about 20 cars still running. It is expected that the winner will have traveled more than 2,600 miles at an average of at least 115 miles an hour.
CHICAGO, June 14 (UPI)-- Wheat, soybeans and rye futures staged a rally and ended with firm to strong gains today on the Board of Trade.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 14 (UPI)--A 20-yearold Harvard undergraduate crashed celebrity row at commencement exercises yesterday.
A Brooklyn landlord was fined $1,000 and sentenced to 20 days in jail yesterday for health violations in three Bedford-Stuyvesant tenements.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) --The Pentagon notified 13,000 of Alabama's federalized National Guardsmen today that they would be released from duty at midnight Sunday.

ROME, June 14--The Cardinals who are administering the Roman Catholic Church let it be known today that they wanted Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty to attend the conclave that will elect a successor to Pope John XXIII. The conclave is to start next Wednesday.

A wonder of the modern world will pay tribute to the Seven Wonders of the ancient one on Tuesday when eight illuminated panels are dedicated at the Empire State Building.

LONDON, June 14--The former Soviet deputy naval attache in London was alleged today to have sought information about the nuclear arming of West Germany from Britain's then War Secretary through the woman who was having affairs with both men.
A jazz group that carried off all honors at the fifth annual Collegiate Jazz Festival is making its New York debut at the Village Vanguard this week.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- The State Department announced today that the United States Ambassador in Port-auPrince was being withdrawn at Haiti's request and that Haiti was recalling her own Ambassador in Washington.
The Citizens Union accused Louis I. Kaplan yesterday of playing politics through his office as City Commissioner of Investigation and asked Mayor Wagner not to appoint him to the bench.

The Canadian Government's announcement of plans to curb United States investment resulted in hectic activity in Canadian currency on the New York foreign exchange market yesterday. But by the end of the day, it was apparent that operators were unsure as to just what the new policy will mean.

ST. VINCENT, Italy, June 14--Play will begin here tomorrow for the 1963 World Bridge Championship. Four teams are competing: Italy, present would champions; France, European champions; Argentina, South American champions, and the United States, representing North America.
OTTAWA, June 14--Finance Minister Walter L. Gordon was challenged in Parliament today to deny that he had used "ghost writers" in the preparation of last night's controversial budget message.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI)--Bertin C. Gamble, chairman of Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., said today it was legally impossible for his concern to buy outright 3,500,000 shares of the Alleghany Corporation last October.
Five newsmen and a newspaper were named winners yesterday in the newspaper category of the Mass Media Brotherhood Awards of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

WASHINGTON, June 14--Government officials expressed concern today that some of the new taxes announced by the Canadian Government might hurt United States export sales to Canada. The result could be a worsening of the United States balance of payments deficit.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., June 14--A whippet-trim broad jumper from Central State College in Ohio and a brawny, square-jawed chemistry teacher from Boston College shared title honors tonight as the second day of the 42d National Collegiate track and field championships ended at University Stadium with relative tranquility.

CLEVELAND, June 14 (AP) --Willie Kirkland's 19th-inning homer, his second of the game, gave the Cleveland Indians a 3-2 victory over the Washington Senators tonight in the second game of a twilight-night double-header. It was the longest game in the majors this season.

CHICAGO, June 14 (AP)--A Canadian freighter, the Howard L. Shaw, remained idle and empty today despite a Federal Court order aimed at putting grain in the vessel's hold.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- Col. Edward Clifford, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury under Secretary Andrew W. Mellon in the Administration of President Warren G. Harding, died yesterday in Georgetown University Hospital. He was 89 Years old.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 14-- A reorganization of Nassau County's government structure that would simplify it and make it more manageable, more efficient and more economical has been urged by a management consultant.

RYE, N.Y., June 14--A hobby that turned into a business backfired today when a weapons dealer was ordered in court to remove 2,500,000 rounds of ammunition from a garage here.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI)--President Kennedy stepped into the rail work rules dispute tonight. He called both sides to a White House meeting tomorrow morning to try to prevent a nationwide railroad shutdown threatened for next week.

CHICAGO, June 14 (AP)-- Charlie Maxwell's homer leading off the ninth inning gave the Chicago White Sox a 3-2 victory tonight over the Kansas City Athletics. The triumph kept the White Sox in first place in the American League.

CINCINNATI, June 14--A little fan support takes the New York Mets a long way. Over the 500 mark at home, the Mets tonight brought a 5-22 road record into Crosley Field, the only National League park in which they had never won a game. They certainly didn't figure to stop the Cincinnati Reds, the pennant contenders who have recently been on a hot streak.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- The Treasury reported today that it has received a spectacular volume of orders from investors for its new issue of 4 per cent bonds. As a result, the Government ended up borrowing substantially more than it intended.

LONDON, June 14--Michael H.B. Eddowes, a lawyer-writercar-fancier-restaurant-owner who burst into the Profumo affair with the allegation what Christine Keeler had been asked to collect information for the Russians, said today that he had "no political angle at all."
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP ) --The Supreme Court refused today to set aside a Mississippi state court injunction intended to prevent Negro demonstrations in Jackson, Miss., without a permit.

CHICAGO, June 15 (AP)-- A run scored on the first major league hit by Dale Willis, a relief pitcher, in the seventh inning was decisive today as the Kansas City Athletics defeated the Chicago White Sox, 4-3.

SYRACUSE, June 15--Cornell's Henley-bound varsity eight won the championship of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association for the second year in succession today, but the crews from the United States Naval Academy shared most of the glory on Onondaga Lake.

NEXT to the penalty it imposes, a murder trial is probably the most dramatic event our social evolution has produced. The New York Telephone Company has erected a 21story, windowless building on Manhattan's West Side, designed to protect the company's local and long-distance operations from atomic attack.

LONDON--A surprisingly attractive roof garden and restaurant flourish atop one of this city's best known department stores, Derry and Toms, which is set in the heart of Kensington, an upperclass residential district.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., June 15--Miss Nona Hanes Porter, daughter of Mrs. Howard Finger Porter of Winston-Salem and the late Mr. Porter of New York and Saranac Lake, N.Y., was married tonight to Wade Miller Gallant Jr. He is the son of Mrs. Gallant of Raleigh and the late Mr. Gallant.
EASTBOURNE, England, June 15--Britain swept the last two singles matches today for a 4-1 triumph over the Soviet Union and a place in the semifinals of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis competition.
An exhibition of more than 300 paintings, sculptures and other works of art will be held from June 18 through July 27 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 980 Madison Avenue.
FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., June 15 (AP)--More than 100 officers closed downtown streets in Fayetteville tonight in an effort to head off further racial strife, which has left this city in turmoil.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 15-- Sixteen Suffolk County villages will hold elections next Tuesday, but only East Hampton, Quogue and Asharoken will have contests.

HIGHLANDS, N.J.--If sunning on the sands of Sandy Hook State Park becomes boring, visitors to the park can now forsake the beachfront and explore the shady holly forest on the bay side of the peninsula. Trained naturalists will serve as guides.

VIENNA, June 15--The Czechoslovak President and Communist party chief, Antonin Novotny, has struck back in defense of the Government against internal criticism of the last two months.

OMAHA, June 16 (AP)--Bud Hollowell and Gary Holman hit 400-foot homers for the University of Southern California tonight as the Trojans defeated the University of Arizona, 5--2, and won the National Collegiate Athletic Association baseball championship for the fourth time.

NEWARK, June 16--About 2,000 persons at a City Hall rally today heard a State Assemblyman and other speakers urge the state and city administrations to secure equal opportunities for Negroes in employment, housing and education.
AMHERST, Mass., June 16-- Associate Justice Arthur J. Goldberg of the Supreme Court criticized today what he termed the "growing isolation of our educated class from the body of our citizenry."

A 40-year-old Brooklyn man peppered his neighborhood with gunshots yesterday afternoon and hit a 9-year-old girl in the leg.

CHICAGO, June 16--The summer edition of the International Home Furnishings Market opened today with a flurry of castanets and a note of progressive jazz. The castanets were for the Mediterranean, or more specifically Spanish, look seen in some of the furniture unveiled here and the jazz heralded the good clean-lined modern designs being shown.

That was the long-range plan that Mrs. Mary Hardwick Hare broached to the International Lawn Tennis Federation at its Paris meeting last year. ROME, June 18--Cardinals, some of them quite old, will have to live austerely in attics and drafty, if frescoed, halls of the Apostolic Palace during what a Vatican prelate termed today "the most crowded conclave in history."

Steel production declined last week for the third successive week. The drop was attributed to optimism over chances for a quick labor settlement, the completion of strike hedge buying and the normal summer slowdown in industrial activity.

The final assessed valuation of real estate in the city for the fiscal year beginning July 1 has been set at $28,557,458,612, or $1,321,139,497 more than the present figure.

Actors Equity Association has asked the Department of Labor for a stricter interpretation of Federal statutes affecting the admission of alien actors for appearances in Broadway productions.

MBALABALA, Kenya, June 8 On a hunting safari the conversation often turns to the days of 60 years ago and how safaris were made then. There is a large difference in the treks before the motorcar and most of those undertaken today in East Africa.

The London stock market shook off the depressing effect of Britain's political crisis yesterday.

PARIS, June 17--Jean Anouilh, who mysteriously halted work on a play for the Comedie Francaise recently, declined comment today on reports that he had given up playwriting.
RICHMOND, June 18--Thirtyfive of Richmond's better restaurants were added today to those in which Negro patrons may obtain service.

WASHINGTON, June 18-- The Justice Department has found no persuasive evidence to support charges that women arrested for civil rights demonstrations have been molested in the jails of Jackson, Miss., and Albany, Ga.
WASHINGTON, June 18-- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy is tightening the legislative reins on the Atomic Energy Commission.

Herbert Hoover, who became seriously ill 11 days ago, was reported "somewhat better" yesterday. He ate and had a short visit with his sons.

UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., June 18--In the postwar years, Japan's persistent trade deficit has followed a roller-coaster course, plummeting in 1961 to a record low of $1,574,000,000. Exports reached a new high of $4,236,000,00, but were topped out by imports at $5,810,000,000.

BONN, June 18--West Germany is determined to push ahead with its multi-billionmark tank construction program despite an "impressive" performance of a French-built vehicle developed as a possible nucleus for a joint French-German undertaking.
WASHINGTON, June 18 President Kennedy has decided to add a large expansion of the program for job training and vocational education to his civil rights proposals, which will go to Congress tomorrow.
LONDON, June 18--John Cowper Powys, a lecturer, novelist, poet and philosopher, died yesterday at his home in Wales. He was 90 years old.

Sugar futures continued to tally here yesterday in reaction to a stronger London market and reports of new inventory replacement buying. Both the world and domestic sugar markets continued the advance that started anew this week.

The failure of Premier-designate Aldo Moro to put a government together and the resignation of Pietro Nenni as leader of the Socialist party, mean that the Italian political crisis will continue for a long time. It is beyond doubt the most serious internal crisis Italy has faced since the powerful Communist threat of 1948 was turned back.

With rare political acumen, Greece has solved its political crisis within a week by what looks like a three-way compromise. Under this compromise, all the three principal parties involved would seem to get what they most wanted.

The grand jury investigating corruption in the administration of the state liquor law was given a six-month extension yesterday.

OTTAWA, June 20 Renewed cries of "Resign! Resign!" assailed Finance Minister Walter L. Gordon in the House of Commons today, but Mr. Gordon seemed likely to ride out the freshening storm over the antiforeign tax proposals of his new budget.

AN EXHIBITION of paintings by eight artists from India opens at Lever House, Park Avenue and 54th Street, today. The show includes examples of early Indian, sculpture, and photo graphic displays emphasizing the Indian tradition in painting, sculpture and architecture. One aim of the exhibition is to show how that tradition influences the artists on display.
LONDON, June 20 Prime Minister Macmillan won an important round tonight in his struggle to retain the leadership of the governing Conservative party for at least a few months more.
A series of problems, including mounting racial unrest, will crowd in on Mayor Wagner today when he returns here after a two-week trip to Hawaii and Japan.
PITTSBURGH, June 20 The United Steelworkers of America and the steel industry agreed today on labor contract revisions insuring a minimum of almost two more years of peace.
PHILADELPHIA, June 20 The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People accused the city administration, and the Philadelphia Labor Council today of being anti-Negro.
MOSCOW, June 20 The Soviet Union warned today that it might terminate its program of aid to Iraq if the Government continued military operations against the Kurds.
Negroes and Puerto Ricans will be sought out by Local 1 of the Plumbers Union for its apprenticeship program in a new recruiting drive.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., borrowed $22,000,000 on electricrevenue certificates yesterday at an interest cost of 2.9154 per cent. Smith, Barney Co., and associates bought the issue and offered the securities to the public priced to yield 1.70 to 3 per cent on 1964 to 1976 maturities. Goodbody Co., and associates bid a 2.936 per cent interest cost.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., June 20 Hopeful of settlement of their desegregation demands here, Negro leaders said tonight they would extend their drive to other Eastern Shore communities.

CHICAGO, June 20 The International Home Furnish ings Market is drawing to a close. Store buyers from all over the United States are packing up and heading home to await the late summer arrival of the goods they ordered here.

The stock market suffered a sharp midsession break yesterday as reports of a commando landing in Cuba raced across the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Volume boiled upward to 4,970,000 shares -- an even 1,000,000 shares higher than the previous session.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 20 Rafael Osuna, was in trouble again today dire trouble in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tennis championships on the Princeton University courts.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 20 Henry T. Adios overtook Royal Rick 30 yards from the wire tonight and won the $25,000 Tar Heel Pace by a neck at Roosevelt Raceway. The time for the mile was 2:00 2/5. Irvin Paul and Stephan Smith finished third and fourth, respectively.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 20 Henry Hirschberg, a lawyer since 1900 who specialized in criminal cases and who served as defense counsel or prosecutor in more than 100 murder trials, died yesterday in his home at nearby Balmville. He was 84 years old.
It's becoming contagious. With no apologies to Cassius (The Great) Clay, the shy, modest, mild-spoken Floyd Patterson came up with a jingle and a prediction yesterday.
The fate of the Emilia, a cargo ship up for sale to satisfy creditors' liens against Manuel E. Kulukundis, her owner, may be decided today.

WASHINGTON, June 20--A group of New Jersey and New York officials and businessmen today urged Congress to appropriate $95,000 for a study this year aimed at reducing navigational hazards in the port of New York. The hazards currently are costing the shipping industry an estimated total of $8,000,000 yearly in damages.

A tiny but masterful painting by Henri de ToulouseLautrec brought on Tuesday the greatest price recorded at an auction for a work by the French artist 1,037,870 francs ($211,651). It was purchased in Paris.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 20 The underdeveloped and advanced countries joined today in submitting five resolutions that are intended to provide an interim solution for the United Nations financial crisis.

Back from a meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors in Hawaii and a side trip to Tokyo, Mayor Wagner will face an almost staggering agenda of major issues demanding sound judgment, political courage and exercise of strong leadership.
PARIS, June 20 The French Government intends to withdraw the naval forces earmarked for the English Channel forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Government sources said tonight.

MOSCOW, June 20 Lieut. Col. Valery F. Bykovsky could have prolonged his recordbreaking flight in space if his superiors on the ground had not called him back to earth after 81 orbits, it was reported today.
CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) Billy Williams's two homers against a 24-mile-an-hour wind paced the Chicago Cubs today to a 5-0 victory over the Houston Colts.
Stock prices trembled briefly in the winds of a Cuban squall yesterday.

SPOLETO, Italy, June 20 (Reuters) The annual Spoleto Festival of the Two Worlds opened here tonight with a wildly acclaimed performance of Verdi's opera "La Traviata," produced by the film director Luchino Visconti, and the discovery of a singing star.

The principle underlying the efforts of Dr. James E. Allen Jr., New York State Education Commissioner, to speed integration in the public schools deserves universal support. The Commissioner has a duty to keep a sharp eye on the practices of all districts to prevent them from standing in the way openly or by covert maneuver of equal opportunity for all children, regardless of color or race.
JERUSALEM (Israell Sector), June 20 David BenGurion, retiring as Premier, appealed today to the Israeli Army to continue to set an example of national unity.

WITH the film, "Cleopatra," holding forth at the Rivoli and the play, "Antony and Cleopatra" bestriding the stage of the Delacorte Theater in Central Park a question. The Chinese sage who said that one picture is worth more than 10,000 words was he an advance man for 20th Century-Fox? Surely, he didn't know Shakespeare.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 20 Golf's greatest players learned anew today how humbling their paying pastime can be. Only two sub-par rounds were posted as the 63d United States Open championship started at the Country Club and neither was posted by one of the "big name" players in the field of 150 that is scrambling for the game's supreme title.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 20--Four Iraqi Cabinet minister have resigned in protest against the resumption of hostilities against Kurds in northern Iraq, according to a reliable report from Baghdad.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 20 The Special Committee on Colonialism voted 19 to 0 today to call for a special session of the General Assembly on Southern Rhodesia unless Britain acted to end white supremacy in the colony.
The trim white Dutch liner, Prinses Margriet, making her first call here, is scheduled to depart at noon tomorrow with 105 passengers for Rotterdam.

Making his way "between the horses" in the final stages, the 4-year-old colt Saidam registered a neck victory over the Little M Farm's Sunrise Flight in the feature at Adueduct yesterday. The event was a onemile purse called the White Tie Handicap, and it attracted a field of eight.
Canadian stock prices reacted slightly in trading here yesterday to the confused investment picture in Canada.
LONDON, June 20 Incredibly, the United States has won the Federation Cup.
A four day tie-up of 45 American vessels on three coasts and in Puerto Rico, which had threatened to spread to twothirds of this country's merchant marine, ended abruptly yesterday.

Government sources in Paris disclosed last night that President de Gaulle would deliver a new blow to NATO's principle of integrated defenses withdrawal of French naval units earmarked for NATO forces in the English Channel. The units consist of one aircraft carrier, six destroyers and a dozen destroyer escorts. [Page 1, Column 1.]
Reports of a Commando landing in Cuba halted a three-day advance in sugar futures yesterday.

Adlal E. Stevenson hailed the "important ambassadorial effect" of free exchange of books at the opening yesterday of the Eighth International Book Exhibition at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 20 Three of Birmingham's four municipal golf courses, which have been closed for 17 months to circumvent a Federal court desegregation order, are to be reopened June 29 on an integrated basis.

IT is unlikely now that Graham Greene will ever change his dismal opinions about men, women, the flesh and the Devil. He pities mere mortals, but finds them a miserable lot, tormented by sex, haunted by guilt, doomed to self-destruction in this world and to harsh justice in the next. In his celebrated novels, Mr. Greene has regularly mixed...
WASHINGTON, June 20--The Administration's urban mass transportation bill is being withheld from the House floor to await a more favorable reception than its sponsors now foresee.
Educational station WNDT (Channel 13) is within $60,000 of balancing its first year's budget of $3,000,000. Its 196263 fiscal year ends June 30.
WASHINGTON, June 20 The Administration denied today that it had any information about the alleged commando landings in Cuba by exiles and voiced strong doubt that anything significant had occurred.
All-things are relative. To the Yankees, it was simply an exhibition game played for charity at Yankee Stadium last night, but to the Mets it was pure World Series.
WASHINGTON, June 20--The Administration's urban mass transportation bill is being withheld from the House floor to await a more favorable reception than its sponsors now foresee.
Educational station WNDT (Channel 13) is within $60,000 of balancing its first year's budget of $3,000,000. Its 196263 fiscal year ends June 30.
WASHINGTON, June 20 The Administration denied today that it had any information about the alleged commando landings in Cuba by exiles and voiced strong doubt that anything significant had occurred.

STAY-AT-HOMES can entertain their traveling friends abroad by getting in touch with By My Guest Inc. The company's catalogue includes the traditional bon voyage flowers and steamer baskets delivered to the ship, but its specialty is "bon arrivee" gifts.

WASHINGTON, June 20--President Kennedy's European tour was pictured today by Administration officials as an important effort to impress the Atlantic alliance with the strength of American purposes and the vigor of American policies.
ST. LOUIS, June 20 Two thousand Negroes demonstrated nearly two hours today against "resegregation" in St. Louis schools.
Traders on the London stock market were inhibited again yesterday by their doubts about the future of the Macmillan Government.

The World Food Congress that assembled nearly a thousand delegates from more than a hundred nations in Washington has ended without quite meeting the challenge it faced or the hopes it had aroused. It issued a declaration expressing alarm at the rapid increase in the world's population without an adequate increase...

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 20 The moaning sounds that emerged from the first session of the United States Open golf championship today were not caused by the breezes rustling through the treetops of the stately elms and oaks. They were the agonizing wails of the vast majority of the contestants. The hidden ferocities of The Country Club had just hit them where it hurt.
Vassar College announced yesterday the selection of Dr. Alan Simpson, dean of the college at the University of Chicago, as its seventh president.
PARIS, June 20 One of France's proudest traditions, the intensive instruction she gives her school children, came under attack today from parents and teachers.
BEVERLY, Mass., June 20 (AP) Bruce Lancaster, the author, died today at the Beverly Hospital. He was 66 years old.

FRANKFURT, Germany, June 20 The production of petroleum in the United States could be increased sharply if deposits were placed under artificial water pressure to bring crude oil to the surface, the sixth World Petroleum Congress was told today.
A request by the Niagara Falls City Council to the State Power Authority to refinance the $720,000,000 Niagara Power Project was rejected yesterday.
Supreme Court Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff ruled yesterday that the Playboy Club may sell membership keys without fear of losing its liquor license.
BUENOS AIRES, June 20 The Argentine Government by a decree today has barred from the election of July 7 any parties considered linked to the ousted dictator, Juan D. Peron.
JACKSON, Miss., June 20 Negro leaders here have agreed to end racial demonstrations that have led to the arrest of more than 1,000 Negroes and whites in the last four weeks.
ROME, June 20 Giovanni Leone, the Premier-designate, reported tonight to President Antonio Segni that he was ready to form a new Government and would submit a list of Ministers tomorrow.
The landlord of an East Harlem tenement was fined $380 yesterday for a total of 76 housing violations listed against the property.

WASHINGTON, June 20 The great issues in politics are seldom simple. Increasingly, the question is, not whether a principle is right or wrong, but whether one admirable principle should take precedence over another contradictory but equally admirable principle.
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 20 Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood today won the Garden State Women's Golf Associatien's 54-hole medal-play championship.
Production and consumption of newsprint in May set new records for the month, according to reports of trade associations.

The General Drive-In Corporation of Boston, a national theater chain, has leased a 1,000-seat motion picture theater that will be constructed in the Blue Star Shopping Center on Route 22, Watchung, N.J., near Plainfield. The lease was arranged by J.I. Kislak, Inc., broker, for Philip J. Levin, realty developer who is building the shopping center.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 20 Trowbridge Callaway, former president of the Investment Bankers Association of America and the Better Business Bureau of New York, died today at Huntington Hospital at the age of 80. He was a resident of Cold Spring Harbor.
Arthur Ochs Sulzberger was named president and publisher of The New York Times yesterday. He succeeds Orvil E. Dryfoos, who died on May 25.
SAVANNAH, Ga., June 20 Negro leaders refused tonight to suspend demonstrations, which erupted into violence last night.
For the better part of seven innings at the Stadium yesterday, the Yankees performed listlessly against the Washington Senators before rousing themselves for a 5-4 victory.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 John H. MacFadyen, executive director of the New York State Council on the Arts, charged today that "America's approach to the arts is not working."
GADSDEN, Ala., June 20 A personal emissary of Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy's sought today to work out a settlement of Gadsden's 11-day racial crisis.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 20 President Kennedy, wet, crushed, but cheerful, helped West Virginia celebrate its hundredth anniversary today.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 20 One out of every 236 persons in South Africa is in jail, officials acknowledge.
HOLLYWOOD, June 21--The United States will participate in the Moscow Film Festival next month primarily to stress American film art and not propadanda.
WASHINGTON, June 21 The presidents of the two largest stock exchanges put their full support today behind proposed legislation to enlarge the Government's powers to police securities trading.
LONDON, June 21 Britain disclosed today that she had been unable to get the Soviet Union to agree to a renewed appeal for a cease-fire in Laos.

A team that can crush the Yankees, baseball champions of the whole world, shouldn't have too much trouble with the eighth-place Philadelphia Phillies, and the Mets didn't at the Polo Grounds last night. Figuratively glancing at their fingernails and whistling softly with confident disdain, they won the opener of a four-game series, 3 1.

DENVER, June 21 Colorado Republican began organizing today a Western bloc of convention delegates around the favorite son candidacy of Senator Gordon L. Allott. The move looked in part like a tactic to consolidate the mountain states strength of Senator Barry M. Goldwater of Arizona.

ST. LOUIS, June 21 (UPI) Sandy Koufax of the Los Angeles Dodgers pitched eight innings of shutout ball tonight, then needed help to weather a St. Louis Cardinal rally in the ninth to win, 5 3, and gain his 11th victory of the season.
Sugar futures recovered yesterday from selling touched off during Thursday's session by reports of rebel landings in Cuba.

NEWTONVILLE, Mass., June 21--Miss Amy Dunbar Sylvester, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Lenthall Sylvester of Cohasset, was married this afteroon in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church to Yuichi Katoh. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Taiichi Katoh of Tokyo.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 21 Fair winds and clear weather were predicted today for tomorrow's start of the yacht race from Annapolis to Newport, 473 sea miles away. The forecast for Chesapeake Bay was for winds of 15 knots from the north and northeast.
WASHINGTON, June 21 The steel settlement reached yesterday at Pittsburgh is more than just another labor agreement.
Leib Spizman, a journalist, author and Labor Zionist leader, died Thursday in the Caledonian Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 60 years old and resided at 200 Brighton 15th Street, Brooklyn.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 21 Mayor Wagner of New York called on Governor Rockefeller today to summon a special session of the Legislature to deal with racial problems.

The Transamerica Corporation of San Francisco anpounced plans Yesterday to acquire the North American group of title insurance companies through an exchange of its common stock for the net assets of the group.
State Democratic leaders are considering a reorganization plan that would for the first time give upstate Democrats a major, if not dominant, role in party affairs.
ST. LOUIS, June 21 A citizens committee urged the Board of Education today to adopt and carry out a strong...
Three hundred student nurses at Metropolitan Hospital have learned that it takes more than a dedication to make a home.

ROME, June 21 (AP) St. Peter's Square was a sunlit area of jubilation today for excited throngs of more than 100,000 attracted by the drama of the newly elected Pope. The crowds poured into the place where sorrow had kept vigil for dying Pope John XXIII just three weeks ago.
ALBANY, Ga., June 21 The police temporarily closed all business establishments in the Negro district today and banned all Negroes from the sidewalks.
WASHINGTON, June 21 The Navy ended uncertainty over the future of Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover today by announcing that he would be recalled to active duty after retiring next winter.

KATONAH, N.Y. CARAMOOR, the Venetian villa that the late Walter Tower Rosen built for his family in the rolling green hills of Westchester County, is attracting increasing numbers of students of music and the decorative arts. This private estate has been the scene of the annual Katonah music festival for 15 years and summer lectures in the arts for three years.

The International Union of Masters, Mates and Pilots said yesterday that it was resigning from the Maritime Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 21 Evariste Kimba, acting President of South Katanga Province, arrived here today to seek an understanding with the Central Government.
WASHINGTON, June 21 A New York photographer and his wife who claim that children would willingly practice typing if the typewriter made music have invented such a machine.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 21 Arnold Palmer toured the wind-whipped course of The Country Club in a brilliant twounder-par 69 today to share with Dow Finsterwald and Jacky Cupit the lead at the halfway mark of the United States Open golf championship.
WASHINGTON, June 21 The House Appropriations Committee approved a $47,092,209,000 defense fund measure today, with only relatively small changes in the Administration's original request.
REDDING, Conn., June 21 A new house that a young Negro family was about to buy burned to the ground here at dawn today. The state police suspect arson.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 21 Steuart L. Pittman, the nation's Civil Defense chief, today urged the Portland City Council to change its mind about abolishing its civil defense program.
CHICAGO, June 21 The delayed reaction to the Controller of the Currency's proposals to broaden commercial bank dealings in the municipal revenue bond underwriting field burst forth here today.
GADSDEN, Ala., June 21 Waves of young Negroes picketed downtown stores today despite a report of progress toward settling this industrial town's 12-day-old racial deadlock.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he would appoint "in a day or two" a panel of three qualified persons to induce construction unions to take in more Negroes.
The "Salute to Southern Freedom" concert at Carnegie Hall last night brought together two generations of performers and fused two traditions in presentday Negro music.
A 39-year-old novelist, who until several years ago had doubled as a dairy farmer in Virginia, will have his first play produced on Broadway in the fall.
OTTAWA, June 21 Walter L. Gordon, the harassed Minister of Finance in the minority Liberal Government, gave fresh ammunition to his critics in Parliament today.
A culling of the stocks listed on the American Stock Exchange, begun last April when stiffer listed requirements were adopted, has lopped 43 stocks from the nation's second biggest stock exchange.
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., June 21 Four hundred gifted North Carolina high school students are undergoing special training at the new Governor's School here to broaden "academic and artistic disciplines."

WASHINGTON, June 21 The election of a new Pope from the clearly progressive wing of the Roman Catholic Church aroused almost as much interest here as an important secular vote in Europe. Moreover, there was some feeling that the new strength of liberals inside the Vatican may yet have a bearing on the stirrings of Europe's political left.
WASHINGTON, June 21 The United States condemned today as "inaccurate and highly colored" the claims of Cuban exiles that there have been several landings of large numbers of men in Cuba.
The world has its answer with the election to the Papacy of Giovanni Battista Cardinal Montini, Archbishop of Milan.
ALBANY, June 21 The State Police closed in today on a statewide lottery syndicate said to be grossing $2,000,000 annually.

ST. VINCENT, Italy, June 21 In the sixth day's play of the world championship bridge matches, the United States lost back three of the 56 international match points by which it had led France today but still was ahead, 249 to 196, after 96 deals of their 144-deal match.
PARIS, June 21 France announced today that she would resume unrestrained control of virtually the whole of the nation's naval fighting force.
WASHINGTON, June 21 There has been a quiet undercurrent of amusement all season here over the bush-league exhibitionisms of the New York Mets baseball fans.
American Airlines, Inc., ended its merger agreement with Eastern Air Lines, Inc., yesterday following the Civil Aeronautics Board's rejection Thursday of the proposed... union.

Steel executives were moderately optimistic yesterday that the industry, in the months following the new labor agreement reached Thursday, could avoid the sharp drop in production that followed last year's labor settlement.
The new unit set up by the National Council of Churches to take direct action in the nation's racial crisis will get down to business next week.
Travel experts say the tourist boom in the Far East and Pacific will reach new peaks this year.

The National Conference of Christians and Jews said yesterday that the recent Supreme Court ruling on Bible reading in public schools "challenges parents and religious leaders to shape and strengthen spiritual commitment by reliance on voluntary means."
GENEVA, June 21 The United States now plans to bring into force its simplified tariff on Aug. 31, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade announced today.
MANILA, June 21 (AP) Nicasio Osmena, son of the late President Sergio Osmena, died today in a hospital at the age of 60. His death was attributed to a heart ailment after an attack of hepatitis.
ROME, June 21 Pope Paul VI began his pontificate today amid general forecasts that it would bring an energetic continuation of the progressive course charted by Pope John XXIII.

St. James Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Julie Davis Vietor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Vietor Jr. of 21 East 90th Street, to Joseph Horne Holmes 3d. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Holmes Jr. of New Canaan, Conn.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 21 Finance Minister Carlos Carvalho Pinto said today that Brazil had "no insuperable problems if there is the courage to confront them."

LONDON, June 21 The future of the 17-year-old Royal Philharmonic Orchestra is up in the air. The uncertainty arises just three months before the start of the orchestra's 58city tour of the United States and Canada.

PARIS, June 21 The French Government believes President de Gaulle's visit to West Germany next month will counteract any weakening of the French-German alliance resulting from President Kennedy's talks with German leaders.
ROME, June 21--Giovanni Battista Cardinal Montini, 65year-old Archbishop of Milan, was elected Supreme Pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church today. He will reign as Pope Paul VI.
MOSCOW, June 21 The newspaper Pravda, organ of the Soviet Communist party, sharply attacked Prime Minister Macmillan today for seeking to connect the Soviet Union with the Profumo affair.
ROME, June 21 (AP) The new Pope is the 262d recognized Pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church. He is not the first to bear that number, and may not be the last.
LONDON, June 21 The House of Lords defeated today a move to permit divorce in Britain on the ground that a marriage had failed.
Two pairs of gunmen one pair in the Bronx and the other at La Guardia Airport escaped with a total of $29,211 in holdings yesterday.

The fact that one of every two Americans has a driver's license indicates that "we haven't been very selective in the licensing process," a state official told a conference of judges and prosecutors here yesterday.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 21 Negro residents started a boycott of local merchants today to protest "discriminatory" zoning practices.

LONDON, June 21 Prime Minister Macmillan announced today that a judicial inquiry would be held into the security aspects of the Profumo scandal. The form of the inquiry was immediately criticized by the Opposition Labor party as a "cover-up."

Mary Martin's heart belongs to "Jennie." At the 54th Street Theater yestrday, "Jennie," Miss Martin's new musical, became the first of next season's Broadway shows to officially begin fullscale rehearsals.

Last August one would have thought a Philippine claim for $73,000,000 in damages done by United States forces in the island republic during the Japanese war had been disposed of finally and forever. Both the Senate and the House at that time approved payment of the claim, acknowledged by the United States Government since 1946.
ROME, June 21 The new Pope is the sixth to take the name of Paul since it was first used in the latter part of the eighth century.

FROM a city long associated with meat-packing and railroads come the ladylike designs of Catherine Scott, a Chicagoan who, since 1956, has been creating clothes comparable in price to those of top designers in New York and California.
ROME, June 21--One of the first messages that Pope Paul VI sent from the Vatican after his election today was to Milan: "Please send me my books."
Mayor Wagner made it clear yesterday that he would actively oppose Carmine G. De Sapio's attempted political comeback.

CLEVELAND, June 21 (AP) Early Wynn lost his bid to become the 14th 300-game winner in baseball history tonight when Ron Hansen hit a two-run homer with two out in the ninth inning and gave the Chicago White Sox a 2-0 victory over Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) A two-week North Pacific fisheries conference ended in a deadlock today with the United States and Canada opposed to a Japanese plan that would ease restrictions on halibut fishing.
WASHINGTON, June 21 The Air Force awarded today three contracts to California defense conoerns to study a new piloted space plane.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 21 Teen-agers took to the streets here today to find summet jobs for themselves and their companions.

IN June the shops are filled with everything fresh and summery. Cool greens and blues, lavender, mauve, pale yellow, orange and gold are the colors of the Indian madras tablecloths in large block checks in Bloomingdale's second floor linen department.
LOS ANGELES, June 21 Negro leaders here, dissatisfied with two weeks of negotiation, have scheduled a series of integration demonstrations starting Monday.
Stock prices advanced in moderately active trading yesterday as the market continued to settle down from Thursday's mid-day excitement over reports of a landing in Cuba by refugees.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 20--The Government of President Ngo Dinh Diem and his family is engaged in an all-out struggle for political survival.
Investor's on the London stock market ended a week of cautious trading yesterday on another cautious note.
CHICAGO, June 21 (UPI) Prices of grain futures fell sharply today on the Board of Trade.

ST. LOUIS, June 21 Bob Hayes, a muscular football player with a sprinter's gift of speed, stormed to a world record in the 100-yard dash tonight as the 75th Amateur Athletic Union national track and field championships began at Public Schools Stadium.
The shipping industry here is deeply concerned about a new Congressional challenge on Federal shipping policy.
THE day before the bomb fell on Hiroshima, the Japanese granted independence to Indonesia.
Dealers in corporate bonds traded actively yesterday, but their's was the only section of the bond market with any life.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 21--Rafael Osuna of Mexico and the University of Southern California finally met his master today in defense of his title in the National Collegiate tennis championships.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., June 21--Negotiations between white officials and militant Negro leaders reached an impasse late tonight.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 21 The usually erratic Duke Rodney stayed on the trot tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Because he did, the 5-year-old son of Rodney upset Su Mac Lad in the $25,000 Trader Horn Trot.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 Attorney General Kennedy said today that the nation could not stand for the stalling involved in waiting for the United States Supreme Court to "spell out each new particularity of civil rights."
A patrolman shot and killed a knife-wielding holdup man near Grand Central Terminal yesterday at 3 P.M. as heavy crowds looked on.

WASHINGTON, June 21 Commissioner of Education Francis Keppel said today that such problems as equal treatment of the races must be resolved before the nation can concentrate on seeking excellence in education.
The city's ultra-high-frequency television station, WNYCTV, is planning an hour a day of programing in Spanish by the end of the summer.

MOSCOW, June 21 Leonid I. Brezhnev, a member of the ruling Presidium of the Soviet Communist Party, emerged tonight after plenary meetings of the Central Committee as a likely political heir of Premier Khrushchev.
BONN, June 21 Soviet authorities in Berlin have given assurances that President Kennedy will not be molested in his flight to and from the Communist-encircled city next week.

A Triple Crown of a rather esoteric nature may be retired for the first time today with the running of the Coaching Club American Oaks at Aqueduct. The race, at a mile and a quarter, is the final part of a triad for 3-year-old fillies competing in stakes presented by the New York Racing Association.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 21 Adlai E. Stevenson said today that the present special session on finances had headed the United Nations "back toward financial health" after a threat of "financial chaos."
WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) For the last three days, the Soviet Union has not jammed United States Voice of American programs beamed to the Soviet people.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 A case history of the building of a path-charting symphony orchestra in a city with formerly "chaotic" musical conditions was related today.

MILAN, Italy, June 21 All activity was suspended in this city for hours as the Milanese celebrated with great joy the election of their Archbishop, Giovanni Battista Cardinal Montini, to the throne of St. Peter as Pope Paul VI.

Six building trades unions representing 65,000 workers reached agreements with employer associations yesterday, marking an important break in contract negotiations in the city's construction industry.
Nearly half a billion dollars of corporate and municipal debt obligations is slated to reach the market next week. It will be one of the busiest weeks for bond dealers in history.
THE handsome bell shape and rich green color of sweet peppers make them a particularly attractive shell in which to cook and serve other foods.
ROME, June 21 Giovanni Leone, Premier-designate, and speaker of the Chamber of Deputies since 1955, formed a oneparty government tonight of Christian Democrats.

DETROIT, June 21 A groupof Michigan labor leaders challenged the constitutionality today of the legislative districting provisions of the state's recently adopted Constitution. The challenge was made in a suit filed in United States District Court here.
KANSAS CITY, June 21 (AP) A Negro policeman, who was previously an administrative assistant to Chief of Police C.M. Kelley, was promoted today to command of the night patrol.
ATHENS, June 18 In the evening when the jeweled lights of Athens wink on, all eyes shift to the center of the city to see the Parthenon alit on the hill of the Acropolis.
BOSTON. THE 12th annual Boston Arts Festival, which opened on Thursday in the parklike Public Garden, has managed to preserve its informal and unpretentious character through the years.

LONG BEACH, Calif., June 1 (UPI) A Marine pilot who survived a 15,000-foot fall when his parachute failed to open told today how he had tried to open the chute before he landed feet first in the ocean.
BONN, June 21 The Federal Parliament, locked in a states rights battle with West Germany's 11 states, adopted the 1963 national budget today over warnings that its act was unconstitutional.

PARIS, June 21 Because he is chief of an actual state, Vatican City, and because he is in a position of immense diplomatic influence, the Pope may properly be regarded in political as well as religious terms. In this respect the new Pontiff, Paul VI, has particular interest to the entire world and above all, perhaps, to Italy.

WASHINGTON, June 21 Many of the nation's leading lawyers promised President Kennedy at a conference today that they would help open the lines of communication between the races. But they were told by a participant at the conference that they faced "a long hot summer."
William L. Cary, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is seeking broader powers for regulating the securities industry.

AMSTERDAM. THE peripatetic World Fes tival of the International Society for Contemporary Music took place this year in Amsterdam between June 8 and 14. There were four orchestral and two chamber music concerts, in which 34 compositions from 17 countries were heard.

"SUNRISE SEMESTER" will be televised nation ally for the first time next fall by the Columbia Broadcasting System. College courses conducted by fac ulty members of New York University will be offered for credit either through N.Y.U. or many other colleges and universities that will be invited to participate in the project.

MANY features of the preColumbian Indian civili zations of Central and South America strongly suggest contact with the Bronze Age civilizations of the Eastern Mediterranean and (much later) with Polynesia.
LONDON, June 22--A thriving Asian smuggling trade in baby orangutans has been temporarily suppressed by the efforts of an international group of wildlife conservationists.
More than 1,000 coaches, from all fifty states and five foreign countries, will attend the annual free coaching school that begins tomorrow at Kutsher's Country Club in Monticello, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- President Kennedy acted today to remove "a serious morale problem" among Negroes in the armed forces. He ordered the secretary of Defense to report in 30 days on action taken on complaints of discrimination made by a special committee.

STUDENTS of African music customarily make two major divisions in that most musical of continents. North Africa, which is linked by custom and culture to the Near East and the Arab world, is usually considered a separate entity from the diverse musical traditions of Negro Africa.
AIRLINE liability for air passengers traveling on international routes will be doubled to $16,582 a person starting Aug. 1, according to the International Civil Aviation Organization.

MANCHESTER, Vt., June 23 --Stutz Plaisted of Salem, Mass., didn't break any records today but he was the fastest traveler over the 5.2-mile Mount Equinox road in the Sports Car Club of America's annual hill climb.

Buildings Commissioner Harold Birns announced yesterday that, beginning today, summonses for housing violations would be served personally on Manhattan landlords instead of being sent through the mail.
RUTHERFORD, N. J., June 23--Edward Williams College, a two-year coeducational institution, will be established as an affiliate of Fairleigh Dickinson University.
CINCINNATI, June 23 (AP) --The Cincinnati Reds moved to within one game of the National League lead today with two victories over the Houston Colts.
One of the world's largest inventories of marine parts and engines under private American ownership has been sold.
ELKHART LAKE, Wis., June 23 (UPI)--Harry Heuer scored his first major victory today at the Elkhart Lake Road America track in the feature of the international June auto sprints.
A Roman Catholic priest yesterday termed the recent Supreme Court decision on school prayer "a momentary victory of the secularists in the field of education in our country."
Dedication services were held yesterday for 68 newly commissioned lieutenants of the Salvation Army at the Army's Centennial Memorial Temple, 120 West 14th Street.
WHETHER shoppers speak Spanish or Swahili, Mrs. Maria Theresa Gilmour is prepared to deal deftly and diplomatically with their clothing and home furnishings problems.
Prices of cotton futures showed gains of 70 cents to $2.10 a bale last week in trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The latest Soviet excursion into space can have fruits that transcend the national or the scientific if the words Premier Khrushchev used in welcoming back cosmonauts Valentina Tereshkova and Valery Bykovsky embodied something more than the euphoria of a magnificent achievement.

ZANDVOORT, the Netherlands, June 92--Jim Clark of Scotland, in a Lotus, won the 220-mile Dutch Grand Prix auto race by more than a lap today and took a commanding point lead toward the drivers' world championship. Phil Hill of California, the 1961 world champion, crashed early in the race but was unhurt.
Operations of the Duro-Test Corporation in the nine months ended April 30 resulted in record sales and improved earnings, according to the report issued today.
Edmond J. Bartnett, a reporter for The New York Times, died yesterday at Bellevue Hospital, where he had undergone a series of emergency stomach operations.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 23 (AP)--Al Smith provided the power and Stu Miller the pitching relief today as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Minnesota Twins, 4--1.

PITTSBURGH, June 23-- Steel officials expect inventory liquidation to begin in August.
WASHINGTON, June 23--A shadow cast by the Berlin wall is threatening international scientific meetings in the United States and other North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations.
DETROIT, June 23-Negroes protesting discrimination were joined by white leaders and residents today in a mammoth freedom parade and rally here.
The performance of the stock market over the last year is even more remarkable than the performance of the economy. But only a few brave souls have ventured any... explanation of its phenomenal rise.
Ground was broken at Idlewild Airport yesterday for three chapels--Jewish, Roman Catholic and Protestant--that will rise side-by-side by next summer.

An eight-week training program for youth workers will get under way today under the auspices of the State Division for Youth, aided by a $55,000 grant from the President's Committee on Juvenile Delinquency and Youth Crime. Mrs. Roosevelt Is Honored

WEST JORDAN, Utah, June 23 (UPI)--The manager of the middleweight contender, Gene Fullmer, said today promoters had consented to a two-week postponment in the FullmerDick Tiger championship bout because of a foo injury suffered by the Utah boxer.

Six floors in a 38-story office building, under construction at 777 Third Avenue at 48th Street have been leased by Grey Advertising, Inc., one of the largest agencies in the country. The lease is for 20 years and involves 115,000 square feet.
BONN, June 23 (AP)--Following are the texts of Chancelor Adenauer's speech of welcome to President Kennedy, the President's reply, and the toasts that the two proposed at dinner later:

GADSDEN, Ala., June 23-- Negro leaders called today for a resumption of mass demonstrations after the Justice Department failed in an attempt to mediate this city's racial dispute.
BONN, June 23--More than 1,000,000 cheering Rhinelanders turned out today to give President Kennedy a "herzlich willKommen"--a heartfelt welcome.

COLORADO SPRINGS, June 22--The management of the union-subsidized Free Press was heartened this week with a minor victory in the 16-year-old battle with The Colorado Springs Gazette-Telegraph one of the R.C. Hoiles chain of newspapers.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., June 23--The New York Athletic Club senior eight sprinted at 43 strokes a minute today to overtake and defeat the Union Boat Club of Boston by a length in a 1,200 meter (about threequarters of a mile) race on the Orchard Beach Lagoon.
LONDON, June 23--There is a major change under way in the concept of the educational requirements of the British businessman.

HONG KONG, June 23-- Communist China and North Korea joined today in a militant declaration that emphasized a common ideological stand against the Soviet Union and warned that differences in the Communist camp must be settled "through interparty consultations on an equal footing."

While the Federal Government is pressing tax cuts as a means of freeing the economy from an artificial restraint on growth, the states and cities are looking for--and find ing--new sources of revenue to meet their burgeoning needs.
Traffic "horror" films intended to scare motorists into being better drivers have proved of little value, Dr. James L. Malfetti of Columbia University said yesterday.

West Ham United of London and Kilmarnock of Scotland, two smartly-drilled clubs, moved into a first-place tie in the First Section of the International Soccer League yesterday at Downing Stadium, Randalls island.
Despite recent rises in air and steamship fares, middle-income groups on both sides of the Atlantic are increasingly able to afford travel, according to The Travel Agent, a trade magazine.

A New York clergyman called on churchgoers yesterday to defend openly Negro rights "to live on any street that he wants to, to go to any school of his choice, to worship in any church or to be employed in any job he is capable of filling."

The sign on the wall of the Chess Checker Club of New York read "Kibitzers Not Welcome," but by 2 P.M. a halfdozen of them had slipped into the small clubroom at 212 West 42d Street--waiting, hoping that the world's checker hero, Tom Wiswell, would make a fool of himself.

ST. VINCENT, Italy, June 23--Italy has won the world bridge championship again, for the third year in a row and the sixth time in seven years. The Italians clinched the title against the the United States yesterday, winning by 313 to 294 international match points.
WASHINGTON, June 23-- President Kennedy's civil rights bill starts up the long, tough legislative trail this week.

PARIS, June 23--About the only concrete achievement President Kennedy might expect from his European trip is to get some motion into our stalemated plan for a multilateral nuclear force in NATO. But even this prospect is dim.
CLEVELAND, June 23 (UPI) --Barry Latman of the Cleveland Indians hurled a five-hit, 2-0 victory today after the Chicago White Sox had won the opener of a double-header, 2--1.
LONDON, June 23--The annual performance by the Royal Ballet School, which took place at Covent Garden yesterday, is always among the most eagerly awaited London dance events.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. L., Jun. 23--After a long vigil, during which members of the host Knickerbocker Yacht Club prepared six potential courses, the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound's regatta wac canceled today.

Edward Albee, author of "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?," is planning to have his second Broadway play, "The Ballad of the Sad Cafe," performed without an intermission because "there's no stopping place."
BOSTON, June 23--The New York Yankees dealt the Red Sox pennant aspirations a final devastating blow today as the Bombers crushed Boston, 8 to 0, before 29,402 fans.

ST. LOUIS, June 23--After two days of high-pressure competition in the 75th Amateur Athletic Union championships, the United States' Moscow-bound track and field team today became a dashing diplomatic delegation with a victorious tradition to uphold.
JACKSON, Miss., June 23-- Byron de La Beckwith, known as an outspoken white supremacist, was charged with murder today in the ambush slaying of Medgar W. Evers, Negro civil rights leader.

In China, where the chow chow has been known for more than 2,000 years, it is referred to as the black-tongued dog, the bear dog and the wolf dog. In this country a dark red representative of the breed, Ch. Ah Sid's The Dilettante, should simply be called the winning dog.
THE first season of New York Philharmonic pop concerts at Philharmonic Hall ended last night with a program entitled "The Dance." The event was a repeated Saturday-night concert.
The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey is not planning to renew its sponsorship of the "Festival of Performing Arts" series next season.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 23-- Challenge, a brand new 64-foot aluminum sloop owned by George F. Johnson of Philadelphia, was the first yacht to round Chesapeake Bay Lightship in the Annapolis-to-Newport race today.
The Government agency that regulates most of the nation's savings and loan associations is in one of the most awkward dilemmas public regulators encounter.
MARYVILLE, Tenn., June 23 Activities planned at a moun tain biracial camp raided Thursday by the police were canceled today "until further notice."
Orders for 41 ships aggregating 2,279,000 tons have been placed with Japanese shipyards by Greek companies in the last nine months. The orders total $240,000,000.

The virtues of the reorganization of New York's courts are well shown by the increased operations ordered for this summer. Long judicial vacations and suspended sessions used to pile up backlogs of business and worked special hardship on persons being held for trial.
The 10-story building containing 64 apartments at 72 to 78 West 68th Street, near the Lincoln Center, has been sold by Jack Grossman to Philip Gold for investment.
The invitational opening of the Festival Theater at 6 West 57th Street tonight, marks a high point in the current wave of movie theater construction in this city and throughout the country.
TORONTO, June 23 (Canadian Press)--Dr. Herbert Alexander Bruce, a former Lieutenant Governor of Ontario, died yesterday in his home at the age of 94. He suffered a heart attack two weeks ago.

The B'nai B'rith Hillel Foundations, now celebrating its 40th anniversary as a campus religious and cultural movement, is encouraging "more positive interest" in Judaism and Jewish activities among faculty members of that faith.

DENVER, June 23--Representatives of Trans World Airlines management and three labor unions within the airline met in Denver last week with a labor relations expert in a seminar on how to avoid strikes.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 23 --Big Julius Boros, playing with the indolent ease of a club champion in a social Sunday match with nothing at stake, reclaimed golf's most cherished title today after an interval of 11 years.

MONTREAL, June 23--When the president of the Montreal Stock Exchange and the Canadian Stock Exchange says "The financial capitals of the world have just about had enough from Canada," it is enough to shake Parliament to its very rafters.

"I HAVE TAKEN all knowledge to be my province." So wrote Francis Bacon as a young man. The province of knowl edge was less extensive in Bacon's time than in ours. Neverthless, there is something magnificent in such an ambition.
WASHINGTON, June 23--A convention of national leaders in the field of litter prevention opened here today and will continue through Tuesday. Its outcome will be closely watched.

The criminal parts of the Supreme Courts in Manhattan and the Bronx will maintain full trial schedules in July and August in an effort to reduce court congestion and to shorten the stay in jail of persons awaiting trials.
Carl Willey and Tracy Stallard pitched the New York Mets into ninth place yesterday, beating the Philadelphia Phillies, 5--0 and 4--1, at the Polo Grounds.
Congress has called for reports from two Federal maritime agencies on practices in ocean freight shipments.

OTTAWA, June 23--The "60 days of decision" heralded by the minority Liberal Government ended last Thursday on a discordant note. The Government forces, rattled by the erratic behavior of the Finance Minister, were in retreat.
The International Ladies Garment. Workers Union reported yesterday that employers had contributed more than a billion dollars to its 127 health and welfare and other benefit funds.
LONDON, June 23-Roy Emerson and Margaret Smith of Australia are top-seeded and the favorites to win the AllEngland lawn tennis championships, which start tomorrow.
BILOXI, Miss., June 23 (AP) --The police arrested today 68 Negroes and 3 white men who staged a "wade-in" demonstration at a Gulf of Mexico beach near the downtown waterfront.
ST. LOUIS, June 23 (AP)-- Jim Gilliam's three-run homer in the fifth inning today carried the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 4-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.
Carmine G. De Sapio indicated yesterday that he had no intention of engaging in a personal fight with Mayor Wagner over his political comeback attempt in Greenwich Village.
TUCSON, Ariz., June 25 (AP) --Dr, Robert L. Nugent, for 16 years vice president of the University of Arizona, died Saturday of cancer. He was 61 years old.

In January of 1959, Mrs. Ceil Leon shut down her liquor package store in Flushing, Queens, and put her stock into a bonded warehouse. A widow, she had made a good living for eight years from the store at 185-18 Horace Harding Boulevard until a project to widen the boulevard brought a wall that isolated the business.
An appeal was made yesterday to Mayor Wagner to keep school playgrounds open until late evening throughout the year.

It was business as usual at Central Park Mall last night as the Goldman Band rounded out its 2,500th free public concert and faced immediately to No. 2,501. No ceremonies marked the occasion, beyond the usual one of fine music freely given and freely enjoyed.

The newspaper industry has long been eager to expand its share of national advertising. While newspapers account for more that 60 per cent of all retail and local advertising, the medium carries only about 11 per cent of all national advertising.

WASHINGTON, June 23-- The proposed repeal of a 1954 law that provides $460,000,000 in annual tax benefits to corporation stockholders has become the most hotly disputed tax reform sought by President Kennedy.
ALGIERS, June 23--Informed officials said tonight that Mohammed Boudiaaf, a leading opponent of Premier Ahmed Ben Bella, had been arrested.
The two Latin-American statesmen assigned to make a study of the Alliance for Progress have done a job which, like the curate's egg, is both good and bad.

BONN, June 23--President Kennedy began a four-day working visit to West Germany today with a pointed exchange that indicated considerable differences between him and Chancellor Adenauer on Western policy.
Thirty-two African states are imperiling the United Nations by the campaign they have begun to coerce the world organization into expelling South Africa from membership.

CAIRO, June 23--Richard M. Nixon, hailing the Aswan High Dam as "one of the wonders of the modern world," indicated today that, in retrospect, the Eisenhower Administration might have made a mistake in withholding aid for the project in 1956.
An enlarged and greatly revised edition of the mutual-fund bible was published today, heralded by its ever-optimistic sponsor's forecasts--also enlarged and revised.

The oldest Methodist congregation in America greeted a new pastor yesterday.

ABOARD U.S.S. FORT SNELLING, at Sea, June 23-- Preparations were virtually completed this evening for the first dive by the bathyscaph Trieste tomorrow morning in its search for the wreckage of the nuclear submarine Thresher. The submarine was lost with 129 men April 10.

Fresh from his Pacific trip, Mayor Wagner has plunged into the problem of anti-Negro discrimination in employment, especially in the construction trades, as his task of first priority. To the New York State Conference of Mayors he said that the question as to the wrongs of the past being righted was "not whether and when to do it, but how to do it, now."
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 23--One of Kataga's last foreign mercenaries told today of plans for training Katangese gendarmes in Portuguese Angola.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 23-- United States servicemen coming to South Vietnam are now being told by their officers to give a more positive picture of events here to American reporters. They have been told to avoid "gratuitous criticism."

An official of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said last night that mass demonstrations would take place this summer if school officials did not make clear promptly what they intended to do to end racial imbalance.

SAN CRISTOBAL, Mexico, June 23 (AP)--Frans Blom archeologist who spent most of his life among the Lancandon Indians in the remote jungles of the State of Chiapas, died here today of a liver ailment He was 70 years old.

A new and comprehensive center for the deaf will be built by the Lexington School for the Deaf at a cost of $6,000,000. The site will be a seven-acre plot between 25th and 30th Avenues and 73rd and 75th Streets in Jackson Heights, Queens.

A FIVE-MAN chess team from the United States will compete for the World Students' Team Championship at Budva, Yugoslavia, this July. The participation of the Americans was made possible chiefly through the generosity of E.B. Martin.
