BEVERLY FARMS, Mass., June 23--In St. John's Protesttant Episcopal Church this afternoon, Miss Dorothy Batchelder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Lawrence Batchelder of Haven Hill, was married to Spencer Borden 4th. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Borden of Concord.

For the third time in a century, new vistas and unmapped roads are opening for Japan. Full to the brim with energy and the zest of creative talent, the nation moves forward eagerly toward them and then suddenly hesitates and withdraws, afraid of the test like a timid giant aware of his hidden weakness.

PARIS, June 23-- "Other countries might well be able to profit" from studying the way Sweden has coped with the business cycle over the recent past, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.
JONES BEACH, L. I., June 23--Armchair tourists, weary of turning pages in the travel sections of newspapers and magazines, may now head for the Marine Theater here.
LOS ANGELES, June 23-- Legitimate theater will boom here this summer with the opening of two theaters in the round.

MILWAUKEE, June 23 (UPI) --Warren Spahn started a sevenrun rally with his 33d career, homer in the fifth inning today and went on to pitch the Milwaukee Braves to a 10-4 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
SAG HARBOR, L.I., June 23--More than 1,000 persons watched parachutists dive more than 10,000 feet, motor boats race and experts water ski at the Old Whalers' Festival today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 23 (AP)--Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, has accused the nation's railroads proposing mergers "based upon the concept of creating regional monopolies, shrinking rail capacity and eliminating service."

DETROIT, June 23--The automobile industry's 1964 models will feature bigger compacts, racier slant-roof sports cars and more luxurious refinements, Except at the Ford Motor Company, there will be relatively few major styling changes on the standard lines.
The city is making it easier to produce motion pictures, television and commercial films here.
Dr. Calvin E. Gross, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday he would do everything he could to keep the city's public schools open if there was a teachers' strike this fall.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI)--Senator Henry M. Jackson predicted today that the Soviet Union would soon resume nuclear weapons tests and called the prospects for a test-ban agreement "virtually hopeless."
ADEN, June 23--Five British soldiers were killed and 21 others, including four servicewomen, were taken prisoner by Yemeni tribesmen after being ambushed when they strayed over the border from Aden.
ALBANY, June 23--Governor Rockefeller moved today to intensify state activity on minority problems by appointing Alexander Aldrich as chairman of a special Cabinet committee on civil rights.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 --President Kennedy was asked today to name Mrs. Helen M. Thompson, executive vice president and treasurer of the American Symphony Orchestra League, to his new National Advisory Council on the Arts.
ROME, June 23--Pope Paul VI marked his first day of official business as Pontiff by sending his special blessing to New York through Cardinal Spellman.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 23--In the Grecian courtyard of a one-time millionaire's mansion overlooking the blue Pacific, about 170 people sat for six hours this weekend discussing democracy.

GEORGETOWN, British Gulana, June 23--Less than 12 hours after an anonymous threat was telephoned to police, saboteurs blew up Georgetown's ferry terminal to halt a steamer service being operated by nonstrikers.

The airline situation is as murky as ever as a result of the Civil Aeronautics Board's 3-to-2 rejection of the proposed merger of American Airlines and Eastern Airlines in their domestic operations. No reason was given for the decision, which is considered tentative until the White House decides the separate question of merger of their international routes.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 23--Somehow or other, a playoff for the United States Open golf championship seems slightly anticlimactic. After excitement has reached a boiling point on the final day of the regulation tournament, the extra round is akin to reheating a meal, It usually loses much of its savor.

HANOVER, N.H., June 23--The Dartmouth College Alumni Council has chosen F. William Andres, Boston lawyer, to fill the vacancy on the Dartmouth board of trustees caused by the death of Orvil E. Dryfoos.
Image making, the art of projecting oneself as one wishes to be seen, will be explored on an international level this week in Aspen, Colo.

WASHINGTON, June 23-- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, a do-it-yourself man, recently, picked up the telephone and called a businessman to ask him to come to the White House for a meeting to discuss lowering racial barriers.

Albert C. Simmonds Jr., board chairman and chief executive officer of the Bank of New York, died yesterday in they Harkness Pavilion, of the, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. His age was 60. He lived at Indian Trail in Harrison, N. Y.

Much of the world's petroleum is found beneath deserts. The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) is developing what it hopes will be a commercially valuable method of returning some of that petroleum to the desert sands.
WESTPORT, Conn,, June 23 --Winning the bonus-point stake, High Noon today gained the reserve open jumper championship of the four-day Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show.

THE season for high quality, moderately priced fresh fruit is relatively short in the New York City area. Cherries, grapes, peaches, nectarines, plums, mangoes and melons have already begun to arrive in quantity, and all are suitable. for a major role in main dishes for summer dining.

City Commerce Commissioner Louis Broido declared last night that the State Commission for Human Rights was without authority to investigate charges that one of his deputies, in seeking to hire a secretary, had specified "white only."

BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y., June 23--St. Matthias Roman Catholic Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Constance Ann Congdon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard Davis Congdon, to William Paynter Wolfe 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wolfe Jr. of Eastchester.

GENEVA, June 24--David A. Morse, director general of the International Labor Organization, has drafted a four-point plan aimed at blacklisting South Africa because of its racial policy of apartheid, or segregation.
A. Philip Randolph, president of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, announced yesterday that the union has called a nationwide strike for midnight July 1.

FALLSBURG, N. Y., June 24 --The head of the largest Jewish Orthodox rabbinic body in the country called tonight for legislation to grant income-tax credit to parents who pay tuition for children in parochial hand private schools.

A $60,000,000 recreational and tourism project in eight Southwestern and Rocky Mountain States was announced yesterday by the Frontier West Corporation, a new wholly owned subsidiary of the Goldfield Corporation.

David Charnay, chairman of the board of two corporations, and two other corporate officers were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to defraud the public through high-pressure selling in a boiler room operation.

Gerardo A. (Jerry) Re and other brokers received undercover cash payments in excess of $550,000 for allegedly manipulating and selling unregistered Swan-Finch common stock in 1955-57, it was testified yesterday in United States District Court.
Gov. Endicott Peabody of Massachusetts expressed hope yesterday that "an agreement can be worked out" on the planes and other equipment on which Northeast Airlines owes money.
Steel production dropped below an estimated 80 per cent of capacity last week for the first time in more than two months.

The hero's welcome accorded President Kennedy in Bonn can easily be misinterpreted. This is always the case with mass demonstrations. There is no doubt that the outpouring of sentiment is genuine. General de Gaulle was given an equally warm and tumultuous reception by the German people.
Dr. Irving Rose of 5502 Kings Highway, Brooklyn, director of radiology at Coney Island Hospital, died Sunday while playing golf at the Dyker Heights course in Brooklyn. His age was 53.
PARIS, June 24--President Kennedy's tumultuous welcome in Bonn was accompanied today by some critical examination here of France's position within the Atlantic community.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 24 --The Tennessee Valley Authority announced today it was planning to offer short-term notes for sale periodically through the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. They will be sold to commercial banks, trust companies and securities dealers.
MOST STOCKS SAG AS RAILS ADVANCE Railroad stocks highballed ahead yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange for the second straight trading day. The market as a whole, however, sagged.
WASHINGTON, June 24-- The Senate committee with jurisdiction over Ellis Island has given the sponsors of public development for the island one more chance to find an acceptable plan.

WASHINGTON, June 24-- Businesses and individuals who deduct the cost of business entertaining on their tax returns will have until Aug. 1 to comply with the Government's new expense-account regulations.
MOSCOW, June 24--The Kremlin openly rebuked the Chinese Communist leadership today for the first time.
MIAMI, June 24 (AP)--The Cuban Revolutionary Council elected Dr. Manuel Antonio de Varona, former Cuban Premier, as its president today and struck back at its critics.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, June 25, --Premier Khrushchev will visit East Berlin later this week. Tass, the Soviet press agency, said Mr. Khrushchev would go to the city to take part in birthday celebrations for Walter Ulbricht, the Communist chief of East Germany. Mr. Ulbricht will be 70 years old Sunday.

HISTORIANS may well mark this decade as the period of elegance in restaurant design. It is apparent in the trappings of such dining places as the Four Seasons and the Forum of the Twelve Caesars, La Caravelle and La Cote Basque, La Fonda del Sol and the new Regency Hotel. Such elegance is also much in evidence in the Voisin, which opened within recent weeks at a new address, 30 East 65th Street.
CHICAGO, June 24 (UPI)-- Soybeans and corn ended with strong gains, oats were firm and other grain futures were weak today on the Board of Trade.
DETROIT, June 24 (AP)-- Automobile production eased last week but still appeared headed toward a 7,000,000-unit year.

HURLEYVILLE, N.Y., June 24--Rip Van Winkle awoke from a long sleep to find himself surrounded by dwarfs. The residents of this village in the Catskills awoke today to find 300 puppeteers from 37 states and Argentina converging on their community for a weeklong puppet festival.

HOLLYWOOD, June 24-- John Frankenheimer, the director, has justified the suspicions of the Pentagon that it would not be treated kindly in the movie version of "Seven Days in May," the best-selling novel by Fletcher Knebel and Charles W. Bailey 2d.

TRENTON, June 24--Gov. Richard J. Hughes has notified David C. Thompson that he will be replaced by State Senator Donal C. Fox as the New Jersey member on the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

The Board of Education was urged yesterday to consider transporting white children to schools in Negro neighborhoods to help achieve better racial balances in the city school system.
LOS ANGELES, June 24-- The national wave of Negro civil rights demonstrations extended today to the West Coast and the country's second largest metropolis.

Production started yesterday on the first film in New York's newest motion picture studio-- a remodeled hangar at Roosevelt Field, L. I., where Charles A. Lindbergh took off on his flight across the Atlantic 36 years ago.

Representative Wright Patman led a 23-man delegation from Congress on a day-long tour of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday, where some of the policies he has criticized so sharply over the years are executed.
WASHINGTON, June 24-- The Senate headed off today a threatened revenue loss to the Government of $4,200,000,000.

The Detroit uniform was new because the confessed little genius had just been appointed manager of the floundering Tigers. For some totally incomprehensible reason, the Bengals failed to respond to his uplifting influence and continued to lose. Hence the subdued look.

One woman was killed and two other persons were injured seriously last night when they were struck by a car that mounted the sidewalk on the south side of West 33d Street.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 24 (AP)--George M. Trautman, president of minor-league baseball since 1947, died today at his home. He was 73 years old. Mr. Trautman had been ill for some time with a heart ailment, but cancer was given as the primary cause of death.
ALBANY, June 24--Alexander Aldrich, head of a new state Cabinet committee on civil rights, said today he saw no need for a special session of the Legislature.

Excellencies, Dear Sirs: We accept, with a recog nition mixed a little with embarrassment, the words addressed to us by your very worthy spokesman, which were somewhat too full of praise for our humble person. WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) --The Urban Renewal Administration announced today two steps to combat racial discrimination in housing.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) --The Interior Department announced today it had recommended that Congress allow the use of public lands for geothermal steam to generate electricity.
The fleet of 88 yachts in the Annapolis-Newport race made slow progress yesterday, the third day of the race, as light winds plagued the boats in their passage up the shore of the Delmarva Peninsula.
"C.B.S. Reports" is considering the telecast of a documentary on ratings next season.

CHICAGO, June 24--President Kennedy urged union members today to work in their communities for desegregation. He did this in a color movie made at the White House last week for showing at the convention of the Retail Clerks International Association.

Flashing into the lead soon after the start and staying there to the end, the Cambridge Stable's Timbeau captured the 51st running of the colt division of the National Stallion Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. John Rotz rode the winner, who had a 1 -length margin over Alphabet of the Claiborne Farm in the $30,680 event.

Some 75 per cent of supported vinyl production will be in the category of expanded coatings within five years, according to Martin Fife, president of Fife Associates, a vinyl fabric distributing and converting company.
The United States formally notified the United Nations yesterday that it would ratify the International Coffee Agreement. The Senate approved ratification of the agreement on May 21.
A Harlem delegation told Deputy Mayor Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. yesterday that "if nothing is done to alleviate the Negro employment situation here, the dikes will break."
Cotton futures advanced 15 to 60 cents a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Mrs. Helen Kozeradsky of Passaic, N. J., who spent three years in prison in Communist Czechoslovakia on an espionage charge, arrived at Idlewild Airport yesterday from Prague.

The directors of Leeds Northrup yesterday increased the quarterly dividend 5 cents to 20 cents a share and also voted an extra of 15 cents on the common stock. The dividends are payable July 25 to holders of record July 10.

WASHINGTON, June 24--Attorney General Kennedy offered sound counsel to Negro leaders yesterday against an anti-discrimination "march on Washington" until Congress had debated the President's omnibus equal rights bill with the deliberation such radical proposals impose on responsible legislators.

WEST BRENTWOOD, L.I. June 24--Dr. Majer Kahan and his wife, Dr. Rose Kahan, supervising psychiatrists at Pilgrim State Hospital here, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Alice Kahan, to Dr. Howard S. Zucker, son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Zucker of Brooklyn and Lake Mohegan, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP)--The Senate passed today 72 to 1 a bill extending the Export-Import Bank for five years to June 30, 1968, and adding $2,000,000,000 to its borrowing authority.
The broadcasting industry was warned yesterday that the urgency of the times was forcing a speed-up of employment of Negroes in radio and television.

Following his usual procedure, Mayor Wagner asked the Bar Association of the City of New York, composed of recognized leaders of the legal profession, for its opinion on Louis Kaplan's qualifications for an interim appointment to the City Civil Court bench. This was done under a standing agreement with the Mayor that the Bar Association findings be kept confidential ...

Railway Express Agency, Inc., began yesterday a coordinated rail-sea-highway shipment container system, that, it claims is faster and cheaper than older piggy-back operations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 24--Yemen, beset by civil war and discord with Saudi Arabia, protested to the Security Council today that she was being attacked by British forces from the Aden protectorate.

The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company has leased 60,000 square feet of space in the St. Johns Terminal at 340 West Street, on the Lower West Side. The bank will use the space to consolidate its supply and record facilities, now scattered throughout the city.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 24 --Dr. and Mrs. Sal J. Prezioso have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Rita Prezioso, to Lieut. Daniel Demchuk of the Army. He is the son of Mrs. Peter Demchuk of Detroit and the late Mr. Demchuk.

WASHINGTON, June 24-- The United States Government was said today to be convinced that if Communist China set off a nuclear explosion soon, the achievement would have little influence on the world situation.

KANSAS CITY, June 24 (AP)--Bobby Del Greco's tworun homer in the third inning and a two-run triple by Jerry Lumpe in the fourth led the Kansas City Athletics to a 6-3 victory tonight over the Detroit Tigers.

MARYVILLE, Tenn., June 24 --A biracial camp in the Great Smoky Mountains was destroyed by fire today. The Blount County sheriff, Roger Trotter, and the State Fire Marshal, Gene Hartsook, joined in an arson investigation.
IF the modern teen-ager's musical tastes reflect his life and times, as some Tin Pan Alley habitues contend, the adolescent outlook is decidedly grim.

ONCE there was a brave little tailor who polished off seven flies with one blow. Last night, at the aptly named Pocket Theater on Third Avenue, the brave little After Dinner Opera Company matched this legendary feat by polishing off seven operas in a little under two hours.
WASHINGTON, June 24-- Atlantic City and Chicago, in that order, appeared tonight to be the leading bidders as hosts to the 1964 Democratic convention.
OCEANPORT. N. J., June 24 (AP)--Well rated by Howard Grant, Dixie McKinley's keep Counting won the mile-and-70yard feature today at Monmouth Park. The race was for 3-yearolds of the allowance class.

The Advertising Council, whose campaigns have been identified mainly with such noncontroversial causes as fire prevention and traffic safety, has initiated a "hard-sell" campaign on behalf of the United Nations. The campaign lists the achievements and failures of the United Nations, but asserts, "The U.N. is not perfect but it is our best hope."

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 24--Premier-designate Levi Eshkol presented his new Government to the Knesset (Parliament) this evening, and pledged it to carry on the policies of retiring Premier David Ben-Gurion.
CHICAGO, June 24--The Yankees met the latest challenge to their leadership in the American League tonight in much the same manner as they did the last one in Boston.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 24--Frederick C. Tanner, a New York lawyer since 1901 and former chairman of the Republican State Committee, died of a heart attack last night at his home at 7 Wellington Road. He was 85 years old. Mr. Tanner, whose New York home was at 1 East 66th Street, was senior member of the law firm of Tanner, Friend Kinnan Post, 1 Madison Avenue.

About ten days ago Max J. Rubin, president of the New York City Board of Education, wrote to Governor Rockefeller, Mayor Wagner and the State Commissioner of Education asking that they sit down together and discuss "the financial needs and problems that urgently and immediately face our school system."

PARIS. THE inexpensive Cricket lighter has inspired what may become the fashion accessory of the season. The Cricket, a black cylinder with a gilt top, costs about 80 cents and is thrown away when the gas runs out.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) --The General Services Administration announced today that it was requiring information about racial employment practices from contractors and subcontractors on "virtually all significant construction projects" for which it has responsibility.
BONN, June 24--President Kennedy made a vigorous plea to West Germans today to share their. Wealth and knowledge with people in the less developed nations.
FLORALA, Ala., June 24 (AP)--Gov. George C. Wallace said today the Federal Government should have prosecuted him for contempt of court instead of sending troops to the University of Alabama.

RICHMOND, Va., June 24 (UPI)--A Federal judge ruled today that the United States has the right to file school desegregation suits against communities that accept Government aid for federally impacted areas.
WASHINGTON, June 24-- Treasury bill rates were down slightly in today's sales of the regular weekly issues.
POWNAL, Vt., June 24-- Green Mountain Park switched to night racing tonight, stumbled slightly--and then took a small step forward on what could be the road to solvency.

First National Stores, Inc., plans to open at least 30 new supermarkets in the present fiscal year, ending next March, Adrian O'Keefe, president, told shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday in Somerville, Mass. Many existing stores will be remodeled or enlarged. The food chain operates about 650 stores.
New York will be an athletic festival in 1964, the host city for the United States Olympic trials in preparation for the Tokyo Olympiad.
Most issues on the London stock market edged forward yesterday as traders continued to show a discreet interest in buying.

Hundreds of dealers came to town yesterday to attend the furniture industry's summer market week. At the New York Furniture Exchange, the National Furniture Mart, the 71st Regiment Armory, 192 Lexington Avenue, 1 Park Avenue and individual showrooms here, furniture manufacturers displayed their fall lines to hordes of visiting buyers.
The Rockaway Council of Civic Associations, Inc., charged yesterday that plans for the Breezy Point Park "threaten the entire Rockaway Peninsula with economic disaster."
Treasury and corporate bonds held firm yesterday in quiet trading. The tax-exempt market awaited the competitive sale today of a number of large offerings.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 24--Pat Paradise, an amateur from Twin Brooks, shot a 36, 33 --69 today to lead 48 northern section qualifiers into the New Jersey open golf championship at the Crestmont Country Club.
Estimated net earnings of General Mills, Inc., for the fiscal year ended May 31 rose to $14,900,000, equal to $1.90 a common share, the company reported yesterday.
The New York Hilton, newest of Manhattan's new hotel belles, has scored socially significant points in the battle of the ballrooms, but it has yet to best its older, already established sisters.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 24--President Sukarno of Indonesia arrived today for a three-day state visit to Pakistan and called for closer collaboration against colonialism and exploitation.

Mrs. Emory F. Thames of Ormond Beach, Fla., and Edward E. Weadock of New York and Litchfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Amy S. Weadock, to Vernon A. Bahr, son of Mr. and Mrs. John O. Bahr of Weiser, Idaho.

ST. LOUIS, June 24 (UPI)-- The San Francisco Giants scored four runs in the first inning tonight and took the National League lead with a 4-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. The Cards fell to second.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP)--Representative Paul Findley charged today that the Administration had tried to use Federal licensing power "to blackjack radio and television stations into publicizing" its viewpoint on the recent wheat referendum.

Heading towards a two-month recess, the grand jury investigating the State Liquor Authority spent two and a half hours yesterday taking testimony from the authority's Deputy Commisaioner, Alfred de F. Licato.

ASSATEAGUE ISLAND, Md., June 24--The natives are restless and unfriendly on this Atlantic Ocean island.
LONDON, June 24--The Government expanded its case today against Dr. Stephen Ward, the society osteopath who is.. a central figure in the Profumo scandal.

The common stock of the Whirlpool Corporation slumped 5 1/8 points to 43 7/8 in heavy trading of 24,500 shares yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. This abrupt decline followed a company announcement of plans to write down certain receivables of its finance subsidiary, Appliance Buyers Credit Corporation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 24--An informed source indicated today that Aleksandar Rankovic would be named Vice President of Yugoslavia when the new Federal People's Assembly, or Parliament, convenes next weekend.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 24--The Congolese Government has taken strong measures to head off threatened demonstrations against Portuguese in the Congo.
Mayor Wagner is to meet Board of Education members at City Hall at 4:30 P.M. today to discuss what a board spokesman yesterday called "critical fiscal problems."
More than 500 Protestant ministers in the New York area were asked yesterday to give spiritual as will as financial support to the $3,000,000 Protestant Center at the 1964-65 World's Fair.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, June 24--The Proposed Federation of Malaysia suffered a new setback today over the amount of money that Singapore should contribute to the federation's central Government.

MBALABALA, Kenya, June 13--The big game and the curious forms of horned animals usually get the attention of visitors to East Africa. But there are many minor forms of life and curious situations that are equally fascinating, at least to this writer.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
CHICHESTER, England, June 24--The second Chichester Festival opened here tonight with a dazzling Joan in Shaw's play "St. Joan." She was Joan Plowright.

OTTAWA, June 24--The Government of Prime Minister Lester B, Pearson easily defeated a no-confidence motion tonight. It had been aimed at Finance Minister Walter L. Gordon and his controversial antiforeign budget.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., June 24--Philip Rudolf Sr., a member of the accounting firm of Rudolf, Cinnamon Calafato with offices here and in New York, died at his home in nearby West End early today of a heart ailment. His age was 63.

Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman granted yesterday a request by the New Rochelle Board of Education to modify the two-year-old decree that ordered the desegregation of the predominantly Negro Lincoln School.

The Chicago and North Western Railway challenged yesterday the plans of the powerful Union Pacific and Southern Pacific Railroads for splitting the property of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad between them.
MOSCOW, June 24--Premier Khrushchev accused "imperialist" forces in the United States today of making war preparations on a "scope unparalleled in history."
Julius Perlbinder, realty investor and builder, has bought the 15-story air-conditioned apartment building at 301 East 62d Street, northeast corner of Second Avenue, from Milton Barkin.

Three Negro leaders asserted on a television program presented yesterday that the Kennedy Administration had not shown enough leadership in the struggle for civil rights. But they stood far apart on what Negroes themselves should do to help improve their condition.

A tired Julius Boros explained yesterday that the best way for a golfer to win a big, windy tournament was to try to aim his low-numbered iron shots under the wind. Boros said he used this tactic in winning the United States Open, plagued by wind Saturday and Sunday. He explained, too, that he'd spend the next couple of weeks relaxing.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 24-- All indications are that the twin double, a form of parimutuel betting that has been sending attendance and handle figures at Monticello Raceway skyrocketing, will be introduced on a trial basis at Roosevelt Raceway on July 8.

WASHINGTON, June 24-- Assistant Secretary of Labor Esther Peterson said tonight that there was a parallel between the current civil rights struggle and the efforts of women to achieve "full partnership in the affairs of the nation."

LEVI ESHKOL has the extraordinary distinction of having achieved popularity as Finance Minister in a country where taxes are heavy and economic difficulties are chronic. Mr. Eshkol's passion for more and more taxes is the subject of many anecdotes that he takes good-naturedly.
JACKSON, Miss., June 24-- District Attorney William L. Waller said today that he would seek the death penalty for the man charged with the murder of Medgar W. Evers, Negro civil rights leader.

Sylvan Lawrence, realty investor and builder, has purchased and taken title to the 19-story Post Building at 75 West Street. The building occupies the blockfront on the south side of Carlisle Street, ...

WASHINGTON, June 24-- Senator Maurine Neuberger charged today that many organizations, including the Daughters of the American Revolution, appeared to be abusing their tax-exempt status by circulating "extremist propaganda."

PALO ALTO, Calif., June 24 --An atom smasher that would accelerate nuclear particles to energies of about 100,000,000,000,000 electron volts and cost perhaps $100,000,000,000 was declared today to be perhaps the "most exciting" machine that could be conceived with present technology.

WASHINGTON, June 24-- Unions and employers in many industries are developing, through the system of grievance arbitration a body of private "laws" that are as important to workers as the public laws under which they live.
A program to give guidance, testing and counseling to the so-called hard-core unemployable youths is being planned for the city.

WASHINGTON, June 24-- Three United States Air Force men are undergoing questioning about rumors involving the British party girl Christine Keeler, the Pentagon said today.
ROME, June 24--The Communist party made pressing appeals today to the Left-Wing Socialists and other left wingers for their collaboration.

Competition among retailers cut the profit margin of the nation's leading department stores to 2.47 per cent of sales last year from 2.66 per cent the preceding year, according to the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago.

The decision of the Regents of the University of California to rescind the 12-year-old ban on Communist speakers at the university is a vote of confidence is the judgment of the student body. President Goulart of Brazil has "changed the guard" again. The political complexion of the new Cabinet, taken as a body, is about the same as the old one, but it is disturbing that Mr. Goulart should have felt the urge to make changes at such a critical juncture for Brazil's economy and finances.
BONN, June 24--President Kennedy said today he would expect the parties signing an atomic test-ban agreement to persuade other countries to avert the "disaster" of a spread of nuclear weapons.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., June 24--Mrs. Philip Cudone of Forest Hill F.C., won the qualifying medal in the 60th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship here today.

The Massachusetts Investors Growth Stock Fund reported a gain in net asset value a share from $7.51 to $8,26 in the second quarter ending May 31, compared with $7.05 a year earlier. A capital gain of 10 cents a share was paid last Dec. 22.

John Crowe Ransom, who was 75 years old last April 30, will have a new book of poems published by Knopf on July 15. "Selected Poems," a revised and enlarged edition of a collection that appeared in 1945, contains 45 of his works. Prizewinner, lecturer at many universities ...
ABOARD U.S.S. FORT SNELLING, at Sea, June 24-- The bathyscaph Trieste today completed the first of a series of dives to locate the lost nuclear submarine Thresher.
FRANKFURT Germany, June 24 (AP)--A French official suggested today the use of underground atomic explosions to increase the world's oil production.
ST. VINCENT, Italy, June 24--The 1963 world championship tournament officially ended tonight with a dinner to celebrate Italy's victory.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 24--Dr. Henry H. Welles, headmaster of the New Canaan Country School, a coeducational private school here, died today in St. Joseph's Hospital, Stamford, after suffering a stroke about two weeks ago. He was 65 years old and was to retire July 1.
East Harlem's only academic high school, Benjamin Franklin, had in its record graduating class yesterday three Negro boys who won all-expense scholarships to leading colleges in the East.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI)--James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said today that many of his union members were moving into higher tax brackets and that this might influence his wage demands on the industry this fall.

LONDON, June 24--Two stars of another era--Herbie Flam and Gardnar Mulloy-- provided the excitement today on the opening day of the allEngland lawn tennis championships at Wimbledon. Rain interrupted play and finally washed out nearly half of the firstround matches.
BONN, June 24--President Kennedy continued today to move through this impressed capital in campaign style.
A PACT made over rice bowls in a New York restaurant three years ago has resulted in a collection of Japanese tablewares that is being introduced in stores across the country.
A proposal to establish a new national bank in New York's garment district received preliminary approval yesterday from the Federal Government.
OKLAHOMA CITY, June 24 (AP)--Maj. Gen. Thomas J. Gent Jr., outgoing commander of the 32d North American Air Defense Command, was critically wounded early today.

The Ford Foundation gave a total of $25,000,000 to thirteen private liberal arts colleges yesterday under a program of grants without academic strings attached.
Three brokerage houses have joined forces to form the New York Stock Exchange firm of Carreau, Smith, McDowell, Dimond, Inc.
WASHINGTON, June 24-- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia declared today that President Kennedy had encouraged Negro demonstrators.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI)--The Civil Aeronautics Board assured Congress today that it contemplated a "substantial and continuing reduction" in subsidies to United States commercal airlines.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 25 (AP)--Dancing Prince, who startled Monmouth Park patrons a week ago by winning a mile turf race and returning a mutuel of $178, ran right back to that form to win today's feature, at a mile and a sixteenth on the grass.
An offering of $50,000,000 of Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation first-mortgage pipeline bonds is being made today by an underwriting group headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc.
Two appraisals of President Kennedy are on the way. Atheneum will publish "John F. Kennedy, President," by Hugh Sidey, on Aug. 19. The author is White House correspondent for Time Magazine.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz obtained a court order yesterday directing a former Cabinet member, a former member of Congress, an actress and other prominent figures to explain what they knew about a scheme to sell $3,000,000 in worthless oil leases.

A festival of films made by John Ford is a rarity in a commercial showcase but the uptown New Yorker Theater has announced a comprehensive program to be devoted entirely to works of the Hollywood director, beginning on Tuesday and continuing through July 11.

PITTSBURGH, June 25 (UPI)--The Carnegie Hero Fund Commission presented 25 awards today. Thirteen were issued to persons under 21 years of age. Five other recipients were under 30.

WASHINGTON, June 25.-- Under considerable prodding from the United States, India has agreed conditionally to accept international inspection of a large, American type of atomic power plant to be built near Bombay.

WASHINGTON, June 25-- The American Bankers Association told Congress today that bankers would willingly disclose additional financial information to their stockholders, providing, the proposed new disclosure requirements are administered solely by Government agencies that normally regulate banks.

THE rapidly increasing importance of television throughout the world is evidenced in the number of transmitters that went on the air in 1962. New foreign stations began operation at the rate of two a day for a total of more than 700 during the calendar year. This year is likely to bring a similar increase.

A charge that "Negroes are faring very poorly" in getting policy-making and high-paying jobs in the state and city governments was made yesterday by the New York branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

TOKYO. American officials experi ence some rather unusual sensations when they consider the relations between their own Government and the Government of Japan, the United States' major ally in the Far East.
Malcolm A. MacIntyre, president of Eastern Air Lines, disclosed yesterday that his airline planned to refinance a $205,000,000 order for 40 Boeing 727 jets.

ALBANY, June 25--Governor Rockefeller said today that it was imperative that Congress act promptly on President Kennedy's civil rights proposals.

PARIS, June 25--Statesmen and their speech writers take meticulous pains to express themselves precisely on occasions such as President Kennedy's tour, For they are aware that public statements at such junctures receive maximum propaganda fanfare.

ROME, June 25 (UPI)-- Prince Ferdinando Umberto of Italy, the Duke of Genoa, died yesterday at the age of 79.

ALGIERS, June 25--The United States signed today its first direct aid agreement with Algeria. It involved "food for wages" and technical assistance, but little cash.

MBALABALA, Kenya, June 14--The extraordi nary power of wild elephants is best appreciated when a herd smashes through a forest in headlong flight. If the observer happens to be in their line, he is more than likely to feel remarkably puny.

WATKINS Glen, N. Y., where sports car racing on a national scale was started 16 years ago, faces one of its busiest weekends. The annual Grand Prix Cup races will be held on the 2.3-mile tear-shaped panded Contours d'Elegance and two races in the new Sports Car Club of America road-rac ing championship series. Friday will be a day of practice for all contestants.
New Yorkers go to Cape Cod and admire the dunes, which became part of a Federally protected National Seashore in 1961. They will be there, unspoiled, for all to see and enjoy forever.
Most major Continental currencies weakened against the United States dollar in trading on the New York foreign exchange market yesterday.

FRANKFURT, Germany, June 25--President Kennedy renewed today in the heart of the Old World his call for interdependence between the United States and what he said must become a "fully cohesive Europe."

MOSCOW, June 25--The ideological dispute between the Soviet Union and the Chinese Communists found an echo in the proceedings of the Communist-sponsored World Women's Congress here tonight.
FRANKFURT, Germany, June 25--President Kennedy visited his troops today and then went on to a triumphal reception in Hanau, Frankfurt and Wiesbaden.

ST. VINCENT, Italy, June 25--When the individual prizes were awarded to the Italian team for winning the 1963 world bridge championship last night, the Italian captain, Carlo Alberto Perroux, stepped to the microphone and said he was giving his prize, a silver cup, to the American captain, John Gerber of Houston, as a memento of the friendliest but hardestfought and closest match in the history of world tournaments.

The Conservative party announced yesterday that Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo, leader of the Republican majority in the State Senate, had agreed to be the principal speaker at the party's first anniversary dinner, on Sept. 26.
OMAHA, June 25--Nine hundred cattle, the first in modern times to move from ranch to feedlot by river, arrived by barge from Greenville, Miss., today.

The Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad--courted by rival railway suitors--moved to a new 1963 high yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and closed at 25 7/8, up 1 3/8. The stock, selling as high as 26 3/8, traded 63,800 shades and ranked as the second most active issue on the Big Board.
HIGHLANDS, N. J., June 25 --The Army said today a new "recreational wonderland" for all armed forces would open July 3 on nearby Sandy Hook.

Employing a style of diplomacy that reminds one of an American election campaign, President Kennedy is inviting Western Europe to reject President de Gaulle's brand of nationalism and to choose instead the kind of Atlantic partnership envisaged by the United States.

Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon, who advocates increased competition in banking, has given his preliminary approval to the establishment of a new national bank in New York City. Undoubtedly, banks provide better services at lower cost where there is intense competition than in areas of near monopoly.
MASSAPEQUA, L.I., June 25 --Dr. Leo J. Kelly, retired director of surgery at St. Mary's Hospital in Brooklyn, died at his home today. He was 64 years old and lived at 37 Bayview Street East.
Major civil rights organizations have chosen Wednesday, Aug. 28, to arrive in Washington on a nationwide "march" and possible sit-in at the capitol for civil rights legislation.
NEW DELHI, June 25-- India has renewed her appeal to the United States and Britain for speedy and large deliveries of arms and equipment, qualified sources said today.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) --The Senate approved today a bill that would authorize Army engineers to investigate whether year-round navigation on the Great Lakes and the St. Lawrence Seaway is possible.
The city will get a big, new hotel today--the New York Hilton at Rockefeller Center.

WASHINGTON, June 25-- Chief Justice Earl Warren's call for a "great national debate" on three proposed states' rights constitutional amendments is being answered in an unusual way in downstate Illinois tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 25-- The pesticide industry, fighting the prospect of stiffer Government controls, challenged today a report by the President's Science Advisory Committee that cautioned the nation and criticized the Government on use of the chemicals.
WASHINGTON, June 25-- The staff of the Federal Power Commission opposed today a proposal by Transwestern Pipeline Company to increase its natural gas deliveries to, southern California.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25--Adlai E. Stevenson warned today that the United States world stature demanded prompt approval of President Kennedy's civil rights program.
The magic word for many of the new hotels that have opened or are about to open here and abroad is "conventions."
LONDON, June 25 (Reuters) --The second cricket test between England and West Indies fended in a draw at Lord's today.

ROME, June 25--Pope Paul VI invoked "rich heavenly grace" upon all Americans, Catholic or non-Catholic, this morning and imparted his apostolic benediction to all the American faithful and their friends. He expressed his particular regard for all Americans.
Stung by the continued rise of private-label products, the Brand Names Foundation is starting a provocative new advertising campaign utilizing dome $20,000,000 in space and time in the mass media.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI)--The Defense Department cleared three American Air Force men today of any security breach in connection with Britain's Profumo scandal. Two of them had met the British party girl Christine Keeler.
The railroad recovery ran out of steam yesterday and stock prices weakened all along the line.
LONDON, June 25--Dealers and private collectors paid a record sum of $506,660 for porcelain today at the first of the long-awaited Rene Fribourg auctions.
LONDON, June 25--Chuck McKinley, America's tope tennis player, got off the Wimbledon launching pads today in fine style despite wretched conditions.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 25-- The Syrian Government has headed off what it believed to be an attempt at a coup d'etat by discharging or transferring 30 officers, according to reports received here.
The 88 yachts in the Annapolis-Newport Race yesterday had another warm and rather exasperating day as light winds continued to plague the fleet.
BOSTON, June 25 (UPI)-- Dick Radatz preserved victories for Bill Monbouquette and Earl Wilson tonight to give the Boston Red Sox 4--1 and 3--2 triumphs over the Cleveland Indians.

STRASBOURG, France, June 25--President de Gaulle reflects only a minority French viewpoint in opposing a close relationship between the European Common Market and Britain, a spokesman for the six-nation community indicated today.
RALEIGH, N. C., June 25-- Mass demonstrations have "got across your message," Gov. Terry Sanford told Negro leaders today. He urged that they halt the demonstrations to prevent violence.

LEE, Mass., June 25--The Berkshires awoke from their spring somnolence tonight to the conversation of castinets. Ted Shawn opened the 30th season of Jacob's Pillow with the Ballet Espahol XimenezVargas.

The Government securities market passed another dull day yesterday, with most prices barely changed. High-grade corporates were firm in a moderately active session and the municipal bond market was steady in the face of a heavy flood of new issues.
Five Bronx teen-agers began a round of receptions and ceremonies yesterday after their selection as winners of the fourth annual Juvenile Decency Project.

Fire Commissioner Edward Thompson went out last night with about 180 friends and friends of friends to see Macy's annual fireworks display on the Hudson River. Even before it began, the party had caused fireworks at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)--State Department spokesman lauded the Indian and Canadian members of the International Control Commission in Laos today for exposing "Communist bad faith" and winning democratic world support for the policies of Prince Souvanna Phouma; the neutralist Premier.

WASHINGTON, June 20-- The House Science and Astronautics Committee made the first substantial budgetary cuts in the space program today by eliminating $259,122,000 in funds for the manned space flight program.

LONDON, June 25--The imagination of Britain's horse players, as avid and colorful a group as ever peopled a Damon Runyon yarn, has been caught by a bet aimed at making 250,000 pounds from a one-pound investment ($800,000--for $2.80).

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 25 (AP)--The optimistic view of consumers toward the American economic picture has weakened in the last few months despite recent economic gains, according to the University of Michigan Survey Research Center.
A proposal to install a city parking lot in Coney Island has stirred a many-sided dispute among city agencies and community groups.
The American Photocopy Equipment Company showed a sharp drop in earnings for the second quarter ended May 31, which reduced half-year profits from those of a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, June 25-- New Jersey will be able to acquire 10,493 acres of open land at five sites as a result of $,211,500 worth of Federal grants announced today.
ROME, June 25--President Kennedy's tour of European countries became an issue in Italy's tangled domestic politics today.
The High School Principals Association yesterday chided the members of the Board of Education for their "strange neutrality" in the face of recent "threats to the integrity of our merit system."

Tax rates for Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx were set by the City Council yesterday at $4.41 for each $100 of assessed valuation. The rate for Manhattan will be $4.38 and for the Borough of Richmond it will be $4.37.
ERIE, Pa., June 25--Former Judge William E. Hirt, a member of the Superior Court of Pennsylvania for 20 years before his retirement in 1959, died last night at the age of 82.
Sentiment and politics, promises and challenges, mark the in-fighting between the two contenders for the presidency of the 60,000-member International Longshoremen's Association.
POWNAL, Vt., June 25--If cows could bet, Vermont's first pari-mutuel race track would have the biggest handle in the country.
Major steel companies, thwarted in their effort to stop what they consider dumping of steel wire rod in this country, are now calling for stronger antidumping laws to protect the domestic industry.
The following listing includes events that have been selected by New York Times critics. For children of all ages, unless otherwise noted.
The latest version of the Internal Revenue Service's regulations on expense-account deductions is a craven retreat in an obvious attempt to give offense to no one.
In case we are inclined to forget that the history of the text books was real, we can turn to Austria. That new-old country is again being convulsed by a Habsburg.
MOSCOW, June 25--The Soviet spacewoman who circled the earth for three days less one hour last week could have returned after one day and would still have fulfilled her assignment.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)--Representative Robert T. Ashmore, Democrat of South Carolina, introduced today a bill to put the inscription "In God We Trust" above the bench in the Supreme Court.

The Anaconda Wire and Cable Company, which has a plant and executive offices at Hastings-on-Hudson, has leased three floors in the office building being constructed-by Fiher Brothers. Inc., at 605 Third Avenue, corner of 40th Street.

For the last thousand years the Iraqis have tried and failed to crush the Kurds. The strain of fruitless warfare against them gravely weakened the regime of Abdul Karim Kassem and contributed to his bloody downfall. Reminders such as these give no cause to foresee success for the drive on the Kurds just launched by the new Baath regime at Baghdad.

WIESBADEN, Germany, June 25--The United States and West Germany have agreed to put off plans for an allied nuclear force of mixed-manned vessels, but are agreed on the necessity for keeping the idea alive.
Supplemental airlines have given their side of the story to the State Attorney General as a result of his recent warning to travelers to investigate before buying space on cut-rate flights.

The Aetna Life Insurance Company has made a building and permanent first mortgage loan of $6,550,800 on a 20-story apartment building to be erected on the blockfront on the west side of Eighth Avenue, between 54th and 55th Streets.
Leopold Stokowski played to an empty house but full stage last night at Carnegie Hall.
STOCKHOLM, June 25--The Swedish Government announced today the arrest of one of its disarmament specialists on charges that he had spied for the Soviet Union since 1948.

WASHINGTON, June 25-- Ambassadors of 27 African Governments sent a letter to President Kennedy protesting Senator Allen J. Ellender's public statements that Negro peoples are incapable of governing themselves.

David L. Yunich, president of Macy's New York, told a conference of the New York State Chamber of Commerce at Saratoga Springs yesterday that urban renewal to help take care of the population explosion would be one of the "growth industries" of the future.
City students soon may no longer have to use science textbooks that tell of strange new flying machines called helicoptars and that predict that some day man will be able to harness atomic energy.

WASHINGTON, June 25-- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara received powerful support in the House today in the controversies over his TFX airplane decision and his cutback of the RS-70 bomber program.
BONN, June 25--President Kennedy was reported today to have restored the intimate relationship between the United States and West German Governments that has been lacking for the last three years.

Directors of Indian Head Mills, Inc., voted yesterday to split the common stock on the basis of three new shares for each two presently outstanding, effected by means of a 50 per cent stock dividend on Sept. 30 to stockholders of record of Sept. 16.

TORONTO, June 25 (AP)-- Jim Beatty of Los Angeles ran the mile tonight in 3 minutes 56 seconds in the Toronto International Games. The time was a half-second slower than his American citizens' record.

Suspended by the International Professional Tennis Players Association in a controversy over the production of tennis films for a television series, Richard (Pancho) Gonzalez took further issue with the association yesterday for remaking the draw in the United States professional grass court championships.

Hotter even than the 90-degree weather at Aqueduct yesterday was Johnny Sellers, the California-born, Oklahomareared jockey, who brought home four winners. Included among the 26-year-old rider's successes was that with the Christians Stable's Smart in the AO,000 Black Gold Handicap.
David Schoenbrun resigned as chief European correspondent of the Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday.
LONDON, June 25--A plan to span the English Channel with a combined bridge and tunnel was presented in London today by Jules Moch, president of the Channel Bridge Survey Company.

BONN, June 25--President Kennedy delivered his major address in West Germany today in the Paulskirche--the church of St. Paul--a structure regarded by Germans as the symbol of the best of their political history.

The Diners' Club, Inc., which has reported net income of $2,375,308, or $1.61 a share, for the fiscal year ended March 31, is expected to have higher earnings in fiscal 1964, Ralph E. Schneider, chairman, predicted at the annual meeting here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)--The Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee accused officials of the American Guild of Variety Artists today of conniving with international vice rackets that held some B-girl members of the union in "literal bondage."
Some men who may one day run the economies of their countries were guests here yesterday of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 25--The Congolese Parliament struck a heavy and perhaps decisive blow today at Moise Tshombe.
DUBLIN, June 25 (Reuters) --A 21-gun salute and thousands of enthusiastic Irishmen will welcome President Kennedy tomorrow on his arrival here in the land of his ancestors.
Orders for machine tools continued to gain in May, but the increase was wholly from foreign buyers. The rise was sharp enough, in fact, to wipe out a drop in orders from domestic buyers.

PARIS. FOR several months, couturiers have been preparing their fall collections, which will be unveiled in late July. Every designer must make sketches, decide on fabrics and select mannequins, but each approach es his work in his own way. Yves St. Laurent, whose last two collections were smash hits, has evolved a method that works well for him.

LONDON, June 25--Fortyeight playwrights, expressing their "personal repugnance to the policies of apartheid," have instructed their agents to refuse performing rights of their plays in any theater where there is racial discrimination.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 25 (AP)--Lee Stange allowed five Detroit singles tonight and the Minnesota Twins beat the Tigers, 1--0, on Harmon Killebrew's home run over the center-field fence in the third inning.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 25-- The conservatives are firmly in control at the opening here today of the 13th biennial convention of the Young Republican National Federation.
CHICAGO, June 25 (UPI)-- Soybeans did an about-face today and fell sharply on the Board of Trade. Other grain futures closed steady to weak.
The first ferry commuter service across the East River since the summer of 1936 began yesterday when a 100-passenger, diesel-powered craft departed from the sea wall at the Battery at 11:30 A.M.

SEOUL, Korea, June 25--The ruling junta accepted today the resignation of the Agricultural Minister, Maj. Gen. Chang Kyu Soon, in the face of what is called South Korea's worst food crisis since 1945. General Chang was replaced by Brig. Gen. Yu Byung Hyun, a member of the Junta.
PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., June 25--Lewis C. Fralick, a retired customs staff officer, died here on Sunday. He was 89 years old.
Sugar futures beat a retreat yesterday after showing strength for more than a week.

HOLLYWOOD, June 25-- Hollywood movie and television companies were threatened today by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People with nationwide economic and legal offensives to end discrimination against Negroes as performers and crafts workers.
BRISTOL, England, June 25 --Western Theater Ballet, Britain's smallest and most enterprising ballet company, celebrated its sixth birthday with a gala performance in its home town here last night.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)--A three-in-one oral vaccine to provide simultaneous immunity against all three types of poliomyelitis has been licensed by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, a spokesman for the United States Surgeon General's office said tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 25-- The Democrats decided today to hold their 1964 Presidential convention in Atlantic City.

Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, pleaded not guilty today to charges of fradulently manipulating $20,000,000 in loans from the union pension fund. He contended that the indictment was "just another propaganda move" by Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy.

The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it had decided to buy 600 stainlesssteel cars with picture windows from the Budd Company of Philadelphia. The order is the largest ever placed in the United States for subway cars.

PARIS, June 25--Informed French opinion strove tonight to play down President Kennedy's strictures against those who doubt United States pledges to Europe or seek to split the North Atlantic alliance.
Directors of Purolator Products, Inc., and of Tung-Sol Electric, Inc., yesterday approved a plan for the merger of the two Big Board companies.
The final piece of structural steel for the Unisphere, symbol of the 1964-65 New York World's Fair, was swung into place yesterday.

In the sanctuary of Judson Memorial Church at Washington Square, a big, chandelier-like construction of self-playing drums rose from the lowered position in which it had been playing (agitatedly but quietly) in almost total darkness. A spotlight focused abruptly on a white curtain.
FALLSBURG, N. Y., June 25 --An Orthodox Jewish scholar accused Jewish writers and intellectuals today of creating a "distorted image of the basic values of Orthodox Judaism."
The State Education Department notified schools throughout the state yesterday that it had lowered the passing mark for two Regents examinations because they were unfairly difficult.

WASHINGTON, June 25-- President Kennedy has agreed to a $400,000,000 cut in his $4,500,000,000 foreign-aid authorization bill.
BERLIN, June 25--The entire West Berlin police force was placed on a stand-by alert tonight in preparation for the seven-hour visit of President Kennedy tomorrow.
John G. Forrest, retiring as financial and business news editor of The New York Times, was honored at a luncheon yesterday by more than 800 friends and associates from the financial community.

Pan American World Airways proposed a new class of service to Europe and Hawaii yesterday that would radically reduce fares and eliminate meals and liquor aboard the plane.

An audience of 3,000 would be fine at Philharmonic Hall, but that many persons at Lewisohn Stadium last night didn't look like enough for a poker game. The sound echoed off the empty stone seats so audibly that many who were there got two concerts for the price of one.

EIGHT students recently participated in a round robin qualifying tournament at the Marshall Chess Club under the direction of Dave Daniels. The purpose of this competition was to win some places in the five-man student team four regulars and one alternate that will play in the world championship student's team tournament in Budva, Yugoslavia, this July.
WASHINGTON, June 26 The Navy appointed a civilian academic dean for the Naval Academy at Annapolis today as part of a major program to improve general education standards for midshipmen.
CHICAGO, June 26 (UPI) Soybeans shot upward in a late flurry of heavy buying and posted sharp gains today on the Board of Trade. Corn ended firm, wheat weak and other grain futures were easy.
BOSTON, June 26 More than 3,000 chanting Bostonians paid tribute today to the memory of Medgar W. Evens, Mississippi integration leader who was slain from ambush on June 12.
The temperature rose to 96 degrees at 3:10 P.M. yesterday, making it the hottest day here since last July 9. More of the same was forecast for today.
LONDON, June 26 Secretary of State Dean Rusk flew here from Berlin tonight to prepare the ground for weekend talks between President Kennedy and Prime Minister Macmillan.

CHICAGO, June 26 Rallying round Whitey Ford, the Yankees tonight retained their hold on first place in the American League by turning back the White Sox, 3 to 2, in a tense struggle before a crowd of 44,305.
WHITE PLAINS, June 26 Westchester County was ordered in State Supreme Court today to pay real estate taxes on its Glen Island Casino at New Rochelle.
Mayor Wagner announced the appointment of a special threeman commission yesterday to "review and assess" the procedures for selecting members of the Board of Education and Board of Higher Education.
The Darby Dan Farm of John W. Galbreath has been having marked racing success at Aqueduct since Chateaugay, the Kentucky Derby victor, won the rich Belmont Stakes.
The Board of Elections decided yesterday to use the form of the old paper ballot on the voting machines in the Sept. 5 primary, despite a threatened court fight.

The city announced Federal approval yesterday of a $230,230 grant for a study to see if a massive low-rent housing rehabilitation industry can be developed here.

ABOARD U.S.S. FOR SNELLING AT SEA, June 26 The second dive by the bathyscaph Trieste in its undersea search in the Atlantic for the lost nuclear submarine Thresher disclosed "nothing significant" on the bottom, a Navy spokesman said this afternoon.
West Ham United of London won the First Section title in the International Soccer League by playing a 1-1 tie last night with Recife of Brazil at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 26 (UPI) Homemade bombs jarred the homes today of two policemen, one a rookie under suspension for hitting a Negro with a blackjack.
Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges has been asked to review the operating subsidy that Grace Line, Inc., receives for its Caribbean operations.

MBALABALA, Kenya, June 15 Death can be dealt to a bull elephant in a number of ways, some of which are wretched. But the sportsman with a sense of responsibility exerts every effort to make his kill of the largest land mammal instantaneous and humane. Such a magnificent animal deserves a good death.

WARSAW, June 26 Measures designed to increase trade among Soviet-bloc countries, including a multilateral payments system, a more rational price structure and an international bank, will go into operation next Jan. 1, the Polish Government announced tonight.

PARIS, June 26 Jean Vilar, director of the state-operated Theatre National Populaire since its formation 12 years ago, announced today that he would leave France and direct three operas at La Scala in Milan next season.

The indicated net income of Schenley Industries, Inc., rose during the third fiscal quarter ended May 31 to $2,261,563, including special credits, compared with a loss of $300,778 in the 1962 fiscal quarter.

BERLIN, June 26 The Berlin wall, which President Kennedy viewed today, was put up Aug. 13, 1961, to halt the flow of refugees from Communist East Germany into West Berlin. It was also intended to seal off East Germans from Western influence.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 26 Kurdish informants who arrived from Baghdad said today that Syrian Air Force MIG's and Hawker Hunter aircraft purchased from Britain were reinforcing Iraqi air forces fighting Kurds.

"Brecht on Brecht," which closed an Off Broadway run of 424 ,performances in January, will return July 9 for an "unlimited engagement" at the Sheridan Square Playhouse. The offering again will be under the auspices of the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theater and Academy and Cheryl Crawford.
LONDON, June 26 Seventyone American debutantes and their escorts attended the Anglo-American Ball here tonight at the Hilton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 26 The Senate passed and sent to the House today its own bill to strengthen the program for aid to economically distressed areas. The vote was 65 to 30. The House, which rejected a similar bill two weeks ago by only five votes, is now expected to reverse itself and approve the job-stimulating program.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission advocated today another suspension of the requirement for equal free time for political broadcasts by major Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates.

ATRUISM is unfailingly applied at the start of spring training each season. It is offered as portentously as it had just been discovered. "The pitchers are ahead of the hitters," the experts say with knowing shakes of their heads. The assumption, of course, is that the hitters eventually will catch up with their more advanced brethren and pass them. They usually do, too.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) A Senate Judiciary subcommittee approved today the nomination of Harry Phillips of Nashville, Tenn., to be a Federal judge.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 Gov. Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon denounced extremists and warned young Republicans today against party "fragmentation" and "fratricide" in advance of next year's election. "Hate groups" with "questionable goals" appeared to be multiplying in the nation, he said.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 26 An advisory committee for a statewide arts council was formed here today. It will assist Gov. Otto Kerner in establishing a permanent body.
The new Belgian Line cargo ship Jordaens received an official harbor welcome yesterday afternoon as she arrived on her maiden voyage from Antwerp, Belgium, her home port.
The Board of Education declined yesterday to permit a Negro student to enter a high school outside his school district. It had been pondering the request for several days.

Edward Sansom Perot, a former president of the Ford Instrument Company and other companies in the New York area, died on Tuesday in Santa Barbara, Calif., where he had lived since his retirement in 1948. He was 73 years old.

Plans for the Saratoga Centennial Ball, to be held Aug. 10 at the Canfield Casino in Saratoga, N.Y., were discussed recently at a meeting of committee members at the home of Mrs. Leslie Combs in Lexington, Ky.

Col. Don Hull, executive secretary of the Amateur Athletic Union, agreed yesterday to meet the rival United States Track Federation for a peace meeting July 8 and 9. He suggested New York as the site.

Governor Rockefeller will confer this morning with heads of the city school system about the budgetary squeeze that has led to a threat of a teachers' strike this fall.
The suicide by fire of a Buddhist priest in Saigon has aroused a denunciation of the Government of South Vietnam by twelve American clergymen--eight Protestants, three Jews and a Buddhist.

LONDON, June 26 Chuck McKinley and four other Americans landed safely if shakily in the third round of the Wimbledon tennis championships today, but some gaps were made in the ranks of the seeded players.

Richard (Pancho) Gonzalez of Los Angeles, former king of professional tennis, comes out of retirement today at Forest Hills, Queens.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 26 (AP) Colonial Farms' Accordant, the only 3-year-old in a field of seven sprinters, won the 17th running of the Oceanport Handicap at Monmouth Park today.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 26 An Annapolis-to-Newport yacht race that was distressingly slow for all but the first three finishers ended in a romp for the 58-foot aluminum yawl Dyna today. She restored the Blue Water Bowl for best corrected time to the larger Class A yachts and did it with a minimum of strain.
BERLIN, June 26 President Kennedy saw the miracle and the tragedy of West Berlin today as the city turned out to greet him and applaud his country.

Mrs. Manuel P. Rivera of New York and Mahopac Falls, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Diana Esther Rivera, to Russell Howard Bartley. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Bartley of Verona, N.J.

A joint committee of physicians and lawyers was set up yesterday to act on complaints against "a very small fringe of unethical practitioners in each profession."

JERSEY CITY, June 26 This city unveiled plans today for a $35,000,000 shopping center and commercial complex to cover 12 acres of the Journal Square section. Eight of the acres would be "air rights" over the tracks of PATH, formerly the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad.

THE small exhibition of paintings, drawings and prints by Andr Derain (18801954) opening tomorrow at the Museum of Modern Art focuses attention on a French artist of considerable distinction who, nonetheless, promised more than he performed.

The 16-story and penthouse apartment building at 46 East 91st Street, southeast corner of Madison Avenue, has been purchased by the Cole Leasing Corporation for cash over mortgages amounting to $420,000. It is on a plot 37 by 100 feet and contains 28 apartments and four stores. The sale was negotiated by Adele Kirsch and Edith Lewis, co-brokers, for clients of Harry Neumann, lawyer.
The public does not have a high regard for juries and believes that most intelligent people avoid jury service, according to a recent survey by the Missouri Bar Association.
Investors on the major foreign stock markets remained cautious yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 26 It may have escaped general notice, but the 1964 Presidential campaign is already under way. Several candidates for the Republican nomination are off and running, and more will be appearing every day now as the civil rights issue cuts down President Kennedy's popularity rating.

MOSCOW, June 26 (AP)--Chinese Communist delegates threw the World Women's Congress here into an uproar today by invading the speakers' platform and demanding time to air their views on the Chinese-Indian border conflict.

HOLLYWOOD, June 26 Executives in Hollywood were avoiding argument with the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People over its charges yesterday that the movie and television makers here were treating the Negro as an "invisible man," and as a "caricature."
Earlier this week the University of Michigan found that consumers were acting fickle and had become pessimistic about the economy at a time economists have been making bright predictions.

A recommendation that the Board of Education consider transporting white children to schools in Negro neighborhoods to further integration was disavowed yesterday by several of the sponsors of a conference from which the proposal came.
Mayor Wagner called upon the Police Department yesterday to be ready to maintain order in the face of "the longoverdue social revolution that is sweeping the length and breadth of our country."

Several years ago Stuart T. Saunders was disturbed at what he regarded as the lagging pace of industrial development in Virginia. Part of his concern was that not enough new plants were being built along the Norfolk Western Railway.
Screen rights to "Caravans," a forthcoming novel by James A. Michener, have been purchased by Metro-GoldwynMayer the company announced yesterday. It will be published by Random House in August.

Eugene Burdick, co-author of "The Ugly American" and "Fail Safe," has been signed to write a television play for Bob Hope's series of comedy and filmed dramas that begins next season on the National Broadcasting Company network.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 437,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 194,915,000 barrels, compared with 195,352,000 a week earlier and 190,810,000 a year ago.
PARIS, June 26 France acted today to consolidate her relations with Algeria and Morocco, two North African states that she once dominated.

The Inter-American Development Bank has agreed to lend $30,500,000 to help develop diversified farming in southeastern Mexico. The project also includes the building of houses, schools, public buildings and water and sewage facilities.
MOSCOW, June 26 Premier Khrushchev declared today that Soviet armed forces must stand guard against the danger that the West would unleash a nuclear rocket war.
WASHINGTON, June 26--The House of Representatives heard charges today that lobbyists had suppressed testimony taken by a Foreign Affairs sub-committee in connection with Philippine war damage claims.

Three days of ceremonies to mark the opening of the New York Hilton at Rockefeller Center began at noon yesterday with the firing of a small red cannon on the setback of the four-story base of the 46-story building.

OTTAWA, June 26 (Canadian Press)--The Canadian Government, in a "strictly short-term" measure designed to maintain employment in two communities, announced here tonight that it would buy and stockpile enough uranium to keep three Ontario uranium mines operating with present employment until July 1, 1964.

WASHINGTON, June 26--Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said today that the Administration would be willing to exempt small stores and tourist homes from its proposed ban on discrimination in privately owned public accommodations.
OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 26 The favorites advanced into the semi-final round in the 60th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.
WASHINGTON, June 26 The House Science and Astronautics Committee cut back the scientific portion of the space program today, eliminating $134,248,600 in funds for research and exploration.

The explosive growth of television as an advertising medium has been one of the most dramatic success stories of the last decade. Lately, however, some advertising men have been, posing a question: Has success spoiled TV? Is the medium losing its effectiveness as a result of its swift growth?

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The Radio Technical Commission for Aeronautics said today that weather briefing services and the quantity and quality of weather information and forecasts given to pilots were unsatisfactory.
Carnegie Hall's program booklets will have a new look next season, and will weigh a lot more, too.
ROME, June 26 Pope Paul VI has set Sept. 29 as the dated for resumption of the ecumenical, or universal, council of the Roman Catholic Church, wellinformed Vatican sources said today.
Tim Harkness and five hardworking pitchers turned in one of the Mets' more heroic efforts yesterday at the Polo Grounds.
Schick, Inc., introduced four products yesterday to broaden the diversification program it started last year.
Nine Federal employes, a retired employe and a Long Island builder were indicted yesterday in a bribery inquiry by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn.
CARACAS, Venezuela, June, 26 Venezuelans have become convinced of something that most of them had been doubting up to now: that there will be elections after all.
To the long record of man's inhumanity to man, Communism in all its varieties has added many sickening chapters.
The Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency announced yesterday it would offer for public sale next month $42,016,000 of college housing bonds from its portfolio.
PHILADELPHIA, June 26 Stuart T. Saunders, dynamic, 53year-old president of the Norfolk Western Railroad, was elected today as board chairman and chief executive officer of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

The directors of the Hoover Ball and Bearing Company declared yesterday a year-end extra dividend of 25 cents a share and the regular quarterly of 25 cents. Both dividends are payable July 29 to holders of record July 9.

LONDON, June 26 (UPI) Except in France, newspapers of the non-Communist world said President Kennedy's speech in Frankfurt yesterday had contributed to closer allied cooperation in Europe.

The United States Court of Appeals in a two-to-one decision yesterday lifted an injunction that had barred the transfer of funds held by the First National City Bank of New York in its Montevideo, Uruguay, branch for the account of Omar, S.A., a Uruguayan holding company.

New York's Civic Center plan is admittedly a rescue operation rather than a daring act of creative design. It was never represented as a great or visionary scheme; its architects claimed only to have worked within existing realities (a polite word for past mistakes and present commitments) to perform the near miracle of bringing order, focus and some sense of scale and symbolism out of a monumental muddle.

HERBERT GOLD has an excellent idea for his new anthology, "First Person Singular." His book is a remote-control symposium of declarations on modern life by contemporary avant-garde authors who often are better known as novelists. Or in other masks.
