Certain wave lengths of ultraviolet light have an attraction for hornworm moths that can be fatal to the moths and beneficial to smokers.
Wheat prices declined and sugar prices were mixed in a generally quiet day on the nation's commodity exchanges.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy was prepared today for a challenge to the Administration's civil rights bill on the ground that it would encroach on private property rights.

OBEDIENCE training is comparatively new in the United States. It wasn't until 1936 that the American Kennel Club recognized dog pedagogical work. Since then it has made tremendous strides and each year there has been an increase in the number of dogs seeking degrees.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes threatened yesterday to drop plans for a parking lot at Coney Island if his department's proposals were not acceptable to businessmen there.
The Majestic Savings and Loan Association of Denver announced yesterday it was reducing its dividend rate from 4 to 4 per cent for the second half of 1963.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP)--The House Commerce Committee approved today a bill designed to block retail price-cutting of trademark merchandise.

Wall Street's only private resident is moving out. Hugh Harley has carefully bundled his books, battened down some of the model ships of which he is so fond, packed the ancestral Saracen helmet that he picked up in Palermo while in the Navy in World War I, and is shipping out to Ireland for another adventure.
In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
PHILADELPHIA, June 26 Publicker Industries, Inc., bought today the stock of J.A. Dougherty's Sons, Inc., distillers, for $2,178,000 at public auction.
A representation election among 1,600 American Airlines' pilots has been held up by a temporary court order. A hearing on whether to extend the order will be held today in Washington.
Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association from 1927 until 1953, died yesterday at his home, 433 West 21st Street, after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The American Medical Association was criticized today by Senator Ernest Gruening, Democrat of Alaska, and it promptly accused him of attempting to blame it "for the failures of Government agencies."

A diverting new revue at The Howff, 4 St. Marks Place, is bound together by folk songs and some good-natured ragging of the British Empire. "Rule, Britannia ? ?" opened Tuesday night at the new theater-cafe, replacing "The World of Kurt Weill in Song," which has moved to 1 Sheridan Square.

Forgetful of the soft, sure growth of lawn grass and the spectacle of dish-filled kitchen sinks, several hundred beaming parents stood in the sun on Pier 40 here yesterday and cheered farewells to their summer labor force: their teen-age sons and daughters.
FRANKFORT, Ky., June 26 Gov. Bert T. Combs signed an executive order today forbidding racial discrimination in all businesses licensed by the state.
THERE is really nothing wrong with iceberg lettuce. It is simply that in comparison with other salad greens it is commonplace and pedestrian.

Joseph I. Katsh, vice president of Katsh Brothers Co., Inc., 2521 Broadway, insurance brokers, died on Tuesday in the Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. He was 67 years old and lived at 737 Park Avenue.
SAVANNAH, Ga., June 26 State troopers moved out of Savannah today as negotiations replaced demonstrations on the drive for integration.
WASHINGTON, June 26--The Consumer Price Index remained unchanged in May for the second straight month, but experts in the Labor Department think that prices are about to begin going up again.

Prices of Government bonds tended to inch upward in continued light trading yesterday. Prime corporate issues were again in demand at firm prices and municipals were snapped up at a faster rate in active trading.
HOUSTON, June 26 The Alley Theater, which be gan in 1947 as an idea in the mind of Nina Vance, yesterday began a campaign for $900,000.
WHAT may be the largest collection of old inkstands in the world is now at Lord Taylor.

WASHINGTON June 26--David E. Bell, Foreign Aid Administrator, endorsed today the proposed formation of an inter-American development committee to provide central direction for the lagging Alliance for Progress.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 26--A. Dayton Oliphant, former head of the State Court of Errors and Appeals, died last night in Princeton Hospital. He was 75 years old.
TOKYO. Eighteen years after the end of World War II, Japan is a portrait in bright colors, but a portrait unfinished.
Carmine G. De Sapio said yesterday that Mayor Wagner's election to a third term in 1961 was "the greatest hoax" ever perpetrated on the people of New York City.

OTTAWA, June 26 The Liberal Government's controversial budget won approval in principle this afternoon when the House of Commons voted 119 to 74 to go into committee to pass upon each proposal separately.

Electric Bond and Share Company took another step yesterday in its seemingly neverending plan to change from the old utility holding company of the past to a new operating corporation of the standard variety. Its present status is that of an investment company.

ARNOLD TAGER, director and actor" and FM radio station WBAI undertook a theatrical venture last night that might give pause to any impresario. They offered a virtually uncut "Hamlet" running from 7:15 to almost midnight. The ambitious project assuredly enjoyed a listener's goodwill but it was not really too well advised.

CHICAGO, June 26 The Ravinia Festival opens its 28th summer season of music and ballet tomorrow night at Ravinia Park in the Chicago North Shore suburban area with Pablo Casals conducting his Catalan oratorio "El Pessebre."

FALLSBURG, N.Y., June 26--The largest Orthodox Rabbinic body in the country called on Mayor Wagner and the City Council today to adopt at once a resolution permitting Jewish merchants to operate their business on Sunday in New York City.
WASHINGTON, June 26 Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said today that the attitude of Congress ruled out any wheat legislation this year.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 The city administration notified two contractors tonight that their contracts with the city would be canceled unless they adopted promptly a nondiscriminatory hiring plan satisfactory to the city's Commission on Human Relations.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 26--As had been expected, permission to begin the twin double at Roosevelt Raceway, starting July 8, was granted today by the New York State Harness Racing Commission. The action came 48 hours after the petition from Alvin L. Weil, the track president.
Frank Irving Fletcher, a prominent freelance advertising writer, died yesterday in his apartment at the Bancroft Hotel, 40 West 72d Street, after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

A race between two powerful but unevenly matched sea horses will begin next month. The distance is the North Atlantic and the prize the extensive military traffic in wheeled and tracked combat vehicles.
ACCESSORIES have a multiple role to play for summer. They should be cheerful as well as practical and should tuck easily into a suitcase because they will spend a considerable time traveling.

BUFFALO, June 27--State Senator Walter J. Mahoney and Mrs. Mahoney have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Desmond Mahoney, to Joseph F. Biondolillo. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Biondolillo.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 27 --Around a race track, one hears lots of rumors, few of which check out under close scrutiny.
BUFFALO, June 27--The argument about who is better, the 1963 New York Mets or the . 1962 New York Mets, was settled once and for all tonight. , It is the 1963 Mets.

National Car Rental System, Inc. announced yesterday it has acquired four car rental companies in the New York metropolitan area. The four concerns provide National with immediate operating locations in Idlewild, La Guardia and Newark Airports and in midtown Manhattan and Newark.
The Board of Education's appeal for more state funds was rejected yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.
WASHINGTON, June 27-- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said today that equal job opportunities for Negroes could be obtained only by achieving "fuller employment" of the national work force.
Steamfitters Local 638 announced yesterday that its membership had voted to accept a new three-year contract, raising hopes that a strike in the city's construction industry could be avoided.

The former president and treasurer of a bankrupt commercial finance company testified yesterday that they caused the company to pay off subordinated notes to relatives, while primary debt remained on the company's books.

DUBLIN, June 27--President Kennedy lifted the spirits of County Wexford today. He lifted them higher than they've been since the Rising of '98.
New York City sold yesterday $30,539,000 of short-term, taxexempt City bonds in five lots to two bidders, Abraham D. Beame, Controller, said.

Warring Democratic reform factions in Greenwich Village have agreed to a temporary truce in an effort to block Carmine G. De Sapio's political comeback.
Conflicting influences gave a mixed appearance to the London stock market yesterday.

An unusual export, a live television show, is going to Japan from the United States. The program is "Romper Room," the popular show for toddlers seen on more than 100 stations, including Channel 5 here.
New York City had its fourth straight day of temperatures in the 90's yesterday. No relief is in sight for the next two days at least, the Weather Bureau said.
ST. PAUL, June 26--"Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" will be performed in one of the Twin Cities next year, but not in the other.
An apparent smoldering feud between directors of Lee Rubber and Tire Corporation broke into the open in court here yesterday.
The construction of the first sections of a 10.6-mile, $55,000,000 expressway to serve southeast Queens and adjoining Nassau County was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, June 27-- The Senate Appropriations Committee is expected to consider soon the budgetary requests of two Federal shipping agencies for 1964. Appropriations for the agencies were cut earlier this month by the House of Representatives.

CLEVELAND, June 27 (UPI) --Gary Player, Bo Wininger and Bill Eggers, who drives with a 19-year-old brassie, fired fiveunder-par 66's today to share first-round lead in the $110,000 Cleveland golf open.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI)--Representative William M. Tuck, Virginia Democrat, asked Congress today to make it unlawful for any person to cross state lines and take part in a demonstration.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 27-- Gov. Bert T. Combs's Executive order banning racial discrimination in businesses and professions licensed by the state drew mixed although generally favorable reaction today.
DETROIT, June 27--George Malvin Holley, automotive pioneer and a friend of Henry Ford, died here today at the age of 85.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 27 --Maj. Gen. Ziad el-Hariri, Syria's Minister of Defense and Chief of Staff, seemed to be getting the upper hand today in maneuvering for power in Damascus.
The natural-gas invasion of the once-sacred realm of electric utilities is moving ahead at a record pace on Long Island.
BERLIN, June 27--East Berlin broke out flags and bunting today for Premier Khrushchev, who arrives tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 27--(UPI)-The Department of Commerce curtailed today all exports of beet and cane sugar to higher-priced markets outside the United States. It an nounced that future exports of sugar would require a license issued by its Bureau of International Commerce.

Paul Libin, head of the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers, said yesterday that if the league acceded to new demands by the stagehands' union the death knell would be sounded for most small playhouses next season.

Plans to renew and brighten part of the West Side were reactivated by the city yesterday.
A patrolman testified yesterday that he smelled alcohol on the breath of the 23-yearold son of a Criminal Courts judge when he arrested him after an automobile accident in which five persons died.

Directors of the Amerada Petroleum Corporation yesterday ordered a quarterly dividend of 50 cents on the new common stock, payable July 31 to holders of record of July 15. This is equal to $1 on the old shares, which were split recently on a two-for-one basis.
Robert Moses and a lawyer clashed loudly and sharply in court yesterday over the proposal to put an outdoor cafe in Central Park.

GENEVA, June, 27--A special trade negotiations committee met here today to begin the preparations for the so-called Kennedy round of bargaining for tarriff cuts to be held next year under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).

ABOARD U.S.S. FORT SNELLING, at Sea, June 27-- The bathyscaph Trieste made her third dive today in an effort to find the remains of the nuclear submarine Thresher, which vanished on April 10, 220 miles off Boston, with the loss of 129 men.

With the recent completion of a $25,000,000 construction program, the Consolidated Edison Company says the chance of another big power failure like the one that darkened much of Manhattan two years ago is minuscule.

MIAMI, Friday, June 28-- (UPI)--Premier Fidel Castro told Cubans last night that their economic future in the Communist camp depended more than ever on sugar. He called for "a big push" in 1964 to make up for this year's lagging crop.

LONDON, June 27--Secondseeded Manuel Santana of Spain used a rapier backhand across court today to defeat Rafael Osuna of Mexico, 2-6, 0-6, 6-1, 6-3, 6-4, in an exciting thirdround match in the Wimbledon tennis championships.
WASHINGTON, June 27--A Nobel prizewinner proposed today a new approach to cancer treatment. It is based on evidence that a natural substance found in mice inhibits cancer growth in them.

The Treasury sold $65,000,000 of gold on Tuesday, bringing the reduction in its gold reserves so far this year to $245,000,000. This compares with a decline of $455,000,000 in the similar 1962 period.
As a step toward the study of astronomy from space, an astronaut is to ride a jet plane chasing the moon's shadow across Canada during the total eclipse of the sun July 20.

WASHINGTON, June 27-- The Administration has received encouraging signs that the Soviet Union, despite its public threats, is still willing to accept three annual inspections in a nuclear test ban treaty.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)--Alan S. Boyd, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, assured New England Senators today there would be no interruption in locals air service to their region if Northeast Airlines were to lose its FloridaNew York route and go out of business.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 27--The Special Committee on Colonialism agreed by consensus today to name a fivemember commission to investigate the situation in British Guiana, where independence has been delayed by internal disorders.

WASHINGTON, June 27--The sight of the Berlin wall has evoked a sense of outrage in most of those dedicated to human freedom who, like President Kennedy, have viewed it from the West.

DUBLIN, June 27--President Kennedy's arrival in Rome will be delayed until Monday morning so it will not conflict with the coronation of Pope Paul VI Sunday evening, a Presidential assistant announced today.

A committee representing 12 artists' societies is pressing for an exhibition of contemporary American art in a separate pavilion at the New York World's Fair. At the moment there are no official plans for such an exhibition.

DETROIT, June 27--Howard Charles Baldwin, a lawyer, banker, industrialist and pioneer in the American Automobile Association, died in Harper Hospital here Tuesday after a short illness. He was 72 years old.

LONDON, June 27--President Kennedy is expected to urge Prime Minister Macmillan to take the broadest possible view of the proposed mixed-crew fleet of nuclear-armed surface vessels during their weekend talks.

WASHINGTON, June 27-- The Securities and Exchange Commission is refusing to back down on its proposal that large companies whose stock is owned by at least 500 persons be required to comply with certain basic rules of the Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 27-- The Pentagon quietly has eliminated racial segregation from the armed forces' Reserves.

The New York Stock Exchange ends its biggest second quarter in volume today with trading totaling about 303,000,000 shares. The second-best quarter came in 1933, when 282,730,080 shares changed hands.

LONDON, June 27--Miss Faith Beatrice Wright and Julian John Evelyn Shuckburgh were married this afternoon at St. James's Anglican Church in Piccadilly.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 27 --This city's Mayor accused the John Birch Society today of blocking civic progress.
Heavy purchases of Treasury bills by the Federal Reserve enlivened an otherwise quiet day in the Government securities market yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 27 (UPI)-- Soybean and corn futures shot upward today to show substantial gains on the Board of Trade. Wheat eased, oats steadied and rye was mixed.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he would accelerate $4,000,000,000 worth of state construction contracts to create more jobs, especially for Negroes.

GADSDEN, Ala., June 27 (UPI)--The police broke up a demonstration described by Negroes as a "peaceful protest march" here today. Fifty-two demonstrators were arrested. The march was led by 11 women whose children are being held in connection with previous demonstrations.

ONLY the imagination is the limit when it comes to concocting cool and refreshing desserts with unflavored gelatin. Flavor sources include fresh or canned fruit juices, the syrup in which fruits are packed, instant coffee, wines and liqueurs and frozen juice concentrates.

Lewis B. Maytag Jr., president of National Airlines, said yesterday that, as soon as arrangements could be completed, National would sell on the open market 353,000 shares of Pan American World Airways it now holds.
John Humphreys Sullivan, a 39-year-old electrical engineer, was sentenced yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to a 30day jail term for violating the Federal Bomb Hoax Law.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 27 --Dr. John Maurice Clark, professor emeritus of economics at Columbia University and one of the great economists of this century, died of cancer at his home here today. He was 78 years old.
FALLSBURG, N.Y., June 27 --A Jewish Orthodox leader urged today the American Jewish community to meet the challenge of "overcoming the evils of monolithic secularism on college campuses."

WASHINGTON, June 27-- Dr. Maynard Owen Williams, chief of the foreign editorial staff of the National Geographic Society from 1930 until 1953, died in Istanbul, Turkey, on Wednesday. He was 74 years old.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 27 (AP)--A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals granted the Government a temporary restraining order here today halting the planned merger of American Viscose Corporation of Phila

It was hot at Lewisohn Stadium last night, too. A few desultory breezes at the start of the concert promised more than they fulfilled. The flags at the top of the stadium wall hung limp for the rest of the evening.
SEA CLIFF, L.I., June 26-- Light and variable winds stretched the Long Island eliminations for the Syce Cup into a fourth day with Mrs. Maude Kirby of the host Sea Cliff Club leading with 11 points.
LONDON, June 27--The British Ministry of Health has put up 1,000,000 posters in the country warning of health hazards from smoking cigarettes. Early next year the campaign may be put on television.

LONDON, June 27--The oil sell-out fever has hit Britain. Two of the biggest oil companies in the world announced today plans to take over the assets of the Burmah Oil Company, Ltd., of London, a medium-size producer with a huge investment portfolio.

Directors of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad voted unanimous approval yesterday of a merger plan with the Union Pacific Railroad after considering a rival offer from the Chicago North Western Railway.

MBALABALA, Kenya, June 16--The Midtown Turf, Yachting and Polo Association, Inc. (Hunting and Fishing) is represented in strength in East Africa. There is a small unofficial competition under way among the members on the scene.
LONDON, June 27--"A Severed Head," the Iris Murdoch novel, which Miss Murdoch and J.B. Priestley adapted to the stage, opened at the Criterion Theater here tonight.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 27--President Sukarno returned to Indonesia today to face rising resentment over the Government's new economic regulations.
LONDON, June 27--An impromptu, and certainly unofficial, team match was held last night between the United States and Britain.
Late-afternoon selling depressed stock prices yesterday, wiping out minor gains shown in morning trading.
The new Metropolitan Opera House will not offer spectators a complete view of the stage, as originally promised, Wallace K. Harrison, architect for the structure, acknowledged yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 27 --A Government survey has found that, of 5,658 skilled journeymen employed on 47 Federal construction projects, only 300 were Negroes.
AN unusual boutique opened yesterday at the unusual hour of 6:30 P.M., but when the closing time of 9 P.M. had arrived several hundred guests attested to its success.
WASHINGTON, June 27--A move to cut down on what one member described as "a lot of guff" in debate on the Senate floor got under way in a Senate Rules subcommittee today.
The New York Shipping Association criticized yesterday what it called "the high-handed manner" of the Waterfront Commission in issuing new rules against dock pilferage.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 27--Mrs. Allan A. Ryan of Long Island and Mrs. Philip Cudone of New Jersey Field Club will meet tomorrow in the 36-hole final of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's 60th annual championship.
PARIS, June 27--President de Gaulle's Cabinet spokesman today questioned the durability of President Kennedy's pledge to defend the United States' allies in Europe.

DAYTON, Ohio, June 27-- Southern delegates to the annual convention of the Congress of Racial Equality expressed concern here today over what they said was the imminent possibility of a violent racial explosion.

Richard (Pancho) Gonzalez paid the penalty of his years in the extreme heat at Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday, and lost his comeback bid in the United States professional grass court tennis championships. Lewis Hoad also was beaten.

WASHINGTON, June 27-- Two Federal grants totalling nearly $1,400,000 were awarded to the Tri-state Transportation Committee today to help improve commuter service in the outer areas of Westchester, Putnam and Rockland Counties in New York.

LOS ANGELES, June 27-- The sixth and final pro duction of the Theater Group's fourth season is an extra dividend of the most stimulating sort--an intelligent and spirited revival of Shaw's "Heartbreak House."

At the request of Richard Rodgers and Alan Jay Lerner, authors and producers of "I Picked a Daisy," the Shuberts have granted them two more weeks to decide whether the musical will be ready to occupy the Majestic in December The previous deadline was June 30.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 27--Dick Stockton of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Alex Mayer of Woodmere, L.I., captured the New Jersey boys' championships today at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.
LONDON, June 27--Prime Minister Macmillan today named Joseph Godber, Britain's chief delegate to the disarmament talks at Geneva, to succeed John Profumo as Secretary of State for War.
WASHINGTON, June 27-- Henry Cabot Lodge, the Republican candidate for Vice President three years ago, is joining the Kennedy Administration as Ambassador to South Vietnam.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 27 --A reorganization of the Plainfield school system to reduce racial imbalance was approved tonight.

The General Tire and Rubber Company had record sales and earnings in first fiscal halfyear ended May 31, the semiannual report of T.F. O'Neil, chairman, and M.G. O'Neil, president, disclosed yesterday.

William W. Jordan, president of the Pacific Coast Marine Firemen, Oilers, Watertenders and Wipers Association warned his members yesterday to become "less choosy" in the jobs they accept aboard United States flag ships.
WASHINGTON, June 27--Republican leaders cast doubt today on prospects for enactment of a tax-reduction bill this year.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., June 28 (AP) A Circuit Court judge quashed anti-subversive charges against three Indiana University Socialists today and said the wording of the indictment was unclear.
A Federal judge, overturning a two-year-old jury verdict, has ruled that an airline must pay damages to the estate of William Kapell, the renowned young pianist who was killed in a 1953 crash.
HARRISON, N.Y., June 28 The trustees of the New Haven Railroad said today $5,000,000 in public assistance was needed to continue commutation service between New York City ands New Haven.

If on Broadway next season Charles Boyer speaks with greater clarity, Mary Martin Founds authentically Irish and Dennis O'Keefe is able to project his voice beyond the first theater row, the success for this speech and dialectical facility rests with a 53-year-old former actor.
Robert Porter Allen, an ornithologist who was research director of the National Audubon Society, died yesterday in Tavernier, Fla. His age was 58.
WASHINGTON, June 28 Secretary of the Navy Fred Korth warned today "against a tendency to rewrite history" in the heated controversy over the TFX airplane contract.
BONN, June 28--Foreign Minister Gerhard Schr der said today that the United States would never give up Europe without a fight.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 An attempt to equate members of the John Birch Society and other Right-wing groups with Communists failed today at the biennial convention of the Young Republican National Federation.
ROME, June 28 Pope Paul VI granted a private audience this morning to Richard M. Nixon, former Vice President of the United States, his wife and their two daughters.

The Presbytery of New York City, representing 122 churches in the five boroughs, has abandoned its attitude of "passive approval" of antisegregation activities and will turn to "active participation."
Pancho Segura furnished the most exciting moments thus far in the United States professional grass court tennis championship at Forest Hills yesterday in taking a set from Rodney Laver of Australia.

WASHINGTON, Pa., June 28 The racing strip was synthetic, all right, but there was nothing artificial about the enthusiasm of the crowd that greeted western Pennsylvania's introduction to pari-mutuel wagering.
OLD WESBURY, L.I., June 28 Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club in Bloomfield, N.J., today won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship.

MODERN readers like to fly from the troubles of the present to the troubles of the past. And those of us who would not dream of making a picturesque gesture today revel vicariously in the swagger-dagger shenanigans of bolder--and safely departed--spirits.
Northeast Airlines, threatened with foreclosure of its jet and turboprop fleet, got a new lease on life yesterday at a meeting with its creditors in Boston.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., June 28 Judy Kimball of Sioux City, Iowa, added a 4-under-par 68 to her opening-round 71 and took the lead in the Carvel women's open tournament at the Tam O'Shanter Golf Club today.

The price of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) shares climbed to the highest point in history yesterday. They rose as high as 68 , thus topping the preceding 1963 high of 68 3/8 and Jersey's former historic high of 68 back in 1957.
A ruling in the Federal Court of Appeals yesterday upheld a District Court order that the costs of unloading the tied-up freighter Emilia be deducted from the proceeds of the sale of the vessel.
A 33-year-old plainclothes patrolman was shot and fatally wounded early yesterday in a ground-floor room of the Congress Hotel, 19 West 69th Street.

Things were going along smoothly for the New York Yankees for a while last night against the Boston Red Sox. Al Downing was pitching a nohitter, the Yanks had a 2-0 lead and the return to Yankee Stadium was shaping up as a fine homecoming.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 28 The police were unable to find new leads today in the case of the bombing of the homes of two white Minneapolis policemen who were under suspension after a racial incident.

NEW DELHI, June 28 Ambassador John Kenneth Galbraith countered left-wing criticism of United States aid to India today with statement that the critics "are in the rather ambivalent position of complaining that we are not doing enough and warning that we want to do too much."
WESTBURY, L.I., June 28 A four-horse collision in the fourth raced brought 22,914 screaming fans to their feet tonight at Roosevelet Raceway.
Stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange were sharply up in the first six months of this year.

ALBANY, June 28 Fiscal independence for the big city schools of the state would give them added flexibility to cope with problems of racial imbalance, the State Commissioner of Education said today.
CORVALLIS, Ore., June 28 (UPI)--Steve Pauly of Oregon State took the halfway lead today in the Amateur Athletic Union's national decathlon championship.
CHICAGO, June 28 (UPI)--Soybean futures reached strong ground in a late bout of buying today on the Board of Trade. Corn and nearby wheat contract prices retreated, while other grains were uneven.
WASHINGTON, June 28 The news accounts of "fun-loving" Russian diplomats and "society osteopaths" leading Tiberian lives in England have secretly delighted some of the most sober spies in Washington.

The United Nations escaped bankruptcy and the concurrent collapse of its peace-enforcement function when the special session of the General Assembly approved in the nick of time the necessary funds to maintain the peace-keeping operations in the Congo and the Middle East until the end of this year. What is probably the final chapter of the TFX hearings opened yesterday against a background of possible change in the Pentagon's contractual procedures. Secretary of the Navy Fred Korth testified before Senator John L. McClellan's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.
WASHINGTON, June 28 Suffolk County officials who came here to scoff at the Interior Department's Fire Island plans today remained to praise them.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) United Press International told a Senate committee today its Special Service Bureau "does not accept assignments on behalf of foreign governments."

LONDON, June 28 Prime Minister Macmillan reaffirmed tonight his intention to lead the Conservative party in the next general election. Seeking to stem party discon tent in the wake of the Profumo scandal, he asserted that he had "plenty of support" among his party's backbenchers.

The first-quarter sales of the General Instrument Corporation are expected to set a record and earnings are expected to increase from those in the similar period last year, Martin H. Benedek, chairman, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Newark.

Bonds called in June for redemption before maturity totaled an estimated $453,586,000, a six-fold gain from $67,064,000 in the similar month of 1962, a survey by The New York Times disclosed yesterday.
VIENNA, June 28 Dr. Vladimir Clementis, former Foreign Minister of Czechoslovak who was executed in 1952 as a spy for the West, has been rehabilitated by the Communist party of Slovakia.
MOSCOW, June 28 The ideological dispute between Moscow and Peking has disrupted some operations of Communistsponsored international organizations.

BRUSSELS, June 28 The Belgian Defense Ministry said today the Belgian military plane that crashed at Sennelager, West Germany, Wednesday might have been hit by a mortar shell fired by British Army units.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, June 29 (UPI) The North Koreans informed the United Nations Command today that the two U.S. Army officers whose helicopter made a forced landing in Communist territory May 17 were alive.
Once again racial discrimination in the building trades unions has been conquered on paper.
DUBLIN, June 28 President Kennedy declared today that "there are no permanent enemies" in this world. He cited Ireland's achievement of freedom as inspiration for the peoples living under Communism.
When "Man and Boy," the Terrence Rattigan play starring Charles Boyer, opens Nov. 12 at the Brooks Atkinson Theater it will offer three matinees a week.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) Farm product prices increased four-tenths of 1 per cent between mid-May and midJune, the Agriculture Department reported today.

Morris Margolis, president of the F.M. Charlton Company, Inc., bookbinders, died yesterday of a heart attack in Montefiore Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 260 West End Avenue and in Brewster, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, June 28 A retired Naval captain has discovered that putting an electric charge on the surface of a rocket or missile greatly increases its velocity and stability. In experiments with small rockets, the electric charge multiplied the altitude five or six times.
About 125,000 Jehovah's Witnesses will gather at Yankee Stadium next month for an eight-day international convention beginning July 7.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 28 Leaders of major Jewish community-relations groups warned today that any Federal aid to parochial and private education, such as national defense funds, would weaken the public school system without any corresponding benefits to interfaith relations.

Devotees of the original Benny Goodman Trio can hear two-thirds of the group in Manhattan these nights, However, it takes a little commuting. Gene Krupa is playing on the West Side while Teddy Wilson is on the East (last night Mr. Goodman played a concert of classical music in Stamford, Conn.).
LOS ANGELES, June 28 (AP)--Warren Spahn retired the first 19 batters, finished with a three-hitter and broke a 15-year jinx tonight as the Milwaukee Braves defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 1-0.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) In a first official forecast, the Agriculture Department's Economic Research Service said today farmers probably will seed 60,000,000 acres of wheat for the unrestricted 1964 crop.

Sugar futures advanced and cocoa prices fell sharply in active trading here yesterday. Most other commodities traded in New York rose in quiet dealings.
WASHINGTON, June. 28 The Federal training program for unemployed workers faces slow strangulation unless a provision calling for state sharing of its costs is lifted.

CINCINNATI, June 28 The marriaeg of Miss Marcia Myers Tucker, daughter of the Rev, and Mrs. Luther Tucker, to Tom Boogaard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Christian Boogaard of Amersfoort, the Netherlands, took place here this afternoon.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 28 Miss Alice Stackpole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Stackpole, was presented here tonight at a large dance given by her parents at Normandy, their Ocean Avenue estate.

The Government securities market ended the week on a dull note yesterday in slow trading. Volume was light, as it was for most of the week. High-grade corporate and municipal bond traders also succumbed to the usual pre-weekend influences and were quiet.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 28 (AP) Gold Dot Stable's Royaume, who had graduated from the maiden ranks only a week ago, won his second race in succession at Monmouth Park today.

ABOARD U.S.S. FORT SNELLING, at Sea, June 28--The first identifiable article from the nuclear submarine Thresher was observed and photographed yesterday by Lieut. Comdr. Donald Keach on the third dive of the bathyscaph Trieste. The sighting was made at a depth of 8,400 feet.

WASHINGTON, June 28--Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. said today that there was no chance of passing the section of President Kennedy's civil rights bill barring discrimination in privately owned public accomodations.
JACKSON, Miss., June 28 Six months ago 28 young white Methodist ministers issued a manifesto proclaiming their belief in "freedom of the pulpit" and opposing racial discrimination in Mississippi.

PARIS, June 28 The principal book on probabilities in bridge was published in Paris, with the theory and calculations supplied by the celebrated French mathematician, Emile Borel, but that does not necessarily make French players more percentage-minded than players of other nationalities.
Burmah Oil shot up yesterday on the London stock market on the strength of the takeover offer from British Petroleum and Shell.

WASHINGTON, June 28 Conservatives outnumber liberals on the House Judiciary Committee, which opened hearings this week on President Kennedy's civil rights bill, but the panel has a fairly consistent record of cooperating with whatever Administration is in power.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 28 The East team, with a 255pound defensive line and a plethora of big-name backs and ends, is the favorite over the West in the All-Star football game to be played here tomorrow night.

DUBLIN, June 28 President Kennedy's history but not his instincts failed him today, as he presented the Irish Republic with a Civil War battle flag of the Irish brigade.
It was Summer Festival Day at Aqueduct yesterday but along came John L. Rotz, the pleasant 29-year-old jockey from nearby Kew Gardens, to steal most of the show before 23,194 onlookers.

Miss Anne M. Kelly, deputy commissioner of the city's Department of Commerce, conceded yesterday that she had asked the State Employment Service whether she could specify white or Negro in re questing the agency to supply a secretary for her. However,

After hearing eight weeks of testimony, Federal Judge Joseph C. Zavatt reserved decision yesterday on an application by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to change the racial balance in Manhasset L.I., schools.
DUBLIN, June 28 Tomorrow's Irish Sweeps Derby is down on money, down on entries and down on excitement over last year, but is up on facilities at the bar, if that is what you like about horse racing.
BERLIN, June 28 Premier Khrushchev rode through East Berlin today in a "friendship visit" that drew a milder response than President Kennedy's tumultuous reception by West Berliners two days ago.

LONDON, June 28--Shares of the Burmah Oil Company rocketed on the London Stock Exchange today amid reports that the company was preparing to fight the joint take-over efforts of the British Petroleum Company and the Shell Petroleum Company.
ACCRA, Ghana, June 27 At a recent diplomatic garden party an affable Soviet correspondent based here remarked that Accra "is the most nonaligned capital in the world."
DAYTON, Ohio, June 28 The Congress of Racial Equality congratulated Gov. Bert T. Combs of Kentucky today and invited him to come to Dayton to address its convention.
WASHINGTON, June 28--Congress was warned today that it was losing status with the public and effectiveness as an arm of government because of its cumbersome and outmoded methods of doing business.

Leopoldo Torre-Nilsson, the Argentine screen writer and director whose prize-winning import "Hand in the Trap" opens Monday at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, is working on his first English-language feature. The film, a drama entitled "The Beautiful Family," will also be the second movie production for Paul Heller of the highly successful "David and Lisa."
SAN DIEGO, June 28 Since Shakespeare is prime currency everywhere, a town need not be named Stratford to qualify as the home of a Shakespeare festival.

CHICAGO, June 28 (UPI) The Cleveland Indians rallied for two runs in the ninth inning tonight, driving out Jim Brosnan for the first time in the American League, to beat the Chicago White Sox, 4 3, and spoil their bid to take over first place.
Traffic through the MontrealLake Ontario section of the St. Lawrence Seaway was 15.6 per cent higher in April and May than in the same two months in 1962.

LONDON, June 28 The name of Viscount Astor of Cliveden was brought into the widening Profumo scandal today.
The 1962-63 school year ended in the city yesterday with many school officials and teachers uncertain whether the public schools would reopen as scheduled Sept. 9 for the new academic year.
The defense of Gerardo A. (Jerry) Re and five others, including his son, Gerard F., charged with a multimilliondollar stock swindle, lasted only 28 minutes yesterday in United States District Court.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy declared yesterday that his department would pay no heed to race in making appointments, promotions or assignments of policemen.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) A House subcommittee announced today it plans to look into editorializing by radio and television stations.
A blast from Bolivia, warnings from Malaya, the disclosure of secret international discussions and a bold shift in United States policy have kept the tin market in turmoil all week.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., June 28 Automobile race drivers accelerating and decelerating in and out of sharp curves and on long straightaways apparently undergo stresses similar to an astronaut maneuvering into outer space and returning to the earth's atmosphere.
Stock prices inched forward yesterday as trading activity dropped sharply.

The Kroger Company, the country's third-largest supermarket chain, reported yesterday that its net income for the 24 weeks ended June 15 rose 11 per cent from the level in the comparable period a year ago.
Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan is to be sworn in at City Hall next Tuesday noon by Mayor Wagner as a $25,000-a-year Judge of the City Civil Court.
Temperatures hit the 90's at midday in New York City for the fifth successive day yesterday. Then they dropped five degrees to bring some slight relief.
MOSCOW, Saturday, June 29 Premier Khrushchev has asserted that President Kennedy had been compelled by Communist strength to reassess United States relations with the Soviet Union.
TRAPPE, Md., June 28 (AP) Home Run Baker, a baseball slugger of the "dead-ball" era, died today in his home at the age of 77. He suffered his second stroke in two years this month.

The marriage of Miss Thankful Dimmock Bailey, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Randolph Bailey of New York and Sharon, Conn., to Daniel Richard Southerland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fitzhugh Lee Southerland of Arlington, Va., took place here yesterday noon.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) The Justice Department filed suit in Oxford, Miss., today seeking the release of 45 Negroes who have been held in the Leflore County jail since June 19.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) Senator John O. Pastore of Rhode Island, and Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, engaged in a squabble today after Senator Thurmond accused radio and television networks of "following the N.A.A.C.P. line."
Puerto Rican enthusiasm for Hispanic poetry is turning New York into a major center for the art.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 28 The United States won modest praise today for its opposition to South Africa's apartheid or racial separation policy. But Washington was simultaneously advised to tell its position to the world in spectacular style.

Spokesmen for Great Lakes carriers, the domestic coastwise trades and maritime unions voiced strong support yesterday for legislation seeking to extend shipbuilding subsidies to vessels in the coastwise trades.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 28 Miss Hazel Ford Walling, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Cheves Thomson Walling of Upper Montclair, was married this afternoon to David Alden Nourse. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Nourse of Westboro, Mass.

ROCHESTER, June 28 Governor Rockefeller combined state business and politics today in a visit to three western New York counties where the Republicans have a big stake in the outcome of local elections this fall.
Israel's largest steamship operator, Zim Lines of Haifa, will consolidate its New York terminal operations at Pier 32, Hudson River at Canal Street, on Monday.

Fyodor Abramov, Soviet author of a novel that will be released in a translation here today, has informed a British publisher he is dissatisfied with the story and wants publication postponed until he had reworked it.

PARIS, June 28 Peeking under the confetti one finds the only diplomatic agreement of President Kennedy's brilliant grand tour has so far been the decision to shove into the icebox our plan for a multilateral NATO nuclear force. It is probable deferment ultimately means interment.
AS scientists learn more and more about the moon, cu rious children are likely to have less of a chance to learn about nature in their own back yards. In many cases they don't even have one.
WASHINGTON, June 28 Dr. Leland J. Haworth, a former Atomic Energy Commissioner and a nuclear physicist, was sworn today as the director of the National Science Foundation.

An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner has recommended the dismissal of applications by nine barge companies to operate on a waterway that is not expected to become navigable for another seven years. He said the applications were "premature."
Two levels of savings and loan association dividend rates seem to be solidly established in California for the coming three months, in contrast to the almost perfect uniformity that had prevailed.

Directors of the Alleghany Corporation, at a meeting here yesterday, decided to appeal a recent Federal District Court decision to dismiss a $100,000,000 fraud suit against financier Allan P. Kirby and three others.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) Lieut. Gen. Homer L. Litzenberg, retired Marine Corps officer and a veteran of campaigns in North Africa, Central Pacific and Korea, died yesterday of cancer at the Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital. He was 60 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 30-- The Government's guaranteed-loan program for railroads, designed to help the rail industry improve its facilities and services, goes out of existence at midnight tonight. Its prospects for revival are questionable.

WESTON, Conn., June 30-- Mrs. Jerome Francis Donovan has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Charlotte Lovekin Donovan, to William J. O'Shea Jr., son of Mrs. O'Shea of New York and the late Mr. O'Shea.
Proximity to a good highway is the single most important factor in new plant location, according to a study released yesterday by the American Trucking Associations.
Proper understanding of the parables of Jesus requires consideration of the situation in which they were spoken, the Rev. Dr. Joseph Sittler said yesterday.

SULTRY summer days and the attendant activities of cutting the lawn, Little League baseball or even lazing in a hammock create a demand for tall, refreshing drinks. All ages need to replace body fluid lost in perspiration in order to cool down and maintain body temperature.
PARIS, June 30--Among European cities Paris prob ably most closely resembles New York in its many bridge clubs and duplicate bridge games.

A Lower East Side congregation of Roman Catholics of Slavic ancestry moved slightly uptown yesterday and into one of the city's most modernistic churches, St. Mary's Church of the Byzantine-Slavonic Rite.
PITTSBURGH, June 30--Steel users were moving last week to bring inventories into line with consumption.
Miss Charlotte Louise Harris and James Ralph Wiener were married at the Delmonico yesterday. Rabbi Leon A. Jick performed the ceremony.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., June 30--What's more difficult than conducting a pro-celebrity golf event on a day in which the temperatures and humidity are high but the desire of competitors only lukewarm?

PARIS, June 30--N.R.A., a keystone of the Roosevelt New Deal, was invalidated almost 30 years ago by the so-called Sick Chicken case. Today the Grand Design of the Kennedy New Frontier is menaced by the case of the unsick chickens.
ROME, June 30--In a multilingual homily, Pope Paul VI said tonight that he intended to encourage "greater mutual comprehension, charity and peace between peoples."
The still-widening, though gentler, ripples of disturbance that emanated from last year's stock-market break continue to pass over the sales-depressed mutual fund industry.
SHOPPING in the city, which used to be a pleasurable way to spend an afternoon, is turning into an exhausting chore, many women complain.
A solemn pontifical mass was celebrated yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral in honor of the coronation of Pope Paul VI.
LOS ANGELES, June 30 (UPI)--Tony Cloninger of the Milwaukee Braves pitched a two hitter today for a 7--0 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
LONDON, June 30--Whaling has come a long way since the days when the Pequod hunted the white whale, Moby Dick.
A struggle for political power's has erupted in Harlem and threatens to destroy the alliance of Negro district leaders there.
Two highly praised Italianmade dramas, "I Fidanzati" ("The Fiances") and "La Terra Trema" ("The Earth Quakes"), were announced yesterday as the first selections for the New York Film Festival.

Following is the text of the homily delivered in nine languages by Paul VI at his coronation in Rome yesterday, as made available by Reuters and The Associated Press. The translation from the Latin was made by the Rev. Thomas Moriarty, teacher of Latin at Cathedral College in New York.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP)--Despite strenuous ef forts to streamline it since Stalin's death, the Soviet bureaucracy under Premier Khrushchev remains oversized, overstaffed and overage, a Congressional research report said today.

A nostalgic visit was paid yesterday in Central Park to some sights and sounds that no longer exist: the sheepfold replaced by the Tavern-on-theGreen, the water trough formerly clustered with horse-drawn carriages and the once-wicked Casino where Jimmy Walker used to drink.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP)--Maj. Gen. James Lawton Collins, brother of the former Army Chief of Staff, J. Lawton Collins, died early today of a heart attack at Walter Reed Hospital. He was 80 years old. The retired general lived in Alexandria, Va.

Investigations Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan was described by the city bar association yesterday as "lacking in the qualities of temperament, impartiality of judgment, dignity and decorum that the bar regards as essential for judicial office."
Two youths were charged in Criminal Court yesterday with the slaying of a policeman in a West Side hotel last Friday.
DETROIT, July 1 (AP) Preliminary figures for last month showed today that the United States automotive industry built 689,519 cars the highest production for any June.
WASHINGTON, July 1 United States officials indicated today that the passports visiting Cuba would be withdrawn after the students returned to the United States.
DEDHAM, Mass., July 1 Fifteen-year-old Lesley Milliken of Walpole, Mass., posted the best round today in a junior girls' golf sweepstakes at the Dedham Country and Polo Club, Her score was 39, 40 79.
WASHINGTON, July 1 Republican Congressional leaders contended today that President Kennedy could not control his heavy majorities in the Senate and House.
Cottonseed-oil and silver futures advanced here yesterday and led most commodities in registering new gains.

WASHINGTON, July 1 A staff executive of the American Medical Association and the head of the National Medical Association, a Negro doctors' organization, plan to meet in Chicago tomorrow to discuss racial problems in organized medicine.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 (UPI) Home runs by Tommy Harper and Ken Walters and clutch pitching by Jim Maloney and Bill Henry carried the Cincinnati Reds to a 4-3 victory over the San Francisco Giants today. The Reds stranded 13 Giant runners.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 1 Any foreign trotter regardless of age, sex or won-and-lost record that can earn 165,000 guilders [$45,936] although barred from lucrative championship competition, rates a berth in the Roosevelt International.

Moderation has been the order of the day in most of the recent labor-management agreements. The steel workers have once again passed up any direct wage increase, in the interest of fringe benefits intended to spread employment. The steel settlement reflects a general stress on job security, rather than higher pay.

MBALABALA, Kenya, June 17 This arid, desolate section of Kenya is noted for its big elephants with heavy ivory. At the other end of the scale, however, is a variety of shooting that is sensational. This is the bird shooting.

WASHINGTON, July 1 Members of a prominent Washington law firm were accused by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today of misconduct and evasion of the Foreign Agents Registration Act while lobbying for sugar interests of the Dominican Republic during the Trujillo regime.

WASHINGTON, July 1-- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy was intensively questioned by the Senate Commerce Committee today on the scope of the Administration's proposed ban on discrimination in privately owned public accommodations.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) Camille Chautemps, a former Premier of France, died at his home here today. He was 78 years old.
Harlem's hot and crowded streets are serving as the nation's first proving ground for the proposed Domestic Peace Corps.

Just before he led his Red Sox against the Yankees in the series finale at the Stadium last night, Manager Johnny Pesky said: "These Yankees are an amazing well-balanced club. They've always got somebody coming up to win that big one for them."

Supreme Court Justice Abraham N. Geller yesterday ordered a trial of a suit for $131,000 brought by Montgomery Clift, the screen actor, against Universal Pictures. At the time the Court directed that the company's counterclaim against Mr. Clift for $686,383 also be tried.

The waterfront paid tribute yesterday to Joseph P. Ryan, leader for a quarter-century of more than 60,000 longshoremen. Mr. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association from 1927 until 1953, died last Wednesday at the age of 79.

The 59 United States college students who defied the State Department, broke a Government regulation and went to Cuba were wrong to do so. They were repeatedly warned, and if they are fined and/or imprisoned on their return they will have no right to complain. The law they broke is a regulation linked to the Immigration and Nationality Act requiring a passport especially validated for travel to Cuba.
ROME, July 1 Today was a day of farewells for Pope Paul VI as he received all the official delegations and some of the individuals who had gathered in Rome for his coronation.
DALLAS, July 1 The Kalita Humphreys Theater, one of Frank Lloyd Wright's last buildings, in itself justifies a visit to this city.

The appointment of I. J. Steinhoff as general manager of the electro-mechanical division of the Indiana General Corporation was announced yesterday. He replaces Frank S. Greenwald, who has been named the corporation's manager for special product sales. Mr. Steinhoff formerly was...
Two supplemental Air Force contracts totaling $66,300,000 have been awarded to the Northrop Corporation for production of F-5A, F-5B and T-33 aircraft.
HARTFORD, Conn., July 1 Gov. John N. Dempsey signed a bill today that joins Connecticut with New York and New Jersey in the Tristate Transportation Committee.

THE Ides of March proved to be a redletter day blood red for Julius Caesar. There also is a day of reckoning for big league baseball managers, including those who don't get stabbed in the back. The day will be here soon, too. It is the Fourth of July.

A leading producer and carrier of coal is investing over $4,000,000 in improved water transport equipment on the theory that West Virginia coal can be moved to New York more cheaply by seagoing barge than by rail.
Max J. Rubin, president of the Board of Education, said yesterday that the school system had no immediate plans to transport white pupils into Harlem and other Negro areas to achieve integration.
The weather broke its weekend truce with the metropolitan area yesterday with the hottest, stickiest assault of the year so far.

LONDON, July 1 Amid scenes of enthusiasm recalling its first visit to London seven years ago, the Bolshoi Ballet, led by its prima ballerina, Maya Plisetskaya, opened its second London season at Covent Garden tonight with "Swan Lake."
Gary Player will defend, his Professional Golfers' Association championship in the new role of a golfer in shining white armor.
An airline pilot told aviation and civic leaders yesterday that pilots had gone as far as they could to reduce aircraft noise near airports.
LYNCHBURG, Va., July 1 (UPI) The Babcock and Wilcox Company will train a new crew for the nuclear merchant ship Savannah to replace engineers who quit the ship in a pay dispute.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 1 Dr. Harry A. Curtis, a former director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, died here today of abdominal cancer. He was 79 years old.
William Tully of Pelham, winner of the title in 1954 and 1957, headed the field of 64 players who began competition yesterday in the New York State clay court tennis championship.
Paul Draper created the kind of light and airy atmosphere in the Delacorte Theater in Central Park last night that is too often missing in outdoor summer events.
ATLANTA, July 1-- The Southern Christian Leadership Conference will soon become a membership organization similar in some respects to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

DETROIT, July 1 (UPI) Bill Muncey of Seattle, the defending champion in the Gold Cup race, today piloted his Miss Thriftway to a qualifying round of 113.207 miles an hour for three laps between Belle Isle and the Detroit riverfront.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 1 The Congress of Racial Equality will demand that public and private organizations "initiate compensatory, preferential treatment" for Negroes, Puerto Ricans and other minorities in training and employment opportunities.
When a new G.I. receives his first issue of clothing from his supply sergeant, he can thank 4,225 persons in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) The Justice Department announced today it had reached an agreement with six transmission-line hardware companies under which they were forbidden to engage in antitrust law violations.
Three men and two corporations were found guilty yesterday in Federal court of conspiring to sell blood plasma that had been manufactured in unlicensed laboratories.
ATHENS, July 1-- Earl Warren, the Chief Justice of the United States, called today for an effective international court with power to enforce its judgments.
SAIGON, Vietnam, July 1 A two-week test of intentions in this country's religious dispute ended today, and Buddhist leaders said they were still dissatisfied with the Government's attitude.

Two acres in the Lawrence Park West area of Yonkers, near Bronxville, have been purchased by Charles G. Cavaliere, president of the Charpeg Construction Corporation. The tract, which is being subdivided into four half-acre plots, will be improved with two-story Colonial homes.

BALTIMORE, July 1 (UPI) John Wyatt retired Jim Gentile and Boog Powell in the last of the ninth inning with the tying runs on base tonight and preserved a 6-4 victory for the Kansas City Athletics over the Baltimore Orioles.

BRUSSELS, July 1-- The Common Market is taking steps to establish a central authority to coordinate the monetary policies of the six member states, Robert Marjolin, vice president of the Common Market's Executive Commission, announced today.

A lively advertising battle will get under way soon involving a product that isn't on the market yet. When it reaches the market, however, some think the new product may change the face of a $700,000,000-a-year industry.
Three Criminal Court judges cleared the 23-year-old son of a fellow judge yesterday of criminal responsibility for a traffic accident that killed five persons in the Bronx six weeks ago.

WHITE PLAINS, July 1 A revolt by 18 towns against the representation of cities on the Westchester County Board of Supervisors was temporarily halted after an hour of debate a board meeting here today.
The Ivy League, after first voting to have its own "unlimited" substitution rule this fall, has decided to follow the National Collegiate Athletic Association's football substitution rule for 1963.

Mayor Wagner made official yesterday his long-heralded appointment of Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan as a judge of the Civil Court. The Mayor said he would not give the city's bar associations any veto power over the selection of judges.
PARIS, July 1 At least 12 persons were injured, four seriously, as farmers battled with the police in the southern city of Avignon today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 1 Al Feminelli and Robert Polsky of Dellwood today won the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association's pro-amateur tournament at the Wykagyl Country Club with a net best ball 31, 32 63. They led 143 teams by a stroke.
HOUSTON, July 1 (AP)-- Rusty Staub's run-producing single in the 11th inning lifted the Houston Colts to a 4-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 1 The Committee for a National Trade Policy called today for a complete overhaul of United States laws to prevent dumping of foreign products in this country at cut-rate prices.
TOPEKA, Kan., July 1 (AP) Nelson Antrim Crawford, publisher of Author and Journalist, a magazine, died in a Topeka hospital last night. He was 75 years old.
TORONTO, July 1 (AP) Frank Beard of Louisville, Ky., shot a six-under-par 65 over the Scarboro Golf Club course today and took medal honors in the $50,000 Canadian open.
WASHINGTON, July 1-- A major step was taken today to incorporate science into the foreign aid program.
Stock prices took another tumble yesterday as volume increased slightly from Friday's six-month low.

LONDON, July 1-- Top-seeded Roy Emerson is out of Wimbledon, beaten in a nerveracking five-setter by Wilhelm-Bungert, a 24-year-old architecture student from Munich.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 1 The Legislature has adjourned until 1965 without acting on a bill that would have ended discrimination in public accommodations in Missouri.
Sales of New York department stores rose 8 per cent last month from the level of the 1962 month, a survey of The New York Times showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 1 The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today a reshuffle of staff assignments that would bring into high jobs three men who have been closely associated with recent investigations of securities markets.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

MANY people begin to gurgle at the very thought of Venice. Which is appro priate, I suppose, considering the liquid landscapes of its lagoons. But the true splendor of it all is best set forth in a book such as today's "The Treasures of Venice."
NEWARK, July 1 Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio and Councilman Irvine I. Turner made separate proposals today to improve the conditions of minority groups in the city.
DETROIT, July 1 The National Education Association today stopped short of issuing nationwide "sanctions" against Utah in a controversy over the size of the state's education appropriation.

Harry Lefrak, chairman of the Lefrak Organization, one of the largest building companies in the nation, died last night in Kew Gardens General Hospital in Queens. He was 78 years old and lived at 103-25 68th Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens.
ROME, July 1 President Kennedy conferred with leading Italian statesmen for two hours today on means of strengthening the Atlantic alliance.
ALBANY, July 1 Governor Rockefeller said today that concerted action with minimum delay was needed to prevent drastic deterioration of urban transportation facilities.
Prices of lead and zinc were increased by fractions of a cent yesterday. The reason given was a rise in demand, especially from automobile producers.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 1 The rift between Rumania and the Soviet Union over economic specialization has not been healed, Western observers agreed today. They offered this as the prime reason for the absence of Gheorghe.
BUENOS AIRES, July 1 Raul Matera, former leader of the Peronist movement here, indicated today he would accept an offer to become the Presidential candidate of the Christian Democratic party.

The British pound improved again in dealings on the New York foreign exchange market yesterday. The spot pound closed at $2,8013 offered, up from $2,8009 the previous day. Sterling futures were slightly narrower.
Record sales and earnings were attained by Corning Glass Works and its subsidiaries in the first half of this year, the company announced yesterday.
Holiday motorists who avoid travel in the peak hours will encounter virtually no delays except in widely scattered areas where construction of new facilities is under way.

The Cuban Government has invited "15 to 20" Americans to attend the 10th anniversary celebration this month of Premier Fidel Castro's 26th of July Movement, and has offered to set up a Mexico-Havana trip for them.

In selecting his old political opponent Henry Cabot Lodge as the next United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, one of the most difficult posts in the American Foreign Service, President Kennedy has made a shrewd move to emphasize the nonpartisan character of a wearing, hazardous enterprise.

Frank S. Adams, city editor of The New York Times since 1952, has been appointed a member of The Times's editorial board. The appointment was announced yesterday by John B. Oakes, editor of the editorial page.
Prices of Treasury securities declined on a wide front yesterday for the first time in two weeks. Trading was quiet in the corporate and municipal bond secotors.
CLEVELAND, July l (UPI) Arnold Palmer beat Tony Lema and Tommy Aaron by three strokes today in a playoff for the $22,000 top prize in the $110,000 Cleveland open golf tournament.
LONDON, July 1 London has decided to do away with the controversial school examination for 10-year-olds that bars all but the "clever" ones from a higher academic education.

Cotton futures were unchanged to $1.50 a bale down on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.

PART knight on a white charger, part pugnacious boy, Louis Ira Kaplan, who was named a Civil Court judge yesterday, sees his world as one large battleground.

BUDAPEST, July 1, U Thant, United Nations Secretary General, arrived in Budapest today. His official visit formally, marked the end of the long period of tension between the world organization and the Government of Premier Janos Kadar.
The London stock market broadened yesterday the gains generated at the end of last week by the offer of Shell Oil and British Petroleum to take over Burmah Oil.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y. July 1 Evans Ward, board chairman of the Russell. Burdsall Ward Bolt and Nut Company and formerly president of the Westchester County Park Commission for 25 years, died last night in his home on King Street. He was 76 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 1 The United Brotherhood of Carpenters today directed its 3,000 locals to eliminate racial discrimination if they were practicing any. The union, with 750,000 members, is the largest of the building trades unions.
ZANZIBAR, July 1 (Reuters) The Sultan of Zanzibar died today after an emergency operation yesterday in which a surgeon amputated both his legs. He was 53 years old.

T.J. Ready Jr., president of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, said yesterday that he expected further increases in the prices of aluminum products.

MILFORD, N.J., July 1 Hugh Kendall Boice, a pioneer in broadcast advertising in New York, died today at Hunterdon County Medical Center in Flemington. He was 79 years old and lived here on Ellis Road.
ALBANY, July 1 (AP) Persons convicted of premeditated murder no longer automatically face the electric chair in New York State.

THE outstanding new bridge book of recent months is "All Fifty-Two Cards," by Marshall Miles of San Bernardino, Calif., whose previous book on duplicate bridge tactics is already considered a classic. Both books are published by Exposition Press here.
Senator Kenneth B. Keating told workers at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday that he was concerned about the steady decrease in jobs at the yard.
Steel production showed the largest decline last week since Christmas week last year.

KANSAS CITY, July 1 (AP) The Kansas City Athletics bought Charley Lau, a catcher, from the Baltimore Orioles today and optioned Manny Jiminez to Portland on a 24-hour recall.

WEST POINT, N.Y., July 1 Brig. Gen. Charles J. Barrett, a retired Army officer who was head of the department of languages at the United States Military Academy, died yesterday at the age of 63.

BONN July 1 President de Gaulle's two-day visit to Bonn this week will lack the pomp and splendor that marked his tour of West Germany last summer.

An elderly landlord who failed to remove health and housing violations from a lower East Side tenement was fined $400 yesterday and sentenced to 15 days in jail.
BERLIN, July 1-- The informal gathering of four Communist-bloc leaders with Premier Khrushchev ended today in East Berlin.

HELSINGBORG, Sweden, July 1 (AP) Rolf Lacourt of West Germany today outpointed Andy Fitch of New York in a firstround flyweight match of the world Greco-Roman wrestling championships.

TRENTON, July 1 The State Supreme Court ordered the nation's largest dairy concern today to pay a $1,000 fine and stop violating the state's minimummilk-price act or cease all of its operations in New Jersey within 30 days.

In 1963 the same bar association found Mr. Kaplan, who in the interim has been the city's Commissioner of Investigation, still unqualified to be a judge. So has the Citizens Union. Mayor Wagner is again appointing him anyway, this time to the Civil Court, and Mr....

GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 1 The same failure of moral vision that caused the Civil War exists in the nation today as Negroes a century later try to achieve civil rights and equality of opportunity, Gov. Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey declared here today.

UNION, N.J., July 1 (AP) Conde J. McGinley Sr., editor of a semi-monthly newspaper described by a Congressional committee as a "clearing house for hate propagandists," died here today of cancer. He was 73 years old.

Stock prices opened the second half of 1963 with a brisk decline yesterday. But a survey of analysts showed that they remained mildly optimistic. "It looks like a lot of ennui at the moment and this boredom compounds on Wall Street," observed Lawrence Lewis, a partner in Pershing Co.
WASHINGTON, July 2-- Senators sharply questioned Secretary of the Navy Fred Korth yesterday on what one of them described as "an amazing situation" concerning plans for producing the TFX warplane.

DETROIT, July 2 (UPI) A two-time Gold Cup winner, Danny Foster, who was making a comeback after having been in semi-retirement for seven years, escaped injury today when his hydroplane threw a propeller and sank in 28 feet of water.
Sugar futures rose sharply yesterday while cocoa and silver futures declined in active trading here. Other markets were quiet and mixed.

HELSINGBORG, Sweden, July 2 (AP) Jim Rascke, a senior at the University of Nebraska, and Wayne Baughman, a senior at Oklahoma, scored victories for the United States today in the world Greco-Roman Wrestling championships.

BRUSSELS, July 2 After simmering in the Belgian Parliament for a month, a century-old language conflict between French-speaking and Flemish-speaking Belgians boiled over today and precipitated a full-scale governmental crisis.

A maritime labor dispute that came close late last month to paralyzing two-thirds of the seagoing American merchant fleet may be resumed today. Resumption of the dispute threatened the Friday sailing of the nation's prestige liner, the United States.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 2 Edwin D. DeWitt, who had been general manager of The New York Herald and was an introducer of American advertising methods in Europe as business manager of its Paris edition, died today in Lisenby Hospital in Panama City, Fla. His age was 89.

GEORGETOWN, British Guianna, July 2-- Troops of the Coldstream Guards moved out of Georgetown this morning and took up stations in the east coast villages of Plaisance and Better Hope where bitter racial clashes have occurred.
ROME, July 2 President Kennedy was received in private audience by Pope Paul VI this morning.
CHICAGO, July 2 Charles H. Percy announced today that he was a Republican candidate for Governor of Illinois.

For 37 years, New York City children have been unable legally to celebrate the Fourth of July with a bang. Firecrackers have been taboo since 1926, and those who sell them are fined and jailed if caught.
CHICAGO, July 2 The American Bar Association set up today a 17-member special committee on civil rights.

Styles in advertising, as in women's clothing, tend to change fast. And some ad men who claim to be students of these changing styles say that what they call "reason why" advertising is making a comeback.

Miss Alice Gates, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan H. Gates of 829 Park Avenue and Seaview, Fire Island, N.Y., was married here last evening to Michael O. Magdol. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. David A. Magdol of Great Neck, L.I.

SEATTLE, July 2 (AP) Brian Sternberg, University of Washington pole vaulter whose 16-foot-8-inch mark is pending as a world record, suffered an injury to his neck in a trampoline accident tonight and was temporarily paralyzed.
Pan American World Airways and National Airlines announced yesterday that they had reached an agreement to reexchange the shares of each company held by the other.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 2 The village of Goshen is imbued with the nostalgia of early America and its Historic Track is a remnant of another century compared with the behemoths of New York harness racing Roosevelt and Yonkers raceways.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 2 A new $5,000,000 bridge over the Hackensack River on Route 3 was dedicated tonight by Gov. Richard J. Hughes. An after-dark ceremony showed off the low-level roadway illumination system that is contained within the handrail of the 2,650foot span.

WASHINGTON, July 2 The National Labor Relations Board ordered today an election to determine whether 50 unlicensed seamen on four oceanographic research ships operated by the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution want to be represented by the Seafarers' International Union.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 2 Seven persons were killed and 36 were injured at 5 P.M. today when a Mohawk Airlines twin-engined plane crashed on take-off at the Rochester-Monroe County Airport. A violent thunder and hail storm struck after the plane had cleared the runway.
Clouds and thundershowers broke the metropolitan area's heat wave abruptly at midafternoon yesterday, paving the way for promised fine weather today and on the Fourth of July.

With great joy do we welcome Your Excellency to the Vatican, recalling with true happiness our first meeting almost 25 years ago, when, as a young man, you accompanied your parents to the coronation of the Pope Pius XII, our venerated predecessor of happy memory.
The Government securities market sold down sharply yesterday in fairly active trading. Prime corporate bonds weakened in sympathy, and most municipals were steady in quiet trading.
DETROIT, July 2 (UPI) Bob Allison hit a two-run homer and Jim Hall a three-run homer tonight as the Minnesota Twins scored their eighth straight triumph, a 7-4 rout of the Detroit Tigers.
LONDON, July 2 It was No. 13 and unlucky today for The London Daily Mail's efforts to parlay ($2.80) into a fortune by picking 18 successive winners on Britain's race tracks.
Mayor Wagner indicated yesterday that he would attempt to get approval for the controversial Breezy Point park from the Planning Commission and the Board of Estimate by the end of the month.
BUENOS AIRES, July 2 The Peronist-backed National and Popular Front accused the Government today of organizing a fraudulent national election for next Sunday.

Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior in the Truman Administration, answered questions as a voluntary witness yesterday in the state's investigation of a scheme to establish title to oil leases in New Mexico. The leases contribute $6,000,000 a year to the revenues of the Federal Government.

Arthur Simon, vice president and advertising manager of Radio-Television Daily, a trade paper, died of a heart attack Monday in his office at 1501 Broadway. He was 59 years old. Mr. Simon lived at 77-14 113th Street, Forest Hills, Queens. He had a summer home at 1213 West Park Street, Long Beach, L.I.

The Hershey Chocolate Corporation is expanding its business through the acquisition of the H.B. Reese Candy Company for 666,316 Hershey common shares. Hershey recently purchased these shares from stockholders at $34.50 a share to pay for the acquisition.

LONDON, July 2 The editors of The Sunday Observer and The Economist, the weekly magazine of comment, said today that H.A.R. Philby was employed as their joint Middle East correspondent at the suggestion of the Foreign Office after he had resigned from the diplomatic service.

DETROIT, July 2 The National Education Association, which has been unable to solve the problem of segregation among some Southern affiliates, went on record today in support of President Kennedy's civil rights legislation.
Business prospered in the year ended last Sunday, New York City's 1962-63 tax collections indicated yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, July 2, (AP) The Los Angeles Dodgers took over the National League lead from St. Louis tonight. They defeated the Cardinals, 1 0, on Ron Fairly's run-producing single and the five-hit pitching of Don Drysdale.

Premier Khrushchev has opened up before a Berlin mass rally a double-barreled attack on the theses expounded by the President on his European trip. These theses call for Western unity and at least an amelioration of the cold war between East and West in line with the President's "strategy of peace."

A $2,000,000 grant from Mrs. Rebekah Harkness Kean to the New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center was announced yesterday. The Cornell University Medical College will use the gift toward the construction of a building for science and research, primarily in medicine and surgery.

Stock prices staged one of the sharpest recoveries of recent months yesterday, on relatively low volume. The advance easily erased losses shown on Monday.

Albert Milton Austin of White Wood Lane, Wilton, Conn., a retired lawyer and business executive, died Monday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 89 years old.
