Dutch enthusiasm for the twist and trading-stamp merchandising was cited yesterday as evidence of an uncommon market in the Netherlands for American products.

The American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations will recommend to its member unions the establishment of apprenticeship information centers to encourage youths, especially Negroes, to enter skilled trades.
ALGIERS, July 2 Premier Ahmed Ben Bella was accused today of seeking to install "a personal dictatorship."
GREENWICH, Conn., July 2 Policemen in swim trunks and sports attire are mingling with the bathers these days at the town's main beach here.

Gareth Martinis, central figure in a three-car accident that killed five persons six weeks ago, still holds his driver's license despite an order by the State Department of Motor Vehicles to surrender it.

The advisability of seeking a 4-4 major suit in the combined hands is internationally known, but the theory of when the 4-4 trump suit should be rejected in favor of a suit divided 5 3 or 6 2 is not so well understood.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that a four-year city program had succeeded in saving seven Manhattan neighborhoods from becoming slums.
LOLIONDO, Tanganyika, June 18-- The last thing a hunter moving around the Equator in East Africa expects is to be afflicted with bone-chilling cold. But he can be.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 2-- Too old for the traditionally rich 3-year-old stakes and too young and inexperienced for the always-lucrative free-for-all competition, 4-year-old trotters and pacers were orphans in the storm not so long ago.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 Billie Jean Moffitt is still on the rampage. Unsung and unseeded when the All-England championships started, the 19year-old Californian blasted seventh-seeded Maria Bueno of Brazil, 6 2, 7 5, today before 25,000 tennis fans jammed around the center court.
PARIS, July 2 Farmers in the south of France, angered by low fruit and vegetable prices, continued violent protests today.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 2 (AP)-- Dr. Edmund G. Zimmerer, Iowa Commissioner of Public Health and a past president of the Public Health Cancer Association of America, died, apparently of a heart attack, today. He was 74 years old.

Alicia Patterson, editor and publisher of Newsday in Garden City, the largest daily newspaper on Long Island, died at 11:25 last night in Doctors Hospital. Her age was 56. She was the daughter of the late Capt. Joseph Medill Patterson, publisher of The New York News.

The residents of Staten Island were assured by Mayor Wagner yesterday that the city was taking "every possible precaution" against the occurrence of fires that might get out of control through a water shortage or low water pressure.
Mischa Elman, soloist last night at Lewisohn Stadium, lengthened his lead over all other soloists who have performed there.
MOSCOW, July 2 (AP) An American and a Frenchman carried off top honors in key events against Soviet Union stars in a 19-nation track and field meet in Lenin Stadium today.

WASHINGTON, July 2 Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy announced tonight that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had arrested four persons in New York and Washington today on charges of conspiracy to spy for the Soviet Union.

BOSTON, July 2 (UPI) Manager, Ralph Houk of the New York Yankees today named 17 additional American League players, four of them Yankees, to the All-Star squad for the game against the National League at Cleveland next Tuesday.

RYE, N.Y., July 2 Mrs. Robert Stern, representing the Beach Point Y.C., of Mamaroneck, won both races today as the Westchester eliminations of the women's Long Island Sound championships for the Syce Cup opened off the American Yacht Club.

Thomas L. Hickey, a New York Teamsters Union leader for many years and a resolute foe of James R. Hoffa, died yesterday at the Veterans Administration Hospital, Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn. He was 70 years old.

Council President Paul R. screvane asserted yesterday that Louis I. Kaplan's success in balking a "hatchet job" on the wagner administration in 1961 inspired the opposition to his appointment as a Civil Court judge.
A spot check of the seven areas cited by Mayor Wagner yesterday as having been improved by the Neighborhood Conservation Program indicated generally acceptable living conditions.
Mayor Wagner and Walter Hoving, head of Tiffany's, differed yesterday over whether the city's shoppers and buyers were accepting the recent sales tax increase.
NAPLES, July 2 President Kennedy ended his 10-day tour of four European countries tonight and flew back to Washington.

LONDON, July 2 Premier Khrushchev told leaders of Britain's Labor party two weeks ago that the Soviet Union had withdrawn its offer for on-site inspections of underground nuclear tests, it was announced in Commons tonight.

A funeral service for Harry Lefrak, the builder, will be held at noon today at the Schwartz Brothers Forest Park Chapel. Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills, Queens, Mr. Lefrak, who founded and headed the Lefrak Organization, one of the nation's largest building companies, died Monday at the age of 78.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 2 Julius S. Wikler, former State Superintendent of Insurance, died of a heart attack here today in his home at 10 Elmsmere Road. He was 56 years old.
Favorites wilted in the heat at Aqueduct yesterday with the same regularity as the 22,155 customers. Only one of the public choices reached the winner's circle.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 2 Colombia's Magdalena River Valley has become that country's new frontier. It surges with the vitality that characterized the American West of a century ago. A key factor in this development has been the railroad.
BERLIN, July 2 Premier Khrushchev called today for the simultaneous signing of an East-West nonaggression pact and an agreement to outlaw nuclear tests in the sea, the air and space.
Cottrell Corbett Wheeler, a Long Island boat builder early in this century and a pioneer in the development of racing craft, died yesterday at his home in Ojai, Calif. He was 78 years old.

EAST HADDAM, Conn., July 2 It was in 1876 that the Goodspeed Opera House opened its doors, but it wasn't until tonight that its stage held an operatic performance. Evidently, opera house was once more a status symbol than a statement of fact.

ROME, July 2 President Kennedy is the third President of the United States to have been received in audience by a Pope.

LONDON, July 2 After repaying in full a $250,000,000 loan from European central banks during June, Britain's gold and currency reserves fell $215,000,000, to a June 30 total of $2,713,200,000, the Treasury reported today.

Periodically, Columbia University's American Assembly sponsors a gathering of intellects in the comfortably cloistered Arden House at Harriman, N.Y. One such conclave last autumn considered the topics in the title of this newly published volume, which supplied the factual working papers upon which the thinkers based their discussions and conclusions.

WASHINGTON, July 2 Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy looked on today as Democratic and Republican supporters of the Administration's civil rights bill fought over who should offer "perfecting" amendments.

Harold J. Getting, a private detective who supplied watchmen for state construction projects at which charges of payroll padding are being investigated, pleaded not guilty yesterday to a charge of setting fire to the trailer office of a construction company.

CHICAGO, July 2 (UPI) Soybeans plummeted from yesterday's heights in a frantic last-minute flurry of selling today on the Board of Trade. Nearby wheat ended firm, while other grains plunged with soybeans in a finale of profit taking.

BONN, July 2 (AP) Chancellor Adenauer declared today that disarmament and nucleartest negotiations might be useful to the West in trying to persuade the Russians to change their policy so that East-West tension could be reduced.
An ambitious project for an operating motion picture studio as part of the New York World's Fair was announced yesterday.
The fourth antitrust indictment since April, 1962, against steel companies was filed yesterday in Federal Court here.

Four drivers who started their speed careers on motorcycles are entered in the Firecracker 400-mile late model stock car race tomorrow on the two-and-a-half-mile high-banked Daytona International Speedway in Florida.

The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension was the setting here last night for the marriage of Miss Carol Lois Boggs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifton H. Boggs of River Edge, N.J., to Leonard Eames Ryan. He is a son of Bernard Ryan, former Presiding Judge...

Two of New York City's major banks reported declines in after-tax earnings yesterday. A third posted an increase. Reports from other banks generally showed that earnings for the first half of 1963 ran ahead of the 1962 period.

Lambert Brothers, jewelry retailers and designers of jewelry here since 1877, have leased the store at 545 Madison Avenue, southeast corner of 55th Street. They will move about July 15 from Lexington Avenue and 60th Street, where they have occupied their own building since 1930.
WASHINGTON, July 2 The State Department is preparing a fresh set of regulations to clarify and tighten restrictions on travel to Cuba.

GETTYSBURG, Ja., July 2 Memories of the battle that raged here 100 years ago were revived today by a two-hour parade participated in by 6,500 men, women and children in the uniforms of the Union, the Confederacy and modern military organizations.

The London stock market was gloomy yesterday, mainly because of an electric power failure. Trading was irregular before the lights went out. When they came back on, it was still irregular.
OTTAWA, July 2 The Liberal minority Government of Canada survived another Conservative attempt to defeat it tonight by a vote of 115 to 75.
CHICAGO, July 2 Some of baseball's basic charms were demonstrated today at Wrigley Field where Bob Buhl of the Chicago Cubs defeated the Mets, 4-1.

The Habimah Theater will return to New York in February after being absent since 1948. Israel's renowned troupe will open a nine-week repertory engagement Feb. 1 at the Little Theater. 240 West 44th Street, before going on the road for an additional nine weeks.

Back in the White House after the personal successes and the diplomatic frustrations of his European sales trip, President Kennedy will find plenty to keep him busy this summer on the legislative front. Congress has been moving so sluggishly that it could stay in session until New Year's Eve without completing the urgent tasks before it.

LONDON, July 2 The Government was consulted on the bid by two international oil giants for the assets of the Burmah Oil Company and "saw no reason to object," Chancellor of the Exchequer Reginald Maudling said today.

Noisy, tempestuous dialogue the sort rarely heard in the quiet, contemplative quarters of sidewalk cafes exploded throughout a courtroom yesterday during a taxpayers' trial aimed at blocking the construction of a sidewalk cafe in Central Park.
JACKSON, Miss., July 2 The Hinds County grand jury indicted Byron de La Beckwith today for the murder of Medgar W. Evers, Negro civil rights leader.
MIAMI BEACH, July 2 The need for better and more centralized Federal office buildings was outlined today by Robert T. Daly, commissioner of public buildings for the General Services Administration.

Seven major organizations, predominantly composed of Negroes announced yesterday, that they had agreed to coordinate their planning and activities for "racial desegregation and equal opportunity." They said they would try to raise $1,500,000 in a joint emergency-fund drive.

Allan P. Kirby will regain today firm control of the Alleghany Corporation, the holding company that controls the $2,500,000,000 New York Central Railroad and the $4,000,000,000 investment company organization, Investors Diversified Services, Inc., of Minneapolis.

WASHINGTON, July 2 The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a union's failure to file with the Government a notice of a dispute made a subsequent strike unlawful and cost the union's members their jobs.
TEL AVIV, July 2 Former Premier David Ben-Gurion indicated today that he hoped his retirement from active political leadership of Israel could be permanent.

CHICAGO, July 2 The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People criticized President Kennedy's civil rights program today as "inadequate to meet the minimum demands of the existing situation."
ABILENE, Kan., July 2 Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower returned to his boyhood home today without fuss or fanfare.
The Greenwich Village Democratic Club voted by a narrow margin last night to back the candidate of a rival reform group for district leader to block the comeback of Carmine De Sapio.

A theatrical jigsaw puzzle involving 14 actors in a fourcharacter play, a stalwart director, a patient stage manager and two adventurous producers is being pieced together these days at the Billy Rose Theater.
DEDHAM, Mass., July 2 After a lapse of four years, New York won the junior intercity golf team matches at the Dedham Country and Polo Club today.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 2 (AP) Grand Pep Stable's Fat Cat, the favorite, won today at Monmouth Park, but at the head of the stretch the 15,691 fans wouldn't have given much for his chances.
WASHINGTON, July 2 The Air Force has decided to stop asking returning personnel whether they married a member of another race while they were overseas.

The state government should establish two new medical schools and encourage other measures to train at least 42 per cent more physicans by 1980, the New York State Committee on Medical Education says.

STOCKHOLM, July 2 Swedish civilian and military scientific units that have often been among the first to detect Soviet nuclear blasts said today that they could not corroborate reports of new Russian tests in the atmosphere.
The New York State Dormitory Authority borrowed yesterday $17,600,000 for New York University and $4,900,000 for Syracuse University on revenue bonds.
The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that the Mark Hellinger Theater did not have the right to terminate the six-year run of "My Fair Lady" in 1962.

An executive of a New York electrical supply company filed a complaint yesterday in United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, seeking to remove the three trustees of Texas Pacific Land Trust.

Employes of the Union Carbide Corporation have been busy picking up cash--about $68,000,000. The amount represented savings of 57,000 employes in the company's savings plan over the last two years. The average distribution was about $1,200.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 2-- Some United States officials in South Vietnam who two months ago were praising President Ngo Dinh Diem have changed their minds about him and his chances of winning the war against the Communists. They would like to see a new government in Saigon.

WASHINGTON, July 2 The Justice Department supported more than 100 Negro civil rights demonstrators in Danville, Va., today in seeking to transfer their trial from a Danville city court to a Federal court.
TRENTON, July 2 The Englewood Board of Education was ordered today to adopt a plan for ending racial imbalance at the Lincoln School before the September term.
The proposal made to the City Council yesterday to create a 30-member Temporary Commission on Fiscal Planning represents a constructive consolidation and broadening of several previous resolutions.

CHICAGO, July 2-- Seven nuns who joined a Roman Catholic student protest against alleged discrimination in the Illinois Club for Catholic Women last night have received crank calls, a student protest leader said today.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 2 The Air Force announced today the approval of a one-year, $128,000,000 contract with Pan American World Airways for the operation of the Atlantic Missile range.

State Supreme Court Justice Sidney A. Fine reserved decision yesterday on a move by a dockworkers' local to bar the Waterfront Commission from taking "embarrassing and degrading" photographs of longshoremen for identification cards.
The National Maritime Union offered 74 American steamship companies a five-point contract package yesterday under which it said it would guarantee strike-free operations until 1969.

WASHINGTON, July 2 The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it was postponing, until further notice, the effective date of its consent agreements with 163 apparel manufacturers and distributors ordering them to stop discriminating between customers in granting promotional allowances.

DETROIT, July 3--The president of the National School Boards Association warned the nation's largest teacher organization today against the use of "sanctions" to gain salary increases or changes in working conditions.

ALBANY, July 3--The Rockefeller administration is considering the appointment of Secretary of State Caroline K. Simon to the Court of Claims to clear the way for the designation of a Negro to her present position.

Leaders of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association said here last night that Engineer pickets were still under orders to start picketing the freighter Maximus at Port Everglades, Florida.

Mrs. Richard C. du Pont's Kelso will be racing against the Cash Register today. The 6year-old son of Bryan G. is listed for the $100,000 added Suburban Handicap at Aqueduct, but he appears to have nothing to beat.

As they might paraphrase it along Broadway, a funny thing happened at the Yankee Stadium yesterday as the fans prepared to head for the exits.
PARIS, July 3--For the first time in French military history, conscientious objectors were given legal status today.

LONDON, July 3--Britain's "seriously out-of-date" road signs were criticized today in a report recommending that they be scrapped for the Continental variety, in which symbols are used instead of words.

Bathing beauties, muscle men and millions of other Americans will trek to beach and mountain resorts in the next two months. In addition to rest, relaxation and fun, a luxurious tan will be the goal of many of these followers of the sun.

PARIS, July 3--The Government brushed aside labor opposition today and approved a bill requiring five days' notice before workers can begin a strike in the nationalized public services.
LONDON, July 3--Sotheby's auction house set a record today, its third in a month, when 112 old masters' paintings were sold for $2,573,760.

Most of the coaches of the teams competing in the second section of the International Soccer League agreed yesterday that their clubs were stronger than the first-section clubs. The local portion of the I.S.L. second-half play begins today at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

Directors of the Algoma Steel Corporation, Ltd., voted yesterday to increase the quarterly dividend to 40 cents a common share from 35 cents in preceding quarters. The dividend will be paid Sept. 30 to holders of record of Aug. 30.

NOT since the nineteenthirties have teen-agers been so involved in the social and political issues of their time. Their parents, some of whom spent their adolescence in the social causes of the New Deal era, are now uncertain whether to point with pride or view with alarm.

CLEVELAND, July 3 (AP) --Raising the morale of employes and stopping the "cash drain" are immediate objectives of William White, who has moved into the driver's seat of the ailing Erie-Lackawanna Railroad.
WASHINGTON, July 3-- The United States received and rejected today a Soviet protest against the arrest of a Russian couple in New York yesterday on espionage charges.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., July 3--Negro youths picketed the Woolworth and McCrory downtown stores today to press demands for total desegregation here.

A party of West Coast travelers stranded here since last weekend were left to shift for themselves last night. They are trying to get to Europe.
GRANADA, Spain, July 3 (Reuters)--Lord Audley, husband of Sir Winston Churchill's daughter Sarah, the actress, died of a heart attack this morning at the Alhambra Palace Hotel. He was 49 years old.
Dr. Albert Kaufman, who retired 10 years ago after nearly 50 years of practice, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 17 West 71st Street.

Brokers and their customers spent two sweltering days this week trying to beat the heat as well as the stock market before yesterday's big break in temperature.

THE criteria by which "bestplayed" games are evalu ated ought to be revamped. It is common practice to award an honorarium for the "bestplayed" game to the winner. The loser also should share the booty; not the lion's share, perhaps, but a modest portion, for contributing to an outstanding performance.
Former Representative Joseph E. Casey of Massachusetts said yesterday that he did nothing but a lawyer's job for James L. Lofland, whose oil-lease venture is under investigation.
MOSCOW, July 3 (AP)-- Larry Questad scored his second victory today at the Znamensky Brothers track meet as he won the 200-meter dash in 20.9 seconds.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Mann of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Erica Mann, to Michael Scott Werthman. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Werthman of San Diego, Calif.

Controls by governments over international airline rate-making seem certain to be intensified as a result of a meeting of aviation officials that will open in Ottowa July l5.

NICE, France, July 3 (AP)-- A French court upset today W. Somerset Maugham's plans to disown Lady John Hope as his daughter after having legally adopted his secretary-companion, Alan Searle.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) --Two markers at 640 and 1240 on the radio dial will gO out of use this summer, as Conelrad ceases as a wartime communication among the civilian population.
Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., confirmed yesterday that it had completed arrangements to sell 1,600,000 shares of Alleghany Corporation stock to Allan P. Kirby and two associates.

WASHINGTON, July 3--Since the Administration contends in behalf of its equal rights bill that Government enforcement of anti-discrimination in all public-connected forms fulfills a "moral" as well as a legal obligation on the American democracy, Senator Cooper of Kentucky had the best of the argument over methods in the Senate Commerce Committee's hearings today.

CHICAGO, July 3--Accord ing to newspapers, magazines and those who form their ideas about baseball by reading various publications, there exists a tradition that the team in first place on the night of July 4 will win the pennant.

A decline of 1,432,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 193,483,000 barrels, compared with 194,915,000 a week earlier and 187,271,000 a year ago.
A Brooklyn man was killed last night in a three-alarm fire that involved four two-story frame dwellings.

BACK in 1929 the most appealing figure in golf was Robert Tyre Jones. He still was one year short of achieving his grand slam but the Emperor Jones was the glamour boy of the links. At that point in his career he had won the United States Open twice and the amateur four times. No one could make the turnstiles spin as the Georgian could.

BABYLON, L.I., July 3-- The Long Island Chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality said today that there would be a "maximum" sit-in effort at Jones Beach tomorrow, Independence Day, in its campaign to get jobs for Negroes with the Long Island State Park Commission.

EAST PATERSON, N.J., July 3--This borough took matters into its own hands at dawn today and set up two barriers in a move to end what it considered a menace on heavily traveled Route 46. By 3 P.M. the State Highway Department had taken them down.
Radio station WCBS yester-- day morning proclaimed that it was having trouble with transmission, and received curious calls from listeners who were unable to detect the trouble.

CZECHOSLOVAK music would seem to be ideal fare for a Lewisohn Stadium program, and so it proved to be last night when Franz Allers led the Stadium Symphony in a series of works by Weinberger, Smetana and Dvorak.
LONDON, July 3--An urgent call for greater private research spending so that Britain can compete better in world markets was made today by the country's major industrial association.

"Selected Poems of Vachel Lindsay," edited by Mark Harris, will be published by Macmillan on Aug. 12. The editor continues his old interest in the writer of "General William Booth Enters Into Heaven,"...

MANILA, July 3--President Diosdado Macapagal reacted critically today to a reported move in the United States Congress to pay Philippine war damage claimants up to a maximum of $25,000 each and to channel the remainder of money into an educational exchange program.

The driver's license of Gareth Martinis, central figure in a three-car accident that killed five persons on May 19, was picked up yesterday by the Bronx office of the State Department of Motor Vehicles.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 3 --A funeral service for Alicia Patterson, editor and publisher of Newsday, will be held here at 2 P.M. Friday in the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation. The Very Rev. Harold F. Lemoine, dean of the cathedral, will affciate.

WESTBURY, L.I. July 3-- Lehigh Hanover won the $93,163.50 Realization Pace by three-quarters of a length at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. This richest of all events for 4-year-old pacers belonged to the favored Lehigh Hanover by the first quarter of the mileand-a-sixteenth race.
Limited budgetary freedom for several city agencies and for the courts was ordered yesterday by Mayor Wagner as permitted under the new City Charter that took efect Jan. 1.
CHICAGO, July 3 (UPI)-- Corn future prices rose but most other grains finished mixed today on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, July 3--The Kennedy Administration's controversial deal with Cuban Premier Fidel Castro for the release of nearly 10,000 refugees in exchange for food and medical supplies worth $53,000,000 came to an end today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 3--A United Nations inquiry mission back from a Middle Eastern visit said today that political unrest in British-controlled Aden was "dangerous" and likely to threaten peace.
LONDON, July 3--Prime Minister Macmillan said tonight that the United States and Britain were still determined to negotiate with the Soviet Union for a treaty banning nuclear tests of all types.

LOLIONDO, Tanganyika, June 19--The life of a professional hunter in Africa is not all hunting and sitting around a fire spinning tales. It is often back-breaking labor, such as getting a safari of three heavy trucks and hunting cars across a stream bed that is generally considered impassable.

SANDWICHES, as most Americans are well aware, make an excellent light lunch or supper for hot weather. They may be served with a cold or hot drink or with soup, either piping hot or, as has become the vogue in recent years, "on the rocks"--that is, well chilled.
NORWALK, Conn., July 3 (AP)--A Norwald housewife, her telephone ringing constantly, said today that she was shocked, annoyed and puzzled by finding her name involved in an international spy case.
BRUSSELS, July 3--King Baudouin refused today to accept the resignation of Premier Theo Lefevre and his Cabinet.

Fifteen buses carrying a total of 674 Girl Scouts left Washington Irving High School at 40 Irving Place yesterday for summer camps. The girls, aged 8 through 17 years, will be in camp for two to eight weeks.

World sugar futures opened strong here yesterday but retreated during subsequent trading to close very near their lows for the day. Traders attributed the downward trend to profit taking on yesterday's early advance.

Clarence L. Coleman Jr., presdent of the American Council for Judaism, expressed the "earnest hope" yesterday that the Roman Catholic Ecumenical Council at the Vatican would adopt a statement opposing anti-Semitism.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) --The Republic Aviation Corporation of Farmingdale, L.I., won a competition today to develop an "advanced orbiting solar observatory."
ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., July 3 --Miss Barbara Butterfield and Josiah French Hill 2d of Whitefield, N.H., plan to be married next month.
CLEVELAND, July 3 (AP) --The Boston Red Sox broke a 2-2 tie with four runs in the ninth inning today and beat the Cleveland Indians, 6--2.

The century-old conflict between the Frenchspeaking Walloons and the Dutch-speaking Flemings who together constitute the Belgian state has erupted anew and led to another Cabinet crisis. The immediate cause of the crisis is a split in the ruling coalition of Christian Socialists and Socialists over incorporation of six outlying communes into the bilingual Brussels city administration. But the conflict goes deeper than language and in its extreme form threatens the foundations of the state itself.

Many buyers returned to the London stock market yester day in response to encouraging British economic news that included a favorable prognosis for the sterling area's reserve position. Tuesday's rally on Wall Street also had a salutary effect.
Norman Beasley, author and former journalist, died Tuesday night in the New York UniverSity Hospital. He was 76 years old.

McKinsey Co., international management consultants, who occupy 46,500 square feet of space in the Union Carbide Building, 270 Park Avenue at 47th Street, have expanded their quarters by leasing 17,500 additional square feet.

THE Pembroke Welsh corgi, for the last half-dozen year's, has stood at about the halfway mark among the breeds in the American kennel Club's annual registration lists. In 1962, there were, 678 of the little herding dogs listed and the breed was 48th of the 111 recorded.
The Beacon Hill, a garden apartment development for 77 families at 24 to 82 Beacon Hill Drive, Dobbs Ferry, has been bought by Leonard L. Steiner Associates.

The state Democratic party was urged yesterday to consider whether the state should spend up to $6,000,000 a year is helping political parties to finance their campaigns.
Stock prices bounded ahead for the second day in a row yesterday as traders set off some pre-holiday fireworks.

WIMBLEDON, July 3--It will be Chuck McKinley against Fred Stolle of Australia in the final of the all-England tennis tournament at Wimbledon. Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court will head a group of nine judges, enforcement officials and lawyers departing for London tomorrow for a two-week study of British criminal trial procedures.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 3--An automobile racing record was broken twice within an hour on the 2.5-mile, highbanked Daytona International Speedway today.

PARIS, July 3--The United States, Belgium and other West ern countries contemplating aid to the Congo served notice on the Congolese Government today that extensive economic reLeopoldville before their assistance will be forthcoming.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, July 3--Racial violence spread through Georgetown and much of the east coast region of British Guiana yesterday and last night.

WASHINGTON, July 3--The Common Market isn't the only problem faced by the American chicken business. Warning signals have been raised indicating a "massive price depressing" situation for the industry.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) --The National Labor Relations Board filed a contempt proceeding today against the Kohler Company. It charged that the Wisconsin plumbing supply company had not complied with a 1962 order to offer reinstatement to employes on strike from 1954 to 1960.
The cotton surplus weighs heavily on the mind of Orville L. Freeman, Secretary of Agriculture, and he has called an advisory committee on that commodity to a special meeting July 15 and 16.

LOS ANGELES, July 3 (AP) --Sandy Koufax fashioned a three-hitter tonight for his seventh shutout as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 5--0, and stretched their National League lead to a game and a half over the Cardinals.

Three Negro writers decided yesterday to take up the Cuban Government's invitations for expense-paid trips to attend the celebration this month of the anniversary of Premier Fidel Castro's revolution.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 3 --The lush green fields of Gettysburg reverberated again today with the roar of battle.

WASHINGTON, July 3--Senator John Sherman Cooper said today that Negroes would get "only partial relief" from the Administration's proposed ban on discrimination in privately owned public accommodations.
The Wagner administration's move to fluoridate the city's water supply, originally set for early summer, probably will not be made until fall.
Cool, dry winds from Canada and a promise of fine weather for the Fourth of July weekend quickened the holiday flow of people away from the city last night.
MIAMI BEACH, July 3--The failure of downtown renewal programs to provide for the needs of the people and thus attract residents was decried here today.
BAY SHORE, L.I., July 4-- Three New York businessmen have contracted to buy a chain of eight weekly newspapers in western Suffolk County and radio station WBIC at Islip, L.I.

Dr. Joseph Zimmerman, a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, died Wednesday in his home at 55 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 52 years old. His office was at 100 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) --Two members of the Senate Judiciary Committee said today they agreed with Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy that new legislation on wiretapping was needed to fight increasing Communist espionage activities.
LONDON, July 4--Margaret Smith gained the Wimbledon tennis final today against Billie Jcan Moffitt.

LONDON, July 4--The Bolshoi Ballet continued its season at Covent Garden tonight with a first performance in the West of "The Little Hump-Backed Horse."
IMPRESSIVE statistics and the swell of feminine voices yearning to return to work after marriage and motherhood indicate that women will be knocking at employers' doors in increasing numbers.
Robert Barker of Manhasset and Dr. Richard Raskind of Forest Hills, the second and third seeded players, were beaten in the New York State clay court tennis championship yesterday.

Allan P. Kirby spent untold millions this week to regain firm control of the Alleghany Corporation. This holding company controls the $2,500,000,000 New York Central Railroad as well as Investors Diversified Services, Inc., a $4,000,000,000 investment company complex based in Minneapolis.
AALBORG, Denmark, July 4 --Dr. Ralph J. Bunche predicted today that the newest American revolution, now being fought for Negro equality, would soon be won.

WASHINGTON, July 4-- A large increase during May in the value of inventories held by manufacturers more than offset declines in the value of wholesalers' and retailers' stocks so that total business inventories continued to rise.
MOSCOW, July 4--A Soviet leader declared today that conditions were ripe for the conclusion of an agreement on a nuclear test ban. He asserted that everything now depended on the West.

LOS ANGELES, July 4--The world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, was upset last night in the second round of the Piatigorsky Cup tournament here by Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 4 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Ellis Tepper of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maxine Barbara Tepper, to Lewis Jay Krulwich. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Krulwich of New York.

CHICAGO, July 4--The Mets may or may not be their own worst enemies, but they are certainly Roger Craig's. Today at Wrigley Field, before a crowd of 32,654, the stumbling New Yorkers stretched Craig's torments and their own futility to new and greater lengths.
EUGENE, Ore., July 4 (AP) --Dyrol Burleson, the Amateur Athletic Union national champion, won the mile in 4 minutes .3 today in the Oregon A.A.U. track and field championships.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 4 (UPI)--Cornell's heavyweight crew successfully began its bid for the world's top rowing honors today when it rallied to defeat its most highly regarded challenger, the Nassovia Hoechst crew of Germany, in the Grand Challenge Cup preliminaries of the Royal Henley Regatta.
The Very Rev. Joseph McSorley, a former Superior General of the Paulist Fathers, died Thursday at the Paulist rectory, 415 West 59th Street. He was 88 years old.
MOSCOW, July 4--Frol R. Kozlov, who stood second to Premier Khrushchev in the ruling Presidium before suffering a paralyzing stroke last April, was reported today to be recovering slowly.

LEH, Kashmir, July 4--United States Air Force planes are airlifting thousands of tons of cement, asphalt and heavy building equipment to this Himalayan outpost as part of the effort to help India defend herself against Communist China.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, July 4--Within the next few days 50 United States Army officers and enlisted men will arrive here to begin teaching Indonesian Army engineers how to use heavy road-building machinery.
LONDON, July 4--The Burmah Oil Company directors rejected today a multimillion-dollar acquisition bid from the British Petroleum Company and the Shell Petroleum Company.
Every day a line of men carrying blueprints and odd-shaped boxes forms outside the office of a young man named James L. Marcus.

HOUSTON, July 4 (AP)-- Jim Campbell's grand slam home run in the eighth inning off Joey Jay gave the Houston Colts a 6-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds in the second game of a twi-night doubleheader today. The Colts also won the onener, 5--2.
In weather that was close to perfect, Americans celebrated the nation's 187th Independence Day yesterday with fireworks, bells, speeches and travel.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 4-- Under a cool and cloudless sky, the Newport Jazz Festival started its 20th annual series of programs tonight at Freebody Park with a crowd estimated at 7,000. The capacity of the park is 10,000.

Soviet-Chinese differences have erupted so violently and publicly these past few weeks that no informed observer expects any important results from the Moscow-Peking ideological confrontation beginning in Moscow today.
A new mechanism to give neighborhoods a voice in governing the city is being promoted by the Borough Presidents, five years in advance of a planned schedule under the new Charter.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (UPI)--The Philadelphia Phillies swept a twin bill from the Pittsburgh Pirates today behind the pitching of Art Mahaffey and Ryne Duren. Mahaffey hurled a two-hitter to win the opener, 1--0, in 10 innings and Duren pitched a three-hitter to take the second game, 5--1.
TORONTO July 4, (AP)-- Doug Ford of Yonkers carded a four-under-par 67 today and took the lead in the Canadian open golf tournament with a 36hole total of 136.
WASHINGTON, July 4-- President Kennedy hailed the Peace Corps today in terms of the spirit of 1776.
BUENOS AIRES, July 4-- The decision of the huge Peronist movement to abstain in Sunday's national elections may mean that an old Peronist enemy will become Argentina's next president.
New York was a great place to visit yesterday.

Kelso again. The famous 6-year-old owned by the Bohemia Stable did exactly what was expected of him at Aqueduct yesterday. He won the $108,500 Suburban Handicap, finishing 1 lengths ahead of Mrs. J. Deaver Alexander's Saidam in the 77th running of the stakes. Saidam had 1 lengths over the Harbor View Farm's Garwol. The victory was Kelso's fourth straight in a stakes.

AMERICUS, Ga., July 4 (AP) --A prisoner shot three men to death and wounded another today in a break for freedom, then died with a gun in his hand while digging a foxhole to fight off his pursuers.

VIENNA, July 4--After a stormy four-hour debate, the Austrian Parliament amended tonight the 1919 Habsburg Law, declared Dr. Otto Habsburg "unwanted" in Austria and, in effect, ordered the Government to keep him out.

LONDON, July 4--Lord Burnham, a former managing director of The Daily Telegraph and a former vice chairman of the Newspaper Proprietors Association, died in a London hospital today. He was 73 years old.
Development of big barge bulk transport on the Great Lakes is being aided by a novel means of propulsion equipment, the bow thruster.

The Wiener Sport Club of Vienna got off to a good start by beating Valladolid of Spain, 1--0, as the local portion of the second section of the International Soccer League began yesterday at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
OTTAWA, July 4 (Canadian Press)--Canada's official foreign exchange reserves declined slightly during June.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP)-- The Judicial Council of the American Medical Association said today Dr. Charles E. Smith, medical director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, had not violated the principle of medical ethics in the case of former Maj. Gen. Edwin Walker.
VIENNA, July 4 (AP)--The Hungarian Communist Government has announced that it will approve assignments of new Roman Catholic bishops to the country's six vacant sees by Pope Paul VI.
LONDON, July 4--Despite a slight quickening of American interest in British securities, Americans still remain leery of the British stock market, Wall Street representatives said today.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) --A leading aeronautical engineer predicted today that the world's airlines would purchase nearly 800 supersonic craft.

CLEVELAND, July 4 (UPI) --Jerry Kindall hit a homer in the 14th inning to decide the opener and a two-run homer in the second game today to pace the Cleveland Indians in a 4-3, 7-5 sweep over the Boston Red Sox.
SPOLETO, Italy, July 4 (Reuters)--Henry Miller's first play, "Just Wild About Harry," was enthusiastically received at its premiere last night in the Festival of Two Worlds here.

BIRMINGHAM, England, July 4 (Reuters)--Another fighting innings by Brian Close helped redeem an indifferent batting display by England today, the first day of the third cricket test against the West Indies.
MIAMI BEACH, July 4-- Building managers were warned today to get all the protection they could against the substantial and growing liability in building management.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 4 (UPI)--Dr. Kacy rallied and beat Admiral's Voyage by half a length today in the $57,000 American Handicap at Hollywood Park. Favored Native Diver finished seventh.
The city's first experience with new Charter procedures for approving the expense budget was "not very satisfactory," according to the Citizens Union.
BONN, July, 4--President de Gaulle conferred separately today with Chancellor Adenauer and his successor-designate, Vice Chancellor Ludwig Erhard, at the outset of a 30-hour visit.
A proofreader's right to "moonlight" as a school principal has been upheld by a National Labor Relations Board examiner.
THE fallacies that all Pakistani food is curry and all curry is hot are quickly discredited by Syed Wasiqullah during his cooking classes at the Old Library Cooking School in Palisades, N.Y.

LOS ANGELES, July 4 (AP) --The Los Angeles Dodgers scored eight runs in the sixth inning--four on a grand-slam home run by Ken McMullen-- and took a 2 -game lead in the National League by defeating the second-place St. Louis Cardinals, 10--7, tonight.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 4--Alfred E. Baxendale, retired vice president of the HegemanHarris Company, Inc., New York, building contractors, died yesterday in his home here at 106 North Arlington Avenue.

In an effort to keep the African states from crippling the work of international organizations, Ambassador Stevenson, chief American delegate to the United Nations, is in Europe trying to cope with a situation potentially destructive of the United Nations itself.
The International Air Transport Association is attempting to put a stop to the "upgrading" of certain passengers by some of its member carriers.

LIMA, Peru, July 4 (Reuters) --William Willis, 70-year-old American navigator, explorer and author, was towed out of the harbor here today in a 10ton pontoon raft to begin his second lone trans-Pacific voyage of 10,000 miles to Sydney, Australia.

The 14th floor at 529 Fifth Avenue, corner of 44th Street, has been leased by Rose Assosiates, builders, owners and managers of apartment and office buildings. The lessees, who occupy the 15th floor, will use the additional floor of 2,000 square feet to expand their construction department. John Dowling of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agents for the building, was the broker.

DAYTON, Ohio, July 4 (AP) --Sally Griffith of the Santa Clara (Calif.) Valley Girls Club broke the American girls' quarter-mile record tonight. She won her qualifying heat in 59.6 seconds in the Amateur Athletic Union girls' and women's national outdoor track and field championships.
MOSCOW, July 4--Relations between the Soviet Union and Communist China deteriorated rapidly tonight on the eve of scheduled talks here between the two countries on ideological differences.
"Mama and papa" package stores in which most New Yorkers buy their bottled spirits are opposed to any major change in state controls over their segment of the liquor industry.
Frenetic activity in Burmah Oil shares marked trading on the London stock market yesterday.

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 4 --Forty Negro and white members of the Congress of Racial Equality lay down in front of moving cars with their children here today to draw attention to a campaign to force the Long Island State Park Commission to hire more Negroes and Puerto Ricans.
WASHINGTON, July 4--A move to draft Senator Barry Goldwater for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1964 got off to a noisy, enthusiastic start here tonight.
HOLLYWOOD, July 4-- Wrecking crews at the Hal Roach Studio are symbolic of a trend and perhaps the end of a Hollywood era.

DETROIT, July 4--Robert Hall Wyatt, who takes office tomorrow as the president of the 860,000-member National Education Association, conceals behind a lowpressure manner the kind of determination and hard work that produce high-pressure resuits.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 4--Glenn (Fireball) Roberts of Daytona Beach won the Firecracker 400-mile late-model stock car race today on the 2.5mile Daytona International Speedway. He averaged 150.927 miles an hour in a 1963 Ford and earned $11,600 from the $63,000 purse.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 44 --It was a glorious Fourth for the yachtsmen on Long Island Sound today, glorious because the wind blew up to 30 knots on a clear, blue-sky afternoon and racing conditions were testing and ideal at the Larchmont Yacht Club's 84th annual regatta.

Rather than have "I Was Dancing" done as a play first, Edwin O'Connor has decided to bring it out as a novel. The author of the Pulitzer Prize book, "The Edge of Sadness," said that "I Was Dancing" would be published next spring by Atlantic-Little, Brown.
GENEVA, July 4--Delegates representing the African states walked out of the 26th International Conference on Education here today when the Portugese delegation refused to heed a vote to exclude it.

ALTHOUGH ours is an age of world wars and of total warfare, it is even more characteristically an age of resolutions and of civil wars. These bloody intramural conflicts are always going on somewhere. They have been fought in such great powers as Russia and China with consequences so momentous that another century will have to pass before they can be evaluated.
WASHINGTON, July 4--The Kennedy Administration has abandoned plans to ask the Organization of American States to declare an economic embargo against Cuba.
WASHINGTON, July 4-- Congressional leaders plan to seek a reconsideration by the House of the Administration's bill to speed development in distressed areas.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 (AP)--A Japanese-American newspaper has advised Negroes to "do a little soul-searching."

Earlier this year the floodgates of Glen Canyon Dam were closed, signaling the completion of a major engineering feat to control the Colorado River for hydroelectric power and irrigation. Now the flow has been halted halfway up the nearly two-hundred-mile-long Glen Canyon, from northern Arizona northeastward across southern Utah, as the waters fill in behind the dam.

LONDON, July 2--Opposition from Britain is reliably reported to be balking a concerted move among the Atlantic nations to put a ceiling on the rapidly growing volume of credit to Soviet-bloc countries.

The last of 101 Californian travelers stranded here since last weekend finally left yesterday. Meanwhile California's Attorney General ordered an investigation of the travel agency that had arranged their Europebound charter flight that never materialized.
GOSHEN, N.Y., July 4--It may have been difficult to identify the trotters and pacers without a program, but it was easy to spot the city slickers among the 3,565 customers at Historic Track today.
WASHINGTON, July 4-- Tentative plans for strengthening the free world's international financial system are picking up support in important quarters in this country.
LONDON, July 4--The various contributors to "Pickwick," the new large-scale musical at the Saville, attempt to repeat the "Oliver" formula. But what they have produced is a sort of debased version.

Television's preoccupation with serving generous slabs of news at dinner time has been carried one step further by a Los Angeles station that plans to deliver 90 minutes of news each weekday at 6 P.M.

DETROIT, July 4--A "cult of reactionism" is threatening the "simple idea of providing an educational opportunity for all youth, free not only financially but intellectually," the president-elect of the National Education Association said here today.
LONDON, July 4--Prime Minister Macmillan's ruling Conservative party suffered sharp setbacks tonight in two by-elections. Labor candidates won by increased majorities.
WASHINGTON, July 4-- President Kennedy marked the nation's independence anniversary today by naming 31 persons to receive the new Presidential Medal of Freedom.
LONDON, July 4--General Lord Freyberg died in a hospital at Windsor, Surrey, tonight at the age of 74.
ALBANY, Ga., July 4--A year ago, this pleasant little military and industrial center of 60,000 persons drew national attention as the chief target of the Negroes' civil rights drive.

WASHINGTON, July 4-- President Kennedy and Labor Secretary W. Willard Wirtz conferred today on how to head off a national railroad strike next Thursday.

OVER this holiday weekend many of New York's tournament players are in the Sacandaga tournament at Lake Sacandaga, N.Y. This is an annual meeting place for players of New England, upper New York State, eastern Canada, and, incidentally, New York City.

CHICAGO, July 4--A Negro clergyman narrowly escaped manhandling and Mayor Richard J. Daley was booed off the platform at a rally in Grant Park here today. The mass meeting followed a civil rights parade down State Street.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 4-- Something new is being added to something new at Roosevelt Raceway. Ten-dollar tickets as well as the $2 variety will be available when the twin double makes its debut at the Nassau County plant Monday night.

GREAT FALLS, Mont., July 4--The Air Force has declared the first Minuteman missile wing fully operational. It is able to launch 150 nuclear armed intercontinental rockets from underground silos within 32 seconds after receiving an order to fire.
"Two television sets in every home"--that's the slogan that appears to have been adopted by the makers of television receivers.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 4 (AP)--Larry Questad of Stanford, the National Collegiate sprint champion and a double winner at the Moscow international meet this week, scored an easy victory in the 100-meter dash at the third World Athletic Games today. Questad was timed in 10.3 seconds.

WASHINGTON, July 4--Intercity truck tonnage in the week ended June 29 was 1.7 per cent above the volume for the corresponding week in 1962. The American Trucking Association reported that this was the second consecutive week in which truck tonnage has been above the 1962 level.
Caedmon Records and Spoken Arts, Inc., two of the leading record companies in the dramatio field, will increase production of contemporary and classical plays this fall.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 4--President Kennedy arrived on sunny Cape Cod late this afternoon for a warm reunion with his family and a long holiday weekend.

ROME, July 4--The Vatican described today as not corresponding to fact statements to the effect that a declaration condemning anti-Semitism had been dropped from the agenda of the Ecumenical Council of the Roman Catholic Church.
CINCINNATI, July 4 (UPI) --Stan Musial made it again-- for a record 24th time--when he was named to the National League All-Star team today by Manager Alvin Dark of the San Francisco Giants.

LOS ANGELES, July 4 (UPI) --An archeologist told today of the excavation of a 4,000-yearold house about 70 miles south of Lima on the Peruvian coast. Victor Nekrasov is a well-known Soviet writer and a member of the Soviet Communist party. Several years ago he visited this country; late last year a Soviet magazine printed two essays in which Mr. Nekrasov recorded his impressions abroad. He liked some things he saw here; he disliked others. His comments were written in a civilized and humane spirit.

It looks as if Argentina is really going to have its scheduled election on Sunday. Not many people would have bet on this in recent months. It is going to be a rather strange election, and the rules are so confusing that no Argentine can be sure where his vote is going to end. All he can be sure of is that no one openly labeled as a Peronist can be elected.

MEMPHIS, July 4--Miss Ann Merrill Garcelon and Brainerd Gray Hencken, members of the class of '64 at Rollins College in Winter Park, Fla., will be married late next month. Their parents are Mr. and Mrs. Fessenden Merrill Garcelon, who have announced the engagement, and Mr. and Mrs. Harold Gray Hencken of Greenwich, Conn.

BOBBY RICHARDSON returned to Yankee Stadium yesterday and displayed not the slightest embarrassment over the fact his absence had been caused by an attack of the children's disease, German measles. For the most part he was warmly greeted as he sat in front of his locker in the clubhouse, although the needlers couldn't quite resist their opportunity.
WASHINGTON, July 4--The Administration feels that Premier Khrushchev has again confronted it with an old problem: how to do business with Moscow without further disrupting the Western alliance.
MOSCOW, July 4--Diplomats at the Chinese Communist Embassy here were as tight-lipped tonight as they had been open-handed with their propaganda material on previous occasions.
MOSCOW, July 4 (AP)--Premier Khrushchev sent President Kennedy and the American people "warm congratulations and wishes of peace and prosperity" today in a July 4 message.
PARIS, July 4--French farmers clashed again with police forces in the south today as unrest over low prices for fruits and vegetables continued.

BALTIMORE, July 4--The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, chief executive officer of the United Presbyterian Church, was among 283 persons arrested today when they... attempted to integrate an allwhite amusement park near Baltimore. Those arrested in cluded 12 other white and Negro clergymen.

LOLIONDO, Tanganyika, June 20--Hunting the plains game of East Africa in northern Tanganyika frequently involves a choice between an animal that would look good mounted and one that looks good enough to eat.
Billy Rose's forthcoming production of "The Deputy" was attacked yesterday by the Rev. Robert A. Graham, an associate editor of America, a Roman Catholic weekly published by the Society of Jesus.
LONDON, July 4--The system by which British professional football, or soccer, players have been bound to their clubs was upset today in a historic court ruling.
Detroit automotive executives are "looking through the wrong end of the telescope" when they report that foreign car sales have reached a plateau here, according to a leading French importer.

WASHINGTON, July 5 The design of the self-opening beer can that is spreading throughout the country was patented this week. The inventor is a Dayton, Ohio, engineer who has given the Aluminum Company of America exclusive licenses under this patent and others pending.

BLACKPOOL, England, July 5 (U.P.) Arnold Palmer shot a three-under-par 69 today to defeat the British Ryder Cup captain, Dai Rees, 4 and 3, and lead the "rest of the world" to a 6 3 victory over a British golf team. The matches were staged by Prince Philip as a prelude to the British open next week.
The State Attorney General's office said yesterday that it was investigating the need for state legislation to regulate airline charter flights and travel agencies.
BUNI KASIH, Indonesia, July 5 This Village consists of a tattered group of palm-thatched and tiled houses raised on short blocks of wood to allow winter rains to flood down the hillside under them.

Pan American Airways carried 28,000 passengers across the Atlantic to Europe during the first 23 days of June, a 31 per cent increase over the same period in 1962, according to Willis G. Lipscomb, vice president for traffic and sales.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 5 President Kennedy has renewed his appeal to the Soviet Union for a joint effort to solve "those key problems which divide us."
Exporters and importers in the trans-Atlantic trades have been notified that their freight bills would be increased about 25 per cent in September.

TOULOUSE, France, July 5 In bike racing, the mountains rise up stark and terrible out of the plain, and each rider, looking up at them, is afraid. It is like going into battle. No soldier is ever sure in advance how he will behave.
LONDON, July 6 Chuck McKinley has won the Wimbledon title, the highest honor in tennis.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 5 Calcante, a 5-year-old standardbred who never has raced outside his native Italy, and When, the fastest trotter ever bred in New Zealand, today were named for the fifth annual Roosevelt International to be contested July 20 at Roosevelt Raceway.
MESSINA, Sicily, July 5 Three brown-robed, bearded Capuchin friars were sentenced prison today on charges of extortion and conspiracy.
DENVER, July 5 An Alabama Negro woman was unanimously elected an assistant moderator of the United Church of Christ here today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 5 The prosecutor in the trial of 19 Vietnamese servicemen accused of taking part in an attempted coup d'etat here in 1960 told defense lawyers in private session today that there was evidence that the United States Embassy had been involved in the attempt.
The pharmaceutical industry is presently in a controversy that could bring subtle, but important, changes in the way it develops drugs for human consumption.
LINDEN, N.J., July 5 A 36-year-old factory worker shot and killed his wife and sisterin-law and wounded his brother and two neighbors today.

TOKYO, July 5 The marked rise in Japanese exports last year particularly to the United States and Western Europe is expected to play a major role in helping this country achieve a favorable trade balance this year, according to a Government white paper issued here. Major Factors

The largest helicopter ever put into production in this country, a flying crane called the S-64, has been ordered by the Army.
The city was accused yesterday of "throwing overboard," a workable plan to help unemployed youngsters in favor of one that will merely duplicate existing services.

The medical profession and the clergy once seldom noted for compatibility have become firm friends and allies in Washington. The catalyst in the transformation was the capital city's interfaith Pastoral Institute at 3000 Connecticut Avenue, N.W.

The troika coalition in Laos has reached a dead end. For months Pathet Lao members have been absent from the seat of government in Vientiane. Their Vietnamese Communist-backed forces are engaged in sporadic hostilities against troops of the other two government factions, the neutralists and the rightists. These latter two now make common cause, in the government and on the fighting fronts.

PARIS, July 5 (Comptelburo) An international consortium agreed today to cover Turkey's needs in foreign aid this year for her 1963-67 economic development plan.

A major management change at Ohrbach's, Inc., which was announced yesterday, may portend the beginning of active control of the low-markup Ohrbach's specialty stores by C. A. Brenninkmeyer, a Dutch retail company.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 5 (AP) Like the father who takes over the Christmas train, President Kennedy spent part of this afternoon playing with his son's toy sailboat.
LONDON, July 5 Dr. Giuseppe Martelli, the Italian physicist accused here of having been a Soviet spy, admitted in court today that he had been involved with Soviet intelligence agents.

CHICAGO, July 5 James H. Meredith of the University of Mississippi was subjected to verbal attack tonight after he had addressed the convention dinner of the Youth and College Division of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

BUENOS AIRES, July 5 The Peronist-dominated General Labor Confederation urged its members today to cast blank ballots in the Argentine election Sunday. It called for a general strike on Oct. 12, the inauguration day for the new President.

A sharp rise in new issues of fixed-interest offerings is expected to be bid upon next week. This would be in contrast to the dearth of competitive sales of long-term issues during the Fourth of July holiday period.

LOS ANGELES, July 5 (UPI) Kamalii, profiting from 1820-knot winds, took the lead today in the second day of the 2,225-mile trans-Pacific biennial yacht race to Honolulu. But she had plenty of competition from several other craft.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 5 New jazz talents and new jazz situations were the focal points of the Newport Jazz Festival this afternoon and last night.
MOSCOW, July 5 Soviet and Chinese Communist leaders opened ideological talks today without any apparent easing of the tensions that have brought their two parties close to a formal split.
WASHINGTON, July 5 The world's largest waterfowl, the rare trumpeter swan, has successfully nested east of the American Rocky Mountains for the first time in 80 years.
The PT's are back. The motor torpedo boats that played a glamorous role in many of the actions of World War II are now back in naval service after a seven-year interlude.
WOBURN, Mass., July 5 (UPI) An equipment failure forced millions of cubic feet of explosive cooking gas into low-pressure lines throughout the city today.
Cicada of the Meadow Stable is going into a new field today in an effort to add to her bankroll, which even now is the greatest ever amassed by a thoroughbred filly or mare.
ATHENS, July 5 Efforts to agree on a program to strengthen international law ran into conflict this evening at the world conference of lawyers here.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) In a move designed to im prove the management of hiS agency, Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freemen established seven regional offices today to operate in the fields of manpower use, auditing and investigating.

LOS ANGELES, July 5--Johnny Podres pitched a two hitter, Frank Howard slammed a seventh-inning homer and the National League-leading Los Angeles Dodgers gained their fifith straight victory tonight by defeating the Cincinnati Reds, 1--0.
Continued nervousness over the discount rate depressed the Government bond market further yesterday. The week saw one of the sharpest declines this year.

George Stevens Jr., director of the screen service of the United States Information Agency, and John Flory, adviser on nontheatrical movies for the Eastman Kodak Company, will be two of the principal speakers at the workshop seminar on film editing that starts Oct. 7 at the Henry Hudson Hotel.
WARSAW, July 5 Wladyslaw Gomulka, the Communist party chief, has denounced Polish Roman Catholic bishops for hostility to Communism and for allegedly opposing the ideas of the late Pope John XXIII.

Two separate "glamour" stocks with similar names Control Data Corporation and Data-Control Systems, Inc. boomed to record 1963 prices yesterday in heavy trading. On the New York Stock Exchange, Control Data ranked as fourth most active issue on turnover of 39,900 shares. It spurted 3 7/8 points to close at 68 after selling as high as 68 5/8.
WASHINGTON, July 5 For the first time in the United States total employment exceeded 70,000,000 in June, but unemployment remained high.
Young Republicans in the Bronx have complained to Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz about "political harassment" by assistants of the Attorney General.
U.S. INSISTS IT PLANS MORE STEPS ON CUBA WASHINGTON, July 5 The State Department insisted today that it was not abandoning plans to "further isolate Cuba economically and politically."
TORONTO, July 5 (UPI) Doug Ford of Yonkers scrambled to a three-over-par 74 today but retained his two-stroke lead in the third round of the $50,000 Canadian open golf championship.
Today is the 79th birthday of Harold S. Vanderbilt, who in 1925 had an inspiration nonplayers might call it a brainstorm and invented the game of contract bridge.
Despite a gain in first-quarter sales, the Montecatini General Mining and Chemical Corporation showed a substantial decline in first-quarter net income, it was reported here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 5 United States officials were hopeful today that Argentines would go to the polls Sunday and place their country back on the path of democracy.
Landlocked Paraguay's first ocean-going vessel ever to call at the Port of New York is scheduled to arrive here tomorrow morning.

PARIS, July 5 The first time the Russians ever negotiated with the Chinese they were respectively represented by a Pole and by two European Jesuits; Latin was the language used, Perhaps because of this they were able to understand each other and signed the Treaty of Nerchinsk in 1689.

Utah Power and Light Company's Naughton generating station on a windswept plateau near Kemmerer, Wyo., is now in full operation. The dedication ceremonies on June 22 brought the $29,000,000 steam-electric station fully "on stream."

Trading in oil shares on the London stock market quieted yesterday after Thursday's frenzied activity touched off by the collapse of the Shell Petroleum and British Petroleum efforts to acquire Burmah Oil.
What's behind the strength of oil stocks lately? Several of the major oil company stocks have been setting historic highs recently. Yesterday, they made some more price news.
PARIS, July 5--Doubts about the economic impact and benefits of the Common Market are being expressed both inside and outside the community.

The Federal Reserve made its biggest open-market purchases in nine months in the week ended Wednesday, but still failed to offset fully the credittightening influence of the holiday rise in currency and coin in circulation.
An appeal to American women to quit buying leopard skin coats has been made by the National Audubon Society.

HAMPTON BAYS, L.I., July 5 Frank W. La Vista, who earned acclaim in military, educational and industrial aviation, died today in Southampton Hospital after a short illness. His age was 70. He lived on Old Canoe Place Road.

With 6,860 travelers due to debark Monday from eight arriving ocean liners, Customs and other Federal personnel are making preparations over the weekend to handle the year's largest influx of ship passengers.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 5 More than 800 persons attended a funeral service in the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation here today for Alicia Patterson, editor and publisher of Newsday. She died Tuesday of a stomach ailment at the age of 56. Cremation followed the service.

Henry Giebel of 9 Midland Gardens, Bronxville, N.Y., chairman of the board of directors and former president of Thomas Wilson Co., Inc., manufacturers and importers of lace trimmings, died yesterday of cancer at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. He was 70 years old.

BONN, July 5 President de Gaulle and Chancellor Adenauer were in friendly disagreement on European questions today when they ended the first heads-of-government consultation prescribed by the new French-German Treaty of Cooperation.
TRENTON, July 5--The State Commissioner of Education upheld today the legality of a plan used by Montclair to end racial imbalance in its Glenfield School.
OKOBOJI, Iowa, July 5 For the first time since World War I, Iowans openly ordered liquor at taverns and restaurants today.

Mrs. Grace King Knight, a leader in political and civic affairs in Rockford, Ill., died Thursday in St. Anthony's Hospital there at the age of 75. She was the mother of the Rev. George L. Knight, minister of the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn.

GREENWICH Conn., July 5 Miss Suzanne Tenney Sutter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Samuel Sutter, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Newell A very Augur Jr., Son of Mr. and Mrs. Augur of St. Louis, and Prouts Neck, Me.
LAGOS, Nigeria, July 5 Gene Fullmer's foot still may be ailing, but Nigerians are beginning to wonder if the former middleweight champion hasn't also developed a case of yellow fever.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 5 Marshal Augusto Maggessi Pereira of the army reserve, who presided at a meeting yesterday of officers who voted a 10-day ultimatum to the Government to put through a pay-raise measure for the armed services, was arrested tonight. The "threat" in the officers' demand was vague.
WASHINGTON, July 5 The Coast Guard is organizing a specialized group to combat any efforts by saboteurs, spies and weapons smugglers to penetrate United States coastal defenses.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 5 (AP)--William Haggin Perry's Lamb Chop and Eleanora Sears's Spicy Living renew their battle for the 3-year-old filly championship tomorrow when they clash with six rivals in the $50,000 added Monmouth Oaks at Monmouth Park.
The first top-level "working" talks between President de Gaulle and Chancellor Adenauer to implement the new French-German treaty of cooperation have ended without major agreements.
Little flower gardens that might make suburbanites green with envy are sprouting throughout the city these days.

A SEVERE winter, which has restricted production, and soaring economies, which have removed restrictions on local purchasing power, have combined to make many European food products rather dear this year.

HENLEY ON-THAMES, England, July 5 (UPI) Cornell's heavyweight crew advanced to the final of the Grand Challenge Cup in the Henley Regatta today and became a strong favorite to beat the University of London tomorrow.

The racial crisis in the South has become a theme of major importance for folk singers of the North. New songs on this theme are not only weapons in the civil-rights arsenal, but are also developing into valuable commodities in the music industry.

William Miller, who has helped keep the lights of Broadway burning for 57 years, began his working day as usual yesterday he climbed the vertical "Tovarich" sign in front of the Majestic Theater and replaced a burnt out bulb.
Joe Foss, the commissioner of the American Football League, yesterday waved an olive sprig but not a flag of truce toward the rival National Football League.
WASHINGTON, July 5 A key post in the Food and Drug Administration has been unfilled for 11 months. The vacancy sufficiently troubled Government officials to bring it to President Kennedy's attention.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that the investigation into corruption in the State Liquor Authority would be stepped up in September to keep two grand juries busy simultaneously.
Stock prices inched forward on average yesterday as volume on the New York Stock Exchange fell to the second lowest level of the year.
Arthur M. Sherrill, publisher of American Home magazine, died Thursday of a heart attack while sailing his yawl on Long Island Sound. He was 61 years old and lived at 2 Tudor Place.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 5 The discovery in West Pakistan of deposits of 150,000,000 tons of iron ore has provided the basis for an iron and steel industry in that country, which at its birth in 1947 was almost wholly agricultural.
BALTIMORE, July 5 (AP) A group of jailed clergymen planned today another attack Sunday on racial barriers at Gwynn Oak Amusement Park.
PARIS, July 5 The drafting of a basic document to govern establishment of a nuclear fleet with international crews for the North Atlantic alliance is to begin soon.
WASHINGTON, July 5 Department-store sales in the week ended June 29 were 9 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year. All districts showed gains for the period.

On most days, as on the last seven, it is inevitable that the Mets lose the ball game. The point of interest now is how this untalented team comes to lose the game. In absorbing 173 defeats since their inception last year, the Mets may have found all the ways there are.
