ALBANY, July 8--Governor Rockefeller will ask the National Governors Conference to disapprove three proposed "state's rights" amendments to the Constitution.
Six off-duty youth squad policemen early today captured Gregory Egan, the 19-year-old fugitive who escaped from Bronx Criminal Court last week by leaping from a second-floor window.
WASHINGTON, July 8 Yields on newly-issued Treasury bills reached today their highest point in more than three years.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The "hot line" between President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev is not quite installed. But there is another kind of hot line being fed out of Washington over the political terrain of the United States. The message its operators are seeking to deliver is this:

Herman Methfessel, Staten Island district attorney from 1947 through 1951 and a state assemblyman in the nineteenthirties, died Sunday in Miami's North Shore Hospital, of injuries suffered in an automobile accident Saturday. He was 62 years old and lived in Miami.

CLEVELAND, July 8 Albie Pearson, the starting center fielder for the American League in the All-Star Game tomorrow, checked into hotel headquarters last night and an army of small boys swarmed around him for his autograph. They littlest Angel was indistinguishable from the rest of the kids.

LOLIONDO, Tanganyika, June 22 Hardly a day passes while on a safari in Africa without new and unusual things being seen. Sometimes it's an animal or bird. Sometimes it's the geography or the local residents. It happened the other evening during a drive into camp. A half-dozen curious little animals hopped out of the grass in front of the car.
A major Hollywood company will participate in the Montreal Film Festival for the first time when 20th Century Fox's "The Leopard" opens the 10-day event next month.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) President Kennedy greeted the American conquerors of Mount Everest today, and presented to them the Hubbard medal of the National Geographic Society for their outstanding feats.
LONDON, July 8 (AP) A British newspaper correspondent reported today that Egyptian forces in Yemen were using poison gas against remote mountain villages still loyal to the royalist cause.

PARIS, July 8 French workers and peasants challenged President de Gaulle's economic policy on two fronts today, but the Government pushed ahead with its own plans, confident that new agitation would not result to disrupt the economy.
Sugar futures turned against the tide of generally declining prices yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Copper and cocoa were the only other staples to advance.
Nathan H. Knorr, head of the 1,000,000-member Jehovah's Witnesses sect, told his followers yesterday that Armageddon the day when good will overcome evil was "near."
Executives of passenger steamship lines were exultant yesterday at what they said was the setting of a new record for profitable trans-Atlantic traffic.

EASTCHESTER, N.Y., July 8-Al Feminelli posted an eagle on the 17th hole and a birdie on the 18th without putting today and took a three-stroke lead after the first 18 holes of the Westchester open golf tournament. The strong finish gave the 39-year-old pro from Dellwood Country Club a threeunder-par 35, 32 67 on the narrow Vernon HillS County Club course.

Stock prices turned in their usual Monday performance yesterday: They went down. Declines on the New York Stock Exchange topped advances for the eighth consecutive Monday. Railroad, auto, electronics and metal issues ...

WASHINGTON, July 8 The United States banned virtually all financial transactions with Cuba today in a new move to isolate the regime of Premier Fidel Castro economically. Trade with Cuba had been embargoed previously.

LONDON, July 8--Margaret Smith has won Wimbledon. The 20-year-old Australian triumphed over nerves and a last ditch surge by Billie Jean Moffitt of Long Beach, Calif., and took the one crown that had eluded her. The scores were 6--3, 6--4.
William Zeckendorf, chairman of Webb Knapp, Inc., is putting his company back into the realty development business and taking it out of the realty investment business.

ST. LOUIS, July 8 Despite mounting pressure, the five unions that operate trains have never budged in their four-year battle against railroad rules changes. The determination that has characterized their stand is also the outstanding trait of one of their chieftains, H.E. Gilbert.

Demonstrations now taking place in and around New York have the commendable aim of exposing unequal job opportunities and other civil rights shortcomings experienced by Negroes in the North. But the militant Congress of Racial Equality, which has inspired the major protests, must learn that making headlines can be both boon and boomerang for the cause.
Advertising is supposed to be an anonymous business, with agency officials laboring quietly behind the scenes for the greater glory of their clients.

SINCE the late nineteen-fifties, the furniture buying public of Sweden and Finland has been turning its collective bank on teak and walnut and looking to the freshness of blond woods, such as oak, ash and birch.

Tropical Breeze came through with a good performance in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. Isidor Bieber's colt took the event, a one-mile purse called the Spy Song Handicap, by 2 lengths over the Wheatley Stable's Bold Commander.
An unusual auction of real estate will be held in the Astor Hotel tomorrow afternoon, when Webb Knapp, Inc., puts up for sale 25 pieces of property scattered around three boroughs of the city.
CHICAGO, July 8 Field Enterprises Educational Corporation said today that it was canceling its $3,200,000 offer for the personal stories of the 16 United States astronauts.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., July 8--Joseph McD. Mitchell resigned today as City Manager of Newburgh to accept a job with the John Birch Society.
An experimental program to clear part of the baggage of New York-bound passengers abroad is expected to start in Naples next month. It is designed to speed the passengers' debarkation here.
The railroad strike threatened for Thursday if it materializes will test the ingenuity, patience and durability of thousands of metropolitan area commuters already noted for those qualities.
WASHINGTON, July 8 Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff urged the medical profession today to strike down the "barrier of discrimination" against Negro doctors and Negro patients.
THIS year's European bridge championships will be played July 19 through Aug. 1 at Baden-Baden, the historic spa in the Black Forest of West Germany. While the ...
WESTBURY, L. I., July 8-- For the holders of 46 winning $2 tickets on the twin double, money came back into style tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
Hundreds of screaming, jeering white youths roamed the Allerton Avenue section of the Bronx last night, hurling stones and vegetables at cars bearing Negroes.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 8 Maj. Gen. Ziad el-Hariri, leader of the troops that brought the Baath party to power in Syria March 8, was deported to Vienna today.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., July 8 About 150 Negroes staged a peaceful freedom walk here tonight. It was the second desegregation demonstration since the Maryland National Guard left Cambridge at noon today.
Quiet conditions prevailed on European stock exchanges yesterday. Volume was at a low level on the London Stock Exchange, although gains outnumbered losses. Wide gains were made ...

That long weekend is over now, and a number of inescapable conclusions must be drawn. The first of these is does not taste as good ... The first of these is that sand does not taste as good this summer as it did a certain number of years back. Neither does that charcoal which has its origins ...
Building managers and owners are disturbed over the increasing number of private and nonprofit hospitals that are proposing offices for physicians as a source of income to the institutions.

CLEVELAND, July 8 With both managers finding their pitching selections more than a mite scrambled, the National League remained a 7-to-5 favorite tonight to defeat the American League in the AllStar Game tomorrow in Cleveland's Municipal Stadium.
LONDON, July 8 Raissa Struchkova, dancing the title role in the Bolshoi Ballet's "Cinderella" tonight, had the biggest success so far of the company's Covent Garden season.

TOWSON, Md., July 8 A Baltimore County Council tonight established a Human Relations Commission. Its first task will be attempting to mediate between civil rights groups and the operators of segregated Gwynn Oak Amusement Park, the scene of two large-scale demonstrations in the last week.

VIENTIANE, Laos, July 8 (AP) The neutralist Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, charged today that an 85-vehicle convoy from near the border of Communist North Vietnam had reinforced pro-Communist Pathet Lao troops on July 3.

LONDON, July 8 The mystery surrounding the case of H.A.R. Philby remained as thick as ever today after the Government answered questions in the House of Commons about the 51-year-old former diplomat and newspaper correspondent.

Pan American World Airways announced yesterday the signing of an agreement with the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks that calls for binding arbitration of disputes when the machinery of the Railway Labor Act has been exhausted.

LONDON, July 8 Dr. Giuseppe Martelli, the Italian physicist accused of having been a Soviet spy in Britain, said in court today that a Soviet intelligence officer once suggested to him that, unless he were helpful, it might be necessary to dispose of him.
The New York Giants yesterday traded Roosevelt (Rosey) Grier, their 31-year-old 290pound defensive tackle, to the Los Angeles Rams.
Steel production took a severe drop of 11.6 per cent last week, a period that included the Fourth-of-July holiday. The American Iron and Steel Institute reported resterday ...

According to United Nations Secretary General Thant, there will be four main world power centers in the nineteen-seventies the United States, Europe, the Soviet Union and China. In citing the first three, he is clearly as right as any forecaster can hope to be in this uncertain world. To rank China with the others, however, is a much more dubious prophecy.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 9 The Soviet Union accused Communist China today of waging "a deliberate campaign" to worsen Peking-Moscow relations. The five Chinese were charged with distributing in the Soviet Union copies of Peking's June 14 letter challenging the Soviet Central Committee's policies. The letter has not been pubished here.

Van Heflin will be starred as Robert Sloane, counsel for the plaintiff, in "Libel," which is scheduled to open Sept. 28 at the Longacre. The part he will play is that of Louis Nizer, who successfully represented Quentin Reynolds in his libel suit against Westbrook Pegler. An award of $175,000 was made in favor of Mr. Reynolds.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 8 -- Quarreling Angolan rebel groups were splintered even further today following a weekend of denunciations and violence.
CHICHESTER, England, July 8--"The Workhouse Donkey" by John Arden opened at the Chichester Festival Theater tonight as the third play of this year's season.

BUENOS AIRES, July 8 The election triumph yesterday of Dr. Arturo Illia and his resurgent Popular Radical party was hailed widely today as a victory for moderation and a smashing defeat for Juan D. Peron, the former dictator.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana; July 6 President Kennedy has decided to refuse Prime Minister Cheddi B. Jagan's request for United States aid.

The Bowery Savings Bank joined the Federal Home Loan Bank System yesterday and, by virtue of its assets of more than $2,000,000,000, became the largest of the system's 4,900 members. The system, comprising 11 regional Home Loan Banks, is a credit reservoir for member savings and loan associations and savings banks.

WASHINGTON, July 8 Burke Marshall, Assistant Attorney General, said today that Federal legislation was required to deal with discrimination in areas where feelings of racial supremacy were deeply ingrained.
WASHINGTON, July 8 Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon indicated strongly today that steps might be taken soon to increase interest rates on short-term borrowings.
DURING a fleeting visit to New York, Dom Andre sipped a pre-luncheon sherry and watched a companion consume, with obvious relish, a concoction called Yellow Fever.
The Federal Government began yesterday its second attempt to convict a 34-year-old Navy yeoman of espionage in the sale of confidential defense information to Soviet agents.
The two hot spells of late June and early July drove water consumption here to record highs, according to the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

LOS ANGELES, July 8 The world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, defeated Pal Benko of the United States in the third round of the eight-man Piatigorsky Cup round robin tournament last night.
HOLLYWOOD, July 8--The Hollywood Bowl, beginning its 42d summer season tomorrow, will adhere to its slogan of "Music for Everyone."

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 Charles E. Brinley, former chief executive officer of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, now part of the Baldwin-Lima-Hamilton Corporation, died yesterday in his country home at North Haven, Me. He was 85 years old.

NEW DELHI, July 8 Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru gave Ambassador John Kenneth Galbraith of the United States a cordial public farewell today at the inauguration of the expanded Punjab Agricultural University.
IN a top-story studio in East 95th Street, Al Hirsch feld is engaged in a long summer project for a television studio.

The Brooklyn Congress of Racial Equality ended its integration demonstration at the Board of Education yesterday after school officials agreed to transfer a Negro student to a high school outside his neighborhood "for medical reasons."
Admissions standards for summer sessions at colleges and universities in the city are being raised again.
JACKSON, Miss., July 8 (AP) Byron de La Beckwith pleaded not guilty today in State Circuit Court on his indictment for the murder of Medgar W. Evers, Negro integrationist leader.
WASHINGTON, D.C., July 8 (AP) Air travelers pay the nation's highest trunk fares on the 235-mile flight between Los Angeles and Las Vegas and the lowest on transcontinental services.
PAMPLONA, Spain, July 8 In Spain, fiestas are both a sport and a business. As sport they are sometimes dangerous, and as business they are sometimes illegal.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 (AP) The financial troubles of Yuba Consolidated Industries, Inc., were attributable partly to the national recession of the late nineteen-fifties, a former president of the company said today in United States District Court.
LONDON, Tuesday, July 9 Four of the five intended members of the Federation of Malaysia signed an agreement on the union early today.
WASHINGTON, July 8 President Kennedy conferred today with Ambassador Frederick E. Nolting Jr. about difficulties besetting the Government of South Vietnam.

THE violence of the human spirit can be be expressed on woodwinds and violins. It does not really require blaring brasses and thumping big drums. Nor, in literature, do the wildest emotions necessarily need a bellowing prose style to fortify their validity. And yet such a style may help, of course, to indicate that the user ...
OTTAWA, July 8 Walter L. Gordon, the Minister of Finance, acted tonight to soften the impact of his controversial budget of June 13 upon the Canadian economy and on foreign investors.

The Zeckendorf Property Corporation, formed at the end of 1961 as the largest developer of urban property in the United States, now has a new name and a diminished number of projects. Also, it has two corporate owners, instead of three.

NEWARK, July 8 A Federal District Court judge agreed today to review the constitutionality of the plan adopted by the Montclair Board of Education to reassign 183 pupils of the closed Glenfield School.

Sara Greenspan, who never wanted to be an actress, will end one of Broadway's longest runs this week. On Thursday, Miss Greenspan, business manager of the Theater Guild for 20 years, will retire. She started with the guild as a $35-a-week secretary in 1925.

BERLIN, July 8 (UPI) A United States military policeman who shot out four communist border guard searchlights brought Communist charges today that the Army had fired machinegun bullets and teargas bombs and destroyed border fortifications.

ST. LOUIS, July 8 A union leader said today that the fouryear dispute over railroad work rules could be ended in four hours of collective bargaining if President Kennedy would dispel a "smug assumption" held by the railroads.
THE ritual of the weekend exodus from the city is in full swing and, with it, the weekend guest's search for reasonably priced but attractive hostess gifts. At this time of ...
The Federal Communications Commission has given another prod to the New York State Board of Regents over the ultra-high-frequency television station licenses it holds but is not using.

The first action by the Board of Estimate toward creating a Breezy Point park in the Rockaways came yesterday. The board formally referred to the City Planning Commission a map covering 152 acres that are sought as a start.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) The Post Office Department has started a civil rights campaign of its own, moving to curb racial discrimination not only in all post offices but also in every city and hamlet they serve.
DETROIT, July 8 (AP) United States auto plants turned out the 6,700,000th car of the 1963 model run last week, exceeding the entire 1962 production and closing in on the record production of 1955.

Safeway Stores, Inc., the nation's second largest food chain, rang up a resounding total in the 24 weeks ended June 15. Sales and earnings for the halfyear period were the highest in the 37-year history of the company, which operates more than 2,000 stores.

When the market is in a buoyant state, companies like to split their stock. Thus, in the first six months of last year, Standard Poor's Corporation counted 193 stock splits by major companies. But in the first half of this year, a period of recovery from last year's market break, the number of stock splits declined sharply to 97.

The new preferential tariff agreement of the European Common Market and 18 Africa nations was viewed yesterday as a likely "bone of contention" in next year's major round of trade negotiations at Geneva.

CLEVELAND, July 8 A report that Charles O. Finley, owner of the Kansas City Athletics, is seeking permission to move his team to Oakland, Calif., created a storm of rumor and denial today at baseball's midseason convention on the eve of the All-Star Game.
Treasury bills bore the brunt yesterday of the continuing slide in the Government securities market.

The defense of Gerardo A. (Jerry) Re, expelled American Stock Exchange specialist on trial for a $5,000,000 stock fraud, categorically denied the Government's charges yesterday in United States District Court.
The location of the 14 yachts sailing 2,864 miles in a transAtlantic race from Newport, R.I., to Plymouth, England, is anyone's guess.
MILAN, Italy, July 8 (Comtelburo) Pirelli Societa per Azioni of Milan announced today the purchase of the majority of the capital of the German concern of Veith Gummiwerke, A.G., of Frankfurt.
The Manhattan brownstone where Theodore Roosevelt was born and the big Long Island house where he spent his final years were given to the nation yesterday.
ALBANY, Ga., July 5--The girl and the two youths strolled slowly down the dusty street under the blazing noonday sun, pausing at the little frame houses standing back in the trees.

Their position, however, is much more hypocritical and dangerous than the simple-minded, know-nothing resistance that sprang up with the introduction of the spinning jenny. The rail union leadership fully understands its power to disrupt the nation's economy through a strike;...

RIVERTON, Utah, July 8 Elmo and Eldred Hamilton, who farm a 500-acre spread just outside this pleasant crossroads near the slopes of the Oquirrh Mountains, get up early and go to bed late these hot sumer days.
NEW YORK players dominated the annual Inde pendence Day tournament (actually played over five days) at Lake Sacandaga, N.Y., last weekend. The winners of the main contests were:
A late rally halted the weeklong decline in the Government securities market yesterday. High-grade corporates steadied on the success of a large offering and municipals eased further.
CHICAGO, July 9--Arnold H. Maremont, a Chicago industrialist, announced today that a family foundation would engage in large-scale housing rehabilitation for middle-class families.

The Silverado Press clanks away nights in a triplex apartment on the top of 2 Beekman Place. Outside there is a view of the Queensboro Bridge, Mary Martin's balcony and Irving Berlin's roof and there is a breeze.
Despite all the subsidy devices the city has been able to dream up, the Transit Authority is nearing the end of break-even operation on the 15-cent fare.
Violence broke out again last night on the racial picket line at the White Castle restaurant on Boston Post Road and Allerton Avenue in the Bronx.

The Tobacco Institute issued yesterday its long-awaited list of "suggestions" governing cigarette advertising, but the list turned out to be less specific than some industry observers had anticipated.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 9 (AP)--A State Supreme Court referee has declared that an automobile club violated its charter by acting as booking agent for members and nonmembers traveling by air, rail and ship.
FREEPORT, L.I., July 9-- The Around Long Island Marathon will have its fifth running tomorrow and, as usual, there will be as much emphasis on stamina as on speed.
LOS ANGELES, July 9-- Grand Master Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia moved into first place in the eight-man Piatigorsky Cup tournament last night when he drew with Pal Benko of the United States.
WASHINGTON, July 9-- Congressional Democrats criticized today the Treasury for its advocacy of an increase in shortterm interest rates.

The General State Authority of Pennsylvania sold yesterday $50,000,000 of revenue bonds, due from 1966 to 1990. An investment banking syndicate led by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won the issue with a bid of 98,489 for a variety of coupons.
On the theory that better understanding of a country can help its exports sales, Swedish Government and industry will begin a campaign this fall to increase knowledge of Sweden in the United States.
A two-mile stretch of Grand Central Parkway between the Kew Gardens, Interchange and 172d Street in Jamaica, Queens, will be closed to traffic for at least six months starting tomorrow at 11 A.M.
Plans for a $40,000,000 kraft pulp and paper mill in Louisiana were announced yesterday by the Crown Zellerbach Corporation of San Francisco.

The adoption of longer court hours last year was "an unfortunate mistake" that is "overwhelmingly" opposed by members of the bar, according to a report made public yesterday by the New York Criminal and Civil Courts Bar Association.

EASTCHESTER, N.Y., July 9--Bob Watson of Wykagl missed a 15-foot birdie putt on the last green at the Vernon Hills Country Club today. As a result, the Westchester open golf championship finished in a three-way tie for first.

LAST week it was announced that the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (the World Bank) was negotiating a $30,000,000 loan to Colombia. Such news items have been familiar for 17 years. Nevertheless, few newspaper readers know enough about the World Bank to cover the back of an airmail stamp.
MOSCOW, July 9--The Soviet Government again accused Iraq tonight of waging "genocide" against the Kurdish rebels.
Cocoa futures advanced and sugar futures declined in moderately active dealings yesterday. Other New York markets were quiet in irregular trading.
MICHELET, Algeria, July 9 (Reuters)--Hocine Ait-Ahmed said at a news conference today that he had decided to lead an "open political struggle" against Premier Ahmed Ben Bella's Government.
Five former officials of the defunct Dental Insurance Plan were indicted and arrested yesterday in an alleged conspiracy to pay bribes to union officials to obtain contracts with labor welfare funds.

"Man in the Air," a print show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, traces the early history of man's attempt to fly. Monday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sunday and holidays, 1 to 5 P.M. Free.

TALENT came by the pair at Lewisohn Stadium last night. Fresh, young talent-- and authentic. It was present in Seiji Ozawa 26-year-old Japanese conductor, and Andre Watts, 17-year-old American pianist. Both have appeared in New York, but not extensively, and they were making their stadium debuts.
The city considered ways yesterday to ease the plight of the 200,000 metropolitan area commuters who would be affected if the nation's railroads were struck tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 9--A Senate banking subcommittee unanimously approved today, with only one major amendment, legislation expanding the authority of the Securities and Exchange Commission to police securities trading.
Two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation told yesterday of watching from hiding places while a Navy yeoman later accused of espionage extracted confidential documents from Navy files.

PARIS, July 9--The National Ensemble of Cameroon, the last company to appear at the Sarah Bernhardt Theater during the tenth season of the Theater of the Nations, opened with a program of traditional dances and songs here tonight.

Benjamin J. Weil, real-estate executive and president emeritus of Congregation Zichron Ephraim, died Monday of a heart attack at his home in tha Chatham Hotel, 33 East 48th Street. He was 91 years old.

A two-year labor agreement was signed yesterday by American Airlines and a recently formed pilots union, the Allied Pilots Association. The agreement covers pay rates, rules and working conditions for the line's 1,600 pilots.

More rice was grown in the world in the past year than ever before, but there were also more rice bowls waiting to be filled. This is largely because increased consumption in the producing countries is leaving a smaller portion of the gain for export.
WASHINGTON, July 9-- Peru hinted today that a change in foreign policy, reflecting the independent position of President-elect Fernando Belaunde Terry, was in the making.

WASHINGTON, July 9--Dr. Robert H. Felix, director of the National Institute of Mental Health, cautioned experts on alcoholism today that indiscriminate education programs on the dangers of drinking might do more harm than good.

Webb Knapp, Inc., the real estate empire run by William Zeckendorf, said yesterday it had paid off its indebtedness to the Alleghany Corporation by entering into a joint development venture at Garden City, L.I.

Josh Quintero has agreed to stage at least one play a season for several seasons for Lincoln Center's Repertory Theater. His first effort will be Eugene O'Neill's "Marco Millions," opening early next year at the group's temporary home in Washington Square.
Civil rights demonstrators began a sit-in at City Hall yesterday in a demand for more construction jobs for Negroes and Puerto Ricans.

JACKSON, Miss., July 9 (AP) --Negroes here, who stopped their protest demonstrations three weeks ago to concentrate on a campaign to register voters, found today that the registration books had suddenly been closed.
NEW ORLEANS, July 9-- Several witnesses at a civil rights hearing here testified today that industry in the South was penalizing itself when it discriminated against Negroes.
The Scott Paper Company had record sales and earnings in the quarter and six months ended June 29, the semi-annual report of Thomas B. McCabe, chairman, reported yesterday.

DETROIT, July 9--The Communications Workers of America and the Michigan Bell Telephone Company reached agreement today on a 38-month contract. The union president, Joseph A. Beirne, said the agreement would set the pattern for 750,000 employes of the Bell System in the United States and Canada.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 (AP)--A representative for nine of the nation's 16 astronauts said today the apparent cancellation of a $3,200,000 offer from Field Enterprises Education Corporation did not signal any change of mind by James E. Webb, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

PARIS, July 9--The deficit in United States international payments is the most important economic problem confronting the Atlantic countries in the view of the experts of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 9--Mrs. Allen W. Morton is chairman for the Fiesta of the Village Improvement Society, which is being resumed after a year's lapse. Mrs. Edgar Leonard, honorary chairman, is president of the society, which will sponsor the one-day benefit on the grounds of the Parrish Art Museum on Aug. 23.
NEWTON, Ga., July 6--One of the most significant advances in voting rights for the Southern Negroes is taking place in this Black Belt community of southwest Georgia.
CHICAGO, July 9 (UPI)-- Wheat declined but most grain futures gained moderately today on the Board of Trade.

MIAMI BEACH, July 9--The International Longshoremen's Association was advised today to begin cooperating actively in a Department of Labor study of work operations on the piers of the Port of New York.

WASHINGTON, July 9-- W. Averell Harriman, special United States negotiator, received final instructions today for what the White House considers a promising new round of talks on a treaty prohibiting nuclear tests.

NORTHEASTERN divisional championship races will be conducted by the New York Region of the Sports Car Club of America at the Thompson, Conn., course Saturday and Sunday. The principal contests will be started at 2 P.M. Sunday. More than 160 entries have been filed.

The Illinois Bell Telephone Company held a competitive sale yesterday of $50,000,000 of 40-year bonds. The issue was accorded an excellent reception and helped stabilize an otherwise uncertain corporate bond market.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, Juyl 9 (Reuter)--The Zimbabwe African People's Union removed its leader, Joshua Nkomo, today and said its struggle to change the Southern Rhodesian Constitution would continue with new militancy.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI)--A top Administration official told Congress today that President Kennedy's tax cut and civil rights proposals had joint priority. They are so urgently and closely related, he said, that they share top billing on the Administration legislative calendar.
BRUSSELS, July 9--There is an unmistakable feeling in this infant capital of the new Europe that the European Common Market is beginning a door-die series of talks.
The Public Education Association urged the Superintendent of Schools yesterday to reverse his decision to permit the transfer of a Negro student to a high school in an outside zone.
Most of the major European stock exchanges eased or drifted aimlessly yesterday.

Lewis Meyer sells books in his Tulsa, Okla., bookshop. He reviews books for newspapers. He discusses books Sundays on television. He has recently written a book, a novel called "Second Wife," which PrenticeHall will publish on Aug. 5. It is about book publishing.
LOLIONDO, Tanganyika June 23--The gunbear ers who are the jack-of-alltrades to the professional hunters may be short on good English, but they are long on experience.
LEOPOLDVILLE, July 9 -- The Portuguese Charge d'Affaires here was called back to Lisbon today.
WASHINGTON, July 9-- President Kennedy appointed Representative Homer Thornberry, Democrat of Texas, today as United States District Judge for the Western District of Texas.
SYDNEY, Australia, July 9-- In three years of intensive prospecting and research, Australia's known reserves of iron ore have increased more than 20-fold.
WASHINGTON, July 9--The issues in the railroad dispute are both complicated and fundamental.
SAG HARBOR, L.I., July 9-- Dr. Milton Schreiber, a civic worker and retired Brooklyn dentist, died today at Southampton Hospital. A resident of Sunset Beach Road here, he was 70 years old.

High unemployment, especially among teen-agers, and the gold outflow rank as the two major economic problems facing the nation. Ironically, they appear large at a time when most of the basic economic indicators have been faring well.
WASHINGTON, July 9-- The Senate approved today a compromise agreement for making the final $73,000,000 payment of Philippines war damage claims despite protests from Manila.
Yonkers Raceway's petition to keep a letter-class system of racing was denied yesterday by the New York Harness Racing Commission.

MOSCOW, July 9--The ideological conference here between Soviet and Chinese Communist delegations reached a standstill today as leaders of the Peking party assessed a new warning published by the Kremlin.
HARTFORD, July 9--The seven members of Connecticut's new State Insurance Commission were appointed today by Gov. John N. Dempsey.
WESTBURY L.I., July 9-- There were 262 winners of the second twin double at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Each collected $369.60 per ticket, and thus eliminated the necessity of tax inspection.
Andre Mertens, concert manager and chairman of Columbia Artists Management, died yesterday at Baden, Switzerland, from complications of a fall last month in Germany. He was 59 years old.
Dr. Moses Hadas of Columbia University began a series of lectures on "Great Ideas in Antiquity" yesterday with the assistance of two tools from modern times--the telephone and Telstar II.

The case against Gareth Martinis, acquitted of drunken and reckless driving and leaving the scene of an accident that caused five deaths, will be presented to the Bronx County grand jury on July 31, the Bronx District Attorney, Isidore Dollinger, said yesterday.

The Leaseway Transportation Corporation, supplier of leased vehicles and other commercial equipment, has agreed to acquire substantially all the stock of the Arista Truck Renting Corporation of this city.
The New York Board of Rabbis denounced the American Council for Judaism yesterday as "neither American nor Jewish in spirit or in concept."
TRENTON, July 9--Officials of the Delaware River and Bay Authority went to Norfolk, Va., today to open negotiations for the possible purchase of three or four deep-sea ferries.

In the philanthropic tradition of operating on the frontiers of human problems, the Ford Foundation (like the Milbank Fund and the Scripps Foundation) is pioneering in the field of population control in the hope that other groups, both public and private, will follow.

French objections that an international telecast presenting leading statesmen was "too controversial and political" caused a blackout of the live program today in Western Europe, although it will be seen here on the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The defeat of the Peronists in the Argentine election was so surprising and gratifying for everyone except General Peron that one is apt to overlook the positive aspects of the voting. After 16 months of crisis, of meddling by the military, of uprisings, political squabbles and economic distress, the people of Argentina went to the polls, overcame a complicated and frustrating electoral law, and registered a calm and sensible decision.

JACKSON, Miss., July 9 (AP) --Gov. Ross Barnett of Misissippi disclosed today that the State Board had considered asking Federal court permission to expel James H. Meredith, Negro student, from the University of Mississippi because of his public statements.
LONDON, July 9--The Belgian trawler Charles II was seized off Seaford today after she started trawling within the three-mile limit to test a 297year-old charter.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 9--Rocco Magri, a dress contractor and retired musician, died yesterday in his home at 331 North Fulton Avenue after a long illness. He was 75 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 9-- President Kennedy proposed today that Justice Arthur J. Goldberg of the Supreme Court settle the railroad labor dispute.

One of the older stakes for 2-year-olds, the Tremont, will have its 71st running today at Aqueduct. The 5 -furlong dash for $25,000 added drew six juvenile colts. The fact that Hobeau Farm's unbeaten Raise A Native was not among them added to, rather than detracted from, the attractiveness of the event.
DURING the summer months, when families vacate their homes or apartments for long periods, precautions should be taken against burglaries.
WASHINGTON, July 9-- President Kennedy has decided to reaffirm United States support for the embattled Government of South Vietnam.

The decision of city school officials on Monday to allow a Negro student to transfer to a high school outside his neighborhood zone has a significance that goes beyond the immediate question of whether the officials had capitulated to pressure tactics.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9-- Dr. William Walsh Hagerty, dean of the College of Engineering at the University of Texas, was today named president of Drexel Institute of Technology to succeed Dr. James Creese on Sept. 1.

Bolero, a 73-foot yawl belonging to Mrs. Sallly Ames Langmuir of Los Angeles, and Cyane, a Class B boat owned by Henry B. duPont of Wilmington, Del., appeared to hold strong positions as 11 of the 14 boats in the trans-Atlantic race to England were sighted yesterday.
BOSTON, July 9--A young suburbanite with an eye for revitalizing industrial property is gambling more than $2,000,000 that there is need for "a $10 hotel room in the new Boston."

The Upstairs at the Downstairs brought topical cabaret revues to Manhattan seven years ago on a spiked satirical platter. This season the East Side club decided that revues were as outrageous as Sen-Sen sprinkled in coffee and changed its format before the hearty flavor evaporated.
LONDON, July 9--The Foreign Office denied today a forecast by Newsweek magazine that a big British spy scandal was imminent.
The school dropout problem will be attacked on three levels with the assistance of grants announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.
ALBANY, July 9 (AP)--Six cities in New York State have reported cases of intestinal infection traced to the so-called "Salmonella derby" organism.

WASHINGTON, July 9-- President Kennedy's choice of a Justice of the Supreme Court --Arthur J. Goldberg--for special Executive branch assignment has many precedents, going back to the earliest years of the republic.
Investigations into claims made by hospitals for Blue Cross payments spread yesterday from Queens and Brooklyn into Manhattan.
LONDON, July 9--The British Government was reported today to be determined to bring the Sultanate of Brunei into the projected Federation of Malaysia.
A member of the State Commission for Human Rights decided yesterday that a city official had unlawfully specified "white only" when she sought to hire a secretary.
CHICAGO, July 9--Mrs. Frank J. Lewis, founder and president of the Illinois Club for Catholic Women, today announced a no-restriction policy for the organization.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 9--United Nations officials have asked for an inquiry into reports that poison gas has been used in Yemen by forces of the United Arab Republic.
A 15-year-old boy will be tried on a first-degree-murder charge in the death of a 9-yearold girl, according to a ruling yesterday by Justice Miles F. McDonald in Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

Ranging from coast to coast, this catalogue of the ills confronting urban America adds up the toll taken by traffic congestion, air pollution, water contamination, and slum housing--to name a few. Municipal officials are battling these problems resulting from urban sprawl, but within governmental organizations often geared to an America of bygone days.

The packs of white youths who have jeered and pelted Negroes near a Bronx hamburger restaurant since Saturday, are spurred, police officials say, by a craving for "kicks." Some of the youths in tight pants and T-shirts have roamed the neighborhood waving Confederate flags and singing "Dixie."

Soon after Credit Industrial Corporation, a middle-size finance company at 11 West 42d Street, went into bankruptcy in May, many other commercial finance concerns found the climate at their banks turning chillier, the season notwithstanding.
THE question of what to do with long lazy summer hours and the seemingly unrelated question of how to add a needed accent piece to a room both have the same answer: needlepoint.

PARIS, July 9--When Averell Harriman goes to Moscow as United States plenipotentiary in perhaps the most important negotiations we have had since Korea was a war and Berlin was a crisis, he will be representing his third American President in a role of crucial importance.
BUENOS AIRES, July 9-- Argentine political leaders turned their attention to the Electoral College today. This body is to name the country's next President on July 31.
LONDON, July 9--The United States is reported to be urging Britain to suspend the Constitution in British Guiana and to impose direct rule in the riot-torn colony.
Mayor Wagner has promised financial assistance to the Transit Authority to help it meet a threatened operational deficit and thus avert an increase in the 15-cent fare on Nov. 1.

WASHINGTON, July 9-- When a distinguished law yer with a newsworthy record was appointed to the Supreme Court he received an unusual gift from a personal friend. It was a ten-cent-store box of mothballs.
NEW ORLEANS, July 9--A Federal court ordered the combined city-county school system at Mobile, Ala., today to begin desegregation this fall.

WASHINGTON, July 9--Most members of the Senate Commerce Committee agreed today that Congress should ban discrimination in public accommodations. They argued, however, over the proper constitutional underpinning for the ban.
DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., July 9--The first year-round legitimate theater in Westchester County opened its doors tonight in this residential village on the east bank of the Hudson.
ST. LOUIS, July 9--Is there a "featherbed" in the cab of a locomotive?
WASHINGTON, July 9-- Corporations reaped a cash benefit totaling $2,300,000,000 last year from the investment tax credit and revision of depreciation rules.

CLEVELAND, July 9--The National League took another stride today toward closing the gap that separated it from the American League in All-Star competition as it won the 34th game of the series, 5 to 3.

BUDVA, Yugoslavia, July 9-- The American team scored one victory and suffered one loss, with two games adjourned, against Tunisia in the second round of the World Students Team Chess Championship in group 3 last night. Nineteen teams are competing.

Three defendants in the Re stock-fraud trial in United States District Court yesterday, through their lawyers, offered a "So What?" defense--conceding something of the Government's charges against them while denying guilt.

With their financial and political problems of association finally settled, the Southeast Asian states of Singapore, Malaya, North Borneo and Sarawak have formally agreed to merge in an independent Malaysian federation. Inauguration of the new state, scheduled for Aug. 31, will mark the historic end of British colonial rule in Southeast Asia--with one exception.
DENVER, July 9--The United Church of Christ rejected attempts today to reverse the sanction it gave last night to civil disobedience.
TRANS WORLD AIRLINES made a slight attempt yes terday to span the world of art when four large paintings by Bernard Buffet were placed in the display cases at the company's Idlewild flight center.
The city proposed for extensive urban renewal yesterday a 140-acre tract just north of the Coney Island amusement area.

There was nostalgia in the air at the East River Amphitheater last night, as LENA (Lower East Side Neighborhoods Association) began its ninth season of free concerts. Also in the air was the nottoo-distant rumble of traffic over the Williamsburgh Bridge and an occasional tugboat whistle, but that didn't seem to matter too much.
RYE, N.Y., July 9--Laurence A. Tanzer, the last surviving founder of the Citizens Union in New York City, died of a heart attack today at his home, 43 Greenhaven Road. He was 88 years old.

HOLLYWOOD, July 8--Jules C. Stein, chairman of MCA, Inc., asserted today that Southern California was "the heartbeat of entertainment productions" and the "logical place" for MCA to begin the most ambitious program of Hollywood expansion in more than 30 years.

COCOA, Fla., July 9--The desegregation of hotels and restaurants sought by Negro civil rights groups is expected to be carried out here before Aug. 13, G. W. Mayfield, chairman of the Citizens Advisory Committee, said today.
The city proposed for extensive urban renewal yesterday a 140-acre tract just north of the Coney Island amusement area.

Also in the air was the nottoo-distant rumble of traffic over the Williamsburgh Bridge and an occasional tugboat whistle, but that didn't seem to matter too much.

The rail dispute creates, as President Kennedy observed, an "extraordinary situation"; but no matter how extraordinary, we question the appropriateness of calling in a justice of the Supreme Court as the arbiter. Furthermore, the President's proposal would involve a further indeterminate delay in achieving a settlement.
LONDON, July 9--Reliable sources said today that the United States agreed with Britain that the United Nations Special Committee on Colonialism had become a medium for extremist views.
WASHINGTON, July 9--The House Science and Astronautics Committee completed today its trimming of the Administration's fund-authorization requests for civilian space projects.
President Kennedy intervened yesterday in a jurisdictional dispute between two ship officer unions that could paralyze two-thirds of the nation's oceangoing merchant marine.
Paced by a resurgent rail group, stock prices climbed on increased volume yesterday. The advance recovered a large part of Monday's losses.

SOUTH SALEM, N.Y., July 9--Brian E. Benz of Douglas MacArthur High School at Levittown defeated Dennis Troy of Linden, N.J., last year's winner, in the second round of the Metropolitan Golf Association junior golf tournament today.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) --Increases of nearly 2,000 men in the cadet corps at both the Air Force Academy and United States Military Academy were approved today by the House Armed Services Committee.
HARTFORD, July 9--Expressing regret that the Legislature had not passed a stronger bill, Gov. John N. Dempsey signed a new anti-discrimination housing measure yesterday.
The spray of fire boats and the raucous whistles of an official harbor welcome marked the debut yesterday of the Farrell Lines' new cargo ship African Dawn.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., July 9 --Racial violence resumed here tonight, 32 hours after the Maryland National Guard had left the community.

NOROTON, Conn., July 9-- Mrs. Ellen Stern of the Beach Point Yacht Club won the only race completed today as the Syce Cup Regatta for the Long Island Sound women's sailing championship got off to a slow start off the Noroton Y.C.

TRENTON, July 9--Labor unions involved in state construction projects agreed today to accept apprentices regardless of color.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 9-- A record number of boats--236 from 24 clubs--entered the New York Yacht Club's annual junior regatta on Long Island Sound today. Unfortunately, the regatta ran out of wind before the afternoon was over and only three fleets were able to complete their races.

Five youths were wounded by shotgun pellets last night, none seriously, as gang violence with racial overtones broke out only a few blocks from downtown Brooklyn's shopping and entertainment district.
Pension funds of United States corporations, the largest class of institutional buyers of stock, reduced slightly last year the percentage of new funds invested in common shares.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation is expanding its activities into the electrical-connector manufacturing business through the proposed acquisition of the Cannon Electric Company for about $34,000,000.

JERSEY CITY, July 10--The New Jersey State Board of Education today refused to permit the Orange Board of Education to start appeal proceedings that would take the problem of racial imbalance in the schools out of the hands of Frederick M. Raubinger, the State Commissioner of Education.

Hearings on the advisability of adjusting New York State's 25-year-old unemployment insurance laws to current conditions were begun yesterday under the auspices of the Joint Legislative Committee on Unemployment Insurance.
The Cunard Line has scheduled 191 traps-Atlantic crossings next year. This compares with 211 crossings scheduled this year for the line's eight vessels.

READING, Pa., July 10 (UPI) Mayor John C. Kubacki said yesterday that he had "no intentions of resigning" in the face of a Federal indictment charging extortion of $10,500 from two parking meter concerns as a condition of getting city contracts.
ALBANY, July 10--Governor Rockefeller will propose to the National Governors Conference that consideration be given to the problems of handicapped persons in the design of state buildings.

Though saved from immediate bankruptcy, the United Nations continues to face a financial crisis that already imposes a pocketbook veto on its activities and threatens to reduce it to creeping impotence as a peace-keeping agency.
DAMASCUS, Syria, July 10 (AP)--The ruling Baath party put one of its men in charge of Syria's armed forces today. He already headed the police.
The recovery in the Government securities market that began late Tuesday continued yesterday. High-grade corporates were mostly steady and municipal bonds tended to soften again.

HOLLYWOOD, July 10--Hollywood has found a podium performer who makes Leonard Bernstein look staid. The Brando of the baton made his debut here last night to open the 42d annual summer season at the Hollywood Bowl.

NEWARK, July 10 (AP)--A Federal grand jury indicted three men and a Paterson blood bank today on 36 charges, including the sale in interstate commerce of blood falsely labeled "negative for syphilis."
Restless conditions again prevailed on the London stock market yesterday.

PARIS, July 10 (AP)--The International Lawn Tennis Federation today revised its rules on amateurs to make the regulations more realistic.
LONDON, July 10--King Paul of Greece brushed aside today the efforts of left-wing demonstrators to "cause misunderstanding" between his country and Britain.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI)--Continental Airlines is about to place an order for the British-French supersonic airliner. The decision could have wide-ranging effects on the course of United States aviation.

Fourteen members of the American Mount Everest expedition, descending from their moment of national acclaim in Washington, began to explore the book-and-movie-rights terrain in New York yesterday.

The Nassau Bowl, one or the oldest and most prized trophies in tennis, is being put back in competition. This was made possible by the cancellation of the Southampton tournament in the year of its diamond jubilee,

Reductions of 9 to 21 per cent in air freight rates between East Coast cities and San Juan, P.R., were proposed yesterday by Pan American Airways. The cuts would become effective July 27 if approved by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

The Wiener Sport Club of Austria, and Ujpest of Hungary remained in a first-place tie in the second section of the International Soccer League after both posted victories last night at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

The cliche, "don't sell on strike news," was working overtime yesterday among owners of rail shares. The price of rail shares rose, even though the announcement that the strike would be delayed until July 29 did not reach the public until after the close of trading.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 10--Barbara Menoff of Lynbrook, L.I., and Shella Maroshick of Brooklyn were upset today in the quarter-finals of the women's Eastern clay court tennis championships at the, Sleepy Hollow, Country Club.
ST. LOUIS, July 10--Although not putting it so bluntly, railroad firemen convening; here believe that they are the last of a breed.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 10-- The name of the game, which used to be harness racing, became twin double tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, where seven tickets were worth $13,236.90 each.
Failure by Alan Jay Lerner to finish the lyrics for "I Picked a Daisy" has brought about' the cancellation of the show. It was to open in December at the Majestic.
Two of the three Criminal Court judges in the recent trial of Gareth Martinis replied last night to mounting criticism of his acquittal.
Two leading American historians will exchange views on the state of the union and the state of man in a special Columbia Broadcasting system program this month.

CHICAGO, July 10 (UPI)-- A New York lawyer, one of three men charged with possession of $1,500,000 in stolen securities, was ordered removed to New York City today to face a charge of bond forfeiture.

MARLBORO, Vt., July 10-- At Marlboro plans are constantly shifted and nothing is set very far in advance. Today, for example, Pablo Canals was expected to give a master class. Instead, he conducted an orchestral rehearsal. Exciting Uncertainty
A civil rights sit-in was staged at Governor Rockefeller's office in the city yesterday, as one at City Hall went through its second day. Both offices remained occupied into the night.
The Lincoln Repertory Company is considering a plan to operate two playhouses by making its temporary theater at 40 West Fourth Street a permanent home.

Dr. Calvin E. Gross, the Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday that he had no intention of reversing his decision to allow a Negro student to attend a high school out of his neighborhood for reasons of health.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 10-- The Baghdad radio, commenting today on Moscow's diplomatic moves in favor of the Kurds, challenged the Soviet Union's right to speak of genocide.
The Government should delay no longer in returning the atomic liner Savannah to her postponed foreign voyage schedule, Joseph Curran, a maritime labor leader, declared Yesterday.

LYTHAM-SAINT ANNE'S, July 10--Peter Thomson of Australia, the only man to win the British Open three consecutive times in this century, shot a 67 today and shared the firstround lead with Phil Rodgers. Arnold Palmer, who is trying for his third Open in a row, posted an erratic 76.

HANNIBAL, Ohio, July 10 --Completion of a two-year multimillion-dollar program to broaden the aluminum sheet and plate product line of its Omal aluminum rolling mill here was announced yesterday by the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation.

THE Whist Club of New York, this city's oldest and in some respects its staidest bridge club, was the the scene earlier this week of what may stand up as the most unusual hand played in New York this year.

Birmingham, Ala,, one of the major scenes of recent racial disturbances, has tentatively agreed to the presentation of an integrated variety show before a nonsegregated audience in its City Auditorium.

THE reality of instantaneous international com munications was warmly underscored early yesterday afternoon in the live telecast of the "Town Meeting of the World" over the Columbia Broadcasting System. At the same time the unusual presentation also vividly illustrated the problems that can attend global TV broadcasting.

Harold Connolly of Santa Monica, Calif., the world record-holder in the hammer throw, will be unable to join a United States team in its track meet against the Soviet Union in Moscow on July 20 and 21 because of a recurring back injury.

IN his early youth, Edward Globbi pursued both art and cooking sub rosa. He painted in secret and when he dabbled in the kitchen it was rarely for the prying eyes of his young associates.

The Lehman Corporation, a diversified closed-end investment company, showed an increase in total and share assets in its report for the six months ended June 30, it was announced yesterday by Robert Lehman, chairman.
Ondine, the 57-foot yawl owned by Summer A. (Huey) Long of the Larchmont Yacht Club, reported only her own position by radio yesterday to the Coast Guard weather cutter Duane, stationed at Point...
BERLIN, July 10--A Polish fighter pilot with his wife and two young sons, fled to West Berlin today from a military airfield inside Poland aboard a single-engine training plane.

PARIS, July l0--The French Government introduced labor legislation today to bar sudden and unannounced strikes by utility and transport workers such as have plagued Parisians and unwary tourists for years.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 10 (UPI)--The defending champion, Dick Sikes, won two matches easily today in the national public links golf tournament as the field was cut to 16.

The Pan American World Airways and New York Airways, the city's helicopter airline, announced an agreement yesterday under which Pan American will purchase two modern 25passenger helicopters and lease them to the helicopter line.

Racine County, Wis., Unified School District No. 1 borrowed $10,600,000 yesterday on bonds due 1964-83. The Melton National Bank and Trust Company, bidding alone, was awarded, the bonds on a bid of 100,0265 for various coupons.
Strengthening prospects of growing trade in shipping routes between New York and the West Coast of South America have led the Grace Line to expand its current shipbuilding program.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 10 (UPI)--President Joao Goulart's Cabinet has placed a valuation of $142,000,000 on the Brazilian subsidiaries of the American and Foreign Power Company, it was made public here today.
A Federal Court jury of 10 men and two women will receive for deliberation early this morning the multimillion-dollar stock fraud case of Gerardo A. (Jerry) Re, his son, Gerard F., and three others.
